DOC.HEAD: Mayor and City Council Members Indicted on Extortion Charges
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Sweetwater three city council members were indicted Thursday by a federal grand jury on extortion charges, the U.S. Attorney announced. Mayor Irain Gonzalez and council members Carmen Menendez, Hugo Alvarez and Antonio Duran are accused of using their public positions to extort money from a local businessman who wanted them to reverse a land-use restriction, said U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen. ``Public corruption by elected officials strikes at the heart of democracy,'' Lehtinen said. ``Five of seven members of Sweetwater's city council were involved in this extortion attempt,'' he alleged. He apparently counted Gonzalez, who is a council member as well as mayor, and one of two other council members not included in the indictment. Gonzalez, Menendez, Alvarez and Duran each face a maximum of 40 years in prison and a fine of $500,000, Lehtinen said. Lehtinen said he notified Gov. Bob Martinez of the indictment Thursday and that the governor's office would decide who will run the city of Sweetwater. The governor's press secretary, Jon Peck, said Martinez has yet to make a decision on the matter. He said the governor was awaiting written confirmation of the indictment. ``We're aware of the situation and our attorneys are still looking at it,'' Peck said. The other two city councilmen, Manuel Avila and Lucio Cobian, have cooperated with Lehtinen's office and have agreed to testify on behalf of the government, he said. Cobian has agreed to plead guilty to one extortion charge and Avila is an ``unindicted co-conspirator,'' Lehtinen said. The indictment stems from a request made by Maurice Barakat in June 1989 asking the council to lift a land-use restriction. Barakat, who owns the Holiday Plaza Shopping Center, had sold part of the land, which left him with less than the five acres necessary for commercial zoning. Barakat asked the city council to remove the restriction so he could sell the additional commercial units more easily, the indictment said. The defendants allegedly told Barakat he would have to pay them $10,000 in exchange for a favorable council vote on his request. Instead, Barakat went to the FBI. The councilmen voted to continue delaying action on Barakat's request until he paid the money, the indictment alleged. Barakat paid Menendez $5,000 with FBI agents watching, but then was asked to pay $6,000 more, according to the indictment. The city officials are expected to surrender Friday through their attorneys and make their first appearance in federal court Friday afternoon, Lehtinen said. Sweetwater, known in the 1960s as a rural outpost in western Dade County, has recently become a haven for political exiles from Central America.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Government Sues Nevada Over Nuclear Dump Plans
DOC.TEXT: The federal filed suit Thursday against the state of Nevada, claiming the state is acting illegally in refusing to issue environmental permits for work on the proposed nuclear dump at Yucca Mountain. The U.S. District Court suit also asks that legislative resolutions and a state law banning the dump be declared invalid because they are pre-empted by a congressional directive to conduct scientific studies of the site. State officials have adamantly opposed any plans for work at Yucca Mountain, which Congress picked in late 1987 as the nation's only site to be studied for a high-level radioactive waste dump. It would be used to store spent fuel rods from commercial nuclear reactors. The Department of Energy said in November it planned to file the suit. The action asks a judge to order state officials to issue the necessary permits within 30 days and prohibit the state from ``unlawfully interfering'' with the DOE's activities at the site. ``We have tried to work with the state over the years, but unfortunately they have refused to cooperate in that area,'' said Carl Gertz, the nuclear dump project director. ``We were forced into filing this suit so we can move ahead with scientific studies.'' The Department of Justice suit was seen as unusual by attorneys, who said it was rare that the federal government would sue a state for trying to block federal law. ``Usually it's the other way around,'' said DOE attorney Dave Gassman. ``But the federal program must prevail. It is a very basic issue.'' In December the state attorney general's office filed suit claiming the state has the right to bar the DOE from following Congress's mandate because the Nevada Legislature has passed resolutions ``disapproving'' the Yucca Mountain site. The state contends it has the right under the federal legislation to veto the site, and is also bound by a law passed by the 1989 Legislature that makes it illegal to put a nuclear waste dump in Nevada. The 21-page suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Las Vegas, is seen by DOE officials as the only way to get the much delayed project back on track. In November, the agency announced it was revamping its schedule for the controversial facility and would open it in the year 2010, seven years later than planned. Gertz said the DOE needs to get the state permits and begin exploratory drilling and other scientific work at the site by next January to even be able to keep current with the revised schedule. State officials in December returned the air and water permits to the DOE unprocessed, saying state law precluded them from granting permits to build the dump. The DOE originally applied for the permits in January 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks, Hispanics Battle at Crowded Jail, 12 Injured
DOC.TEXT: Black and Hispanic inmates armed with homemade knives brawled at an overcrowded county jail Thursday, and 12 were injured before guards restored order, officials said. One prisoner at the El Cajon detention center was critically injured, said jail Commander Ben McLaughlin. He said the fight began about 4:30 p.m. between black and Hispanic inmates at the jail 15 miles east of San Diego, where a similar racially motivated fight left four inmates injured Dec. 13. Inmates retreated to their cells when deputies entered the cellblock armed with electric stun guns a weapon that fires rubber bullets. Inmates were armed with handmade knives and other crude weapons, McLaughlin said. The brawl, attributed to overcrowding and racial tensions, occurred in a cellblock designed to hold 24 inmates, but which held 100 prisoners when the riot broke out, McLaughlin said. Deputies saw a black inmate and a Hispanic inmate arguing moments before their confrontation erupted into a large-scale brawl, McLaughlin said. ``In this case, it was blacks vs. Hispanics,'' McLaughlin said. ``I was a racial issue, but we're not sure yet what sparked it. It just erupted without warning.'' One injured inmate was transported by helicopter to Sharp Memorial Hospital, where he was listed in critical condition with head injuries, said hospital spokeswoman Melanie Bruce. She declined to release the inmate's name. Two other inmates suffering head injuries were admitted to University of California, San Diego, Medical Center, said spokeswoman Jane Swett. One was in serious condition and the other in fair condition, she said, declining to release their names. At least nine other inmates suffering cuts, scrapes and other minor injuries also were taken to various East San Diego County hospitals for treatment. It took deputies about 15 minutes to get the prisoners into their cells before deputies regained control of the cellblock, McLaughlin said ``There is no damage to the cells. They were really injuring themselves,'' McLauglin said. Deputies with guard dogs were stationed around the jail exterior as a sheriff's helicopter with a spotlight circled overhead to guard against any possible escapes. The detention facility is designed to hold 120, but housed slightly more than 500 prisoners Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Leukemia Patient's Plea Helps National Group
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For the sake of a 20-year-old leukemia victim, about 9,600 people have undergone blood tests in the past three months, hoping that they will be able to give her the bone marrow that might save her life. Allison Atlas is still waiting. But as a result of her search for a compatible donor, eight other patients have found potential donors and a data bank that collects information about possible donors is nearly 10,000 names richer. The Atlas family of Bethesda, Md., is among about 15 families around the country who have gone public with marrow searches, helped by a national organization. The families travel, talk to reporters, hold donor drives and raise money to cover the $75 blood test fee for each volunteer they bring in. Public relations and fund-raising pointers come from the Life-Savers Foundation, the recruiting arm of the National Marrow Donor Program in St. Paul, Minn. ``Help Save Allison's Life,'' entreats an advertisement that has brought volunteers to synagogues and Jewish community centers in Washington, Baltimore, Boston, New York, Harrisburg, Pa., Norfolk, Va., and other cities. Each ad features a photo of the New York University business major. Ms. Atlas, 20, sometimes appears at the blood-testing centers, along with her parents and siblings. ``Several people have come up to me and said, `I hope I'm the one,''' said Ms. Atlas. ``It's reinforced in my mind that we are going to find someone.'' ``It's been a very emotional experience for the whole family to see all these people waiting in line,'' said her father, Alvin Atlas. ``We're private people; it's been a very difficult thing to do,'' said Atlas, a clothing store owner. ``But one of our goals is to save our daughter's life. The doctors don't know how much time we have.'' Doctors told Ms. Atlas in August that her type of leukemia can only be cured by a transplant to replace diseased marrow, which produces new blood cells. Members of her family and 75,000 listings at the National Marrow Donor Program did not match her tissue type. The odds of a match are usually about 1 in 20,000. It was determined that her best chance for a match was among people who shared her Eastern European Jewish ancestry, a group the donor pool was largely lacking. In November, Friends of Allison started a flurry of donor drives at Jewish institutions. Similarly inspired groups are working to enlarge the donor pools for Asian-American, Greek-American and other ethnic groups. The family of Judie Davis in Oakland, Calif., is targeting African-American donors. ``We're concerned because we might be running out of time for her,'' said Liz Quam, a spokeswoman for the donor bank. Dr. Rudy Brutico, a pediatrician and founder of Life-Savers, said it helps the cause when a picture of a leukemia victim reminds would-be donors of Mom or Cousin Joe. ``They identify with it,'' he said. If a match is found between a potential donor and a patient, the donor is asked to consent to a transplant. Doctors remove 1{ pints of marrow from the donor's pelvic bone under general anesthesia. The recipient gets the marrow in a blood transfusion and the marrow cells lodge in the spongy interior of large bones. When the donor bank marked its first transplant on Dec. 15, 1987, ``it was then considered highly experimental,'' said Ms. Quam. Since then, the bank has arranged about 266 transplants. About three-quarters had leukemia; 7 percent had aplastic anemia; and the rest had other blood diseases. Doctors wait five to seven years before pronouncing a cure, but all are doing well, said Ms. Quam. Ms. Quam said one patient has survived 19 years with a transplant from a relative; another has lived 17 years with a transplant from a non-relative. Brutico, of West Covina, Calif., founded Life-Savers in September 1988 to help the donor bank find a match for his wife, Diana, a mother of four who had leukemia. Mrs. Brutico found two matches, got a transplant and no longer shows signs of the disease. ``My wife would be dead _ or dying in despair _ without the goodness of some other person,'' said Brutico. Since then, Life-Savers has tested 50,000 volunteers, entering their names and tissue type in the donor bank, and raised $3.5 million. This year, the national donor bank will begin to link up with similar computers in other countries. The goal is a donor pool of 1 million worldwide by 1995, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Industry and GE Join to Build Airplane
DOC.TEXT: The Czechoslovakian Aviation Industry and General Electric Co. announced an agreement Wednesday to produce a 40-passenger commuter airplane. Under the joint venture, the engines of the CT7-9B powered versions of L610 turboprop plane will be manufactured in GE Aircraft Engines' plant here. The aircraft will be built by the state-owned Czechoslovakian company, which is known in that country by the acronym LET. About 400 engines will be supplied for the plane, which will be marketed around the world by LET, said Robert N. Salvucci, manager of media relations for GE Aircraft Engines. Salvucci said the deal marked the first time a Western nation would sell an aircraft engine to an Eastern Bloc nation for use in a commercial venture. Czechoslovakia, like other Eastern European countries, has undergone dramatic political liberalization in recent months. ``This agreement will allow both parties to serve markets in parts of the world that have not previously been accessible,'' said Wallie Everest, director of GE's CT-7 turboprop program, in a statement released by the company. ``We expect that well over $300 million worth of CT7 engines will be purchased by the late 1990s and spare parts sales will add to that business,'' he said. Czechoslovakian Aeronautics Industry and GE Aircraft Engines also have agreed to develop a long-term relationship that will include the manufacture of selected GE aircraft engine components by LET and other Czech factories. ``This program will be a major step in the development of worldwide commerce for both of our companies,'' said Frantisek Hava, general director of OMNIPOL, a Czechoslovakian aviation company. GE's CT7 turboprop engines were first used in commercial flights in June 1984 and now power more than 190 aircraft in 16 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Tape Transcripts Show Gotti Just After He Allegedly Assumes Mob Power
DOC.TEXT: Reputed mob boss John Gotti was described as ``God's gift to the underworld'' in tapes secretly recorded by law enforcement agents and played Wednesday to jurors at his assault and conspiracy trial. Prosecutors say Gotti, 49, became boss of the Gambino crime family, largest of New York's five Mafia factions, in December 1985 after then-boss Paul Castellano was gunned down in front of a steak house. Transcripts of the tapes, which were released to the news media, show Gotti concerned about keeping underlings, including lifelong friends, in their place. At least once on the tapes, Gotti uses the term ``Cosa Nostra' when he is apparently telling an unidentified man that mob soldiers should not address him directly on business matters but should go through their ``capos,'' or captains. The tapes also indicate a relationship with the Westies, a vicious Irish-American gang that operates on Manhattan's West Side. The Westies are a key factor in Gotti's trial with associate Anthony Guerrieri, 60, on charges of assault and conspiracy in the 1986 revenge shooting of John F. O'Connor, former vice president of a Carpenters Union local. Gotti is accused of commissioning the Westies to shoot and wound O'Connor because the union leader had thugs trash a restaurant owned by Gotti associate Philip ``Philly'' Modica. The transcripts show at least one mention by Gotti of the restaurant and several comments on the Westies. At one point Gotti says ``...they're doing something for me them Irish guys...,'' but does not say what. At another point, Gotti refers to James Coonan as ``my friend'' who is ``the leader of the West Side gang, Irish guys.'' He also says, ``He's on the payroll, and he gets it legitimately ...'' The tapes were introduced by Edward Wright, an investigator with the state's Organized Crime Task Force. Wright said the alleged mobsters, suspecting they might be under surveillance, turned on hair dryers, flushed toilets, whispered and used other means to try to make conversations inaudible. The tapes were made from listening devices placed in Gotti's hangout in the borough of Qeens and monitored by police between June 19, 1985, and Feb. 26, 1986. More than 1,000 cassettes were recorded, prosecutors say. One 1986 tape shows Gotti in a telephone conversation quoting someone who praised him: ``When they say God's gift to the underworld, you are it. ``He speaks with his heart,'' Gotti said on the telephone. ``He means it. I tell ya something, I love the guy.'' On another tape, Gotti expressed annoyance with lifelong friend Angelo Ruggiero for his familiarity during business hours. ``I told Ange, `You gotta forget them liberties you take. Take `em when we're alone,''' Gotti said. Gotti apparently had just made Ruggiero a ``caporegime,'' or crew captain, according to the tape transcripts, and was not satisfied that his friend was acting like a leader. Ruggiero, a defendant in the O'Connor case with Gotti, died of natural causes last month.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes Veto Override; Bush Appeals to Senate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS ``Federal'' to ``Federation'' in name of organization in 14th graf: ``We are,''
DOC.TEXT: The House voted overwhelming Wednesday to override President Bush's veto of legislation protecting Chinese students from deportation, while Bush appealed to Republican senators to resist and help him keep open ties to the world's most populous nation. The House vote of 390-25 sent the matter to the Senate, where both sides said the outcome of Thursday's scheduled vote was in doubt. ``We've got a fighting chance,'' Bush said Wednesday night at a state dinner for the president of North Yemen. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley declared, ``I don't think what's most on the minds of the members of Congress is the sensitivities of the present Chinese leadership. ... This is a leadership that has in our judgment failed to respect the rights of its own citizens.'' ``On the issue of China, the president has lost his credibility,'' said Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Asia subcommittee. Bush pinned his hopes on the Senate, where both Democratic and Republican senators predicted a cliffhanger. The president, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Secretary of State James A. Baker III all were telephoning senators through the day. Bush was publicly appealing to GOP senators to support him in the face of what he termed ``crass politics'' played by some supporters of the override. But the chief House sponsor of the legislation, California Democrat Nancy Pelosi, said she hoped senators would resist the ``full-court press'' by the White House. ``Why would he ask a senator to vote against human rights and principles?'' she asked after the House vote. The legislation would affect as many as 32,000 Chinese students now in the United States on ``exchange visitor'' visas. The bill would waive a legal requirement that those students return home for two years after their visas expire before returning to the United States or going elsewhere. In addition, the bill would permit any Chinese student whose visa has expired _ as many as 8,000 others _ to remain in the United States as long as danger exists at home, and would allow Chinese students to work while in this country. Bush vetoed the measure on Nov. 30 after it had passed unanimously in the House and by a voice vote in the Senate. Chinese student groups have lobbied hard for an override of the veto, saying many of them would face political persecution at home because they supported the pro-democracy demonstrations that brought a violent government crackdown last June. A group made up of Chinese students hailed the House vote as ``an historic victory for human rights in China.'' ``We are hopeful that the strong support in the Senate will be enhanced by the House vote,'' said Haiching Zhao of the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars, which represents 42,000 Chinese students at more than 200 U.S. colleges and universities. At the time Bush vetoed the bill, he ordered government agencies to adopt what he contends are essentially the same safeguards. The veto was simply an effort to preserve executive branch foreign policy prerogatives, he said, and to keep open the door for future student and cultural exchanges. ``I will not break faith with the Chinese students here. ... They were safe then, and they are safe now, and they will be safe in the future,'' Bush told a White House news conference Wednesday. To the 37 GOP senators who attended a breakfast at the White House, Bush hit hard on his contention that a veto override would mean a total cutoff of the flow of students to the United States, and he appeared to be winning a few converts. ``The price of the Pelosi bill is lost opportunity for the Chinese scholars of tomorrow,'' the president told reporters later. ``The bill is totally unnecessary. The long-term policy consequences are potentially great. And Congress, in my view, will have only itself to blame.'' Bush listed steps the Beijing government has taken which he said justified his policy toward China: the lifting of martial law in the capital; the release of jailed dissidents; a promise not to sell medium-range missiles to Syria; acceptance of Peace Corps volunteers, Fulbright scholars and a Voice of America correspondent back into the country; and the muting of anti-U.S. propaganda. But critics have countered that the missile promise was nothing more than a repeating of assurances given months before the crackdown, that the effects of martial law remain in place and that arrests, harassment and secret trials of pro-democracy agitators continue. They also contend that Bush's administrative actions to protect the students can be revoked at any time and could be subject to a court challenge. Three Republican senators who attended a White House meeting with Bush on other matters late in the day said afterward they stood with the president on the China question and predicted his veto would be sustained. Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., said, ``We expect to see that veto sustained.'' Asked if Bush already had the support of 34 GOP senators, Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said, ``We're closing the gap on that question right now.'' ``I'm going to support the president,'' said Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn. All 25 House members who voted against the override were Republicans: Bob Stump, Arizona; John Paul Hammerschmidt and Tommy Robinson, Arkansas; Porter Goss, Andy Ireland and C.W. Bill Young, Florida; Dennis Hastert, Ed Madigan and Robert Michel, Illinois; Richard Baker, Clyde Holloway and Jim McCrery, Louisiana.; Norman Lent, New York; Paul Gillmor, Ohio; Larry Coughlin and George Gekas, Pennsylvania.; James Quillen and Don Sundquist, Tennessee; Larry Combest, Tom DeLay and Lamar Smith, Texas; James Hansen, Utah; Herbert Bateman, Virginia; Thomas Petri and James Sensenbrenner, Wisconsin. Not voting were: Ronnie Flippo, D-Ala.; Don Young, R-Alaska; Jim Kolbe, R-Ariz.; Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; Michael Bilirakis, R-Fla.; Brian Donnelly, D-Mass.; Bob Carr, D-Mich.; Guy VanderJagt, R-Mich.; Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn.; Floyd Flake, D-N.Y.; Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio; Les AuCoin, D-Ore.; Joe Kolter, D-Pa.; Austin Murphy, D-Pa.; Joseph McDade, R-Pa.; and Charles Wilson, D-Texas. Voting for the override were 245 Democrats and 145 Republicans. There are four vacancies in the 435-member House.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Arrest Suspected East German Spy
DOC.TEXT: A 31-year-old East German man has been arrested in West Germany on suspicion of trying to recruit students to work for East Germany's intelligence service, authorities say. The Chief Federal Prosecutor's office on Wednesday identified the suspect as Michael Keiser of the East German city of Halle. Keiser is suspected of spying for East Germany since June, the office said in a statement. It said he had attempted to recruit English-speaking university students and was arrested Jan. 18 in the central city of Mannheim. At the time of his arrest, Keiser was carrying false identification papers and a fake passport, the statement said. The statement did not specify the nature of the information gathered by Keiser, who remains in investigative custody pending completion of the investigation against him. Although the East German governmment has been dismantling the country's secret police under growing opposition pressure, West German officials have warned that East German agents are continuing to spy abroad.

DOC.HEAD: For The Elite, Special Store Offers Convenience
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Privilege in China is rarely ostentatious, and the store at No. 32 Donganmen Street is no exception. The facade is ordinary brown stone, with a narrow entry for cars. The window shades are down, and further protected by heavy iron grills. There is no sign. Inside, however, may be the only food store in China with more sales clerks than customers. Around the corner on Wangfujing Street, thousands of shoppers jostled their way to counters on a recent afternoon to buy food for Saturday's Lunar New Year, but the store at No. 32 was nearly deserted. Four clerks stood idle behind a glass counter displaying China's best-brand cigarettes, liquor, candy and canned food. Two more women sat in the cashier's booth, and four other workers stood nearby. Two men lugging a large crate of eggs out to a truck were the only customers. Across the courtyard, another room housed freezers of meat and fish, also with no buyers. ``Our store is not for the residents,'' said deputy manager Qin Jie. ``Not everyone can come in, only those approved by the higher authorities.'' The store, run by the Beijing City Food Supply Center, a wholesale food distributor, is part of China's little-publicized, decades-old network of special privileges for top-level officials and their families. Qin would not say just who can shop at the store, which opened in 1955. The exchange went like this: ``A few leading comrades can come,'' he said. ``Who?'' he was asked. ``A few. The scope is set by the higher authorities,'' he said. ``Can the president?'' ``Yes,'' Qin replied. ``The premier?'' ``Yes,'' he said. ``A Cabinet minister?'' he was asked. ``Not necessarily,'' Qin said. ``Less than 10 people?'' ``Several dozen.'' he said. ``How many dozen?'' ``A few,'' Qin answered. A recent article in the Hong Kong-based China Market magazine said the store originally supplied only the state chairman, premier and president and their deputies, and the chairmen and deputies of the legislature and Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, a high-level advisory body. But after these officials retired or died, their relatives continued using the store, the magazine said, and their successors expanded the customer list. In August, as part of a package of measures intended to blunt popular resentment of official privilege, the government said it was ending special supplies of rationed foods to top officials. Qin said leaders had been allowed to buy extra cooking oil, meat, sugar and eggs at subsidized prices. Ordinary Chinese were limited to rations, or in recent years, could buy extra only on the high-priced free market. But the government did not shut down No. 32, which still offers the rare privilege of convenient shopping. ``We stock many things so you can buy all in one stop,'' said Qin. He said the store offers a wider selection and generally higher quality of meat and fish than most markets, at slightly higher prices. But a comparison found some items were cheaper: ham, for example, went for less than 85 cents a pound, compared with $1.05 at a regular store. Maotai, China's famous fiery liquor, sold for $18, compared with $19.50 at the ordinary shop. Qin said there was no contradiction in a socialist society offering special stores for special people. ``It's convenient,'' he said with some exasperation. ``China is a developing country and its foodstuffs are not so ample.'' He noted that ordinary citizens are supposed to buy their monthly rations of state-subsidized meat, eggs and rice at assigned stores, and said the concept was similar. ``No store could supply all of society.'' Annual sales to leading officials were no more than $213,000, out of the Beijing City Food Supply Center's total sales of about $17 million, Qin said. The center's main customers are hotels and two small stores for visiting overseas Chinese and foreigners _ who, like officials, often have special status in China. These places buy wholesale from a large, well-marked building across the street from No. 32. Neither building is a place to meet top officials. ``As far as I know they don't come themselves. Usually it's household servants who come. We've never encountered the wife or relative of a (Communist Party) Central Committee member,'' Qin said. ``When you come here it's like walking into any department store,'' added Li Peiji, assistant managing director. ``We don't ask a customer's status.'' That's for three employees who stand near the entrance to do. Qin said they ask customers to show a card indicating authorization to shop there. But three men who walked in for cigarettes shortly before the 5 p.m. closing time said no one asked them for ID. ``I've been here a few times,'' said one, wearing the uniform of a navy commander. ``They have a wide variety of goods and the service isn't bad.'' Asked if they were related to any high-ranking officials, the three just laughed. Qin was unperturbed by the apparent breach of exclusivity. ``Maybe when he came before he was with someone who had identification,'' he said of the navy commander. ``We welcome the expansion of our service.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Raids for Neo-Nazi Propaganda; Republicans Petitions Falsified
DOC.TEXT: Police staged nationwide raids on the homes of dozens of suspected neo-Nazis and confiscated reams of right-wing extremist propaganda, officials said. West German police raided 40 residences in 26 cities on Wednesday in a coordinated move to confiscate neo-Nazi material, according to a statement by state police in Stuttgart. About 200 police officiers took part in the raids, which targeted suspected members of the Action Front National Socialists@National Activists. The group, officially banned in 1986 as a threat to the constitution, was founded by former West Germany army Lt. Michael Kuehnen in the 1970s. Police say the group has between 800 and 1,000 active members. Kuehnen, a self-proclaimed successor to Adolf Hitler, has been jailed several times over the past decade for extreme-rightist activities, including incitement of the public and publicly preaching Nazi propaganda. He is currently free. Included in the confiscated matter was training material to indoctrinate new members along with neo-Nazi advertising propaganda, the statement said. Among the cities where the raids were staged were West Berlin, Hamburg, Cologne, Essen and Aachen, police said. No one was arrested during the searches, but police said arrests were possible after officials have evaluated the confiscated material. Similar searches in West Germany were carried out against neo-Nazis in 1988, resulting in charges against five people for membership in a banned extremist organization.

DOC.HEAD: Deng Reported As Saying Gorbachev's Days Are Numbered
With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: China's senior leader Deng Xiaoping has predicted the downfall of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the resurgence of Soviet conservatives, a newspaper reported today. The South China Morning Post, quoting unnamed Chinese sources in Beijing, said Deng last week told Communist Party leaders that the ethnic turmoil and separatist movements sweeping the Soviet Union are products of the Soviet president's reform program. ``After Gorbachev has fallen from power, he will be replaced by the conservative faction,'' Deng was quoted as saying. The 85-year-old Chinese patriarch did not say when he expected the change. Deng, under whose leadership China's pro-democracy movement was crushed in June, has resigned from all his party posts to make way for younger leaders but is still believed to be the most powerful man in China. China's hard-line leaders have been alarmed by the bloody overthrow of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in Romania and democratic movements sweeping Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Marshals Intervene In Coal Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `It was...,' to CORRECT that six men arrested Tuesday, sted five.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CN1
DOC.TEXT: Non-union coal operators drove trucks through a human barricade Wednesday after federal marshals ordered tow trucks to haul away vehicles blocking a coal company's private road. No one was injured when the three coal trucks, with steel plates protecting their radiators, crossed a makeshift bridge leading to the Rum Creek Coal Sales Inc. preparation plant. A female picket, however, was shoved by a federal marshal escorting the plant's contractor and was taken away by ambulance. U.S. District Judge Dennis Knapp last week issued an injunction barring United Mine Workers pickets from blocking the road leading to the plant and limiting the number of pickets at the site to 15. Two union members arrested for allegedly violating the order appeared in court Wednesday. The contractor, Mike Holbrook, was called to use a cutting torch to slice through a cable that attached a car to the private bridge. Holbrook, wearing a blue baseball hat reading ``Scab 1,'' withstood taunts and insults while cutting the cable in front of about 75 UMW members and supporters. About two dozen union miners struck in mid-August after Rum Creek, a subsidiary of the A.T. Massey Coal Co., hired a non-union contractor to run the plant. It was the third day of unrest at the bridge. Six people were arrested Tuesday after coal trucks plowed through vehicle barricades. Two women were injured in similar incidents Monday. Three cars were on the bridge at sunrise Wednesday when federal marshals arrived accompanied by tow trucks. Two four-wheel-drive vehicles were removed without trouble, and marshals escorted Holbrook to the bridge to free the car. After the vehicles were removed, non-union coal trucks slowly pushed their way past miners in the road. Later, the non-union operators left their coal trucks inside the preparation plant and left the site in four-wheel-drive vehicles with plexiglass protecting the windows. When Holbrook was escorted through a group of miners to a waiting van, a marshal knocked over the picket, Cora Ballard, who is in her late 40s. ``What did she do to you? What did she deserve to get hit?'' said Kimberly Goodman, Ballard's daughter. ``She was just standing and you had to hit her.'' ``All she was trying to do was stand up for her man's job,'' said Kathy Justice, the wife of a miner. Ballard suffered bruises on both arms and hit her head when she fell, and was treated at Logan General Hospital and released, said her brother, John Workman. About 18 West Virginia State Police troopers, who are barred by state law from taking sides in labor disputes, watched from the side. Howard Green, a UMW international executive board member, and Bernard Evans, a union strike coordinator, appeared Wednesday before Judge Knapp and were freed on $10,000 bail each. They were arrested Tuesday for violating the judge's order. Three men arrested Tuesday after allegedly plowing through the picket line in non-union coal trucks were released on bail Wednesday, according to Logan County Magistrate Court assistant Tammy Hall. One of the men pleaded innocent to attempted murder, he added. Rum Creek Coal Sales President Richard Zigmond swore out 90 new complaints Wednesday seeking the arrest of pickets for trespassing and parking other vehicles on private property, Hall said. Arrests on those warrants are expected Thursday, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Ohio Congressman Retiring
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Thomas A. Luken, D-Ohio, a former Cincinnati mayor who has served in Congress since 1976, announced Wednesday he will retire when his term ends Jan. 1. Luken, 64, a lawyer who has maintained his home in Cincinnati, is serving his seventh consecutive term. ``I expect that this is my swan song in elective office. You never say never, but it's likely that I will not attempt elective office again,'' Luken said. He said he has not decided what he will do next, but indicated he may still spend time in Washington after leaving Congress. Luken said he is announcing his departure from Congress now to give other potential candidates for his office time to decide whether to file qualifying documents by the Feb. 22 filing deadline. Luken said he does not know who the Republicans planned to field as a candidate and said he felt confident that he could win again if he decided to seek re-election. Luken's eight children include Cincinnati Mayor Charles J. Luken. The younger Luken, 38, said he is considering running for his father's congressional seat and scheduled a news conference at his Cincinnati home for Thursday morning. ``Being a congressman is something I've wanted to do for a long time,'' Charles Luken said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Policewoman Shoots and Kills Husband, Retarded Son
DOC.TEXT: A retired city police captain shot and killed her husband and retarded son Wednesday, and had turned the gun on herself when police talked her into putting the weapon down. Dorothea Sweeten, 66, called a minister to tell her about the shootings, said Lt. Herman Johnson of the Knox County Sheriff's Department. The minister notified authorities, who rushed to the home south of Knoxville and found Mrs. Sweeten still on the telephone, threatening to kill herself. ``When they arrived she had the gun under her chin,'' Johnson said. ``It was cocked and she had her finger on the trigger.'' Johnson said Capt. Bryan Sturgell, head of the department's SWAT team, talked her into dropping the gun. Mrs. Sweeten's husband Tom, 55, and her son, Charles H. Forester Jr., 39, were found in separate bedrooms of her house after police were notified about 1:30 p.m. Sweeten was managing editor of The Knoxville Journal for 12 years before joining the Tennessee Valley Authority as a communications manager in 1986. Mrs. Sweeten retired as a captain from the Knoxville police department in 1982 after 28 years on the force. She became a security officer for the U.S. Marshal's Service office in Knoxville, from which she also retired. Johnson said Mrs. Sweeten was taken to a hospital for observation. He said no charges were filed immediately.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Women Smokers' Heart Attack Risk Falls Soon After Quitting
DOC.TEXT: Women who give up smoking lower their risk of heart attacks quickly, just as men do, a study today concludes. Women who smoke face nearly four times the usual risk of heart attacks before age 65. Earlier research has shown that the high risk of heart attacks in male smokers goes away within a few years of stopping. But the new study is the first to show that this also happens in women. ``The present data underscore the value of smoking cessation for women, as for men, and may give women a convincing motive to quit, even if they have smoked heavily for many years,'' the researchers wrote in the New England Journal of Medicine. The study found that the risk of suffering a first heart attack was 3.6 times higher among current smokers than among those who never had smoked. However, within three years of giving up smoking, their risk had dropped to the point where it was no higher than that of the non-smokers. Smoking has fallen from favor among both sexes, although the decline has been steeper among men. During the past two decades, the proportion of men who smoke has fallen from 51 percent to 29 percent, while among women it has dropped from 33 percent to 24 percent. The latest analysis was conducted by Dr. Lynn Rosenberg and colleagues from the Sloan Epidemiology Unit at Boston University School of Medicine. The work was based on 910 women who were admitted for heart attacks at 71 hospitals in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut and New York. Their smoking habits were compared to those of 2,375 women who were in the hospitals for other reasons.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Accuses Somalia of New Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International today accused Somalia's government of arbitrarily imprisoning, torturing and executing its citizens without a fair trial. The London-based human rights organization called on the government of President Mohammed Siad Barre to establish ``a comprehensive program of legal and institutional reforms'' to end the abuses. Amnesty pointed to what it called ``political arrests and killings in July, 1989, and further human rights violations later in the year.'' It called them ``a serious setback to human rights improvements made in the first half of 1989,'' when the government of the Horn of Africa country released more than 1,000 political prisoners. With its 13-page report, Amnesty became the second international human rights organization to sharply criticize the Siad Barre regime this year. Earlier this month, New York-based Africa Watch said the Somali military had killed between 40,000 and 50,000 unarmed civilians in the past 19 months. Africa Watch said most of the victims were members of the Isaac clan, from which a northern insurgent group, the Somali National Movement, largely draws its strength. Amnesty noted that it had been allowed to send a delegation to Somalia in June for the first time in 20 years, but said it received ``few replies'' from the government since then. Shortly after its June visit, Amnesty said, ``there were new arrests of suspected political opponents, killings of demonstrators and extrajudicial executions.'' The organization said most political prisoners are held under a vague security law and tried by a court ``lacking judicial independence.'' Amnesty said defendants can be sentenced to death for ``organizing a subversive association'' or strikes and ``exploiting religion for creating national disunity.'' Washington has withheld or canceled more than $50 million in aid dating back to 1987 because of human rights abuses. Britain, France and other Western donors also have slashed funds. Siad Barre, a major general said to be in his 80s, seized power in October 1968 to prevent the election to the presidency of a civilian opposed by the army. In recent years he has ruled a deteriorating nation beset by tribal rebellions in the north and south, clan warfare, and a bankrupt economy. Somalia became independent in 1960 after the unification of the north and south, colonized by Britain and Italy respectively.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: ``It's Anybody's Guess'' whether game show host Monty Hall is out to ``Beat the Clock'' or ``Strike It Rich.'' But apparently ``The Sky's the Limit'' now that he's bowed out of a new ``Let's Make a Deal.'' Hall will not be the host when ``Let's Make a Deal,'' the show he co-created, produced and starred in for 4,500 episodes, returns to the NBC daytime schedule come summer. ``I'm looking for new fields to conquer,'' said Hall, 64. Hall, who keeps busy doing commercials and making guest appearances, may also pop up on the show from time to time as a surprise guest. The new version of the show will originate from the Disney-MGM Studios Theme Park in Orlando, Fla. Hall will remain a half-owner of the new version. A former sportscaster, Hall has also been the host of such shows as ``It's Anybody's Guess,'' ``Beat the Clock,'' ``Strike It Rich'' and ``The Sky's the Limit.''

Gov. Kay Orr's husband, Bill, will be the guest star in a segment of a game show trying to stage a comeback on network television. Three pilots of ``To Tell the Truth'' are tentatively scheduled for broadcast next summer on NBC, Mrs. Orr said Wednesday. Guest panelists attempt to pick out the real Bill Orr, author of the ``First Gentleman's Cookbook.'' ``He got all four votes, he's so believable,'' Mrs. Orr said. One of the fake first husbands was Trevor Valentine, a representative of the British-American Chamber of Commerce. He wore a tuxedo similar to that worn by Bill Orr on the cover of his cookbook.

The guest list includes Fords, Edisons and Firestones, and the man who's catering the party Friday night marking the restoration of Henry Ford's winter home in Florida is excited about it. Don Smith, a caterer whose previous jobs were always Ohio affairs, also conceded Wednesday that he's a bit nervous. ``I guess we call this stage fright,'' said Smith, owner of the Allisten Manor restaurant and Smith Catering in this western Ohio city. More than 500 guests are expected at Ford's home _ called The Mangoes. The historic, lodgelike residence is owned by the city of Fort Myers. Also on the guest list is Donald Trump. NBC-TV weatherman Willard Scott of ``Today'' will serve as master of ceremonies. Smith said his company landed the job by chance. Suzanne Edwards, who coordinated the restoration of the home, was impressed by Smith's job at her niece's wedding reception last summer. He said his company later made a presentation to the restoration committee.

The U.S. theater is superficial, says Arthur Miller, who's in London for rehearsals of his play ``The Price,' which opens next month. Contrasting unsubsidized theater in the United States with the state-aided British theater, Miller said American theater often has degenerated into a search for titillating ways to fill unsubsidized and expensive seats. During a break at the Young Vic theater, the 74-year-old playwright told reporters that standards in British theater could fall if subsidies were reduced. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative government favors financing the arts by private business sponsorship. Miller, known for such works as ``Death of a Salesman'' and ``The Crucible,'' said unsubsidized American seat prices made an evening at the theater so expensive that general audiences would not go unless a critic said the production was a masterpiece, even if the critic was wrong. He said that meant audiences in the United States have become a self-serving clique and the plays appear tailored to match the audience.

A woman who claims she was the companion of ``Star Trek'' star William Shatner has sued him for $3 million in a ``palimony'' lawsuit. Vira Montes claims in her Los Angeles Superior Court lawsuit that she was Shatner's ``companion, confidante and homemaker'' from September 1984 until early this month. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday by attorney Marvin Mitchelson, said she gave up a career as a medical assistant in exchange for Shatner's promise of financial support. Mitchelson said Shatner has remained married to Marci Shatner, his second wife, throughout the relationship with Montes. Mitchelson said the actor spent time with each woman. The lawsuit says Shatner, 58, had promised to marry her. Shatner starred as Capt. James T. Kirk in the ``Star Trek'' television series and subsequent movies. He also had the title role in the series about Los Angeles policeman ``T.J. Hooker.'' He currently hosts ``Rescue 911.'' Shatner's manager was unavailable late Wednesday, and there was no answer at his production company offices.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Another version on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former baseball star Steve Garvey, plagued by low ratings in his new career as a radio talk show host, has been fired after six months at the station. Garvey, 41, was unavailable for comment, said a woman at his La Jolla business office. He was informed of his dismissal after completing his four-hour show at 9 a.m. Wednesday. Tom Jimenez, vice president and general manager of XTRA, said the station and Garvey reached a settlement on the remainder of his contract. The dismissal culminates a difficult year for Garvey, a 10-time All-Star first baseman in 17 years with the Los Angeles Dodgers and San Diego Padres. He reportedly has financial problems, and his image suffered after it was revealed he had fathered two children out of wedlock with different women before marrying a third woman last year. Garvey and his first wife also engaged in a bitter court battle over visitation rights with their two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 6:30 a.m. EST; time set by source
Study Finds Many Early Retirees Anxious to Get Back to Work
DOC.TEXT: More than 1.9 million early retirees are willing and able to return to work, according to a private survey released today that its sponsors say uncovers a promising untapped labor pool for American business. ``The exciting news for employers is it's a far more robust pool than we had imagined,'' said Thomas W. Moloney, senior vice president of The Commonwealth Fund, a philanthropic foundation that commissioned the poll. ``The United States is expected to face a severe labor shortage by early in the next century,'' he said. ``This report should encourage business to look toward capable, committed older Americans to fill many of these openings.'' Moloney said the findings run counter to popular perceptions that there are few older Americans who are available, capable and willing to return to work in the kinds of jobs that are in demand. The findings are based on a 1989 national survey by Louis Harris and Associates Inc. of 1,751 men aged 55-64 and 1,758 women aged 50-59, with 43 percent of those surveyed not working. The different age groups for men and women were selected to catch them at the times when more people traditionally drop out of the work force. The survey found the retirees' main reason for wanting to return to work was to do something useful, cited by 71 percent. Sixty-four percent said working keeps them feeling younger, 46 percent said they were bored without a job, 45 percent said they needed extra spending money and 43 percent they needed money for essentials. The survey data was analyzed by ICF Inc., a Washington consulting firm, which concluded that of the 1.9 million older people who are willing and able to work, 1.1 million are highly committed to and capable of rejoining the work force. These people said they need a job for financial reasons, are physically able to do key tasks such as driving or using a calculator, are seeking work and have reasonable wage expectations, are willing to work under difficult conditions such as standing up or on weekends. They are also willing to take jobs that are in demand such as sales, word processing, clerical positions, day care and managerial posts. These retirees also had education, job skills and experience largely comparable to those of their counterparts still in the work force, the poll found. Seventy-five percent were high school or college graduates, compared to 85 percent of those still working. Sixty-four percent had five or more years of experience on their last job, compared to 77 percent of current older workers. Most also were willing to work under difficult conditions: 83 percent would take seasonal jobs, 60 percent would work standing up, 73 percent would work alone, 60 percent would commute more than 30 minutes and 54 percent would work evenings and weekends. ``What we see here are capable, educated, experienced people who want to get back in,'' Moloney said. ``These are people who certainly should not be at the age of retirement.'' Moloney said the study did not analyze why these people left the work force before age 65, but they may have been forced out of their jobs, quit because of family demands or thought they had enough retirement income to stop working. He said many of the retirees have been discouraged from rejoining the labor force by employers looking for younger workers, but the climate is changing as labor markets tighten and employers' attitudes toward older workers improve. The Commonwealth Fund said employers need to be better educated about the abilities and availability of early retirees, older persons should be encouraged to actively seek work, and programs such as job banks should be established to help match jobs and workers. The foundation said it was launching an Older Americans at Work Program designed to change impressions about the value and ability of older workers.

DOC.HEAD: Virtual Collapse of Warsaw Pact a Mixed Blessing, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: A generation of U.S. military officers reared on the threat of a Soviet invasion of Europe now agree the Warsaw Pact is dying in the wake of the revolution in Eastern Europe. But some regard the demise of their old enemy as a mixed blessing. ``These changes in Eastern Europe reduce the Soviet Union's confidence and capacity to wage coalition warfare,'' said Lt. Gen. Henry Soyster, head of the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency, an organization that historically has emphasized Soviet strengths rather than weaknesses. Soviet officials have not publicly acknowledged the de facto collapse of their alliance, declaring instead their readiness to transform the Warsaw Pact from a military into a political organization. U.S. analysts say such a transformation has little chance of success. For the United States and its 15 allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the collapse of their Eastern counterpart creates some uneasiness. At the height of the East European revolution last fall, many U.S. officials thought the Warsaw Pact should be preserved as a vehicle for negotiating conventional force reductions in Europe and as a forum for resolving potential disagreements within the Soviet Bloc, said one administration source. Most policymakers now have concluded ``that there is a danger in the artificial perpetuation of an institution that might collapse of its own weight,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Dissenters from that view want a Warsaw Pact ``because of the shaken confidence which would result from a sudden demise,'' the source said. Soyster said the collapse of the Warsaw Pact virtually eliminated the threat of an East-West confrontation in Europe, which for decades was deemed the most likely starting place for a superpower war. ``I believe that the Soviets would consider large scale theater operations against NATO with only their own forces as highly risky, if not impractical,'' Soyster testified on the first day of Senate Armed Service Committee hearings on the Soviet threat. At a conference of Eastern and Western military officers last week in Vienna, Lt. Gen. Nikolai Chervov of the Soviet General Staff said ``there will be major restructuring of the Eastern Bloc's military command apparatus,'' handing authority from Soviet generals to East European elected leaders, Soyster told the Senate committee. The point, Chervov and others Soviets have said, is to transform the Warsaw Pact from a military into a political organization. ``The Warsaw Pact is dead as a military organization, because the Eastern European nations are asking the Soviets to withdraw their troops. How can they expect to keep it as a political organization?'' said James A. Blackwell, a former Army officer and analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. Although none of the six non-Soviet nations in the pact have withdrawn, three of them _ Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland _ have asked that Soviet troops be withdrawn from their territory. No Soviet troops are in Bulgaria and Romania. Last week at the Vienna conference, Hungarian military leader Laszlo Borsits said his nation would stay in the Warsaw Pact ``for the time being,'' but would cut its troops by one-third. Czechoslovakia and Poland also have announced force reductions. Despite the changes, Borsits said the Warsaw Pact and NATO should remain as ``a stabilizing factor ... Their loosening would upset the balance and would lead to incalculable consequences.'' The unstated fear is of a unified Germany. Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger suggested in a recent television interview that Moscow should ``maintain some position in Eastern Europe as a safety net if ... there should be a revival of German nationalism or expansionism.'' The unification of East and West Germany, he said, was inevitable.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 36,969.11, up 190.13 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Chances for Success Fading, Economist Says
DOC.TEXT: A Swedish economist, author of a widely acclaimed book on Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempts at reform, says the Soviet leader's chances of success are fading and that he may be pushed out of office. ``The Soviet Union is not only lagging, but plunging further into a crisis that can be called an economic catastrophe,'' Anders Aslund told a small seminar Wednesday attended by several top administration analysts. The Soviets face three likely scenarios: radical reform, deeper chaos or a ``counterrevolution'' by the military or conservative Communist Party leaders who will seek to reimpose an authoritarian system, Anders told a seminar at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank. Aslund, who worked in the Swedish Embassy in Moscow in 1984-87, attracted wide attention among administration and academic analysts last year with his book, ``Gorbachev's Struggle for Economic Reform.'' Consumers are experiencing acute shortages of food and other staples and industry faces an energy crisis. Wages are growing faster than prices although there are fewer goods for workers to purchase, said Aslund. He noted that the Soviet Union experienced a 5 percent drop in 1989 ``national income,'' the statistic the Soviets use to measure their overall economic performance. He predicted a 10 percent drop in 1990 for national income. Two top administration analysts on the Soviet Union shared Aslund's pessimism, but questioned aspects of his dire predictions. Both analysts, speaking on condition of anonymity, shared Aslund's view that deeper chaos was likely, but said Gorbachev had more support on the ruling Politburo than described by Aslund. Aslund said opposition is growing against the Soviet leader in the upper echelons of the Communist Party, in the government bureaucracies and among local party leaders. ``The bureaucracies are ganging up,'' he said. Gorbachev has only two reliable allies on the ruling Politburo, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Aleksandr Yakovlev, said Aslund, predicting the moderate majority might give the top job to Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov. One of the senior administration analysts said Gorbachev has a working majority on the 11-member body, including Ryzhkov and other moderate economic decision-makers. ``He has to have more support. Any other explanation simply doesn't explain what has happened,'' said the analyst. ``The Politburo has been growing steadily more liberal'' under popular pressure. But, he said, Gorbachev might be forced from his job as Communist Party general secretary if fighting continues in and around the southern republic of Azerbaijan or he fails to persuade the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to drop their plans to secede from the Soviet Union. Gorbachev nonetheless might complete his five-year term as president, the analyst said, adding that the Congress of People's Deputies, which elected Gorbachev president last year, does not have enough power to contest the military or the KGB secret police. The prestige of the Communist Party will decrease following elections scheduled in February and March in the 15 Soviet republics, both administration analysts predicted. Aslund said Gorbachev missed an opportunity for radical economic reform by failing to push through a plan advanced last fall by Leonid Abalkin, a deputy premier. Abalkin advocated rapid introduction of market economy along lines followed by the Solidarity-led government in neighboring Poland. Instead, ``what we are seeing is a complete retraction from reform,'' as the central government attempts to reassert economic authority, Aslund said. President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III are taking the correct policy toward Gorbachev, praising his efforts and granting him a number of economic favors at the Malta summit last December, said Aslund. ``Bush and Baker are approaching this in the right way, saying they want perestroika to succeed,'' Aslund said, using the Russian word for the reforms. ``I think it extremely unlikely that it will.'' The payoff from Gorbachev's reforms could come a decade hence, he said. ``I look on what is happening as a learning experience,'' he said. The ideas pursued by Gorbachev and his radical allies will have a better chance of success when Soviet citizens ``are more mature,'' he said. ``I am fairly optimistic about the long-term.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st two grafs of second item to fix typo in `believe,' and CORRECT placement of hyphen in name; longer version moved on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Psychologists say teams in black are scarier, and the Indiana Pacers believe the darker design of their new uniforms will help make them contenders in the 1990s. Florence Griffith-Joyner, the Olympic sprint champion-turned-fashion designer who raced in outlandish outfits featuring lace, pastels and single leggings, designed the new togs, which will be worn by next season's team. Navy blue replaces royal blue in a color scheme that also includes gold and white. Modeling the new uniform at a ringside news conference Wednesday, forward and co-captain Chuck Person did a bit of color psychologizing. ``I think the lighter shade didn't give us the flash, the go-get-'em attitude,'' Person said. The royal blue was a ``slower-looking color.'' The new outfit, which also includes a V-neck and a gold triangle on the top, ``feels great,'' Person said. Guard Reggie ``Hollywood'' Miller, a friend of Flo-Jo since their days at the University of California, Los Angeles, was happy that he would be allowed to wear the nearly knee-length shorts he favors. The uniforms will make the Pacers a ``mean team,'' Miller said. The Pacers have earned a trip to the playoffs only once in seven years, in 1980-81 when they finished 41-41. They were 22-18 after Wednesday night's loss to the Los Angeles Lakers.

DOC.HEAD: Garrett Defends Destroyer From Congressional Attacks
DOC.TEXT: The Navy secretary is defending the service's new $1.2 billion guided-missile destroyer against congressional charges of contracting problems and the absence of a basic test of the ship's sophisticated computer system. ``These ships will be the most advanced, most powerful destroyers ever sent to sea,'' H. Lawrence Garrett III told members of a House Armed Services panel Wednesday that is looking into allegations surrounding the Arleigh Burke-class ship. The Navy currently plans to purchase 33 of the ships at a cost of $27 billion. Martin M. Ferber, director of the General Accounting Office's National Security and International Affairs Division, said the lead ship, under construction by the Bath Iron Works in Maine, is 17 months behind schedule and design changes have resulted in the billion-dollar plus pricetag. ``Bath Iron Works is now accelerating construction to meet the planned delivery in February 1991,'' Ferber told the subcommittee on seapower and strategic and critical materials. But Garrett argued the program is ``on track to provide our fleet the most capable destroyer ever built, within the contractor cost the Navy estimated more than six years ago, and on a delivery schedule which has remained constant for more than two.'' Members of the panel largely agreed with the Navy secretary that the program is important, focusing their criticism on the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, and a fellow colleague who initially complained about the destroyer. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, wrote a letter to the Navy last September citing cost overruns and schedule delays in the destroyer program. Dingell was unable to testify before the Armed Services panel because of a scheduling conflict, but in a four-page letter to the subcommittee said his early assessment of the program as a ``procurement nightmare'' may have been an understatement. Dingell complained the sophisticated Aegis computer system that will be installed on the destroyer has never been tested against some missiles. ``A specific type of missile, known as an anti-radiation missile that is specifically targeted to home in on the Aegis' powerful radar emissions, has never been tested against the system,'' Dingell said. Rep. Charles E. Bennett, D-Fla., chairman of the Armed Services panel, raised that issue with Garrett, questioning why the Aegis hasn't been tested against the anti-radiation missile. ``The ARM is like any other cruise missile to the Aegis,'' Garrett said. But when pressed by Bennett, the Navy secretary conceded there were some dangers involved.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Pledges Strong Backing for Welfare Program
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is assuring Congress of strong support for a popular nutrition program for poor pregnant women and children after a new report showed Reagan appointees erroneously downplayed its benefits. Birge Watkins, deputy assistant agriculture secretary for food and consumer services, said Wednesday the Reagan administration was wrong to change a study on the effectiveness of the Women, Infants and Children nutrition program. ``We are all aware of President Bush's strong support of the WIC program and of its significant investment in the next generation,'' Watkins told a joint hearing of the House Select Committee on Hunger and the Senate Agriculture Committee. He said the Bush administration agreed with a General Accounting Office investigation which showed the Agriculture Department under President Reagan inserted errors and deleted important conclusions in a study of WIC that was released in 1986. ``It's simply no way to do business. We regret this whole incident happened,'' said Watkins. Members of Congress were outraged. ``The original report did not track with the administration ideological bent, so the findings were cooked to make them more palatable,'' charged Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa. ``What a despicable and insensitive action.'' John Bode, assistant secretary for food and consumer services under Reagan, strongly disagreed with that characterization. Bode, who was responsible for the administration's handling of the study, was not invited to testify. He said in a telephone interview after the hearing that the changes were not made for political reasons. ``To assert there was willful misrepresentation to Congress is wrong,'' he said. The revisions were written by Thomas Sullivan, then a special assistant to Bode. Now practicing law, Bode said he believes the compendium was wrong, but thought at the time that Sullivan and others at the department who reviewed the study knew what they were doing. He said that shortly after the review, he changed procedures for handling such matters so the same mistakes would not happen. Bode said the main problem was that Sullivan wrote a compendium for the Reagan administration report on WIC in which he downplayed the strength of the program. Bode said WIC should have gotten a much stronger endorsement. Sullivan, who also has left government service, could not immediately be reached for comment. Keith Fultz, of the GAO, said investigators could not pin down the intent behind the changes. He said the summary written by the original researchers was deleted and replaced by a compendium that ``did not fairly represent what the study team found.'' That the study took almost seven years to complete also angered members of the two committees. ``The final report took six years instead of the originally targeted 2{ years to complete, and cost $6 million, instead of the planned $3.9 million,'' said Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of the hunger committee. The WIC program was started in 1972. Congress appropriated $725 million for WIC in 1980 and increased the amount by at least $100 million each year. That was not always enough to keep up with inflation and has never been enough to reach all the eligible women and children, but was consistently higher than the Reagan budget requests, said a member of the Senate Agriculture committee staff. For instance, Reagan proposed cutting the program in 1982 from the $869 million of the previous year to $637 million. Congress refused to go along and appropriated $948 million. The 1990 appropriation is $2.13 billion, serving about 4.6 million women and children, said Watkins. He said that about two-thirds of eligible recipients are getting help through the program.

DOC.HEAD: In Body Shapes, Pears Are Healthier Than Apples
DOC.TEXT: Having a big potbelly is bad for cholesterol, and this could explain why, when it comes to body shapes, pears are better than apples, according to a study published today. ``When patients come in, we advise them to lose weight,'' said Dr. Richard E. Ostlund Jr. ``This paper suggests that more important than that is how the fat is distributed.'' Researchers have long noticed that folks with big spare tires tend to have an especially high risk of heart trouble, but the reason was unclear. Ostlund's study, in New England Journal of Medicine, suggests that people with beefy hips and trim waists have higher levels of a protective form of cholesterol called HDL than do those with potbellies and small behinds. The study of healthy elderly people, conducted at Washington University School of Medicine, found that body shape alone could account for a large portion of the differences in people's HDL cholesterol levels. ``This may have tremendous importance to the average American, because we all tend to bulge out in this way,'' said Dr. William Castelli, director of the long-running Framingham Heart Study in suburban Boston. HDL _ high density lipoprotein _ is the so-called good cholesterol. The more people have in their blood, the lower their chances of heart attacks. Women typically have higher HDL levels than men. As they grow older, women also tend to put on weight around the hips, while men are more prone to growing big tummies. Doctors have long suspected that differences in sex hormones might explain the HDL disparity between men and women. However, the new study suggests that body shape, not sex, could be the key factor. It found that pear-shaped men tend to have high HDL, while apple-shaped women have lower HDL. ``It's not how fat you are; it's where the fat's located,'' said Ostlund. ``The fat around your hips, the good fat that women have, is predominantly subcutaneous fat. But the fat you have in your belly is intra-abdominal fat. The difference is where the blood supply of those two areas drains.'' Tummy fat surrounds the intestines, and its blood supply drains directly to the liver, he said. ``The liver is sensitive to things that fat cells put out. The metabolism of the liver may be changed because of the intra-abdominal fat,'' including the liver's production of HDL. The blood from hip fat, which is just underneath the skin, does not drain directly to the liver and so has less impact on the way it works, he said. The study was conducted on 77 men and 69 women, all in their 70s. To measure whether they were apples or pears, the researchers calculated the ratio of their waist-to-hip circumference. They found that 32 percent of the variation in their HDL levels could be explained by differences in this ratio. ``The bottom line for the middle-aged and elderly is: Don't let that spare tire get you around the waist,'' said Castelli. ``Get out and exercise and diet.'' However, Ostlund said dieting is a hard way to tackle the problem, since fat patterns may be established at birth. ``It's very hard to change your waist-to-hip ratio,'' Ostlund said. ``You can do it if you lose a massive amount of weight, but losing 10 to 20 pounds doesn't change it very much.''

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Government Should Turn Down the Volume
DOC.TEXT: A panel of experts says the government must do more to turn down the volume in the workplace and on consumer products to save the hearing of millions of Americans. The panel convened by the National Institutes of Health on Wednesday concluded that better protection for workers, noise labeling of consumer products, limits on noise levels for some products and an educational campaign would cut the number of people with hearing problems. Of the 28 million Americans who suffer hearing loss, about 10 million of the impairments were caused at least partly by exposure to loud noises, the panel said. Dr. Patrick E. Brookhouser, panel chairman and director of the Boys Town National Research Hospital in Omaha, Neb., said although the United States is the world leader in hearing-loss research, ``the fact that we're not continuing to implement our own recommendations is a concern to the panel.'' ``We know how to solve the problem. We just don't want to put in the effort and expense for it,'' he said. ``Unnecessary hearing loss is occurring now because we're not implementing what we already know are good preventive strategies.'' Exposure to loud sounds in the workplace is the most common cause of noise-related hearing loss and poses a danger to firefighters, police officers, military personnel, construction and factory workers, musicians, farmers and truck drivers, among others, the panel said. Outside the workplace, hazards include loud music, recreational vehicles, airplanes, lawn-care equipment, woodworking tools, some household appliances and chain saws, the panel said. Short bursts of loud noise as in an explosion or gunfire can damage hearing permanently, while longer exposure to less intense but still loud noise ``exacts a gradual toll on hearing sensitivity, initially without the victim's awareness,'' the panel said in a statement. Hearing loss is irreversible when the sensitive inner-ear structure is damaged, said Brookhouser. ``One of the problems is that people are losing hearing and they don't know it because it's not painful,'' he said. Exposure to sounds up to 75 decibels _ which is the noise of a dishwasher or vacuum cleaner _ are generally safe, even over long periods of exposure, he said. However, sounds at levels more than 85 decibels _ which is the noise level of a lawnmower or food blender _ for eight hours a day over a long period of time can damage hearing permanently, he said. The greater the noise, the shorter the period of exposure necessary to cause permanent damage. Two warning signs of dangerous noise exposure are ringing in the ears and a muffling of sounds that are heard. A rock concert delivers about 130 decibels of sound, which can cause a temporary hearing loss that can take several days or a week to recover from, Brookhouser said. He noted some in the concert industry have begun voluntarily to lower the volume because they are becoming more aware of the dangers to hearing. Panel members called for more such efforts in the entertainment field and for manufacturers to design quieter products and regulations to limit the maximum noise of certain products, such as portable cassette players. The panel also called for re-establishment of the Environmental Protection Agency's Office of Noise Abatement and Control, which was closed during the Reagan administration in 1982. Julia Doswell Royster, president of Environmental Noise Consultants Inc. in Cary, N.C., said existing EPA noise rules are largely unenforced. The Occupational Health and Safety Administration also has regulations covering workers, but she said they should be stronger and better enforced. EPA spokesman Dave Ryan said the agency has taken no enforcement actions since the office closed but is conducting five compliance investigations of makers of hearing protectors.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Opposition Coalition Seems Doomed by Distrust
DOC.TEXT: Japan's opposition parties remain divided by distrust and policy disagreements as campaigning starts for next month's election. Despite a long-awaited opportunity presented by the scandals and the slumping popularity of the Liberal Democratic government, opposition politicians concede they are far from setting up a coalition. ``At this point, we have to admit it is difficult for us to come to any sort of agreement on coalition terms before the general election,'' said Tsuruo Yamaguchi, secretary-general of the Japan Socialist Party, the largest opposition group. ``Each party is busy worrying about its own business ahead of the (Feb. 18) election,'' Yamaguchi said in an interview. Socialist chairwoman Takako Doi and the heads of three centrist parties met Wednesday after the lower house of Parliament was dissolved for the crucial election. They declared they were united on three points: To oust the Liberal Democrats, scrap an unpopular 3 percent sales tax and continue coalition talks. It was the first time since December the four key opposition parties had held a joint meeting. They started talking about coalition terms in April but have been unable to overcome such obstacles as the Socialists' opposition to Japan's armed forces and to the treaty under which the United States bases about 50,000 troops in Japan and is obliged to help defend Japan if it is attacked. The three other parties hold more conservative views. Akira Yamagishi, chairman of the Japanese Trade Union Federation and a key mediator in the opposition talks, said it was ``quite regrettable'' that the parties are divided when they have the best chance in decades to oust the Liberal Democrats. ``To me, their policy disagreements sound like no more than their excuses for not being able to cooperate,'' Yamagishi said. The Liberal Democrats have headed Japan's governments since 1955 and the only time the Socialists have been at the top since World War II was a few months in 1947 and 1948 when they led a coalition. The opposition has been out of power ``for so long that they have lost realistic aspirations to govern the country,'' Yamagishi said. For the Socialists to claim the premiership for Ms. Doi, the Liberal Democrats would have to lose at least 39 of their 295 seats in the outgoing house, and the Socialists would have to join other parties and assemble at least 257 seats, a bare majority in the 512-seat house. While polls show the Liberal Democrats could lose their majority, they seem assured of remaining the largest party, and there is speculation that they _ not the Socialists _ will entice the centrists into a coalition. Prospects for a Socialist-led coalition of the center-left are clouded by the Communist Party, which holds 27 seats in the outgoing house. The Marxist-Leninist party is entirely excluded from the coalition blueprint because of its revolutionary stances, but it could emerge with a key block of swing seats. The Socialists, holding 83 seats, are more moderate than the Communists, but there are radical factions within the Socialist Party which adhere to its traditional stance of making Japan neutral and unarmed, and calling for socialist revolutions. Leaders of centrist parties _ the Democratic Socialist Party (25 lower house seats), the Komeito or Clean Government Party (54 seats) and the United Social Democratic Party (four seats) _ say the Socialists must modify radical policy stances to be a coalition partner. ``We are talking about forming a government of the second economic superpower of the world.
