We'd better be sure who we are dealing with,'' Takashi Yonezawa, secretary-general of the Democratic Socialist Party, which parted from the Socialists in the 1960s over policy disagreements, said in an interview. The Clean Government Party secretary-general, Yuuichi Ichikawa, said, ``How can we take over the government when the leader of the opposition camp is not ready to do so? We just have to wait for the Socialists to become more realistic.'' Socialist leader Doi has softened the party's positions, saying it will acknowledge Japan's armed forces and the security alliance with the United States. ``We have said our party recognizes that Japan is a member of Western allies,'' she said in an interview last week. ``Seeking drastic change is not what we want.'' But Komeito leader Koshiro Ishida and Democratic Socialist leader Eiichi Nagasue demanded the Socialists put their policy modifications into their platform. Yamaguchi argued it was the centrist parties' turn to concede. ``I think it is important for each party to have its own unique goals,'' the Socialist secretary-general said. ``As far as policy modifications are concerned, we did all we can do.''

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Indicts Four Suspected IRA Members on Arms Charges
DOC.TEXT: Four suspected members of the Irish Republican Army are charged by a grand jury with violating the U.S. Neutrality Act by conspiring to ship weapons, including a Stinger missile, to Northern Ireland. The five-count federal indictment Wednesday also accused the men of violating the U.S. Arms Export Control Act, which requires arms dealers to get permission from the State Department before shipping weapons overseas. Department policy is to deny permission when the weapons are intended for use ``in connection with the sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland,'' the indictment said. ``This is in keeping with United States policy to encourage peaceful reconciliation in Northern Ireland.'' Other weapons the indictment accuses the men of conspiring to ship to Northern Ireland include rifles, grenade launchers and plastic explosives. Indictment are Kevin Joseph McKinley, 33, of Riviera Beach; Sean McCann, 34, of Toronto; Seamus Anthony Moley, 30, of Canada; and Joseph Martin McColgan, 39, of Dundalk, Northern Ireland. Each faces a maximum penalty of 38 years in prison. U.S. Magistrate Ann Vitunac ordered the men held until trial. Arraignment is set for Friday. Arms dealers are required to be licensed by the U.S. Office of Munitions Control before shipping weapons abroad. Exporters must tell the federal agency what weapons they wish to ship and to whom, the indictment states. ``At no time did (the defendants) apply for, receive or possess a license to export defense articles of any description,'' the indictment charges. The indictment details a series of meetings between the men and two undercover agents from the U.S. Customs Service and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. The meetings culminated at a West Palm Beach warehouse Jan. 12, when the two undercover agents allowed McColgan to inspect the Stinger missile and place it in the back seat of his car, agents said. The four men were arrested soon after the missile was delivered.

DOC.HEAD: Heart Association to Proceed With Labeling Despite FDA Disapproval
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration took a last-minute stand against a plan to label foods deemed safe by the American Heart Association, but the organization says it will go ahead anyway. The program, known as Heartguide, is scheduled to begin Monday. It's an ambitious effort by the association to make consumers smarter shoppers by identifying products low in saturated fat, total fat, cholesterol and sodium. The program has been in the works for three years, but Acting FDA Commissioner James S. Benson told the association Wednesday it risked regulatory action if it proceeded with the plan. ``FDA believes that your program will increase consumer confusion and hamper any comprehensive solution to the food labeling program,'' Benson wrote to the group. The association decided to proceed. ``We've already talked to the companies'' participating in the program, and ``they are in,'' said a Heartguide spokeswoman, Jamy Poth. Products tested and approved by the association would, for a fee, carry a symbol made up of a red heart and a check mark. Discussions have been held with the FDA throughout the past year, said Vicki Anderson, another spokeswoman for Heartguide, and the heart association was distressed with the last-minute letter. But an FDA spokesman said the agency has expressed concerns to the association during the past year. ``I would think they would have been aware of them,'' said the spokesman, Jeff Nesbit. In the wake of the letter, the second phase of the program _ in which cereals, cheese, cookies, pasta, salad dressings and other foods will be included _ has been put on hold to allow time for further negotiations with the FDA, Anderson said. The FDA has no authority to act before products are sold, Nesbit said. Once they are on supermarket shelves, however, the agency determines whether labels are misleading. If it determined that the association's seal of approval was misleading, it could order that the symbol be removed. Or it could seek a court order to block the sale of products with the symbol, or seize them, Nesbit said. The program has been criticized on the grounds that competitive pressures would force companies to participate, and that it promotes certain foods instead of promoting the idea of a healthy overall diet. The association said its educational program will make clear that Heartguide-approved foods should be incorporated into a diet that is beneficial overall. The fees paid to the association _ up to $640,000, depending upon a product's sales _ also have been criticized. ``What we see here is a realization by the government agencies that you have a non-profit, private organization, a non-regulated organization, trying to establish a set of rules and regulations on labeling _ for a fee. I think that's wrong,'' said John Cady, president of the National Food Processors Association, which has vigorously opposed the program. More than 100 brands of margarine, oil, crackers and vegetables already have been tested and approved. They include Mazola corn oil, Promise margarine, Pam cooking sprays, Melba Toast, and Hanover frozen vegetables. None of the labeled products is currently available on the shelves. Anderson said manufacturers had begun printing containers with the labels, but that products were not yet ready for shipment to supermarkets. The makers of Mazola products had not yet decided how to react to the FDA's action, said Gail Griffin, spokeswoman for CPC International of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. That is the parent company of Best Foods, which makes Mazola. The FDA's letter was addressed to heart association President Dr. Myron L. Weisfeldt of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Benson urged the heart association ``instead to join with the FDA and other groups in our current initiative to develop a comprehensive revision of the food label to promote good nutrition.''

DOC.HEAD: Groups Ask for Phaseout of Standardized Tests
DOC.TEXT: When A. Graham Down taught American history in college he would ask his students such questions as ``How `new' was the New Deal?'' or ``Should President Truman have dropped the bomb?'' Down says such broad questions, aimed at showing the depth of students' understanding of subjects, should replace the standardized, multiple-choice questions that are now used to assess what students know. ``There is no right answer and that understanding of ambiguity is surely the most important source of inspiration that informs citizenry of a real Democracy,'' Down said Wednesday in leading a call for reform of the widely-used standardized tests. Down, head of the Council for Basic Education, joined leaders of more than three dozen national education, parent, and civil rights organizations to urge President Bush and the nation's governors to move toward assessments based on actual student performance. The groups' ``Statement on Genuine Accountability'' comes as the administration and governors move towards setting up national educational goals promised during an education summit last year. One of the key issues is how to judge student performance. ``The testing craze has damaged the quality of our schools,'' said Monte Neill, associate director of FairTest of Cambridge, Mass., which is spearheading the effort for reform. ``Low-income and minority-group children have been particularly harmed. Teaching the narrow content included in multiple-choice tests has prevented students from learning higher order thinking skills,'' he said. The statement was signed by the leaders of 49 organizations, including the American Federation of Teachers, the Asian Law Alliance, Council for Basic Education, the Institute for Learning and Teaching, National Indian Youth Council Inc., National Parent Teacher Association, Federation of Organizations for Professional Women, National Association for the Education of Young Children, NAACP and the National Association of Elementary School Principals. Absent from the list were the National Education Association and the National Association of Secondary School Principals. Gregory Anrig, president of the Educational Testing Service, the Princeton, N.J., group that produces several standardized exams for college-bound students, said he disagrees with the ``blanket rejection of multiple-choice tests.'' ``They remain a valid, efficient and inexpensive means to measure certain important aspects of student achievement,'' he said in a statement. ``To simply call for abandonment of a proven and economical method of measurement is to go forth with one of education's hands tied behind its back, and impede the timely progress that all Americans desire for our schools,'' he said. But NAACP education director Beverly Cole said, ``America needs measures of educational performance which provide a level playing field for all students. Standardized exams, with their well-documented biases and flaws, fail this basic test.'' Barbara Willer of the National Association for the Education of Young Children said better alternatives to standardized tests include teacher observation, portfolios of student work, and performances and exhibitions that are based on the curriculum. ``Too many young children today are retained a grade, assigned to special classes, or held out of school based on the results of readiness and achievement tests that have questionable predictive accuracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Absent as Mayors Begin Meeting Opens With Drug Task Force
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Mayors attending the meeting of the U.S. Conference of Mayors say the absence of their host shows how far the ravages of drug abuse have reached. ``It epitomizes, it symbolizes, the extent of the drug problem in this country,'' Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn said when asked by reporters about Washington Mayor Marion Barry. Barry was in a Florida treatment center, where he had himself admitted following his arrest last week on a charge of possessing crack cocaine. Despite the national attention that's been riveted on Barry's case in the past week, no mayor mentioned their absent host publicly in the 1{-hour strategy session Wednesday of the mayors' drug task force. Nonetheless, Barry's case dominated the talk outside the meeting room as the nation's big-city mayors opened their three-day annual winter meeting. ``It was a tragedy for the mayor, and it was a tragedy for the District of Columbia,'' said Philadelphia Mayor Wilson Goode. ``I don't see how it has any impact on what we do here.'' Houston Mayor Kathryn Whitmire, president of the Conference of Mayors, avoided mention of Barry's arrest in a speech across town to the National Press Club. But when asked about it, she said Barry's arrest underscored the need for the federal government to spend more on drug treatment to make it available for those who need it. So long as there is a demand for drugs, she said, no law enforcement effort will stop dealers from meeting that demand. ``As we see him moving to get treatment for himself, we are caused to realize once again how important it is that treatment be available not only to those in high places, but to everyone who needs it,'' Whitmire said. She and other mayors shied away from saying whether they believed Barry should resign from office because of the cocaine arrest. ``I'm not going to try to give any political advice to any other mayors,'' she said. Flynn declined to say whether Barry should resign but said ``I'd like to see an acknowledgement of Marion Barry's problem'' by the mayor. He said if Barry is cured of a substance dependence problem, he should spend ``the rest of his life as an example'' to young people about the problems of drugs. Barry's appointed drug czar for the city, Sterling Tucker, sat in Barry's chair at the drug task force meeting. ``Even before I came to the job I was aware there were these allegations here (about drug use by Barry),'' Tucker said when questioned by a reporter. ``We've been faced with this all along. ... There's been no major interruption for me. We haven't missed a beat.'' Barry is also chairman of the mayors' transportation committee. Conference spokesman Mike Brown said another mayor would fill in for Barry when that panel meets. The mayors are awaiting President Bush's latest plans for federal anti-drug efforts and an appearance by Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del. Bush plans to address the mayors _ most of whom are Democrats _ on Friday. It will be the first time since Jimmy Carter in 1980 that a sitting president has spoken to the organization of big-city mayors. Several black mayors interviewed said they did not see Barry's case as a particular embarrassment for black officeholders or one that makes their anti-drug efforts more difficult. ``It only proves mayors are human,'' said Mayor John Daniels of New Haven, Conn. Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, N.J., said he did not embrace the suggestion of NAACP Executive Director Benjamin Hooks that the arrest was part of a pattern of harassment of black elected officials and a ``rising tide of racism.'' But he noted the FBI has faced charges of minority harassment and said racism would be a factor in law enforcement ``until we rule out racism in our country.'' Mayor Cardell Cooper of East Orange, N.J., said: ``I do believe black leadership has come under, certainly, scrutiny. ... I don't know if you'd call it undue or not.'' He said Barry ``might have put himself in position to invite'' attention and scrutiny.

DOC.HEAD: ``The Bradys'' Are Back as TV Series
DOC.TEXT: The Brady family of television's yesteryear is returning once again as a weekly series. Starting Feb. 16, one-hour ``The Bradys'' will be broadcast Fridays on CBS at 8 p.m. EST, the network announced Wednesday. The clan's arrival will bump the new ``Max Monroe: Loose Cannon'' series from the time slot. CBS said that series will have its last Friday broadcast on Jan. 26, and return later on a night to be announced. The Bradys first appeared on TV in 1969 in ABC's sitcom ``The Brady Bunch.'' That was followed by a comedy-variety series, ``The Brady Bunch Hour,'' dropped by ABC in 1977 after five months. But members of the clan were not to be denied. They returned, if only briefly, in 1981, in an NBC spin-off sitcom, ``The Brady Brides.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP House Members Oppose Dole Foreign Aid Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bob Dole's proposal to boost aid to Eastern Europe and Panama by cutting funds from major recipients like Israel and Egypt is ``shortsighted and detrimental'' to U.S. interests, 22 Republican House members say. The House members wrote to President Bush on Wednesday to express ``our strong opposition to the Dole foreign aid plan,'' which would slice money from Israel, Egypt, Turkey, the Philippines and Pakistan. ``We believe this is the wrong approach to the burgeoning needs of Eastern Europe,'' said the House members, led by Reps. Vin Weber of Minnesota and Bill McCollum of Florida. ``To reward one ally at the expense of another would be shortsighted and detrimental to American interests,'' they said. At the same time, Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, Dole's Republican colleague from Kansas, said she supported Dole and hoped his plan would lead to ``serious review and substantive reform'' of foreign aid. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, has not taken a stand on the issue, but he is holding meetings with Democratic colleagues to discuss foreign aid, his aides said. Kassebaum, who has introduced legislation to change the way foreign aid is divided up, criticized Congress for ``earmarking'' _ locking up _ 80 percent of the foreign aid budget. As a result, U.S. officials have no flexibility to deal with unforeseen circumstances, she said in a speech on the Senate floor. ``With earmarking, we have set up a system that prevents us from responding to opportunities'' like those in Eastern Europe, she said. Dole suggested changing the 1990 foreign aid budget that earmarks about $3 billion to Israel, slightly less to Egypt, about $500 million each to Turkey and Pakistan and some $160 million in economic aid to the Philippines. His plan would trim 5 percent from the big recipients, creating about $400 million that could go to Eastern Europe and Panama. Many have criticized Dole's plan. ``It's not going anywhere. Period,'' said Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, a member of the Senate Appropriations Committee. Debate on the 1991 foreign aid bill is expected to start soon, once the Bush administration unveils its requests next week. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, has said his panel will hold hearings ``reexamining U.S. foreign aid priorities in light of the vast changes in the international situation.'' ``As far as I'm concerned, every program in the fiscal 1991 foreign aid appropriation will be reviewed,'' Leahy said in a statement. On Jan. 18, Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin met with Bush administration officials and later said he had ``reasons to believe'' U.S. aid to his country would hold steady at $3 billion a year through 1991. But he expressed concern about aid beyond next year.

DOC.HEAD: Post: Donation Came After Congressman Changed Position on South Africa
DOC.TEXT: A scholarship program backed by Rep. Mervyn M. Dymally received a $34,200 donation from a New York diamond importer two months after Dymally softened his opposition to U.S. imports of South African diamonds, The Washington Post reported today. The paper said the California Democrat later agreed to lobby his colleagues to support other changes that Maurice Tempelsman, chairman of the board of Lazare Kaplan International Inc., wanted in a sanctions bill which eventually failed to pass the Senate. LKI, which last year had gross sales of $80 million, buys diamonds from South Africa and other countries, many of them through the London DeBeers syndicate, which does not distinguish the countries of origin of its diamonds. Dymally, who the newspaper said declined to be interviewed, told the newspaper in a one-page statement that he did not ``solicit contributions from Mr. Tempelsman.'' Tempelsman was quoted as saying ``at no time did (Dymally) hint that a contribution from me to the foundation would affect his position on the diamond sanctions.'' ``I do not make charitable contributions merely because a congressman so suggests and would not under any circumstances consider making one in the hope of influencing his vote,'' Tempelsman said in a written response to questions. ``No vote, no bill, no threat to my business could ever induce me to do that.'' The $34,200 was donated to the Ana G. Mendez Foundation and used to finance the 1988 Mervyn M. Dymally Young Minority Scholars Program that sent 14 students from Dymally's district to Puerto Rico for four weeks of study, according to foundation President Jose Mendez. That amount was suggested to Tempelsman in a prospectus sent to him by Amelia Parker, a Dymally aide, the newspaper said. A foundation document, according to the newspaper, noted that part of the $34,200 was set aside to pay honoraria. Dymally reported a $2,000 honorarium from the Mendez foundation in July 1988. The Post said that, other than the honoraria, there is no indication that Dymally personally benefited from the Tempelsman donation. Tempelsman made a second donation of $25,000 in 1989. According to House rules, members may not accept from a person with a direct interest in legislation ``favors or benefits ... under circumstances which might be construed by reasonable persons as influencing the performance of governmental duties.'' In February 1987, Dymally introduced legislation to ban U.S. imports of South African diamonds. Accepting arguments that his initial bill was unworkable, unfair to Zimbabwe and without committee support, he proposed changes in April 1988 to pending sanction legislation to weaken its impact on U.S. diamond importers. The Post reported that Dymally's change of heart came after a meeting with Tempelsman. Howard Marlowe, a lobbyist for Tempelsman, said he drafted an amendment for Dymally incorporating the changes that the Foreign Affairs Committee accepted. The House later went along, but the Senate refused. Tempelsman is a prominent New Yorker who is a frequent escort of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

DOC.HEAD: Laxative Helps Recover Stolen Jewelry
DOC.TEXT: It took patience _ and some laxative _ to recover a stolen $18,000 diamond ring that the suspect had swallowed. ``I'm glad that's out now,'' said Michael J. Weatherspoon. Weatherspoon, 23, of St. Paul, was arrested Jan. 17 after he took a 2{-carat diamond ring from a store manager at the National Jewelry Co., police said. He was chased down and wrestled to the ground by a passerby, but no ring was found, police said. Police obtained a search warrant authorizing ``proper medical techniques, excluding surgery,'' to recover the ring. Sgt. Richard Nelson spent the next day in the jail with Weatherspoon and some laxative. ``It took six hours,'' Nelson said. Nelson put the ring in a plastic bag and took it back to the store. Weatherspoon was being held on $10,000 bail on a theft charge.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Says He Will Never Forgive Father Who Set Him on Fire
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Charles Rothenberg began his parole in a secret location wired with an electronic leash, while the son he set afire seven years ago says he won't feel safe until the day his father dies. Rothenberg left prison early Wednesday, beginning three years' probation, said Tipton Kindel, spokesman for the state Department of Corrections in Sacramento. At a news conference later, 13-year-old David Rothenberg told reporters he fears his father will try to see him again. ``I know that he'll try,'' said the boy, who was severely scarred by his father's arson attack seven years ago. ``If he tries to hurt me I'll do something in self-protection.'' David said he still keeps a BB gun by his bed just in case. ``I would like them to keep him in jail for the rest of his life,'' said David, who was 6 when his father set him on fire in an Orange County motel room. The boy said he could never forgive his father. ``If he wants forgiveness, why did he do this?'' David asked. ``He says he's sorry but he's just saying that stuff just to get near me.'' ``He doesn't love me. If he loved me he wouldn't do this to me.'' ``It was cruel,'' he added. Asked when he thought he would feel safe, he responded unhesitatingly: ``When Charles dies.'' ``I want it known nationally that I don't ever want to see my father again. I want to make it clear to him,'' said David, who appeared at the news conference wearing a Los Angeles Raiders ball cap. David lives in Orange County with his mother, Marie, and stepfather, Buena Park police Lt. Richard Hafdahl, who helped investigate the case. Kindel said a parole officer will accompany Rothenberg at all times and the family would be notified if Rothenberg ever leaves his restricted area. The parole will cost California taxpayers $18,000 a month. Rothenberg set fire to his son in a motel room in 1983 after a telephone argument in which his estranged wife said Rothenberg would not be allowed to see the boy again. Rothenberg had taken the boy on a holiday to Southern California from New York, where the boy was living with his mother. David, dragged from the inferno by motel guests, suffered third-degree burns over 90 percent of his body. He still bears scars on his hands, face and legs from the burning and repeated skin grafts. Rothenberg was convicted of attempted murder, arson and other charges and received the maximum penalty, a 13-year prison term. The sentence was cut in half because of good behavior in prison. If convicted today, Rothenberg would have faced up to life in prison. But sentencing laws at the time required his release within seven years.

DOC.HEAD: Meeting on Boat People Ends With No Agreement
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Vietnamese delegates to a conference on boat people refused to accept a compromise starting date for the forced repatriation of Vietnamese denied refugee status, and the 30-nation talks broke up in disarray. At stake is the future of tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people waiting in camps in Hong Kong. The United States had opposed the mandatory repatriation of Vietnamese deemed to be economic migrants rather than refugees fleeing persecution, but last week softened its stance and advocated slow movement on the issue. Britain wanted deportations to begin at once _ before the sailing season starts in March _ to deter a further influx of boat people into the overflowing camps of Hong Kong, a British crown colony. The Office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) had tried to bridge the gap by suggesting a six-month delay in the repatriation process. But U.S. delegates told the closed, U.N.-sponsored meeting the proposed July 1 date was too early and said no one should have to return to Vietnam before Jan. 1, 1991, officials said. After the talks ended Wednesday, chief British delegate Robin McLaren expressed disappointment at the failure to reach an agreement that would have enabled UNHCR to monitor people sent back to Vietnam. He said Britain now will have to consider whether to go ahead and return more boat people against their will. Under a deal with Hanoi, Britain forcibly sent back 51 boat people from the overcrowded Hong Kong camps last month. McLaren, speaking to journalists after the meeting, said Vietnamese officials told delegates any internationally-agreed program of forced repatriations should not begin before Oct. 1. Vietnam says it needs time to prepare for any mass return of boat people so they can be absorbed into Vietnam's stricken economy. McLaren noted, however, that for the first time there was consensus that boat people deemed to have fled for economic reasons rather than political persecution should be returned even against their will. Sergio Vieira de Mello, a senior UNHCR official who presided over the two-day meeting in Geneva, said Norway's Thorwald Stoltenberg, the new High Commissioner for Refugees, was asked to see if a consensus could be reached. He will negotiate directly with relevant capitals. Vieira de Mello said there were no immediate plans for another international conference. U.S. and Vietnamese delegates declined comment after the meeting. Earlier, Hong Kong security chief Geoffrey Barnes warned that if no agreement emerged, pressure would grow in Hong Kong to push boats of asylum seekers back out to sea. He said Hong Kong could not cope with another influx of 35,000 boat people, the number that flooded into the colony in 1989. About 109,000 boat people are in camps in Southeast Asia, including 56,000 in Hong Kong, according to UNHCR figures. The 44,000 boat people who arrived in Hong Kong after June 1988 may be screened to determine if they class as genuine political refugees. Arrivals before June 1988 were granted refugee status without screening. UNHCR spokesman Raymond Hall said about 7,000 people have so far been screened in Hong Kong and only 15 percent were accepted as genuine refugees. He said 1,100 people have returned voluntarily since March and a further 1,400 are registered to go back. All voluntary returnees receive $50 from the refugee agency and qualify for a year's food aid from Hanoi.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Killed When Farm Labor Van Runs into Canal in Fog
DOC.TEXT: The driver of a panel van carrying Mexican farm workers escaped but 10 others died after the vehicle plummeted over a curve and into a fog-shrouded canal, authorities said. No charges were filed by early today, but authorities said the driver, Rentilio Escobedo, 28, remained under investigation. Fines were possible, too, if the vehicle is found unsuitable for transporting laborers. ``It's like something out of a scary movie,'' said Fernando Lupo, a migrant worker in La Belle, where most of the victims lived. ``I cannot think of a worse way to die.'' The 1979 van apparently was en route to citrus groves when Escobedo failed to make a sharp curve in the dense fog and plowed into the 12-foot-deep canal, surrounded by sugar cane fields about 100 miles north of Miami. Escobedo apparently escaped out the driver's side door, but his wife, Manuela, died in the passenger seat. His 50-year-old uncle, Nicolas Escobedo, managed to squeeze out the rear doors, police said. Neither man was seriously injured. The van was submerged about 15 minutes before rescuers received word Wednesday morning, police said. ``Some of them had stuck their arms out trying to get out, but they just didn't make it,'' said sheriff's Lt. Bill Chamness. ``When the deputies dove in to get them, they were already dead.'' The bodies of the nine men and one woman, ranging from age 16 to 37, were taken to Fort Myers for autopsies. Police withheld their names early today pending notification of relatives in Mexico. Police initially speculated the accident occurred because of the fog, but the driver told investigators he lost control because the steering failed, said Florida Highway Patrol Maj. Mike Kirby in Tallahassee. ``It happened very fast. We were on the road, and then the next I knew we were under water,'' said the driver's uncle. The van was pulled out of the 50-foot-wide canal and has been impounded for the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Men Shot by Militants
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants fighting for Kashmir's secession from India opened fire today on air force officers, killing at least four, police said. The killings raised to at least 61 the number of people killed in Kashmir since Saturday, when the lingering Moslem movement for secession from Hindu-majority India flared. Most of the killings have occured in confrontations between troops enforcing an around-the-clock curfew and mobs of militants defying the curfew. ``The attack makes it clear that the terrorists want to make targets of anyone who is associated with the Indian government,'' said a police official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The air force officers were waiting for a bus to take them to the Srinagar airport when they were attacked by assailants who drove up in a car, the police official said. Three of the officers were killed on the spot in repeated bursts of fire from automatic rifles and at least four others were wounded, two of them seriously, he said. One of the wounded died at a hospital. A woman and a child walking by were also hurt, the official said. Witnesses said they saw at least five bodies being carried away after the shooting. Hundreds of troops and paramilitary police have been deployed to halt the violence in Srinagar, famous for its lakes and tourist resorts. Troops and the militants exchanged gunfire at four places in the city during a four-hour curfew relaxation which began at 5 a.m. today, police said. No deaths were reported although one para-military policeman was wounded, police said. Under the curfew imposed Saturday, people have been ordered to stay indoors except for brief periods when the ban is lifted to enable people to shop. Islamic militants are demanding either independence for predominantly Moslem Kashmir or union with neighboring Islamic Pakistan. Kashmir forms the northern part of Jammu-Kashmir state and Srinagar is the summer capital. The Jammu region, which lies south of Kashmir, is predominantly Hindu. Claimed by India and Pakistan, Kashmir was divided into Indian and Pakistani sectors by a cease-fire line that is monitored by U.N. military observers. The dispute over the territory, which has led to two wars, began after India and Pakistan were partitioned on gaining independence from Britain in 1947. India has often accused Pakistan of aiding Kashmiri militants, and Pakistan has routinely denied the charge. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people are Moslems. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus make up 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Promotional Tambourines Said to Pose Danger of Choking
DOC.TEXT: A manufacturer is recalling more than 20,000 tambourines sold nationwide as a novelty promotion item by two restaurant chains because of sharp points and small parts that could cause injuries to children. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday the orange and white tambourines have a red, black, yellow and gray picture of ``Chuck E. Cheese'' and were sold since 1987 at pizza restaurants under that name. The items were also sold at Showbiz Pizza Restaurants, according to a statement issued by the CPSC. Consumers can return the tambourines to the store where they were purchased for a full refund.

DOC.TEXT: The nation's capital is getting a new newspaper targeted to a select audience looking for intense coverage of the federal government. The Washington Reporter will be given away to ``people in the federal government, politics, media, lobbyists, lawyers and others who make up this industry in Washington,'' publisher Roger G. Kranz said Wednesday. Limited newsstand and out-of-town distribution are also ned. DOC.HEAD: Visitors Provide Glimpse Inside Prague's Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's communist rulers committed three major errors contributing to their overthrow last month, says the spokesman of the new citizens' movement. The first ``bad mistake by the communists'' came soon after they took power after the 1968 Soviet invasion, and ordered ``the country's best people to do nothing,'' by purging reform communists and other educated people from their normal jobs, said Civic Forum leader Martin Palous. Another mistake was when the communist rulers ``failed to completely destroy'' Charter 77, an organization of dissidents formed in 1977, he added during a Wednesday gathering at the Capitol. Hundreds of thousands of victims of the 1969-70 purge had to support themselves as night watchmen, furnace stokers and other manual labor, ``giving them time to study and read and prepare a good organization for humane society,'' according to Palous, who said he stoked furnaces for five years after being sacked from his academic post. People of diverse thinking such as ex-communists, Catholics, Evangelists and socialists got to know each other for the first time in Charter 77, even becoming friends, and turning into an underground network, he added. After those two mistakes on the side of leniency, the hardline government committed an error on the side of harshness that outraged the nation and overnight provided massive new backing for the underground, Palous continued. This was the crackdown in Prague last Nov. 17 in which police beat peaceful student demonstrators. ``It unified their parents, even those not involved in dissident activities, and got all sorts of people involved in a great national movement that proved to be so strong as to change the government in a few days,'' said Palous. Palous and Ivan Havel, brother and adviser to dissident playwright Vaclav Havel, the new non-communist president elected last month, U.S. Prague Ambassador Shirley Temple Black, the former child movie star, and East European specialists experts attended the Capitol meeting sponsored by the Center for National Policy, a private, nonpartisan research group. Palous and Havel are an advance team for a government delegation expected here in late February after U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III's planned talks in Prague.

DOC.HEAD: New Navigation Satellite Orbits Earth
DOC.TEXT: A new military navigation satellite is orbiting the Earth as part of a network of spacecraft that guide bombers, warships, missiles and ground troops with precision accuracy. An Air Force Delta rocket boosted the $65 million Navstar satellite into space Wednesday night and officials reported 25 minutes later that it was in a successful orbit ranging out to 11,000 miles high. ``Everything appears to have gone well with tonight's launch,'' reported Capt. Ken Warren, the Air Force launch commentator. It is the sixth in a series of advanced Navstar satellites launched during the past year from Cape Canaveral. By 1992, the Air Force plans to have 21 orbiting the Earth to form a global system. Coded satellite signals guide U.S. and allied military units such as ships, planes, submarines, tanks and land forces with pinpoint accuracy in any weather. Civilian users such as planes and ships also have access to the Navstar system through an open channel that gives them accuracies within 300 feet.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Another Cartel Says He'll Surrender
DOC.TEXT: The alleged leader of Colombia's second-largest cocaine cartel has offered to turn himself in, just as the government weighs how to respond to a similar peace offer fromthe boss of the No. 1 cartel. The latest offer from the traffickers in Colombia's five-month-old drug war came from Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, the reputed chief of the Cali cartel. It came as Colombia's Supreme Court upheld a presidential decree allowing the government to seize the wealth of suspected traffickers. In a letter to the owners of the Bogota daily El Tiempo, published as a front-page story Wednesday, Rodriguez said he would be prepared to face an extradition request from the United States but that the merits of the U.S. request would have to be judged under Colombian law. That presumably means Rodriguez does not accept the validity of a decree by President Virgilio Barco allowing extraditions, and is hoping the extradition request would be acted upon by a Colombian judge. In the last five months, the 13 Colombians extradited to the United States were sent without judicial review, something feared by the traffickers. Colombia signed an extradition treaty 10 years ago because it is generally regarded as impossible to find a Colombian judge who would handle such an extradition. It is common knowledge in Colombia that judges are often bribed or threatened into making decisions favorable to drug traffickers. Four judges have been killed by traffickers since the drug crackdown began Aug. 18. Earlier this month, the Medellin cartel, the country's largest, said it was willing to stop its cocaine business, give up hostages it had kidnapped the last two months and stop all terrorism. The communique did not specify what the traffickers wanted in return, but it appeared they were asking for assurances they would not be extradited to the United States. Barco has sent confusing signals to the public in responding to the communique. On the one hand he has said the government position would not change, but he also has said the government is not inflexible, suggesting there could be some settlement. Medellin cartel chief Pablo Escobar, who earlier this week sent a letter to El Tiempo, and Cali cartel leader Rodriguez have denied they are behind any terrorism in the drug war. Drug traffickers have been blamed for 262 bombings and other terrorist acts that have claimed 209 deaths since the mid-August crackdown. Those casaulties include all 106 persons aboard a Colombian airliner that was bombed out of the sky near Bogota. Since the crackdown began, security forces have seized millions of dollars worth of mansions, ranches, office buildings, planes, yachts, cars, jewels and money belonging to suspected traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Vandalism Heats up Conflict over Inner-City Tobacco and Alcohol Ads
LaserPhoto CX3
DOC.TEXT: An advertiser threatened to prosecute a paint brush-wielding ``magician'' who made three inner-city ads for booze and cigarettes disappear under a coat of white paint. The whitewasher, who uses the pseudonym Mandrake after a comic strip magician and described himself as a 54-year-old black professional, said he was conducting a one-man civil disobedience campaign to erase a ``blight on the community.'' ``I have seen over the past two years a disproportionate amount of advertising in the black and Hispanic community,'' said Mandrake, in a telephone interview in which he refused to give his real name. ``I believe it was time for us to stand up and fight back.'' Tobacco and liquor producers were alarmed by the actions of Mandrake, whose painting of three South Side billboards in broad daylight last week followed a much-publicized outcry over a tobacco company's plan to target blacks in marketing a new brand of cigarettes. ``He's obviously vandalizing private property,'' said Geoff Obrzut, a spokesman for Patrick Media, whose billboard was covered. A police report was filed, Obrzut said, and ``we would be willing to prosecute if he's caught.'' ``I'm a firm believer in the Constitution and believe the law was broken,'' Mandrake conceded. ``But at the same time, there is a moral obligation, a right, that must be addressed.'' Gary Miller, a spokesman for the American Tobacco Institute in Washington, D.C., said billboards had no effect on young people, who as a group become smokers primarily because of peer pressures and parental influence. Janet Flynn of the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, echoed Miller's remarks: ``We restrict our advertising to responsible adult customers.'' A lively debate over the ethics of aiming tobacco and alcohol ads at minorities came to a head last week when U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan attacked an R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. plan to test-market a new cigarette, Uptown, in Philadelphia starting Feb. 5. While cigarette advertising already is targeted at minorities, Uptown apparently was the first brand to be created, named and marketed specifically for blacks. Reynolds shelved its plans, but Sullivan said he would continue to campaign against such marketing, including products aimed at women. Consumer groups, alarmed at the high rates of smoking and drinking-related illnesses among inner-city minorities, say the producers have an obligation not to aim dangerous products at these groups. Industry representatives say their advertising strategies are protected by the First Amendment and contend that people make their own decision about whether to light up or take a drink. The lung cancer rate has increased four times faster among blacks than among whites during the past 30 years, according to reports from the American Lung Association and the National Cancer Institute. A 1987 study by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington-based health advocacy group, found that black men have a 70 percent higher death rate from cirrhosis of liver than whites. The group contends that children are being encouraged by the billboard ads. ``Children on the way to school and back home or even at recess get the message that the way to be happy, glamorous, or athletic is to smoke and-or drink,'' one publication by the center said. Obrzut said that while 50 percent of billboard advertising does occur in the inner city, only 16 percent of the city's 2,500 ads are alcohol- or tobacco-related. State Sen. Miguel Del Valle of Chicago has proposed legislation to ban the alcohol and cigarette ads within about two blocks of schools. That and even stronger measures are to be reviewed by a governor's task force.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister: No More Arms Exports
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's foreign minister promised that the country will end its profitable arms exports immediately. ``Weapons just won't be sold anymore,'' Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier said in an interview published in The New York Times today. Czechoslovakia's arms industries ranked seventh in total exports from 1984 through 1988, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. ``Czechoslovakia will simply end its trade in arms without taking into account what the pragmatists will say: that it will be a blow to the state coffers, that those people will get arms from somebody else anyway if we don't supply them,'' Dienstbier said. Britain and other countries have charged that terrorist groups have obtained Czechoslovak-made explosives such as Semtex, which British authorities say was used in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in 1988. Dienstbier, a former dissident who two months ago was shoveling coal in a menial boiler-room job as punishment, also said negotiations with Moscow to remove Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia were being complicated by the civil unrest in Soviet Azerbaijan.

DOC.HEAD: Five Officers Indicted in Separate Drug Cases
DOC.TEXT: A police chief and two officers were among seven men charged with ripping off drug dealers for more than $1 million in cash, 110 pounds of cocaine and a ton of marijuana, authorities said. Two other Metro-Dade officers were charged separately with cocaine violations Wednesday. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said the indictments sent a message that officials in south Florida were determined to root out corrupt officers, no matter what their rank. ``Instead of a black mark on the Metro-Dade Police Department,'' Lehtinen said, ``it is an example of how police can uncover corrupt officers.'' The three officers and a former officer in the first case pleaded innocent Wednesday before a federal magistrate and were released on bond. The three others charged in that case were ordered to appear for arraignment on Feb. 5. Defendants in the case, including a district police chief, ripped off drug dealers of cash, cocaine and marijuana from 1981 to 1987, Lehtinen said. The defendants protected their racket by getting honest officers transferred to other assignments, he said. ``They would come into the possession of information about where drug dealers were, where illegal drugs were, and should have engaged in proper law enforcement activities,'' Lehtinen said. ``Instead they would steal the drugs, engage in what in the street might be called a ripoff and subsequently resell those drugs.'' Those indicted included Maj. Roberto Gonzalez, 40, Chief of Metro-Dade's Central Division; his 43-year-old brother, Detective Jose Gonzalez; Detective Mario Beovides, 41; and businessmen Jorge Luis Fonte, 38; Thomas Rivera, 33; and Manuel Rodriguez, 57. Fonte is a former Nevada narcotics officer who served as a Broward Sheriff's Office deputy between 1973 and 1978. He now is co-owner of a Miami automotive business. Former police officer Ernesto Sanchoyerto, currently serving a 17-year federal prison sentence for stealing drugs, also was named in the indictment, and if convicted faces another 50 years in jail. If convicted, maximum sentences faced by the other defendants range from 30 years to life in prison and fines ranging from $250,000 to $4.5 million. In the second indictment, Metro-Dade patrolman Edward Orrett was charged with conspiracy and intent to distribute cocaine. Orrett's bond was set at $50,000, and arraignment was scheduled for Feb. 5. Orrett's brother, Detective Charles Orrett, who was charged with attempting to possess more than 10 pounds of cocaine, will be allowed to surrender.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Students: Override Is More Than Symbol, It Is Protection
With PM-Congress-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chinese students in exile concede that the bill before the Senate today to decide their future in the United States was largely symbolic, but said it provided added protection from deportation. They watched Wednesday as the House voted 390-25 to override President Bush's Nov. 30 veto of a bill eliminating a requirement that Chinese students return to their homeland before applying for a visa to return to America. The matter moved to the Senate, where a vote scheduled for today was expected to be a cliffhanger. ``People here want to make sure they stay here safely,'' said An Wei, who works at the Chinese Student Information Center in Newton, a Boston suburb. Many students were anxious about the prospect of being sent back to China, where they faced probable political reprisals, he said. In Philadelphia, students also anxiously awaited the vote. ``We need the law to protect ourselves,'' said Wei Sun, a 32-year-old graduate student in mechanical engineering at Drexel University. ``If the override is successful, America will send a very strong message to the Chinese government that we cannot tolerate what the Chinese government has done.'' Pei Min Xin, a leader of the pro-democracy protests in Beijing last spring, said he has learned that in China his name is on a blacklist of students in the movement. If he were forced to return, he would face life imprisonment or execution, said Pei. He said he felt disillusioned by the president's actions regarding China, which has included dispatching two advisers there last year at a time when he was pubicly condemning the Chinese government. ``How can the leader of the United States be so accommodating to people back in our own country, who tried to kill us all off, to stamp out our legitimate demands for political change?'' said Pei, a Harvard University graduate student in government. Fleeing China after the Beijing demonstrations were crushed in June, the students in exile first gathered in Paris to form the Front for a Democratic China, an umbrella organization of the pro-democracy movement. Many, including Wu'er Kaixi, the Chinese government's most-wanted student dissident, are studying in the Boston area and coordinating pro-democracy activities among their peers. Pei is one of about 32,000 Chinese in the United States who hold visas that require them to return to China when the visas expire and live there for two years before they can apply for a new one. President Bush vetoed the bill eliminating that requirement, saying it was unnecessary because he signed an administrative order allowing Chinese students to stay in the United States. Bush, attempting to stymie override votes in the House and Senate, said the measure could damage U.S. relations with China, which has condemned the legislation and threatened to curtail exchange programs if it becomes law. Chinese students, who have lobbied Congress on the issue, said the override was crucial because an administrative order was not as solid as a law. The process of revoking an order is easier, and could happen at any time if the situation changes, they said. ``People would feel a lot more secure if they're staying here because of a law,'' An said.

DOC.HEAD: Genetic Defect Linked to Blindness Disease
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `RP Foundation Fighting Blindness' in 7th graf and `Meredithe' in penultimate graf are cq.
DOC.TEXT: Discovery of a genetic defect that apparently causes one kind of retinitis pigmentosa may help researchers find defects that cause other forms of the vision-robbing disease, scientists said. Study of genetic defects may reveal leads for devising treatments for the inherited condition, they added. Retinitis pigmentosa, which afflicts about 100,000 Americans, gradually progresses from night blindness to tunnel vision to blindness. Symptoms are caused by degeneration of the retina, a delicate layer of cells at the back of the eye that detects images and relays them to the brain. The newly discovered defect apparently keeps the eye from producing a fully functional version of an important protein, researchers said. The new work is reported in today's issue of the British journal Nature by Eliot Berson, Thaddeus Dryja and colleagues at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary in Boston. It focuses on the ``autosomal dominant'' form of retinitis pigmentosa, which accounts for perhaps 43,000 cases in the United States, said Jeanette Felix, director of science for the Baltimore-based RP Foundation Fighting Blindness. The genetic defect the researchers found may be responsible for about 5,000 of those cases, she said. But the study's impact may go beyond that because it focuses attention on a particular gene, and further work may turn up more defects in that gene that cause other forms of the disease, she said. In addition, the researchers wrote, the finding suggests that other genes that play similar roles in the eye should be studied for defects that cause other forms of retinitis pigmentosa. The researchers studied the gene that tells eye cells how to make a protein called rhodopsin. This light-sensing substance plays a major role in vision during twilight, and it is found in the ``rod'' cells of the eyes, the first to die in retinitis pigmentosa. The defect appeared in rhodopsin genes from 17 of 148 unrelated patients with retinitis pigmentosa, but not in any of 102 people without the disease, the researchers reported. It is unclear how the defect causes the disease, they said. Scientists must answer that question by introducing the defective gene into experimental animals and studying the result, Felix said. Once the answer is found, it may lead to experiments to find ways to block the disease process, she said. Currently, scientists do not know how to stop the progression of the disease, she said. The new finding allows specific diagnosis of one form of retinitis pigmentosa and accurate genetic counseling for those who have the genetic defect, said Meredithe Applebury of the University of Chicago. Such people have a 50 percent chance of passing the disease-causing defect on to their children, she said in an editorial accompanying the report in Nature.

DOC.HEAD: Ernest Borgnine Made Honorary Mayor on 73rd Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Actor Ernest Borgnine's swearing-in ceremony as honorary mayor turned into a rousing 73rd birthday bash just a few steps from the pond where his old ``McHale's Navy'' TV series was made. Borgnine took the oath of office Wednesday in front of the Universal Studios backlot courthouse used on ``Back to the Future II.'' A dixieland band played ``Hail to the Chief,'' then ``Happy Birthday.'' Borgnine blew out the candle on a birthday cake and joined Gene Autry and Telly Savalas in the celebration. ``In my long career as an actor,'' Borgnine said, ``I've been seen by the public as a butcher, a baker and an Indian chief. I've been a New York City taxi driver, a railroad cop and a bank-robbing western desperado. ``I've held many ranks _ stockade sergeant, general and even Navy captain. But today, I'm taking on a role I've never before played. I've never been a mayor.'' Past honorary mayors of Universal City, a hamlet 12 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles where motion pictures and television shows are produced, include Angie Dickinson, Jerry Mathers, Tippi Hedren and Scott Baio. Borgnine called the community his ``home away from home for 35 years.'' He was there for a role in the movie ``The Square Jungle'' in 1955, and the shooting of the TV series ``McHale's Navy'' in the 1960s and ``Airwolf'' in the 1980s. ``As our new mayor, I've been asked what I'd first like to do,'' Borgnine told the crowd of about 400 people. ``I don't know. What do you want me to do?'' Borgnine, who won an Academy Award for his role as the butcher in ``Marty,'' has appeared in scores of movies including ``From Here to Eternity,'' ``The Dirty Dozen'' and ``Escape From New York.''

DOC.HEAD: Boy Jailed After 625-Mile Joyride in Mom's Car
DOC.TEXT: A barefoot 12-year-old's joyride in Florida turned into a panic-fueled 625-mile drive to Tennessee after he hit a truck with his mother's convertible, authorities said. A deputy found an 85-pound boy behind the wheel of a luxury convertible Monday night after a chase on Interstate 75 east of Chattanooga. ``He seemed like a really nice kid,'' said Hamilton County Deputy Chris Chambers. ``He was just upset, crying and scared.'' The boy pleaded innocent Wednesday to junvile-court charges of car theft, evading arrest and violating the Tennessee driver's license law, authorities said. He was being held in juvenile detention pending his mother's expected arrival today, said court Supervisor Richard Harter. The chase began when Chambers spotted the car at a service station after receiving a report that it had been weaving on the road. The driver fled north onto the highway, refusing to stop even after the deputy flicked on his blue lights and siren. The chase ended when two truckers helped form a moving roadblock, and Chambers forced the car over. The boy, who was barefoot when he got out of the car, said he had learned to drive by watching his mother, according to Chambers. The youth, whose name was withheld because of his age, told officers he panicked after hitting the truck in Sarasota, Fla., earlier in the day and that he had no particular destination. With a half-full tank, he could have made it further had he not been stopped. Chambers said the boy refilled the car once with $30 he had in his pocket.

DOC.HEAD: Tape Transcripts Show Gotti Just After He Allegedly Assumed Mob Power
DOC.TEXT: Reputed mob boss John Gotti speaks of hiring ``them Irish guys'' in a transcript that prosecutors provided as evidence that Gotti paid an Irish-American gang to shoot and wound a union official. Gotti and an associate, Anthony Guerrieri, 60, are charged with assault and conspiracy in the revenge shooting of John F. O'Connor, former vice president of Carpenters Union Local 608, on May 7, 1986. Prosecutors say Gotti hired the Westies, a gang from the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood, to shoot O'Connor in the buttocks because he had thugs vandalize the Bankers and Brokers restaurant, owned by Gotti associate Philip ``Philly'' Modica. O'Connor, who recovered, will not testify at Gotti's trial. Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky told the jury O'Connor is corrupt and has been indicted on various charges. Transcripts released in court Wednesday of conversations secretly taped by the police show at least one mention by Gotti of the restaurant and several comments on the Westies. At one point Gotti says `` ... they're doing something for me them Irish guys,'' but does not say what. At another point, Gotti refers to James Coonan as ``my friend'' who is ``the leader of the West Side gang, Irish guys.'' He also says, ``He's on the payroll, and he gets it legitimately ... '' The transcripts also show Gotti wanted to be an executive-type crime leader whose underlings respected an underworld chain of command. Prosecutors say Gotti, 49, became leader of the Gambino mob, largest of the five New York organized crime gangs, in December 1985 after Paul Castellano, the former boss, was shot dead in front of a steakhouse. On a Jan. 11, 1986, tape, Gotti tells an unidentified man: ``Me and you may socialize, but I can't socialize with these guys. I can't bring myself down. I'm a boss, you know what I mean?'' His annoyance with longtime associate Angelo Ruggiero's familiarity during business hours seems apparent on another tape when he says, ``I told Ange, `You gotta forget them liberties you take. Take 'em when we're alone.''' Gotti apparently had just made Ruggiero a ``caporegime'' (crew captain), according to the tape transcripts, and was not satisfied that his friend was acting like a leader. Ruggiero, a defendant in the O'Connor case with Gotti, died of natural causes in December. The tapes were introduced by Edward Wright, an investigator with the state's Organized Crime Task Force. He said the alleged mobsters, suspecting they might be under surveillance, turned on hair dryers, flushed toilets and whispered to try to make conversations inaudible. Prosecutors say they have more than 1,000 cassettes of secretly recorded conversations, including some where mobsters and associates praise Gotti as ``Jesus Christ'' and ``God's gift to the underworld.''

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Talk Show Scheduled for the Fall
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson's syndicated talk show is on line for next fall, and it could continue to run in most of the country even if he became a candidate for mayor of Washington, D.C., the show's distributor says. Jackson has given assurances he'll do the weekly, one-hour TV series, ``Voices of America With Jesse Jackson,'' said Barry Stagg, a spokesman for Warner Bros. Domestic Television Distribution. The series, to be produced by composer Quincy Jones and Jackson's production company, would debut in September. The program has been picked by 82 stations covering 60 per cent of the national audience, Stagg said by phone Wednesday from Warner offices in Burbank, Calif. There has been speculation that Jackson might run for mayor of Washington in the wake of the cocaine arrest of Mayor Marion Barry. Jackson has refused to confirm his political plans. Were Jackson to seek office in Washington while his show is on the air, the Federal Communications Commission's equal time rules for opposing candidates would go into force, but only in the greater Washington viewing area. The rules require that stations that provide air time to a qualified political candidate must afford equal opportunity on the air to opposing candidates who ask for the time, said Milton Gross, an FCC official. No station in Washington has bought Jackson's series, Stagg said. But the show has been purchased by WMAR-TV in nearby Baltimore. Because WMAR's signal is seen in Washington, that station wouldn't air the series _ until any election race ended _ if Jackson sought election as Washington's mayor, said Arnold J. Kleiner, WMAR's president. ``We'd like very much to run it,`` he said. ``We think it's going to be a good show. Jesse Jackson is certainly an interesting personality, an interesting person, one who always has something to say. ``But if he runs for office, I believe we would be locked into the equal time constraints. We would not be willing to give (Jackson's opponents) equal time, so we probably would not run the show.'' Production of Jackson's series probably will start this summer and may be done in Washington, Stagg said.

DOC.HEAD: China Condemns House Vote On Chinese Students
DOC.TEXT: China today strongly condemned a vote in the House of Representatives to protect Chinese students in the United States, and said passage of the legislation would do ``serious harm'' to U.S.-Chinese relations. The House voted 390-25 Wednesday to override President Bush's veto of legislation that would allow Chinese students, many of whom face possible political persecution at home, to overstay their U.S. visas. Foreign Ministry spokesman Jin Guihua said the House had based its policy on rumors, ``fully revealing its anti-China position.'' ``We express great indignation and strongly condemn this hegemonist act of the U.S. House of Representatives,'' Jin told a weekly briefing. ``Should the U.S. Senate also adopt such a bill, it would certainly do serious harm to Sino-U.S. relations and further impair the cultural and educational exchanges between the two countries.'' The legislation applies to some 32,000 Chinese students, many of whom openly criticized the Chinese government after its bloody suppression of the pro-democracy movement last spring. The Senate was to vote on the bill today, and Bush was pressing Republican senators to oppose the veto override, which needs a two-thirds vote of both chambers to pass. Bush, who says it is important to maintain channels of contact with the Chinese leadership, has initiated administrative measures that provide Chinese students similar guarantees against forced deportation. Jin did not say how the Chinese might retaliate if the student bill becomes law, warning only that the United States must ``take prompt and effective measures to prevent the deterioration of the situation.'' Nearly half of all Chinese students abroad are in the United States, and any Chinese decision to curtail exchange programs would affect thousands of students in China applying for overseas studies. Jin said Congress was trying to obstruct students from returning ``for service in their home country'' and accused U.S. lawmakers of supporting the ``reactionary'' Front for Democracy in China and the Chinese Democratc Alliance. The two groups, based in Paris and New York, are operated by pro-democracy Chinese exiles. The front was organized by dissidents who fled the country after the June military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in which hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed. Jin also took a hard-line stance on two other dissidents, astrophysicist Fang Lizhi and his wife Li Shuxian, who have been given refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing since June. Jin said the two ``are criminals wanted by China's security organs'' and that the United States was breaking international law by harboring them. His statements echoed the stance China had taken before U.S. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft visited Beijing in December. That vsiit appeared to set the two countries on a course of improved relations.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Critical of Police in Racial Attack Trial
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the trial of six white youths charged in the death of a black teen-ager ruled for the second day in a row that police had bungled procedures, and a defendant's statement could not be used in court. State Judge Thaddeus Owens said Wednesday he would not allow prosecutors to use a statement to police by defendant Joseph Serrano because police had refused to allow Serrano to be alone with his lawyer. ``Any time a lawyer can't go talk to his client without somebody looking over his shoulder, it's a sad day for the Constitution,'' said Owens. Serrano, 20, is charged with murder, manslaughter, assault and other crimes in the Aug. 23 attack on Yusuf Hawkins, who was shot in the chest after he and three friends were surrounded by a mob of young whites. Hawkins and his companions, all black, were attacked when they went to the mostly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to look at a used car. On Tuesday, Owens ruled that another defendant's admission of involvement in the crime was illegally obtained. Owens said detectives who took Pasquale Raucci, 19, into custody shortly after the murder failed to advise him of his rights to remain silent or to hire a lawyer. After the hearing, prosecutor Ed Boyar said there would be separate trials for three defendants: Keith Mondello, 19, Charles Stressler, 21, and Steven Curreri, 19. Curreri is not charged with murder. The alleged triggerman, Joseph Fama, 19, may be tried together with Raucci and Serrano, Boyar said. Owens has set the first trial for March 5, but hasn't said who would be tried first.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Urges Complaint Campaign Against Disposables
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release after 11 a.m. Embargo set by source.
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group began a campaign against disposable products today, urging environmentally concerned shoppers to telephone their displeasure to manufacturers' toll-free consumer lines. The New York Public Interest Research Group published a guide to what it said were the worst examples of disposable, overpackaged and non-recyclable consumer products that deplete resources and jam landfills. Although it did not call for a boycott, the group urged consumers to complain about items such as disposable diapers and razors, plastic utensils, polystyrene foam packages and so-called ``degradable'' plastic bags. Given the garbage disposal crisis across much of the country, ``consumers need to send these companies a clear message that they don't want and don't need these so-called convenience items and overpackaged products,'' Steven A. Romalewski, the guide's author, said in an interview. The guide singled out a few items as examples of the worst in throwaway packaging, including Eastman Kodak Co.'s ``Fling'' disposable camera; Quaker Oats Co.'s ``Aunt Jemima Pancake Express,'' which has mix for six pancakes in a disposable plastic mixing bowl; and Heinz U.S.A.'s plastic ketchup bottles. The ketchup bottles are difficult to recycle because they are made of laminated layers of plastics, the guide said. ``Juice-in-a-box'' containers, used by more than a half-dozen fruit drink producers, pose the same problem because they contain layered plastic, aluminium foil and paper, it said. While ``degradable'' plastic bags have been promoted as a partial solution to the landfill crisis, the guide cited complaints from environmental groups that the bags only break down into smaller plastic particles, which remain in the environment. It also said they may not break down when buried, and could weaken products made from recycled plastic. ``Especially at a time when industries are trying to cash in on the green decade and this new environmentalism, they can't just try to give the appearance that they're doing good for the environment,'' Romalewski said. ``They have to take some tough action.'' Heinz spokeswoman Beth Adams, however, said her company was ``between a rock and a hard place'' because consumers prefer plastic bottles, and only the non-recyclable kind are airproof enough to keep ketchup from darkening. She said Heinz, in Pittsburgh, continues to sell glass bottles _ though they now make up only about 35 percent of its bottled ketchup sales _ and is searching ``fast and furious'' for a recyclable plastic bottle it can use. At Kodak, in Rochester, N.Y., spokeswoman Holly Walkland read a letter prepared for customers who complain about the ``Fling'' camera, maintaining that it does not contain significantly more material than some film cartridges. Quaker Oats spokesman Ron Bottrell in Chicago had no comment. Romalewski said boycotts seldom work unless targeted at a specific product. But the public interest group hopes to make its point by listing the telephone numbers of nearly two dozen companies whose products it criticized, and urging consumers to call. The 20-page guide is being distributed to consumer and environmental groups across the country. Copies are available for $3 from NYPIRG, 9 Murray St., N.Y., N.Y. 10007. (212) 349-6460.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Has Second Child
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruot with birth weight, where child born, scene at hospital, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto gave birth today to a girl, her second child, Ms. Bhutto's mother said. She is believed to be the first elected world leader to give birth while in office. Nusrat Bhutto, a co-leader of her daughter's governing Pakistan People's Party, told a news conference that Benazir Bhutto and her daughter were both in good health. A name has not yet been chosen for the infant, who weighed 7 pounds, 5 ounces. She was born in Karachi's slum district of Lyari in a private, non-profit charity hospital. Residents of the southern port city of 9 million said hundreds of women began gathering at the hospital, chanting and singing, as word of the birth spread. ``You can say it's a very festive mood around here,'' said Tanvir Ahmed, a local journalist. In keeping with local tradition, vast quantitites of food were served to people who gathered outside the hospital. Ms. Bhutto, 36, is married to industrialist Asif Zardari. Their son, Bilawal, was born less than a month before the November 1988 elections that brought Ms. Bhutto to power. Ms. Bhutto's often-hostile opposition has been critical of the prime minister's decision to have a second child. Abida Hussein, a key opponent, said the country would be leaderless while Ms. Bhutto recovered. However, the prime minister has temporarily transferred authority to her mother, an elected member of the National Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Jury Awards $1 Million in Sheriff's Dept. Brutality Suit
DOC.TEXT: A jury awarded nearly $1 million to three Mexicans who claimed that sheriff's deputies used excessive force during an altercation that was videotaped. The three San Bernardino County sheriff's deputies were ordered to pay $956,000 to Auro Ruiz, Victor Serrano, and Efren Serrano. ``Nazi-type conduct does not go down well in the United States and that's what the jury said,'' said attorney Stephen Yagman, retained by the Mexican government to represent the laborers. Defense attorney David Lawrence said he had not decided if he would appeal. The altercation occurred in June 1988 when the officers responded to complaints about a loud party at a house in Victorville, 70 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles. The plaintiffs testified they were beaten and harassed without provocation. But deputies said some of the men assaulted officers when they tried to arrest them. The videotape, which was shown to the six-member jury, appeared to prove the men's contentions. The deputies testified that a segment showing them being assaulted was cut from the tape. The U.S. District Court jury Wednesday awarded Victor Serrano $150,000 in compensatory damages and $150,000 in punitive damages against deputy Mark Swagger, and awarded Serrano's father, Efren, $60,000 in compensatory damages and $56,000 in punitive damages against Sgt. Tim Miller. The panel awarded Auro Ruiz $250,000 in compensatory damages, $250,000 in punitive damages against Sgt. John Gocke and $40,000 in punitive damages against Sgt. Tim Miller. Under state law, the county will pay the compensatory damages and the Board of Supervisors may vote on whether to pay punitive damages as well, Lawrence said.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Boat People Attempt Suicide in Detention Center
With PM-Vietnam Refugees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with witness saying stabbings were to protest forced repatriation. Picks up 5th pvs, `Whitehead is ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two Vietnamese men slashed themselves in the stomach today at a detention center for boat people in what a witness said was a protest of the policy of forced repatriation. The incident came a day after reports of boat people threatening suicide to protest forced repatriation and the screening process that determines which Vietnamese can be resettled overseas as refugees. The two men, aged 36 and 39, refused medical treatment after being taken to a hospital, where they were conscious in an observation ward, according to a government spokesman who declined to be identified. He described their condition as ``not so serious'' and said the men were being interviewed by staff of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. An expatriate relief worker, who said he witnessed the incident, said the two men slashed their stomaches with knives in the U.N. agency's office at the Whitehead detention center this morning. ``We cannot call it suicide,'' said the relief worker. ``I think it is their way of communication. They are trying to get attention'' to protest forced repatriation. Earlier this month, two other men at the detention center stabbed themselves in the stomach. They both survived. Whitehead is one of several camps housing a total of about 44,000 boat people who face repatriation against their will unless they can prove they fled persecution in their Communist homeland. About one-quarter of Whitehead's 20,000 inmates already have been classified as illegal immigrants to be repatriated. It was not clear whether the two men who stabbed themselves were among those whose pleas for refugee status were rejected. The cramped, squalid detention centers have been particularly tense since Dec. 12, when 51 boat people were whisked onto an airplane by security forces and forcibly repatriated to Hanoi. Thousands of Vietnamese in the detention centers peacefully protested the forced repatriation policy in the following days, although rioting erupted in one camp when security forces attempted a check for homemade weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Near Great Lakes; Rain in East
DOC.TEXT: Northern Lower Michigan braced for as much as a foot of snow today as low pressure developed along a cold front, triggering winter storm watches for northwestern Illinois and the Lake Michigan shore areas of Wisconsin as well. Warm, wet weather was predicted from the Appalachians up the East Coast. Gusty winds and heavy rain were expected to lash the East Coast by Friday before warm weather returned late Saturday. Southern California looked for more of the gusty Santa Anas that buffeted some mountain areas Wednesday with winds of up to 40 mph. A wind advisory remained in effect for Southern California's mountain areas and below canyons and passes along the coast. A storm system developing rapidly off the northern Pacific Coast was expected to bring high winds and heavy snow to parts of Washington and Oregon by today. Winter storm warnings were in effect today for Oregon's Cascade Mountains. A high wind watch was posted for the coast of Washington and northern Oregon today. Strong winds also were forecast for western Montana. Fog and drizzle enveloped New England and formed in the valleys of California. Rainshowers extended from Texas across the central Gulf Coast states into the mid-Atlantic region Wednesday with scattered thunderstorms from southeastern Texas to northern Georgia. Afternoon thunderstorms Wednesday produced nearly 2 inches of rain and high winds at Baton Rouge, La. One mobile home was destroyed and two buildings and four other mobile homes were damaged. A cold front dumped snow on parts of Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa and Missouri. Light snow extended from eastern Kansas into southern Iowa. Wednesday's coldest reading in the lower 48 was 6 below zero at Truckee, Calif. The nation's hot spots Wednesday: Fort Myers and Orlando, Fla., at 85 degrees.
