DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I think former President Reagan has been hiding out; I think it's cowardly. I think that he should have stood up and taken the heat.'' _ Richard V. Secord, in a news conference after being sentenced to probation for his role in the Iran-Contra affair.

``Me and you may socialize, but I can't socialize with these guys. I can't bring myself down. I'm a boss, you know what I mean?'' _ John Gotti, reputed leader of the Gambino mob family, in a transcript of a Jan. 11, 1986, taped conversation with an unidentified man released at his trial. Prosecutors say the transcripts show Gotti wanted to be an executive-type crime leader whose underlings respected an underworld chain of command.

``It's like something out of a scary movie. I cannot think of a worse way to die.'' _ Fernando Lupo, a migrant worker in La Belle, Fla., home to most of the 10 Mexican farm workers who died when a van they were riding in plummeted over a curve and into a fog-shrouded canal 100 miles north of Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Admits Raping Stepsister After Watching TV Sex Scene
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old boy allegedly raped his 5-year-old stepsister after watching a sex scene on television, and was charged with rape and incest. Alameda County Juvenile Court Referee Alys Briggs on Wednesday ordered the boy held until his Feb. 15 trial. A pretrial hearing was set for Jan. 31. Police, who took the boy into custody Sunday night, said he admitted raping his stepsister twice earlier in the day. ``He said he got the idea while watching TV either the day before or earlier at his aunt's house,'' police Lt. Thomas Hull said. Police didn't ask the youngster what movie or program was on, he said. Doctors at Children's Hospital in Oakland, where the girl was taken after complaining of pain, reported that she was raped. San Leandro is just south of Oakland. If convicted, the boy faces a sentence ranging from probation to a maximum of eight years in the California Youth Authority, said Deputy District Attorney Maryann Migas.

DOC.HEAD: Belgium Plans To Withdraw All Its Troops From West Germany
DOC.TEXT: Belgium plans to withdraw its 25,000 troops from West Germany and has asked NATO to stop insisting that it raise its defense budget by 5 percent, Defense Minister Guy Coeme was quoted as saying today. His comments make Belgium the first NATO ally to suggest troop cuts far beyond those now being negotiated in East-West talks in Vienna. In interviews with two respected dailies, Coeme said that given the dramatic thaw in East-West relations, it is no longer realistic for Belgium to have troops in neighboring West Germany. ``The way the situation in Europe is now evolving, the withdrawal of Belgian troops from Germany becomes likely,'' he told De Standaard. In an interview with the daily Le Soir Coeme said, ``We are moving from the era of (East-West) confrontation to that of collaboration, of mutual respect ... How can we justify the status quo on our side, the maintenance of our troops in Germany?'' His remarks follow demands by Warsaw Pact members Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia for a quick and total removal of Soviet troops from their territories. Belgium maintains 25,000 troops in the central West Germany at an annual cost of $69.4 million. In addition to seeking the withdrawal of Belgian troops from West Germany, Coeme said he has written NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner asking that Belgium no longer be required to increase its annual defense outlays by 5 percent. He said NATO was reacting too slowly to events in East Europe and added, ``It is important which signal NATO now sends to East Europe.'' Belgium's 1989 defense budget totaled $2.8 billion. In the early 1980s, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization set a goal under which its 16 members would boost their annual defense budgets by at least 3 percent. Several NATO members, notably Belgium, have long failed to meet the target, citing financial problems. In the meantime, the target has been raised to 5 percent for Belgium to make up for the lag. The NATO alliance had no immediate reaction to Coeme's comments.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Poet and Scholar Damaso Alonso Dies At Age 91
DOC.TEXT: The poet, writer and scholar Damaso Alonso, director emeritus of the Royal Academy of the Spanish Language, has died after a long illness, a family member said today. He was 91. Alonso, who had suffered from respiratory problems for the last three years, died late Wednesday at his home, said the family member, who asked not to be identified. A poet of the so-called ``Generation of 1927'' that included Federico Garcia Lorca and Rafael Alberti, Alonso was also an essayist considered among the country's leading scholars of Spanish literature. In 1978, he was awarded Spain's Miguel de Cervantes Prize, considered the highest literary prize for Spanish-language writers. He received honorary degrees from Oxford and the universities of Bordeaux, Rome, Hamburg, Friburg, Lima and Costa Rica. Born in Madrid, he became professor of Romanesque philosophy in the University of Valencia and later at the University of Madrid before going on to teach at universities in South America. He became a member of the Royal Academy of the Spanish Language in 1945 and served four terms as its director from 1968-82. His best known works included the volumes of poetry ``Pure Poems, Poems of the City'' (1921) and ``The Sons of Anger'' (1944) and his collected poems ``Man and God'' (1955).

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in quiet trading in Europe this morning, supported by Wall Street's recovery at the end of the previous day's session. Gold was steady at lower levels after a roller-coaster day of trading on Wednesday. Currency trading was hectic Wednesday after Dow Jones industrial average fell 60 points at the start of trading in New York, but the index regained all but 11 points by the end of the day. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 145.30 yen, down 0.50 yen from Wednesday's close of 145.80 yen. Later in London, the dollar traded at 145.13 yen. Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a trader with Daiwa Bank, said speculative investors remained on the sidelines due to their concerns over the New York stock market's performance. DOC.HEAD: Secord Receives Probation in Iran-Contra Guilty Plea
DOC.TEXT: Richard V. Secord, sentenced to probation for his role in the Iran-Contra affair, is accusing former President Reagan of not supporting the participants in the scandal. ``I think former President Reagan has been hiding out; I think it's cowardly,'' Secord told a news conference after his sentencing on Wednesday. ``I think that he should have stood up and taken the heat ... just as previous presidents have done'' in failed covert operations, Secord said. ``But instead of that (Reagan's aides) built a wall around ... him.'' Secord was placed on probation for two years by U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson. The retired Air Force major general pleaded guilty Nov. 8 to making a false statement when he told congressional investigators he was unaware any money from the Iran-Contra affair had benefited North. A focus of the three-year probe by independent counsel Lawrence Walsh, Secord used money from the maze of offshore companies and secret bank accounts in the Iran-Contra operation to pay for Oliver L. North's security system. Secord told the judge he would regret the false statement for the rest of his life. Secord also told the news conference he would mount an attack against the federal law authorizing court-appointed independent counsels. Secord said the law is ``a monster'' that is ``probably unconstitutional'' and he hopes to encourage research on the matter with a fundraising effort that will lead to a drive against the statute. ``I have been involved in this witch-hunt for too long to stop now,'' Secord said. The Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Ethics in Government Act on a 7-1 vote, but Secord said the issues in the case were narrowly drawn. He said the independent counsel statute, enacted in 1977 in response to the firing during the Watergate scandal of special prosecutor Archibald Cox, should be challenged again. Secord, who has met repeatedly with Iran-Contra prosecutors since his guilty plea, may be called as a government witness in the upcoming trial of former national security adviser John Poindexter. Meanwhile, North, convicted of three charges in the Iran-Contra scandal, sent a letter recently to supporters who have contributed to his legal defense, saying he is considering becoming the head of a tax-exempt organization called the Freedom Alliance. The group would be dedicated to promoting a strong national defense, supporting ``those who struggle for freedom throughout the world, maintaining traditional American values'' and countering ``the left-wing dominated national media,'' said the letter. It also would support the anti-abortion movement and encourage grassroots political activity, according to the letter. At an office where supporters of North have been raising money for his legal defense, one North backer, Duane Ward, declined to comment Wednesday on the matter. North is appealing his convictions for aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, altering and destroying National Security Council documents and accepting a $13,800 home security system from Secord.

DOC.HEAD: Donahue in Flint, Mich., with `Roger & Me' Maker as Guest
DOC.TEXT: Phil Donahue will be bringing his program to Flint for an interview with Michael Moore, maker of the General Motors Corp.-bashing documentary ``Roger & Me.'' More than 1,000 people lined up Wednesday morning at Whiting Auditorium for tickets to Donahue's Monday show. ``Roger & Me,'' the critically acclaimed satirical documentary shows Moore trying unsuccessfully to interview GM Chairman Roger B. Smith on plant closings and layoffs in Flint, a hub of the auto industry devastated by declining employment. Flint police helped disperse a crowd of people who waited all night in hopes of seeing Donahue and Moore but were turned away when the 1,266 free tickets ran out. Some of the disappointed chanted, ``Hell no, we won't go'' when about 12 officers arrived Wednesday morning to send people home. The crowd included Moore himself, who signed autographs before dawn, and some who were affected by the plant closings.

DOC.HEAD: Libyans Detain Plane In Apparent Retaliation For Similar West German Move
DOC.TEXT: Libyan authorities, apparently retaliating for a similar action by West German police, held a Lufthansa plane in Tripoli and detained the crew for several hours, the airline said today. A statement by the West German carrier said the nine-member crew of an Airbus 320 was detained for more than seven hours after the plane landed in Tripoli on Wednesday afternoon. The plane's 86 passengers were allowed to leave the plane but were searched, Lufthansa said. The plane was also searched and the crew was held until midnight, when they were brought to a Tripoli hotel. Lufthansa said Libyan authorities released the Airbus later today, but that 81 passengers booked on the flight had been transferred to other European airlines. On Tuesday, West German border police held and searched a Libyan Arab Airlines Boeing 727 for several hours at Frankfurt Airport following a tip that terrorists might be aboard. Three Libyan airline security guards were detained for carrying guns without permits but were later released. The plane left for Tripoli Wednesday morning. West German authorities said no other weapons were found on the Libyan plane and the tip about terrorists proved a false alarm.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Backs Legislation to Create Department of Environment
DOC.TEXT: Legislation creating a Cabinet-level Department of the Environment is expected to move swiftly through Congress, with sponsors saying they hope to send it to President Bush in time for signing on Earth Day in April. Bush endorsed the bipartisan legislation Wednesday, saying, ``The environmental challenges that face America and the world are so important that they must be addressed from the highest level of our government.'' His move drew praise from environmentalists and both Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill, but several senators suggested the president must do more than elevate the status of the Environmental Protection Agency to deal with the world's environmental problems. ``It's not enough just to put an extra chair to the Cabinet table,'' said Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., who has been a past critic of the Bush administration's actions on such environmental matters as global warming and atmospheric ozone depletion. Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., said giving the EPA higher visibility is ``nice frosting'' but added, ``where's the cake?'' He accused the administration of dragging its feet in exerting leadership in international efforts on global warming and other environmental issues. But the president's decision to call for elevating the status of the EPA _ a regulatory agency created in 1970 _ to the Cabinet brought salutes from sponsors of the bipartisan legislation and from many environmentalists, who said the White House support makes passage all but certain. ``It's a welcomed breath of fresh air,'' said Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., one of the cosponsors and chairman of the House Government Operations Committee. Conyers said he hoped a bill could clear Congress within 90 days. The president is said to want a bill ready for his signature as part of the Earth Day 20th anniversary celebrations April 22. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate Government Affairs Committee, also said he would move quickly on the bill with hearings scheduled for next month. EPA Administrator William K. Reilly said today that the creation of a Cabinet department ``is a message internationally ... that the environment is moving now into the mainstream for a whole range of policies _ economic policies, energy policies, foreign policies of all sorts.'' ``It also has another effect domestically,'' Reilly said on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America'' program. ``When the EPA administrator is doing his job, he is in everybody else's hair, whether it's wetlands or water policy ... or dams or transportation projects, energy facilities. ... this is a wonderful way of saying ... that the environment belongs at the big table.'' While the EPA's influence is broad, the agency has toiled far from the focus of power during most of its two decades. When Reilly, an environmentalist by profession, was sworn in as EPA administrator shortly after Bush took office, it was the first time a president had visited the EPA's headquarters in southwest Washington. The agency, with 16,000 employees and an annual budget of more than $5 billion, would become the 15th Cabinet-level department. The Cabinet was last expanded in 1988 when the Department of Veterans Affairs' was added. Congressional and administration sources said the proposal before Congress would not change the agency significantly in structure or size. One exception would be creation of a Bureau of Environmental Statistics to keep tabs on environmental data. But elevation to Cabinet secretary would give the EPA administrator more clout within the government and increased prestige in dealings with other countries, say environmentalists and congressional supporters of the change. Although Reilly attends many Cabinet meetings, he does not as a routine sit at the table. ``It's a different dynamic to have a seat at the table,'' said Frederick Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund. ``Finally we would have a secretary of the environment who can bring things up at Cabinet meeting as well as react to the hare-brained ideas of the secretary of defense or whoever.'' But Michael Fischer, executive director of the Sierra Club, cautioned: ``Elevating the EPA to the Cabinet is no substitute for the president himself being a leader for strong environmental legislation and worldwide environmental negotiations.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first item to RESTORE dropped `a' in lead.
DOC.TEXT: John J. O'Shea, an aide and speechwriter for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and a Democratic Party leader, died Tuesday of a heart-related ailment. He was 70. O'Shea's government service began after World War II, when he became a consultant to the State Department. He helped direct the first international observance of United Nations Day and was President Truman's undersecretary of labor. He moved to Philadelphia in 1954 as executive assistant to the chairman of Bankers Securities Corp. At that time, he also joined the faculty of the St. Joseph's College Institute on Industrial Relations. As an aide to President Kennedy, O'Shea helped draw up enabling legislation for the Agency for International Development. He was president of Thomas J. LaBrum Associates Inc., a Philadelphia-based public relations firm, from the mid-1960s until his retirement three years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses To Free Assassination Suspect
DOC.TEXT: A judge today rejected an application to free a white former police captain allegedly involved in a secret terror network that harassed and assassinated anti-apartheid activists. The suspect, Ferdinand Barnard, has been held without charge since Oct. 31 as part an investigation into the assassinations last year of two white activists: Johannesburg university lecturer David Webster and Namibian lawyer Anton Lubowski. Pretoria Supreme Court Justice H.J. Priess rejected a bid by Barnard's father, a retired police colonel, to have the former narcotics detective released. In Windhoek, Namibia, another Supreme Court judge today set April 18 as the start of a murder trial for Donald Acheson, a suspected accomplice of Barnard who is accused of involvement in Lubowksi's killing. Lubowski, shot and killed outside his Windhoek home on Sept. 12, was the only white to hold a leadership position in Namibia's independence movement, the South-West African People's Organization. Webster, a well-known human rights activist, was shot and killed outside his Johannesburg home on May 1. Police Brig. Floris Mostert, in testimony opposing Barnard's release, said the investigation into the assassinations had uncovered the existence of ``a secret organization ... with members from all levels of society, which strives to terrorize left-wing radicals with the aid of violence and intimidation.'' Dozens of anti-apartheid activists have been the victims of unsolved murders in recent years. Many others have had their cars vandalized, and there have been bombings or arson attacks on offices of militant trade unions, civil rights groups, and opposition newspapers. Mostert said Barnard had been in contact with Acheson prior to Lubowski's murder. The brigadier also said: ``I must respectfully stress that the nature of my investigation is extremely sensitive and that the secrecy of the information which I possess is of the utmost importance.'' Police say the Webster-Lubowski case is not directly related to investigations of claims that death squads within the ranks of the national police force killed government opponents on the orders of high-ranking officers. One black ex-policeman, Butana Nofemela, has pleaded guilty to committing a murder as part of such a death squad, and a white former captain, Dirk Coetzee, has fled abroad after telling a newspaper he commanded a death squad. Thus far, legal steps have been taken only against Nofemela and Coetzee, not against other policemen implicated by them. This has resulted in widespread demands for an independent judicial inquiry and accusations that President F.W. de Klerk's government is engaged in a cover-up. Some of the white officers implicated by Coetzee appeared today at an inquest into the deaths of four young black activists in 1986. The policemen have denied allegations that the youths were murdered, saying they were shot in self-defense by a special counter-insurgency unit.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Governor Rejects Clemency for Man in Racial Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A black man who claimed he was framed for the murder of a white student during school racial turmoil in 1974 must serve his life sentence without parole, Gov. Buddy Roemer said. Roemer on Wednesday rejected a pardon board recommendation that Gary Tyler's sentence be reduced to 60 years, which would make him eligible for parole in 1995. ``Gary Tyler was found guilty after a full jury trial,'' Roemer said in a statement. ``His conviction has been reviewed extensively by the courts over the past 15 years. Those reviewing courts have found Gary Tyler's trial to be fundamentally fair by all legal standards. Also, I believe his efforts toward rehabilitation have not been sufficient.'' At a Dec. 14 hearing, the pardon board was presented with petitions from Amnesty International and other groups that had collected 12,000 signatures. The board's vote was 3-2, with the three black members for clemency and the two whites against. None would comment. Opposition came from prosecutors and from the family of the victim, 13-year-old Timothy Weber. ``I know it had to be hard for the governor, I'm sure, but he made my day,'' said Leah Weber, mother of the dead boy. Tyler's attorney, Mary Howell, read a statement from Tyler, 31, that said, ``This decision doesn't discourage me whatsoever in continuing my battle to win my freedom and to show those out there that I am innocent.'' Tyler was a 15-year-old activist for school desegregation in 1974 when whites and blacks clashed at Destrehan High School. He was among a group of blacks aboard a school bus that had been surrounded by whites hurling bottles and rocks. A shot fired from the bus killed Weber, standing with his mother across the schoolyard. Witnesses said the pistol was held by a gloved hand. Tyler was the only one on the bus wearing gloves, police said. Tyler's supporters say that a student who testified against him was a known liar and that police planted a pistol found in the stuffing of the torn seat where Tyler had sat. An all-white jury sentenced Tyler to the electric chair, but the sentence was reduced to life when the Supreme Court struck down Louisiana's death penalty law in 1976. Tyler's lawyer said the governor was incorrect in saying the courts found the trial to be fair by all legal standards. ``The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeal said the trial was fundamentally unfair, that there was a presumption of guilt,'' she said. ``But the court would not order a new trial because the lawyer failed to object.''

DOC.HEAD: Police in Minority Area Ordered to Be Alert for Unrest
DOC.TEXT: A top official in one of China's largest ethnic minority areas ordered armed police officials to intensify anti-riot training and intelligence work as a prevention against unrest. ``We soberly see that some unstable factors still exist, and must heighten our vigilance and prepare for possible disturbances,'' said Wang Enmao, chairman of the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region's advisory committee. His remarks were quoted in the Jan. 19 Xinjiang Daily, which arrived in Beijing on today. In other developments today: _China criticized Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union, two former socialist allies, over separate cases it said constituted interference in China's internal affairs. _A Foreign Ministry spokesman confirmed that Beijing-based foreign correspondents no longer will have to apply 10 days in advance for press coverage of events outside the capital. However, the spokesman, Jin Guihua, made clear at a news briefing that under new regulations announced Saturday, foreign reporters still will have to receive permission from local authorities for all trips outside Beijing. Regarding the ethnic minority areas, Wang indicated that the danger existed of both ethnic unrest and politically inspired ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' such as the government says took place in Beijing during the spring when students demanded democratic reform. ``We must strengthen training with regard to preventing and supressing disturbances (and) ... Strengthen intelligence work in order to promptly and accurately understand the situation,'' Wang said. ``The armed police must stay in close contact with the peoples of each ethnic group and obtain the support of the people of each.' The report did not say if Wang's meeting with top officials of the People's Armed Police in Xinjiang, a vast region in far northwestern China inhabited mainly by Moslem minorities, was triggered by the ethnic strife in the Soviet Union. Xinjiang's Moslems have rioted from time to time, most recently in May when Moslems in Urumchi took to the streets in anger over a Chinese book they said slandered their religion. China has refrained from any comment on the fighting between Moslem Azerbaijanis and Christian Armenians in the Soviet Caucasus region. Jin, asked at a news briefing today if Chinese newspapers had been told not to report heavily on the Soviet riots, said it was up to each newspaper to decide. He added, ``I believe there is no implication for the minority nationalities in China.'' China's official media have given the Soviet strife routine coverage, with brief stories on the international pages of newspapers, including the Xinjiang Daily, and reports on national television and radio. As usual, the media also have carried a steady diet of reports stressing the need for unity among ethnic groups, which China calls ``nationalities.'' Regions inhabited by minority groups are among China's poorest. Regarding Czechoslovakia, Jin reproached its new president, Vaclav Havel, for inviting exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit. Jin said the Dalai Lama was an exile ``long engaged in activities aimed at splitting China'' and that Havel's invitation for the Buddhist monk to visit in February, even in a private capacity, ``cannot but be regarded as a political action involving gross interference in China's internal affairs.'' Jin said the Foreign Ministry ``has made solemn and strong representations to the Czechoslovak Embassy in China asking the Czechoslovak side to withdraw its invitation to Dalai after careful consideration.'' The Dalai Lama, who lives in exile in India, is deeply revered by the people of Tibet, scene of violent pro-independence and anti-Chinese riots over the past two years. China accused the Soviet Union of violating its sovereignty by reportedly sending a delegation to Taiwan to discuss the possibility of direct air flights. Jin, referring to the Soviet air talks with Taiwan's China Airlines, said the Beijing government was ``resolutely opposed'' to any foreign airlines starting air service with Taiwan. ``This is by no means non-governmental, economic or trade in the ordinary sense, but rather a political issue involving China's sovereignty.'' He said consultations with China ``are a must'' before such a step is taken and ``we hope that the countries concerned act with prudence in this matter.'' China regards Taiwan as a breakaway province. It tolerates economic and trade relations between Taiwan and foreign countries but strongly opposes any kind of official ties between Taiwan and countries that have diplomatic relations with Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Restriction on Press Coverage Outside Beijing Altered
With PM-China, PM-China-US
DOC.TEXT: A Foreign Ministry spokesman confirmed today that foreign correspondents based in Beijing no longer will have to apply 10 days in advance to cover events outside the capital. Spokesman Jin Guihua, however, made clear at a news briefing that under new regulations announced Saturday, foreign reporters still need permission from local authorities for all trips outside Beijing. Consequently, local officials still have the authority to bar foreign reporters from covering demonstrations, natural disasters or other breaking events. The 10-day rule was imposed in 1986 but generally ignored until October 1987 when authorities in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, invoked it to expel foreign reporters who had gone there to cover anti-Chinese riots. Lhasa has been under martial law since March, and with rare exceptions all applications by journalists to visit the city have been rejected. Jin said the ministry had ``taken into consideration the views put forward by foreign journalists in the past concerning the 10-day rule'' and that the new regulations omitted the rule ``to facilitate the press coverage in China by foreign journalists.'' He stressed that the regulations require all foreign journalists to obtain permission from local foreign affairs offices before leaving Beijing for reporting in other parts of the country. Asked about clauses in the new regulations saying journalists may lose their accreditation if they ``distort the facts, create rumors or use improper methods to interview or report,'' Jin urged journalists to follow the regulations. ``Foreign correspondents need not worry so long as they abide by the regulations and observe their professional ethics and make legitimate press coverage in China,'' he said. ``The Chinese government has all along dealt with cases according to facts and according to law.'' After the suppression of pro-democracy protests in June, Chinese authorities expelled two American journalists who had been based in Beijing and ordered half a dozen reporters who had come from outside China to cover the political turmoil to leave the country. The journalists were accused of violating martial law regulations on news coverage. Under martial law, which was lifted in Beijing earlier this month, all interviews had to be approved by military authorities.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Inventors Announced for Hall of Fame
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Corrects spelling of Tuskegee in 5th graf, Carver, once; subs 11th graf, Hollerith invented, to give full name of IBM
DOC.TEXT: Pioneering scientists George Washington Carver and Percy F. Julian are the first blacks named to the National Inventors Hall of Fame. They were among 10 people, including the founders of two of the nation's largest computer companies and the developers of a leading ulcer medicine, chosen for the honor. They ``are the real heroes of our age,'' Jeffrey M. Samuel, acting commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, said about those chosen Wednesday. ``They are the thinkers and the problem-solvers. They have opened new doors and pioneered new frontiers in science and technology.'' Carver, once director of agriculture at Tuskegee Institute, was selected for his work developing countless products from peanuts and sweet potatoes. Julian, a Chicago chemist, was the first to synthesize cortisone and other human hormones. ``He was one of the most persistent men I have known,'' Samuel B. Massie of the U.S. Naval Academy said about Julian, a former colleague. Tenacity was cited as a necessary ingredient by another man being honored. Robert S. Ledley of Georgetown University said the prerequisite skills for success include a pragmatic attitude, boldness, fortitude ``and `stick-to-itiveness' almost to the extent of obsession.'' Ledley was named to the Hall of Fame for his development of the CT scanner, a special X-ray device that allows doctors to see the inner workings of the body in great detail. Honoree Herman Hollerith was described as having left behind a motto for the generations: ``Do not fold, spindle or mutilate.'' Hollerith invented the punch-card system that helped pave the way to modern computers. A Census Bureau employee, he halved the time it took to tabulate the 1890 national head count and later went on to help found the giant International Business Machines Corp. The second computer pioneer honored was Kenneth S. Olsen, developer of the magnetic memory core for computers and founder of Digital Equipment Corp. Graham C. Durant, John C. Emmett and C. Robin Gannellin were selected jointly for their work in medical chemistry. The three developed the drug cimetidine, which has greatly reduced the need for surgery for ulcer victims. It is known by the trade name Tagamet. Charles P. Ginsberg was named for his work leading the engineering team that developed the first practical videotape. Eugene J. Houdry, a French-born engineer, was honored for developing the procedure that allows crude oil to be processed into high-grade gasoline and aviation fuel. The selection of 10 new members is the most since six were chosen in 1985, and brings total membership to 85. The Hall of Fame was Founded at the Patent Office in Arlington, Va. A new Hall of Fame building is scheduled to be built in Akron, Ohio. Thomas A. Edison was the first member. The Hall also includes many of the nation's best-known inventors, including Alexander Graham Bell, Orville and Wilbur Wright, Charles Goodyear, Rudolf Diesel, Henry Ford and Philo T. Farnsworth. The newest members will be inducted in April.

DOC.HEAD: Bacteria Blamed in Deaths of Seven Hospital Patients
DOC.TEXT: A hospital closed a surgical ward and placed 19 patients in isolation after discovering a bacterium caused the deaths of seven patients over the past three months. The patients were moved out of Detroit Receiving Hospital's surgical intensive care ward Wednesday night so that it could be thoroughly cleaned, hospital spokesman Dennis Archambault said. ``Our concern in evacuating the patients is that we have people with open wounds or who are physically weak from surgeries who are more susceptible to this kind of infection,'' he said. Earlier Wednesday, doctors identified the bacterium, determined it came from within the hospital and linked it to the deaths of the seven patients recovering from surgery, he said. Detroit Receiving is a 340-bed hospital that treats critically injured patients, such as those with gunshot or knife wounds, said spokeswoman Diane Cooper. Its only elective surgery is for burn patients, she said. It is a unit of the private, not-for-profit Detroit Medical Center. ``There are always bacterial infections in a hospital, and many are routinely treated,'' Archambault said. ``This happens to be a particularly virulent form of bacterium infection.'' Archambault said the evacuated patients were exposed to or infected by acinetobacter calcoaceticus varanitratus, or ACV. He said the patients are receiving antibiotics and other treatment. Dr. Norman Hayner, chief of the disease control for the state Health Department, said bacteria such as ACV are transmitted in a several ways, including personal contact and contamination of food, water, drugs, intravenous fluid and other hospital materials.

DOC.HEAD: Political Parties Call on Provisional Government To Step Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 5th pvs, ``The three...'' to UPDATE with front inviting opposition parties to talks on election. Pickup 6th, ``A leading...''
DOC.TEXT: Three opposition parties today called on the provisional government to resign and allow a new, broader-based caretaker government to run the country until elections are held in May. The call reflected mounting dissatisfaction with the National Salvation Front, which has reversed its original promise not to get involved in Romania's first free elections in more than 50 years, promised for May 20. The front took power in December during the bloody popular revolt that overthrew Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was executed Dec. 25 along with his wife, Elena. The front has had trouble earning the peoples' trust ever since, partly because some of its members are linked to the previous regime. In a communique published in the newspaper Romania Libera, the National Peasant Party, National Liberal Party and the Social Democratic Party of Romania called for a new interim government to rule until the elections, and said it should include all parties, youth, and former dissidents. The three opposition parties, which before World War II dominated national politics, recently became active again in Romania. In what appeared to be a conciliatory move, the front called today on Romania's 15 new or revived political parties to hold talks Saturday on working out an election law to pave the way for the balloting, Bucharest radio said. ``All political parties are invited to join the talks,'' the report said. A leading dissident poet, Ana Blandiana, also criticized the front's announcement that it would field candidates, telling Romania Libera that move was ``burdened with future dangers'' for the country. ``Illusions Lasted Only One Month,'' headlined the Romania Libera. ``The front's participation in the (May) elections could lead to re-establishing a single party, under other forms, and to missing, perhaps definitively, the chance that Romania become a really democratic country,'' the newspaper editorialized. On Wednesday, 1,000 people demonstrated outside the front's headquarters to demand it not take part in the elections. In response, the front again published in today's newspapers its Jan. 3 decree outlawing demonstrations in Bucharest and allowing them only in some parks, unless they are approved by police 48 hours in advance. The announcement said those taking part in illegal protests could be sentenced to up to 30 days in jail or fined up to $250. The Peasant Party, which before World War II dominated Romanian politics with 2 million members, condemned the front's decision to contest the election, and some of its members joined the Bucharest demonstration Wednesday. Today's communique indicated that the Peasant Party and two other revived groups prominent before the 1947 Communist takeover have formed a virtual alliance against the front. The three-party statement said that by deciding to take part in the elections, the front lost the neutrality needed to administer the balloting. ``What kind of elections are we talking about when the National Salvation Front has monopolized in a totalitarian way all the key systems of the state,'' the communique said. ``The front has funds ... and controls television, radio and the newspapers.'' While the front has set up a nominally separate provisional government, its executive council in fact makes all major governmental decisions. The three parties accused the front of trying to usurp the revolution that overthrew Ceausescu's 24-year rule. ``This victory belongs to the people and cannot be confiscated by anyone,'' it said. It said the front is maintaining power ``under the pretext that some of its members were dissidents at a late hour or that they were shunted aside by the whims of the ex-dictator.'' It repeated opposition charges that some members of the front were Ceausescu's henchmen and want to reinstate Communist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Finds No Attraction in D.C. Mayor's Job
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson, who is being courted to run for mayor of Washington, D.C., in the wake of incumbent Marion Barry's cocaine possession arrest, says the job holds no attraction for him. ``The mayoralty of Washington has zero political leverage,'' Jackson was quoted by columnist A.M. Rosenthal in today's editions of The New York Times. ``It would be, for me, a burden without authority, a platform to address the drug problem but without tools.'' Business, labor and political leaders were scheduled to meet Thursday night to develop a strategy to bring Jackson into the mayoral race, sources in Washington have said. Jackson repeatedly has maintained that he would never run against Barry. The mayor, however, was arrested on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge Jan. 18. Sources said he has decided not to seek re-election to a fourth term in November. Jackson, a two-time Democratic presidential contender, said in Washington on Tuesday night that he had no plans to run for mayor, although he added that public servants ``never say never.'' He repeated his position to the Times that he planned to devote his energies to obtaining statehood for the District of Columbia.

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Atlantis Moved to Launch Pad
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis was moved to the launch pad today for liftoff Feb. 22 on a shuttle mission that reportedly will put a spy satellite into orbit. Sources close to the project report that the secret payload to be deployed by the all-military crew of five is a satellite capable of snapping super-sharp reconnaissance photos and eavesdropping on military communications. The sources said the satellite will be launched into an orbit that will cover most of the Soviet Union, including northern areas not previously within range of shuttle-launched spy satellites. The Soviets have concentrations of ships and submarines and several missile bases in the far north. The last shuttle to fly, Columbia, was to return atop a jumbo jet Friday from its landing site at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Shiite Moslem Militias Clash in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias skirmished in south Lebanon today. Christian radio stations reached a compromise with Christian leader Gen. Michel Aoun over news coverage and ended a weeklong strike. Police said at least five members of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, were wounded when a tank cannon round fired by gunmen of the mainstream Shiite Amal militia hit their position in the southern Apple Province. A police spokesman also said overnight skirmishes with machine guns occurred between Aoun's soldiers and Syrian-backed militias across Beirut's dividing Green Line but that no injuries were reported. By police count, 98 people have been killed and 286 wounded in the latest round of Amal-Hezbollah clashes for control of the 1.2 million Shiites since it broke out in the Apple Province on Dec. 23. The more than 1 million Shiites make up the largest segment of the 17 sects among Lebanon's 4 million people. The Amal-Hezbollah clashes continued despite efforts by Iranian and Algerian envoys to stop the fighting. Amal-Hezbollah battles renewed Wednesday, shattering a 16-day relative lull that had prevailed over Apple Province, the scene of a two-year intermittent inter-Shiite war which has killed 930 people and wounded 2,753. Christian radio stations resumed newscasts for the first time in a week today after the media in the Christian enclave reached a compromise with Aoun. Voice of Lebanon and Voice of Free Lebanon radio stations said the stations agreed to refer to Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi only as ``Mr. Elias Hrawi.'' The compromise also allows the media to refer to Aoun only as Gen. Michel Aoun and not as interim prime minister. As soon as Hrawi was elected president on Nov. 24, he dismissed Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister. However, the 54-year-old general held out in the shell-wrecked presidential palace and challenged Hrawi to oust him from the 310-square-mile Christian enclave northeast of Beirut. Aoun, in a directive issued Jan. 16, banned the media from referring to Hrawi as president and to Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, as prime minister. The directive also said the media should refer to parliament members as former legislators, noting that Aoun had declared the unicameral house dissolved to prevent the election of a Syrian-backed president. The compromise allows the media to refer to Hoss as prime minister and to the legislators as parliamentary deputies, said Voice of Lebanon, which is controlled by the rightist Phalange Party. Aoun's wrath was directed at the media in the Christian enclave. He banned two daily newspapers and a newsletter from publishing for a week each for defying his orders. Voice of Free Lebanon, controlled by the Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia, said the Ad-Diyar and Al-Bayrak papers and Akhbar al-Yom newsletter will resume publishing after the suspension ends.

DOC.HEAD: Four Barry Guards Subpoenaed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf, Ms. Moore, with 3 grafs to correct hometown from Los Angeles to Burbank and update with arrest warrant issued
DOC.TEXT: Four of Mayor Marion Barry's bodyguards are being ordered to testify before a federal grand jury investigating the mayor's ties to a convicted drug dealer, according to sources. The grand jury was meeting today to hear from two of the guards, according to sources who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. The same grand jury heard testimony earlier in the week from Rasheeda Moore, a friend of the mayor who helped lure Barry into the FBI sting operation at a Washington hotel where he allegedly smoked crack cocaine. The sources said the officers called to testify include two who were with Barry on the December 1988 night when he met with Charles Lewis, a former city employee, at a downtown Washington hotel. The federal probe of Barry began after city police aborted an attempt to make an undercover drug buy from Lewis, who has since been convicted of drug charges. The attempt was halted after authorities learned that the mayor was in Lewis' hotel room in downtown Washington. The sources identified two of the subpoenaed guards as city police officers James Stays and Joseph Newman. Judy Smith, a spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens, said she had no comment on whether the officers had been subpoenaed. Attempts to reach Stays and Newman by telephone were unsuccessful. There were no answers at their homes. Meanwhile, Ms. Moore said through her lawyer Wednesday that she would not respond to inquiries about her personal life or ties to the mayor. Moore returned Wednesday to Burbank, Calif., where she lives. Ms. Moore missed a court date on Tuesday in a drunken driving case, the same day she was testifying before the Washington grand jury. An arrest warrant was issued when she failed to show for her hearing in Van Nuys Municipal Court, officials said. The judge, however, postponed the warrant's release until Jan. 30 to give her time to appear, a court clerk said. Ms. Moore was arrested on the drunken driving charge in North Hollywood on New Year's Day, police said. WRC-TV reported separately that four members of the mayor's security detail are facing departmental charges that could lead to dismissal. The four were not identified. Barry is enrolled in a 28-day program at the Hanley-Hazelden Center, a substance abuse treatment clinic in West Palm Beach, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers' Theory: Sun's Activity May Trigger Flu Outbreaks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT proposed cause of flu outbreaks, subs 8th graf to CLARIFY significance of sunspot numbers ^By MALCOLM RITTER
DOC.TEXT: Two researchers haven't come up with a cure for the common cold. But they think they've discovered a link to the cause of another common ailment, flu. They blame an overactive sun, marked by a peak in its sunspot activity. The solar connection was proposed in a letter to the editor in today's issue of the British journal Nature by astronomer Sir Fred Hoyle and his colleague, N.C. Wickramasinghe. But an influenza researcher says he doubts that flu outbreaks are linked to solar activity. There are many other attractive theories about what causes influenza outbreaks, so ``I don't think we have to hypothesize that they come raining down from the atmosphere,'' said Paul Glezen of the Baylor College of Medicine. Sunspots are dark markings that show up periodically on the sun. On average, the number of sunspots peaks every 11 years or so. The analysis of the British researchers suggests that peak sunspot activity and flu pandemics have occurred at about the same time unusually often from 1761 to 1893 and from 1919 to 1979. Solar activity peaks when the number of sunspots is at a maximum, the British researchers said. ``Electrical fields associated with intense solar winds can rapidly drive charged particles of the size of viruses down through the exposed upper atmosphere into the shelter of the lower atmosphere,'' possibly causing the link to influenza, they wrote. But Glezen, an epidemiologist at Baylor's Influenza Research Center, said the idea ``doesn't sound too likely.'' Influenza viruses have a fatty covering that is not very stable outside the body, so it is ``hard to imagine that a virus particle could be floating around for a very long time in the atmosphere and remain viable,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Preparing $1 Billion Aid Program for Panama
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will propose providing more than $1 billion to help Panama recover from the U.S. military invasion and years of corrupt government, U.S. officials say. The aid program, being announced today, will include development aid, loan guarantees and programs to encourage investment, said one official, who insisted on anonymity. About half of the program will be in cash and the remainder in credits, the official said. Earlier Wednesday, Bush told a news conference he was determined to ``try to help _ repair the wounds, repair the damage.'' ``I mourn the loss of innocent civilians in Panama or anywhere else,'' Bush said. ``But you have to look at the broad picture ... and then you've got to do what's right.'' The official said the administration hopes other countries, including Japan and western European nations, will follow the U.S. lead and make contributions of their own. The administration is still talking behind the scenes with leaders of Congress about the Panama aid package. ``Not all of it's new money,'' a senior administration official who asked not to be identified said Wednesday night, confirming the $1 billion figure. Bush also voiced hopes Wednesday that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev would ``Not only survive but stay strong'' in the face of unprecedented domestic upheaval that threatens his stability. Regarding Gorbachev's use of Soviet troops to quell ethnic violence in the southern republic of Azerbaijan, Bush said, ``Anytime you have a use of force and the loss of life, we are concerned. But I don't believe I can judge that question right now.'' The Panama aid package will include aid to rebuild houses that were demolished in the Dec. 20 invasion by U.S. troops, officials said. However, they said the package is unlikely to include any compensation for the survivors of more than 200 Panamanian civilians who died in the invasion. Asked what he would say to the Panamanian survivors, Bush said he would tell them, ``Look, you lost some Panamanian lives. Innocent life was lost. And yet, 92 percent of the people in Panama strongly supported the action of the United States. Isn't that significant?'' Damage estimates from the invasion vary widely, ranging from a few hundred million dollars to $2 billion or more. The United States already has released $400 million in Panamanian assets frozen in the United States in earlier efforts to topple the regime led by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, ousted in the invasion. If the program is approved, Panama would become one of the largest per capita aid recipients in the world after having spent more than two years as a target of U.S. economic sanctions. The United States suspended aid to Panama in late 1987 and began a policy designed to starve the country economically in early 1988 after Noriega's indictment on drug-trafficking charges by two Florida federal grand juries. The result of the U.S. actions was a steep decline in the Panamanian economy, producing a crisis that was aggravated by the U.S. invasion. The U.S. official said the aid proposal will require a supplemental appropriation by the Congress for part of the money but much of it will be paid through cuts from aid programs to other countries. ``A big chunk will be out of the taxpayers' pockets,'' the official said, predicting a tough fight in finding the money. He said Panama, although a small country of about 2\ million people, requires substantial aid because successive military governments, including Noriega's, stole a good portion of the national treasury. Panama is behind on its obligations to international lending institutions, and its total foreign debt amounts to $534 million. Vice President Dan Quayle will take the specifics of the plan when he travels to Panama this weekend for talks with the new government, a White House official said. Also on Wednesday, Bush presided at a full-dress military welcome for the president of North Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, and hailed him as ``a man of extraordinary accomplishment'' at a state dinner. Saleh urged Bush to prod Israel to give Palestinians in the occupied territories the right of self-determination. Bush assured his guest of America's commitment ``to security in the Middle East and to the pursuit of a just and lasting peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Murdered on Beach by Gay-Bashing Ex-Convicts, Police Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Taylor was ...' to ADD age.
DOC.TEXT: Two men with a history of anti-homosexual violence hunted down and killed an emotionally disturbed Vietnam veteran because they believed the victim was gay, police said. Michael Taylor and an accomplice allegedly stabbed James Zappalorti repeatedly Monday night on a beach near his home in the Staten Island borough of New York City. Taylor, 20, was charged Wednesday with murder and criminal possession of a deadly weapon, a knife that was found on the beach. The accomplice, 26-year-old Philip Sarlo, was still at large, police said. Taylor and Sarlo were convicted in an April 1986 attempted murder of another man they believed was homosexual, police said. Taylor was charged as a youthful offender in that case and served 18 months for the crime, as did Sarlo. Inspector Richard Mayronne, a police spokesman, said the two hated homosexuals. ``They killed that man because they thought that he was a homosexual,'' he said. Police said they didn't know if Zappalorti was homosexual. The body was found by Zappalorti's brother Tuesday on a beach near a small lean-to which the mentally disabled man frequented. The shed is across the street from the stained-glass window business and house where Zappalorti worked and lived with his parents. The business produces windows for many of Staten Island's churches. Zappalorti enlisted in the Navy in 1962 and was discharged in 1965 with a disability after suffering a nervous breakdown, said his mother, Mary. A neighbor, Owen Reiter, said Zappalorti was a kind man who swept the street, mowed lawns and cleaned the beach without asking for pay. ``He collected broken bits of bottles and made windows in the hut'' on the beach, Reiter said. ``He was a harmless person. He wouldn't hurt anyone.'' Police sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Taylor and an accomplice ``went out looking'' for Zappalorti on Monday, and had planned to rob and kill him. His throat had been slashed and his chest and neck had stab wounds. A short time after the murder, Taylor and the other suspect allegedly used Zappalorti's house keys to burglarize his family's home. They fled when Mary Zappalorti surprised them, but took a pair of rosary beads said to resemble diamonds, Mayronne said.

DOC.HEAD: Popular Politician Says Reunification Will Happen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with government easing restrictions on foreign investment. Pickup 2nd, `Also today...' subs 13th, `East German...' with 1 graf to conform. Pickup 14th, `Ms. Luft...'
DOC.TEXT: A popular politician who quit the Communist Party said today that East Germany never developed its own identity during 40 years of Communist rule and that reunification with West Germany is ``unavoidable.'' The East German government said it has lifted all barriers to competition between companies and that foreign investors may buy majority shares of enterprises here if the projects are ``in the public's economic interest.'' The announcement by Economics Minister Christa Luft is a major concession to Western businesses, which had shown little interest in joint ventures and other investments when the government said it would limit foreign ownership to 49 percent. Ms. Luft said the revision was made to stimulate the investment necessary to revive East Germany's flagging economy. Also today, the ADN news agency said Communist Party chief Gregor Gysi had been invited to Washington next week for talks with President Bush on Eastern Europe. It did not say when the trip would occur and said it was ``private.'' The Communist Party faces growing opposition among East Germans, in part because of its opposition to unification with West Germany. Wolfgang Berghofer, the mayor of Dresden, quit the party this week. In a speech to the Dresden City Council today, the popular leader said of unification: ``It is unavoidable that what belongs together will grow together.'' ``The only question is in what time frame and in what manner it will occur,'' he said. ``There remain two separate rights of citizenship, but this can no longer be compared to national identity,'' Berghofer said. Berghofer's defection from the Communists came on top of strikes and mass demonstrations against the party, which has been accused of being too slow to adopt reforms. A one-hour strike in Dresden on Wednesday shut down 200 of the city's most important offices and services, and police in Leipzig rallied in support of pro-democracy activists. A leading East German economist warned in a report published Wednesday that the economy could collapse if the country doesn't swiftly convert to a free- market system. Siegfried Schiller, a Communist and deputy director of Dresden's economic research institute, said that such a collapse could come within a year without radical reforms. ``The house is on fire and the government is wasting time posturing,'' Schiller told the newspaper Die Union. ``Every attempt to shore up a planned economy must be resisted.'' He said he feared half-hearted reform attempts could cut off critical supplies of raw materials before East Germany can afford to buy them from the West. Economics Minister Luft also proposed the speedy introduction of market-oriented economic reforms, a West German TV network reported Wednesday. Ms. Luft suggested allowing the East German mark to be freely exchanged for other currencies by 1992, dismantling price controls, reducing state subsidies and introducing performance-oriented salaries and a new taxation system, ZDF television reported. Ms. Luft also wants to end the state's monopoly on foreign trade. Some of the steps could start taking effect this year, ZDF reported. However, Communist Premier Hans Modrow's government has resisted moving toward a free-market economy, calling instead for a ``third way'' between capitalism and communism. But pressure for a conversion to capitalism has built up in recent weeks, with West Germany's powerful business community sensing vast new opportunities. East Germany's inefficient, centrally planned economy has been hard hit by the exodus of some 340,000 citizens to West Germany last year, many of them skilled young workers. The migration tapered off after authorities opened borders to the West in November. But up to 2,000 East Germans are still fleeing daily, disillusioned about the prospects of reform despite free elections promised in May.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Study Casts Doubt on Chance for Success of Soviet Economic Reforms
DOC.TEXT: A NATO study said Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reform program has had little impact in the Soviet Union, and it cast doubt on the chances of it ever succeeding. The study, obtained by The Associated Press today, said the failure of ``perestroika'' is evident in falling living standards of Soviet citizens, and it blamed Soviet leaders for the situation. ``The failure of the Soviet leadership to press ahead with key measures such as price reforms, and the half-hearted manner in which it has approached the growing fiscal and monetary crisis, are reflected in the continuing decline of the Soviet Union's economic position,'' said the study. ``The survival prospects for economic reforms in the Soviet Union _ now admitted by the leadership to be in a `state of crisis' _ become increasingly doubtful,'' said the study. It was done by economic analysts of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The report compared economic reforms in China and the Soviet Union, based on information up to July. It was given to NATO foreign ministers in December. The analysts said no Communist nation has succeeded in transforming a centrally planned economy to a flourishing free-market system. The key reason for failure has been the conflicting interests between the demands for economic reforms and the objectives of Communist parties and the vested interests of their members, it said. Party members want to ``safeguard the kind of economic structures _ mostly inefficient ones _ from which substantial benefits accrue to them,'' it said. ``Whenever it came to do or die in past reform efforts, the party bureaucrats have always put their own interest first, as reflected once again by recent events in China,'' it said. The economic programs in the Soviet Union and China were hampered from the start by ``unsuitable political institutions,'' it said. The analysts predicted that the reform drive in China would lose further ground. ``Its scope has been seriously restricted and its direction rechanneled toward areas acceptable to the new, more conservative and suspicious leadership in Beijing,'' it said. Future reform efforts would likely be limited to modernization measures that would increase efficiency somewhat, but they would not solve ``the deep-rooted real problems of the Chinese economy and society,'' according to the report. It said the governments of Poland and Hungary offered the prospect of severing the ties between the Communist Party bureaucracy and its vested interest in obsolete economic structures. The countries have been leaders in the moves toward democracy in Eastern Europe. ``Gorbachev's support for these efforts in Hungary and Poland may be indicative of his own vision of reform,'' the study said. Without a political opposition, it said Gorbachev would have to loosen the Communists' grip on economic structures by going around the party apparatus in management decisions and giving state organizations more power. It added: ``By trying to maintain the country's `socialist achievements,' economic reforms in the Soviet Union will remain piecemeal.'' ``But piecemeal reforms to a centrally planned economy generate unpredictable frictions that would not arise if other economic variables were free to adapt to remove their sting,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Policewoman Charged With Killing Husband, Retarded Son
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS throughout that minister is female, UPDATES with Sweeten still in jail, detail on son, police comment on suicide note. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A retired police captain has been charged with shooting to death her husband and retarded son, who police say may have been killed because his mother planned to commit suicide and he needed special care. Dorothea Sweeten, 66, was arrested Wednesday at her home after a SWAT negotiator talked her into dropping a pistol she had held to her head for about an hour. She was charged with murdering her husband, Tom, 55, a public relations employee for the Tennessee Valley Authority and a former managing editor of The Knoxville Journal, and her son, Charles H. Forester Jr., 39. She was in jail today on $40,000 bail. Police were called to the home after Mrs. Sweeten telephoned a minister and said she had killed the two and was contemplating suicide, said sheriff's Detective Mike Lett. Mrs. Sweeten told the minister she killed her husband because he had abused her physically and mentally for years, and killed her son ``because there would be nobody to take care of him,'' Lett said. Sheriff's Lt. Herman Johnson said Forester lived at home, did not work and attended a school for the handicapped. The minister, Coy Bays, had a secretary notify police while she kept Mrs. Sweeten on the phone for more than an hour, Lett said. ``When they arrived (Mrs. Sweeten) had the gun under her chin,'' Johnson said. ``It was cocked and she had her finger on the trigger.'' Mrs. Sweeten retired from the Knoxville police force in 1982 after 28 years. Johnson said Mrs. Sweeten had written a suicide note that claimed hospital records would show she had suffered a broken arm and ruptured eardrum from her husband's beatings. Johnson said police had yet to examine the records.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested in Officer's Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Three young men were arrested on charges of shooting an off-duty policeman in a botched attempt to steal $20 to join a basketball league. Officer Troy Patterson, 27, was critically wounded and remained in a coma from the attack Jan. 16, in which the six-year police veteran was jumped and shot in the head as he washed his car in Brooklyn, authorities said. ``We believe they were attempting to obtain some monies to participate in a basketball game that was going to be played,'' Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said Wednesday. Police said the alleged triggerman, 15-year-old Tracy Clark, needed $20 of the $37 entry fee to play in the United Brooklyn Basketball League. Investigators initially discounted robbery as a motive because the officer's wallet, gun and shield were not taken. Detectives theorized instead that the shooting was linked to the officer's arrests or his personal life. But the investigation turned around after a tipster reported the shooting was a robbery gone awry, Borrelli said. ``We're pretty sure they weren't aware he was an officer,'' he said. Clark was charged with attempted murder, attempted robbery, assault and weapons possession Wednesday. Vincent Robbins, 20, Darien ``Wimpy'' Crawford, 17, were charged with attempted robbery, assault and weapons possession. On Wednesday, one of the suspects, while in custody, wore a T-shirt that read ``United Brooklyn Basketball League.''

DOC.HEAD: Franklin Chosen as AID Assistant Administrator
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate C. Anson Franklin, an Energy Department official, as an assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development, the White House said today. Franklin, 42, will become AID's assistant administrator for external affairs. He has been Energy's assistant secretary for congressional, intergovernmental and public affairs since 1987 and was an assistant White House press secretary in 1982-85. He lives in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Sentenced to Seven Years; Allowed to Remain Free Pending Appeals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Lozano, 30 ...', with 4 grafs to CORRECT age to 31, UPDATE with police saying he faces loss of job, city calm overnight. PICKS UP 5th graf pvs, `The defense ...'; DELETES now redundant 12th graf pvs, `The city's ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: A Hispanic police officer was free on bond and predicting his vindication after receiving a seven-year prison term for the deaths of two blacks. One critic called the sentence ``justice delayed and justice denied.'' Officer William Lozano thanked his supporters after being sentenced Wednesday by Circuit Judge Joseph Farina. ``My attorney, my family and I will continue to fight within the system for the truth, for what is right, and at the end, we will win,'' Lozano said. Because of his felony conviction, he faces the automatic loss of his job and his state certification for police duty, the Police Department said. The city's black neighborhoods, which erupted in riots after the slayings a year ago, remained calm overnight. ``I think we can attribute this to the black community feeling justice was served,'' police spokesman Raymond Lang said today. Lozano, 31, was convicted last month on two counts of manslaughter for fatally shooteen longer. ``I see this as both a case now of justice delayed and justice denied,'' said Marvin Dunn, a black psychology professor at Florida International University. ``Seven years does not in fact mean seven years in prison.'' But Dunn, who wrote a book on Miami's 1980 race riots, said he hoped blacks would accept the sentence with equanimity. ``What we have to be concerned about is whether or not the perception of a miscarriage of justice now resurfaces in the black community,'' Dunn said, urging a ``responsible reaction by all of us in the black community to accept and live with the judge's decision.'' Defense attorneys criticized the case as an effort to ease racial tensions in Miami rather than give their client a fair trial. ``If Officer Lozano was black, he never would have been charged with a crime,'' defense attorney Mark Seiden told the judge. ``If the two people on the motorcycle were white, he never would have been charged with a crime.'' Prosecutor John Hogan, who recommended a 12-year prison term, described the sentence as a just one. Lozano could have faced a punishment of 12 to 17 years in prison under state sentencing guidelines. Miguel Degrandy, a vice president of the Spanish American League Against Discrimination, said the judge ``fashioned a sentence that he felt that both parties could live with. ``However, this is a no-win case for our community in Dade County, and there is still going to be unfortunately polarized reaction,'' he said. The shooting on Jan. 16, 1989, sparked three days of racial violence, the fourth riot in this city in the 1980s. All were linked to the killing of blacks by police officers, and in two of the cases, acquittals of the white policemen sparked racial violence. Lozano shot and killed Lloyd as he fled a pursuing squad car after running a stop sign. Lloyd's passenger Allan Blanchard, 24, died of injuries suffered in the subsequent motorcycle crash. Ray Fauntroy, head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said he was disappointed by the sentence. ``We get seven years just for stealing a loaf of bread,'' the civil rights leader said. ``This officer was just given a pat on the back. He'll be out in two or three years.'' The sentence was average for someone convicted of manslaughter, said Miami police spokesman Sgt. David Rivero. ``This is a democratic system, and we (police officers) have to accept that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Subway Motorman Makes Wrong Turn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix typo in `borough.'
DOC.TEXT: Two thousand subway passengers, used to nothing more surprising than an occasional kazoo-playing panhandler, found themselves headed for the wrong part of town when a novice motorman hit the wrong button. The train to Jamaica became a train to Long Island City _ those are two sections of the sprawling borough of Queens _ during the height of the rush hour Tuesday evening. It happened when the unidentified motorman punched the wrong ``route request'' button at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan, switching his train off the F line and onto the Q line. Both lines head toward Queens, but by different routes. ``It's like getting off on the wrong exit on the Long Island Expressway,'' said Robert Previdi, a Transit Authority spokesman. Officials said there was no danger of collision with another train. The driver recognized his error at the next stop, announced it and let passengers off to catch a train back to Rockefeller Center to get a proper F train, Previdi said. He said the motorman might be given some retraining.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Leaving Few Wounded, Many Dead, Refugees Say
DOC.TEXT: Liberian soldiers accused of killing hundreds of unarmed civilians are leaving few survivors in their wake as they scour the countryside looking for rebels, medical workers and diplomats said today. The reports, based on harrowing accounts by refugees, indicate that the mass killings are so thorough and indiscriminate that very few wounded are left behind. ``They tell really horrendous stories of soldiers spraying entire villages with .50-caliber machine guns,'' said a Western diplomat who requested anonymity. Bullets from such heavy weapons tear huge holes into bodies. The diplomat and Ivorian sources estimate at least 500 civilians have been killed in Liberia's eastern Nimba county since soldiers were deployed to halt a Dec. 24 rebel incursion. ``The refugees say there are not many wounded people because the soldiers slaughtered so many,'' said the diplomat. He visited refugees Tuesday with Ivorian government officials, aid workers and other diplomats from nations giving food, medicine and money to alleviate a food shortage. An ongoing stream of refugees was estimated today to number more than 60,000. Between 12,000 and 15,000 other Liberians have sought refuge in Guinea, the diplomat said. At the Ivorian border village of Danane, refugees dash desperately to hide in forests when they hear the staccato of machine gunfire that sounds daily from across the frontier in Liberia. ``They are traumatized by the combat and watching some of their relatives being killed,'' said Claude Regnier, a French adviser to the Ivorian government who heads a committee coordinating refugee aid. ``They are still in shock. When the gunfire starts, they rush to the forest and come out of the bush only when it stops,'' he said in an interview. A Western diplomat said the killings began after rebels from the Gio tribe stepped up attacks in an attempt to oust Liberian President Samuel Doe, who seized power in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted the descendants of freed American slaves who founded the West African nation in 1847. The Gio long have felt oppressed by Doe's Krahn people. ``It started with Gio rebels attacking military outposts in their own ethnic heartland in Nimba county,'' the diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``The army came in and just went nuts because everyone looks like a rebel to them. There has been some very heavy-handed slaughter.'' The rebels retaliated about 10 days ago by moving south into traditional Krahn territory and began slaughtering civilians there, according to the diplomat. That has caused a second wave of victims to flee east into Ivory Coast and north into Guinea, he said. The killing continues, the diplomat said, despite a warning from Doe on Monday that soldiers who harm civilians will face firing squads. Liberian officials say Doe's execution threat is helping to bring the situation under control. Initially, Justice Minister Jenkins Scott said troops killed only armed civilians who attacked them. One Western diplomat conceded it might be difficult for troops to identify rebels, who do not wear military uniforms. Regnier said 40 percent of refugees are women and children, 30 percent boys and youths and the remainder men. Doctors said refugees hospitalized in Ivory Coast include a 5-year-old girl shot in the leg. At Man hospital, a regional health center 75 miles from Danane, director Dr. Maurice Kouame said his staff is treating only eight seriously wounded Liberians.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Forecasts Multi-Billion Dollar Phone Scams for the '90s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with news conference quotes, details
DOC.TEXT: Long-distance telephone services that charge the unwary $30 to $50 for information they could get for free head a list of telemarketing scams that an anti-fraud group predicted today will flower during the 1990s. The costly abuse of ``900'' area code telephone service was just one of several increasingly popular consumer frauds compiled by the Alliance Against Fraud in Telemarketing. ``Our aim is to forewarn consumers so they can forearmed against fraud,'' said Linda Golodner, executive director of the National Consumers League, which coordinates the alliance. ``While the alliance recognizes that many products and services are sold legitimately through telemarketing, we want to warn consumers that con artists are making these types of offers through high-pressure sales pitches providing little concrete information,'' she said. In another scam on the alliance's list, unsuspecting consumers get official-looking envelopes that appear to be from a government agency but actually are peddling various fraudulent schemes. Currently, such look-alike envelopes are not illegal, Tom McClure of the U.S. Postal Inspection Service, said at a news conference sponsored by the alliance. ``A con artist is only limited by his imagination,'' he said. The alliance is a wide-ranging coalition of more than 60 consumer groups, trade associations, state and federal agencies, businesses, news organizations and labor unions. Among the scams cited by the alliance were: _900 phone numbers that keep callers on hold, racking up toll charges, before giving generic information that could be obtained for free elsewhere about how to obtain or re-establish credit. _Bogus health-care promotions for phony arthritis and baldness remedies, sexual aids and weight-loss plans. _One-shot credit cards, good only for purchasing goods from one specific department store or catalog although they are deceptively promoted as an all-purpose bank credit card such as MasterCard or VISA. _False claims by timeshare agents who charge up to $400 to resell a consumer's unit, promising to pay a worthless penalty as a guarantee if they don't sell the unit within a year. ``It's an epidemic. There's about $10 billion in telemarketing fraud a year,'' Kansas Securities Commissioner Doug Mays said in a telephone interview Wednesday. Mays said ``boiler rooms'' _ organized scam efforts promising ridiculously high profits through high pressure sales tactics and banks of telephones _ now are moving offshore. Mays calls such boiler rooms ``the crack houses of consumer fraud.'' Once based largely in Florida and later Colorado, Mays said boiler room scams for precious metals and high-risk penny stocks are now being phoned in to this country from Costa Rica, the Cayman Islands, Panama and Africa. ``Even as far inland as Kansas, we're getting calls from Liberia and South Africa,'' said May, who next year will be president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, an organization of state-level securities regulators. ``In order not to become victims, consumers must be able to tell the difference between fraudulent offers that come over the telephone and legitimate ones,'' said Ms. Golodner. They can do that by asking questions, getting answers in writing and contacting consumer protection agencies when they don't know anything about the salesperson or the product, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Powers of State Security Services Curbed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 2nd pvs, ``The legislation...'' to UPDATE with margin the bill passed by. Pickup 3rd pvs, ``Also, two...''
DOC.TEXT: Parliament passed a law today that limits the powers of the secret police. The new restrictions came in response to reports that security services routinely spied on legal opposition parties. The legislation stipulates that covert intelligence gathering will be permitted only when ``the security of the nation, the sovereignty of the country and its constitutional order are endangered by secret activities.'' The vote was 279 for, none against and 14 abstentions. Also, two government officials _ Interior Minister State Secretary Zoltan Gal and Justice Minister Kalman Kulcsar _ were given responsibility for intelligence operations. Introducing the bill, entitled ``Temporary Regulation of the Use of Special Secret Service Methods and Means,'' Gal told Parliament on Wednesday that intelligence agencies had had little past supervision when Hungary was a one-party Communist state. The interim legislation was hurriedly introduced following a national uproar over revelations that the state security service was spying on scores of people, including some members of Parliament. Gal said a permanent and comprehensive bill governing the activities of the security services will be presented in Parliament in February. The scandal broke Jan. 5, when representatives of two opposition organizations presented reporters with secret documents leaked to them by a member of the secret police.
