Secret police targets of intelligence gathering included opposition parties and personalities, writers and religious figures, according to the documents. Chief Public Prosecutor Karoly Szijarto disclosed Wednesday that the illegal eavesdropping was even more widespread than originally thought. Szijarto told the legislature the internal security department of the Interior Ministry even spied on the Socialist Party, its predecessor, the Socialist Workers' Party and other Communist or leftist organizations. The investigation is still under way. While claiming to have had no knowledge of such practices, Interior Minister Istvan Horvath resigned Tuesday, telling legislators that ``in a democracy that is the custom.'' Hungary formally became a multiparty state Oct. 23, and the first free elections since 1948 are scheduled for March 25. Although the Socialist Party asserts it was uninvolved, the scandal is believed to have hurt its chances at the polls because it happened under its tenure. The Hungarian Democratic Forum, the biggest opposition party, already has signaled its opposition to the idea of a future coalition with the Socialists, in a clear indication of the party's desire to distance itself from what it considers a political liability. The interim law also changed the name of the main intelligence agency from the State Security Service to National Security Service. Gal said the move was meant as a signal ``that the secret service organs no longer serve the state organizatio, but have as their primary aim the security of the entire nation and constitutional order.'' Premier Miklos Nemeth subsequently appointed Gal as interim head of the Interior Ministry, while Parliament agreed to name Kulcsar director of the National Security Service.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Group Trying to Arrange Peace Talks to End Ethnic Unrest
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Baltic group saying Armenians to attend peace talks, no word from Azerbaijanis. Pickup 8th pvs, `Vezirov, a...' Delete 24th graf pvs, `Armenians and...' to conform, and last 5 grafs to trim.
DOC.TEXT: MOSCOW (AP)_ A Baltic nationalist group said today that an Armenian organization has accepted an invitation to attend peace talks aimed at ending ethnic conflict with the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. There was no word on whether an Azerbaijani delegation would attend the talks, planned Monday in the Latvian capital, Riga. The attempt to arrange negotiations was the latest effort to end two weeks of violence that began with anti-Armenian riots in Azerbaijan and has grown into a drive for secession by some Azerbaijanis. Communist leaders in Azerbaijan today blamed their former leader for the crisis and expelled him from the party. More Soviet troops were reported killed in attacks by militants in Azerbaijan's capital, Baku. At least 171 people have been killed since the unrest began Jan. 13. In a telephone interview today from Riga, Anda Anspoka of the Latvian People's Front said the group received a letter of confirmation from the Armenian People's Front to attend a peace conference Monday. The Armenian group authorized its representatives to ``sign any documents'' to end the ethnic strife, Ms. Anspoka said. A spokesman for the nationalist Azerbaijani People's Front, Usus Samed Ogli, said today his group had not decided if it will attend. Ogli said the Azerbaijani front leaders had gone underground out of fear they would be arrested and planned to meet in secret Friday to decide whether to attend the talks. Ms. Anspoka said the talks would be mediated by leaders of People's Front groups in the Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia. Like the groups in Azerbaijan and Armenia, the People's Front groups support autonomy for their republics. Their causes would not be helped by nationalist unrest requiring Kremlin military intervention, which explains in part the Baltics' eagerness to settle the dispute. Successful mediation also would give prestige to the Baltic People's Front groups. In addition, the Baltics are not interested in seeing their young men drafted into military service to control the conflict. Azerbaijan's Central Committee convened at 11 p.m. Wednesday and ousted Abdul-Rakham Vezirov, who was named party leader during Azerbaijani-Armenian unrest in May 1988. He was given a mandate to restore order after a long-running dispute between Azerbaijanis and Armenians erupted. The conflict involves the region of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is under the control of Azerbaijan _ a mainly Shiite Moslem republic _ but populated by Armenians, who are mostly Christians. Armenia wants to annex the region. Vezirov, a former diplomat and career party official, was expelled from the party for ``serious mistakes'' that led to the current crisis, said Baku journalist Tunzala Kasumova. Vezirov had been removed as party chief earlier in the week. Vezirov was replaced by Ayaz Mutalibov, the republic's prime minister. Meanwhile, Tass said militant nationalists were continuing attacks on Soviet troops, who entered Baku on Saturday. It said two soldiers were killed Wednesday and one seriously wounded. Strikes continued in the city in defiance of a military ban, and public transport was at a standstill, Tass said. Azerbaijanis have pledged not to end their strikes until Soviet troops withdraw. The harbor at Baku, a Caspian Sea port of 1.8 million, was reported calm today following reports of a harbor fight Wednesday between military troops and Azerbaijanis blocking the waterway. The military commander of Baku, Lt. Gen. Vladimir Dubinyak, said in a radio announcment today that occasional gunfire rang out during the night at the port but that no one was killed. He said authorities detained more than 100 people during the night, 68 for curfew violations. Leila Yunusova, an Azerbaijani activist, said 100,000 of Azerbaijan's 380,000 Communists have torn up their party cards _ signaling growing resentment of central authorities in Moscow for ordering the crackdown. On Wednesday, soldiers rounded up 43 activists and banned rallies in Baku. Tass today cited Baku Radio as saying troops had detained Mamed Ali-Zade, chairman of the Defense Committee of the Azerbaijani People's Front. It said he possessed various weapons, ``symbols of the popular front, medicines, radio equipment and propaganda materials calling on the population to resist authorities.'' The Communist Party daily Pravda said 400 dependents of ethnic Russian servicemen were flown out of Azerbaijan on Wednesday night, because of fears that Azerbaijanis angry over the troop deployment would turn on them. About 100,000 ethnic Russians live in Baku. Pravda said the refugees were being taken to military facilities and public buildings in Moscow and Kiev and that others are being housed by the Black Sea fleets. On Wednesday, Tass reported, the Soviet military evacuated more than 16,000 wives and children of soldiers from the region because of increasing threats against Soviet troops. Anti-Armenians riots in Baku on Jan. 13 escalated into armed clashes between groups of Azerbaijanis and Armenians. Thousands of Armenians fled as nationalist extremists gained strength in Azerbaijan, and militant Azerbaijanis began fighting Soviet troops who were deployed to restore order.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Libya Remains National Security Threat
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today declared that Libya remains ``an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security'' of the United States as he renewed existing sanctions against the Tripoli government. Bush made the declaration in a semiannual report to Congress required by the national emergency status that the United States has had with regard to Libya since Jan. 7, 1986. The United States bans trade with Libya and bars travel by Americans there, unless an exemption is granted by the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control. ``The policies and actions of the government of Libya continue to pose an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States. I shall continue to exercise the powers at my disposal to apply economic sanctions against Libya as long as these measures are appropriate,'' Bush said in the report. He said that in the last six months, the U.S. government has issued ``a limited number of specific licenses to individuals and corprations to permit them to engage in activities that would otherwise be prohibited.'' The sanctions and trade embargo were imposed by former President Reagan, who declared Libya a terrorist nation.

DOC.HEAD: Tons of Molten Steel Spill; Six Hurt
DOC.TEXT: A ladle containing more than 100 tons of molten steel crashed to the floor at a new mill, scattering 2,850-degree metal and injuring six workers, at least one seriously, authorities said. ``It looked like what happens when water is dropped on a hot skillet,'' Crawfordsville Fire Chief Dennis Weir said after Wednesday's accident at the Nucor Corp. Michael Hinz, who suffered minor injuries, said he was driving a crane, guiding the ladle, when a cable broke and the ladle dropped 30 feet. ``When it hit, steel splashed, knocking a hole in one wall. A blast of heat knocked out another wall in the furnace room,'' Hinz said. He said the concussion blew him off his seat, and slag shattered his crane window. ``I thought it was all over,'' he said. ``I guess if there's a nightmare, that's a crane operator's nightmare.'' About 35 firefighters used extinguishers to put out burning debris, including bags, crates, boxes and other packing materials, Weir said. About 300 employees work at the $270 million plant, which processes scrap metal such as used automobile bodies into new steel. Pat Major, 37, of Valparaiso, an employee of a contractor at the plant, was in serious condition today at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, where he was being treated for burns over 70 percent of his body, a spokeswoman said. Another worker was listed in stable conditon at AMI Culver Union Hospital in Crawfordsville. Four other workers were treated there and released. Keith Busse, vice president and general manager of the plant, which opened last year, said the mill would remain closed until the weekend while siding over a 40-hole in the wall is replaced and equipment checked out.

DOC.HEAD: All Rescued from Crippled Liberian Cargo Vessel
DOC.TEXT: Two helicopters rescued all 23 crew members Thursday from a 7,027-ton Liberian cargo vessel that was taking on water off western Japan, the coast guard said. The crewmen from Hong Kong, the Philippines, Burma, China and Britain all were in good condition after being rescued from the Maritime Gardenia, said Toshikazu Ito, spokesman of the Maritime Safety Agency's regional headquarters in Maizuru, western Japan. The ship was in the Japan Sea, less than a mile from western Japan's Kyoto prefecture, when it radioed for help shortly after midnight Wednesday, Ito said. Waves of 10 feet were reported in the area, he added. Two helicopters from the Air Self Defense Force's Komatsu base took the crew members to Komatsu, 190 miles northwest of Tokyo, Ito said. The Maritime Gardenia was heading for a dockyard in Yamaguchi prefecture in southwestern Japan after unloading Malaysian lumber in a western Japan port, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Queen Greeting Ceausescu Cut From Official Danish Film
DOC.TEXT: The government has recalled a film from its embassies to cut out a sequence showing Queen Margrethe II in 1980 greeting Nicolae Ceausescu, whom she later awarded Denmark's highest honor, officials said Thursday. ``A Living Queen,'' a 28-minute film about the royal family, was distributed to foreign missions as archive material for TV stations. Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacob Benthien said the 90-second sequence ordered expunged showed the queen welcoming Ceausescu during a state visit. ``It's obvious that no one wants publicity for a monarchy with such an awarding ceremony,'' Benthien said. ``No one was happy with that clip.'' Ceausescu, who was overthrown and executed last month, was given Denmark's Knight of the Order of the Elephant. After Ceausescu was deposed, the Royal Palace announced that his name was being stricken from the list of knights. The queen also canceled the Order of the Knight of the Great Cross, which she gave to Ceausescu's wife, Elena. Ceausescu, Romania's hard-line leader for 24 years, was looked upon favorably by Western nations for many years because he steered his Communist country on a path independent of Moscow. He received honors from other Western nations, including Britain, but they were stripped from him when he was toppled. Another scene from the Danish film that was cut showed the queen smoking a cigarette while listening to a speech by Prince Consort Henrik during a 1979 visit to China. The entire film will be replaced after the festivities marking the queen's 50th birthday on April 16, Benthien said.

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Wall Segments Going for Nearly $29,000 Apiece
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western buyers are paying nearly $30,000 for large segments of the Berlin Wall, an East German newspaper said Thursday. Helge Moebius, an official of the East German foreign trade company Limex-Bau, told the Berliner Zeitung newspaper that the 2.7-ton segments of the wall are bringing between $11,800 and $29,400 each. The newspaper did not say how many pieces have been sold so far. The cement wall sections, each about 10 feet high and six feet wide, are being sold to collectors from the United States, Britain, West Germany and other Western countries, the newspaper said. Asked why the pieces of wall were so expensive, Ms. Moebius said that tearing down the wall and replacing it with a six-foot-high metal fence costs about $47,000 per kilometer, or six-tenths of a mile. East German border guards began tearing down a 325-yard section of the graffiti-covered wall Monday night near West Berlin's Kreuzberg district in the southeastern part of the city. Large segments of the wall earlier had been removed from Brandenburg Gate and the Potsdamerplatz where new border crossings have been opened. Profits from sale of the wall are to be used for humanitarian purposes, Ms. Moebius was quoted as saying, such as improving medical facilities and care of memorial sites in East Germany. The Berlin Wall, built in 1961 to prevent East Germans from escaping to the West, was opened in November.

DOC.HEAD: Precede ROME
Pope Arrives in Cape Verde on First Stop of Sixth African Tour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with pope's arrival, remarks. Pickup 4th pvs, ``The countries...''
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II praised the Christian heritage of this African nation today as he began an eight-day tour of the impoverished Sahel region, his sixth pilgrimage to Africa. The pope flew from Rome in a special Alitalia Airbus to Amilcar Cabral international airport on the 10-island archipelago off Africa's northwest coast. After two days in the former Portuguese colony, he heads to Guinea Bissau, Mali, Burkina Faso and Chad. In brief remarks in Portuguese, the pope referred to the predominantly Roman Catholic islands as a country of ``ancient Christianity at the gates of continental Africa'' and wished ``grace, salvation and peace'' on Cape Verdians and the many who emigrated abroad. After greetings from several thousand well-wishers, the pope transferred to a smaller plane for a 40-minute flight to Praia for the official welcoming ceremony. Islanders were out all day sweeping the sand and dust from the streets blown by strong winds gusting across the archipelago. The trip is the 45th foreign voyage of the pope's 11-year pontificate. The countries in the sub-Saharan semi-arid region stretching across western and central Africa are among the world's poorest, with millions of people living on the edge of starvation. The pope is expected to renew an appeal he made 10 years ago for international aid to help save sub-Saharan Africa from its chronic problems of poverty, hunger, disease and encroaching deserts. ``This is the poorest part of Africa and the pope will discuss the realities of these countries,'' said Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro. The visit comes at a time when African government and church leaders are concerned that Western aid and development funds will be redirected from Africa to the new democrtic movements in Eastern Europe. ``The interest of the Western world is focused on the East, and there is a risk of forgetting to save one part of humanity that would fall back into misery,'' Cardinal Paul Zoungrana of Burkina Faso said in an interview with the Italian Catholic magazine 30 Giorni (30 Days). ``This is not the moment to abandon Africa,'' he said. ``The pope can use his moral strength and attract the attention of the whole world.'' Noting that the Polish-born pope himself comes from Eastern Europe, the cardinal said, ``If a new problem arises, you can't forget the old ones. And if it's a pope from the East who reminds us, the world will take note.'' In a special supplement on the papal trip, the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano decried the world's ``indifference'' towards Africa's problems. ``While the eyes of the world are still fixed on the extraordinary events of Eastern Europe, the heart of the church now looks elsewhere ... to the vast territory of suffering that is Africa,'' the newspaper said. A centerpiece of the pope's trip will be a ceremony Monday in Ouagadougou, capital of Burkina Faso, marking the 10th anniversary of John Paul's appeal for the Sahel in which he declared: ``I can not remain silent while my brothers and sisters are in danger.'' The appeal led to the creation in 1984 of the John Paul II Foundation for the Sahel, funded primarily by contributions from Catholics in West Germany and sponsoring agricultural and development projects in the region. John Paul, who is scheduled to make another trip to Africa later this year, is particularly interested in Africa because of the rapid growth of Catholicism on the continent. The African church counts more than 75 million followers today, or about 13 percent of the total population, compared to 1 percent at the turn of the century. About 90 percent of Cape Verde's population of 360,000 is Roman Catholic, the highest percentage in Africa. However, Catholics are a small minority in the other countries on the tour, ranging from less than 1 percent in Mali to 9 percent in Burkina Faso. While Cape Verde is the most prosperous of the five nations, more than 400,000 islanders _ greater than the current population _ have emigrated in recent decades to the United States and Europe in search of jobs and a better life.

DOC.HEAD: Peacekeeper Killed in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: A Norwegian army captain serving with United Nations peacekeepers was killed in a car accident in south Lebanon, a U.N. spokesman said Thursday. Capt. Gunnar Baerhim was killed Wednesday in an accident involving his jeep and a truck in the southern village of Mari, said spokesman Timur Goksel. Baerhim, 34, was a member of the 683-strong Norwegian battalion serving with the U.N. Interim Force in Lebanon. The fatality raised the overall death toll of the peacekeeping force to 167 since it deployed in south Lebanon in March 1978. The 5,800-member force, drawn from nine nations, staffs a narrow buffer separating the Israeli-controlled sector of south Lebanon from the predominantly Shiite Moslem region. U.N. records show that only 70 of the force's fatalities were killed in action, mainly in attacks by various armed groups.

DOC.HEAD: 10-Year-Old Busted on Dope Dealing Charges
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old boy was arrested on drug charges after he was found carrying 10 packets of marijuana at school, police said. Police said the principal of Sacred Heart School called Wednesday to report that a student had been caught carrying the drug. Officers from the department's youth division arrested the boy and charged him with possession of narcotics with intent to sell. The boy, who was turned over to juvenile authorities, told police that he got the marijuana from a relative and would sell it for $5 or $10 a bag, officers said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Drug-Courier Profile Violates Rights of Blacks, Hispanics
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled that a drug courier profile used to justify searching cars during traffic stops violates the rights of blacks and Hispanics. The country can't pay lip service to the rights of blacks by honoring Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday and then trample on their rights through law enforcement, U.S. District Judge Jim R. Carrigan said Wednesday. The traffic stops in Eagle County, west of Denver, violate the rights of blacks to travel freely and to be protected against unreasonable searches, he said. Sheriff A.J. Johnson testified that race is one of the criteria used to target suspected drug couriers. Other factors include having fast-food wrappers on the car floor, having no luggage, motorists who have driven long distances nonstop and cars with out-of-state license plates. The ruling means federal drug charges against reputed Los Angeles Crips gang member Louis Laymon probably will be dismissed. ``So far the only casualty in the war against drugs has been the Constitution,'' said Laymon's attorney, David Lane. ``It's nice to see a judge like Carrigan firing a shot in its defense.'' Laymon was arrested after Sheriff's Sgt. James Perry found crack cocaine in his car during a traffic stop on Interstate 70 about 100 miles west of Denver. Lane argued that the car was stopped only because Laymon is black and his car had California plates. Laymon acknowledged during a hearing to suppress evidence that he has been a crack cocaine dealer, but he denied the cocaine found in the car was his. Perry contended he stopped the car for weaving on the highway and obtained Laymon's permission for the search. But Carrigan said Perry used ``trivial traffic violations'' as an excuse to stop cars for drug searches.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Attempted Hijacking to Undergo Psychiatric Evaluation
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. magistrate today ordered a psychiatric examination for a man accused of trying to hijack an America West airliner to Cuba. U.S. Magistrate Stephen Capelle ordered the examination at the request of Jose Manuel Gonzalez-Gonzalez' attorney, Bennie Ray. Ray said the Cuban native living in New Orleans ``can't carry on a continued conversation with you without drifting off into a political realm.'' Gonzalez-Gonzalez, 39, is charged with air piracy and assaulting a flight attendant in the Jan. 16 incident aboard the flight from Houston to Las Vegas. Passengers said he grabbed the flight attendant, claimed he had a bomb and demanded to go to Cuba. The pilot, saying he had to re-fuel, landed the Boeing 737 in Austin, where Gonzalez-Gonzalez was jumped and subdued. According to Ray, Gonzalez-Gonzalez believes law enforcement officials are after him because he has a tape recording on the death of former New Orleans mayor Ernest ``Dutch'' Morial. He died Christmas Eve of a heart attack.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Wants Former Communist Countries Integrated into Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 19 grafs to UPDATE with Havel speech to parliament. Pickup 13th pvs, `Polish politicians...
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia called today for a unified Europe that incorporates Soviet bloc countries that are adopting democratic reforms and market-oriented economies. Havel, presenting his vision of a unified Europe to Poland's National Assembly, said a joint effort to ``return to Europe'' would avoid rivalries among emerging democracies seeking admission to the political and economic alliances of Western Europe. ``We should not compete in who is going to overtake whom and who will first win a seat in some European body, but we should do just the opposite: help each other,'' said the playwright and longtime dissident who became Czechoslovakia's president after a peaceful pro-democracy movement in November. Havel was greeted today at Warsaw's Military Airport by Communist President Wojciech Jaruzelski, senior government officials, a full military honor guard and the diplomatic corps. Havel appeared uncomfortable and unaccustomed to the ceremonial greeting. He seemed startled when the precision honor guard shouted in unison at him, ``Hail to Mr. President!'' To lawmakers, Havel said: ``Western Europe is much more advanced in integration processes and if we were to return to Europe individually, it would certainly take much longer and it would be much more complicated than if we act together.'' ``This does not only concern economics. It concerns everything including disarmament talks,'' he said. Havel said a power vacuum has existed in Central Europe since the end of World War I and that countries of the region ``until recently colonized by the Soviets'' should unite into a new ``formation.'' Havel said it ``is hard to forecast the institutional shape that our East European or Central European cooperation will create.'' He proposed that representatives of Poland and Hungary come to Czechoslovakia to discuss the form of such cooperation. Observers from other Eastern European countries could also attend the talks, he said. Havel takes his proposal to Hungary on Friday. Havel was warmly received in the parliament chamber. The audience chuckled when he recalled a secret meeting with Czechoslovak and Polish dissidents along the mountainous Polish-Czechoslovak border in 1978. Havel recalled how he and the three Polish dissidents, who now are lawmakers, laughed back then about being able to duck authorities to hold the meeting. ``If someone had told us then that in 12 years we would be deputies, ministers and presidents, then we would have laughed even more,'' Havel said. Earlier, Havel had private talks with Jaruzelski, the only Communist leader not ousted during the wave of revolution that swept the Soviet Union's six East European allies in 1989. With Solidarity's tacit assistance, Jaruzelski was elected president to oversee a stable transition to a fully democratic Poland. Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki visited Prague on Monday in an effort to strengthen Polish-Czechoslovak ties. Polish politicians have argued that the two countries, situated between a powerful Soviet Union and a potentially powerful and reunited Germany, should cooperate to avoid domination by their neighbors. During the 1980s, the Solidarity opposition that now leads Poland's government forged close relations with Czechoslovakia's dissident movement now in power in Prague. But government relations are strained by controversies over environmental issues and restrictions on Poles at Czechoslovak border crossings. In addition, there is a popular tradition of rivalry between Poles and Czechs, neighboring Slavic peoples.

DOC.HEAD: Political Leader Reported Missing; Businessman Exiled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, `At a ...' with 1 graf to ADD background on quote. Pickup 7th pvs, ``Rumors and...''
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A radical political leader was reported missing today, five days after the military government declared a state of siege and arrested, beat and exiled several critics. Rockefeller Guerre, head of the leftist Union of Patriotic Democrats party and an outspoken critic of Haiti's ruler, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, was reported missing by his wife. ``I haven't heard from my husband since Monday, and I am worried because he always told me he would never go into hiding,'' Mrs. Guerre said in an interview. Since declaring a 30-day state of siege Saturday, the military government has arrested and beaten more than 50 political leaders and militants. Most have been released, but five prominent civic and political leaders and two radical militants were exiled to the United States and France. Mrs. Guerre said she believed her husband could have been arrested. She said the house they had lived in before recently moving to the suburbs was plundered Sunday, and several servants were arrested. At a news conference last week, Guerre characterized the Avril government as ``excremental'' after unidentified individuals smeared human excrement on the headquarters of several opposition parties. Rumors and confusion have spread in this city of 1 million and anxiety has risen since all independent radio stations ceased broadcasting local news reports Tuesday after the government told them they could only broadcast officially approved news. Radio is the main source of news in Haiti. Also today, an official of the French Embassy said French Ambassador Jean Raphael Dufour met with Avril on Wednesday to protest the government crackdown. A U.S. Embassy official said Ambassador Alvin Adams met with Avril on Tuesday to discuss American policy toward Haiti. Both officials spoke on the condition of anonymity. In Washington on Wednesday the State Department called the clampdown ``outrageous'' and ``indefensible.'' Antoine Izmery, a major importer, executive member of the Chamber of Commerce and outspoken government critic, became the seventh prominent Haitian to be banished when he was placed aboard a Miami-bound commercial flight Wednesday night. The Chamber of Commerce denounced the crackdown in a statement Wednesday, saying ``Banishment is a crime against humanity.'' The others exiled included prominent conservative Hubert de Ronceray; Dr. Louis Roy, considered the father of Haiti's constitution; Communist Party deputy leader Max Bourjolly; and leftist militants Abby Brun, Michel Legros and Max Montreuil. The state of siege came the day after mystery gunmen killed army Col. Andre Neptune, his wife and a servant. Critics accused Avril of using the assassination as a pretext to crack down on the opposition and renege on promises to hold free elections in October. Haiti's 10 bishops met this morning in the capital to discuss the crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Electronic Darkroom to Become AP's Basic Photo Receiver
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press announced Thursday that it is switching to electronic darkrooms as its basic photo receivers, accelerating the conversion of the nation's newspapers to PhotoStream, AP's picture-a-minute digital photo delivery highway. In the third quarter of this year, AP will begin replacing LaserPhoto receivers at 950 newspapers that receive AP photos with the AP Leaf Picture Desk, a microprocessor-based electronic darkroom developed by AP and Leaf Systems of Natick, Mass., said Louis D. Boccardi, AP president and general manager. ``This is a major step into the electronic future, for us and for our newspaper members,'' Boccardi said. ``This revolutionizes picture handling. The darkroom enormously improves photo reproduction quality and opens the door to production efficiencies and ultimately pagination of pictures in the nation's newspapers.'' He said that installation of the darkrooms would be done by region and would take two years from the start of the project. AP announced plans for PhotoStream in 1987 and has tested aspects of the high-speed digital collection and delivery system at newspapers during the past year. A prototype transmitted photos from the World Series and the Malta summit and will be used at the Super Bowl. The PhotoStream delivery network incorporates a high-capacity satellite circuit and digital technology. AP's present LaserPhoto delivery system transmits black and white photos in nine minutes and color in 30 minutes. PhotoStream transmits black and white in less than one minute and color in less than three. AP's original PhotoStream plans called for replacement of the current nine-minute AP LaserPhoto receiver with a two-minute receiver. Newspapers who wished to buy darkrooms could have done so. ``As the AP experimented further with electronic darkrooms, it became clear that we should opt for the technology of the future, not an updated version of the technology of the past,'' Boccardi said. John Reid, AP vice president and director of communications and technology, said that PhotoStream subscribers will have the option of receiving an expanded photo report or the same report they receive today. The PhotoStream report also will provide more color and a greater selection of photos. If a paper chooses, it can buy the AP VAX Picture Desk, a system that incorporates Digital Equipment Corporation's VAX computer technology. Both the AP Leaf Picture Desk and the AP VAX Picture Desk include a disk storage device with the capacity for hundreds of images and a terminal with monitor and keyboard. The electronic darkrooms will work with virtually all conventional scanning and screening devices and will have the capability, with additional hardware, of receiving the newspaper's local pictures. Each system is fast and easy to use, can handle analog and digital reception and can operate as a single workstation or be expanded _ with newspaper-purchased options _ to a network of editing stations. Storage and ports are also easily expandable with newspaper-purchased options. Both systems have output capability for both receivers and pagination systems, Reid said. If a newspaper does not want an electronic darkroom, AP will install its new two-minute LaserPhoto receiver. The newspaper also will have the option of purchasing a darkroom other than the AP Leaf or AP VAX Picture Desks. ``We have a flexible system here,'' said Hal Buell, AP assistant general manager for NewsPhotos. ``It will fit the kind of picture handling arrangement that individual newspapers want. ``AP's decision to use the electronic darkroom as its basic photo receiver opens the door to the world of electronic picture handling for our members,'' Buell said. The relationship between AP and Leaf Systems began in 1988 when AP helped develop and became the exclusive distributor of the AP Leafax 35, a portable negative transmitter. The two companies decided recently to collaborate on the AP Leaf Picture Desk. The two companies also recently agreed to provide the AP Leafspooler, which allows a photographer to store and transmit pictures that have been processed in the AP Leafax 35.

DOC.HEAD: ABC's `Good Morning America' Scores Third Straight Victory
DOC.TEXT: For the third consecutive week, ABC`s ``Good Morning America'' last week beat NBC's ``Today'' show in ratings, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates released Thursday. In what has become a tight morning-show battle since Jane Pauley left as co-host of ``Today'' last month, ABC's show averaged a 4.4 rating, ``Today'' a 3.9, and ``CBS This Morning'' a 2.5. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. An ABC spokeswoman said the victory of ``Good Morning America'' was the first time the show had won three consecutive weeks since fall of 1987. But a ``Today'' spokeswoman expressed optimism that NBC's show would again be No. 1, saying ``it's only a matter of time.'' On Monday, NBC's program will get a new executive producer, Tom Capra. He is the former news director of NBC-owned KNBC-TV in Burbank, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: 24 Injured in Windstorm, Possibly a Tornado
DOC.TEXT: A windstorm struck two sleeping communities before dawn today and injured at least 24 people, including a boy pulled from the wreckage by a passer-by who witnesses said lifted a corner of a mobile home. David Coggins, county Emergency Management Agency director, said the violent winds, described by some as a tornado, hit trailer communities at Centenary and Fuller's Crossroads, some 40 miles from Montgomery, about 5:30 a.m. About a dozen trailer homes at Centenary were torn from cinder block foundations or ripped open. Furniture, clothes, food, dolls and insulation were strewn about. All the reported injuries were at Centenary. ``We had to take wreckers and pull off the mobile homes to get people out,'' Coggins said. Everyone apparently was accounted for, he said. Lee Helms, state operations manager for the Alabama emergency office, said the damage appeared to have been caused by a tornado. No tornado showed up on radar, but that is not unusual with such thunderstorms, he said. Nancy Williams, a spokeswoman for Crenshaw County hospital, said three children among the 24 injured suffered serious head injuries and were transferred to a Montgomery hospital. Michael Wells, 31, was credited with rescuing several of the injured, including a boy pinned under a trailer. Witnesses said Wells lifted the trailer corner by himself. ``The boy was screaming and his head was bloody,'' said Wells, who was hospitalized for a back injury. ``I picked it up but I don't know how. I had to do it. Somebody had to help.'' John Lee, administrator for Crenshaw County Hospital, said Wells was ``instrumental in pulling several of the people out. After he pulled them out, he collapsed.'' Wells said he had planned to return to his hometown of Racine, Wis., this week after working in Alabama for several months. He said he was walking between two trailers when a tornado hit. ``I saw it coming and the trailers just started rolling like toys,'' he said. Searching for the trapped victims, he said, ``all I could do was tell the to scream so I could find them, it was so dark.''

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Many Older Americans Want Work and They're Not That Picky
DOC.TEXT: More than 1.9 million older Americans wish they were back in the work force, and they aren't just interested in ``cushy'' jobs where they can pick their hours and name their pay, a private group reported Thursday. The Commonwealth Fund, a philanthropic foundation, said a national survey of Americans ages 50-64 found there is an available labor pool of older people that is far larger, more qualified, more flexible and more committed than previously believed. ``This untapped older labor force could be one very important answer to the future labor shortage,'' said Thomas W. Moloney, senior vice president of the foundation. ``What we see here are capable, educated, experienced people who want to get back in.'' Moloney said the report should help dispel the conventional wisdom among employers that most older Americans want only ``cushy jobs'' and that there are few qualified workers in the group who have realistic job expectations. The findings are based on a 1989 national survey by Louis Harris and Associates Inc. of 1,751 men aged 55-64 and 1,758 women aged 50-59. The different age groups for men and women were selected to catch them at the times when people traditionally drop out of the work force. The results were analyzed for The Commonwealth Fund by ICF Inc., a Washington consulting firm, which concluded that 1.9 million older Americans, about 24 percent of non-workers in the surveyed age groups, say they are able and willing to go back to work. ICF identified 1.1 million of these people as highly committed to rejoining the labor force. These people said they need a job for financial reasons, are physically able to do key tasks such as driving or using a calculator, are seeking work and have reasonable wage expectations, are willing to work under difficult conditions, and are willing to take jobs that are in demand such as sales, word processing, clerical positions, day care and managerial posts. These retirees had education, job skills and experience largely comparable to those of their counterparts still in the work force, the poll found. Seventy-five percent were high school or college graduates, compared to 85 percent of those still working. Sixty-four percent had five or more years of experience on their last job, compared to 77 percent of current older workers. On the subject of work conditions, 83 percent were willing to take seasonal jobs, 60 percent would work standing up, 73 percent would work alone, 60 percent would commute more than 30 minutes and 54 percent would work evenings and weekends. Moloney said the polling data has not yet been fully analyzed to determine why these people left the work force before age 65, but preliminary results indicate many were forced out of their jobs.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 11 Injured by Lightning
DOC.TEXT: Lightning injured at least 11 people trying to push snowbound cars from a factory parking lot this morning, authorities said. At least two people were reported in serious condition. ``The bolt hit a telephone pole next to the plant. It conducted itself through the snow,'' said Art Beck, president of Precision Twist Drill Co. in this Chicago suburb. ``There were sparks coming through their fingers.'' At the time, workers were trying to help overnight employees leave by freeing their cars from six inches of newly fallen snow. The lightning was part of a storm that blasted northern Illinois with rain, heavy snow and high winds this morning. Police said 11 people were taken to hospitals. Four were treated for cardiac problems, said Carol Weisbruch, community service police officer. Tia Zeek, a spokeswoman for Memorial Hospital in Woodstock, said three victims were in good condition and two others were admitted for observation. At Northern Illinois Medical Center in McHenry, two people were admitted in serious condition, said spokeswoman Judith Irwin. Two others were in the emergency room, one under observation and the other in fair condition, she said. Dan McCullen, director of human resources at Precision Twist, which manufactures high-speed drill bits, said he was in the building at the time of the strike. ``It scared the living daylights out of me,'' he said. Some of the injured complained of tingling in their necks and hands, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Kills 18 People in Britain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with higher death count, other details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A ferocious storm with winds reaching 90 mph lashed Britain today, killing at least 18 people, paralyzing rail and air transportation and leaving highways littered with overturned cars, police said. All British Rail stations in London were closed except for Victoria Station, Scotland Yard said. The few trains operating in southern England were restricted to 20 mph, British Rail said. Several highways, including the six-lane M25 freeway circling the capital, were blocked by overturned trucks, and service on two subways lines was disrupted by fallen tree limbs. Scottish police warned motorists to stay off the roads if possible. The dead included two children killed when the storm severely damaged their schools _ one near Bristol in western England and the other near Swindon, 70 miles west of London. Several deaths were caused by tree limbs crashing down on cars, and two men working on the restoration of a 17th century house at Uppark were killed when scaffolding was knocked down, according to Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. British Airways suspended flights from Heathrow airport this afternoon. At Gatwick airport south of London, a spokeswoman said only four flights had been affected. She said winds at Gatwick were clocked at 70 mph. Ferry service across the English Channel was suspended, according to the Coast Guard office at Dover. An estimated 250,000 residents of western England were reported without electric power. Thames Valley police reported that at least 16 trucks had overturned on the M4 motorway west of London. ``The motorway has basically closed itself,'' a police spokesman said. ``How anyone considers themselves to be a professional driver can drive ... in this weather _ we have had reports of some going along on two wheels _ there is only one word for it: lunatic'' said the Thames Valley spokesman, who spoke on condition of not being identified. The central lobby of the House of Commons was closed briefly after the wind dislodged a piece of masonry from the exterior, but no injuries were reported. A 36-seat plane owned by Capital Airlines was knocked over on to a wing by a gust at Lulsgate Airport near Bristol in western England, airport authorities said. The plane had just discharged its passengers, and the three crew members still on board were not injured. The airport was closed to traffic this afternoon because of high winds. London to Devon and Cornwall in southwestern England were canceled after 10 a.m., and a number of trains were on the London to Cambridge line. Winds shattered a window at a school near Southampton, and four students were treated for deep cuts. Three people died in an auto accident Wednesday night in Scotland, where five inches of snow fell.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Jets Raid Palestinian Bases, 1 Killed, 3 Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Israeli comment. Pickup 4th pvs, `The bases...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli planes attacked bases belonging to three Palestinian guerrilla groups in south Lebanon today, apparently in retaliation for the killing of an Israeli colonel in a guerrilla ambush, police said. Police, speaking on condition of anonymity, said one man was killed and three people were wounded. Four jets fired 16 rockets in two attacks on bases of the Fatah-Revolutionary Council, the Palestine Liberation Front, and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. In Jerusalem, Israeli officials confirmed only an attack on a base of the Fatah-Revolutionary Council. The military command said in a statement that all Israeli jets returned safely to their bases. The bases, about 10 miles east of the port city of Sidon, are in Kfar Jarra, the Majdalyoun Valley and Mrah el-Hbas. All are near villages controlled by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army. The Fatah-Revolutionary Council is led by terrorist Abu Nidal, the Palestinian Liberation Front is headed by Talaat Yacoub, and the Popular Front is led by George Habash. An official of the the pro-Syrian, Marxist Palestine Liberation Front said the dead man belonged to his group. An official of Fatah-Revolutionary Council said that group suffered no casualities. ``We vacated our bases Sunday in anticipation of an Israeli attack after the heroic operation at Yaroun,'' the official said. The raid came five days after guerrillas shot and killed Col. Yitzhak Rahimov in Yaroun, a city in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone. He was the highest-ranking Israeli officer to be killed in Lebanon since Israel withdrew the bulk of its forces in 1985. Fatah-Revolutionary Council claimed responsibilty for the attack at the village of Yaron, one mile north of the international border. Abu Nidal split with Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1973. He has been blamed for numerous terrorist attacks in Europe and the Middle East. The raid was Israel's third on Lebanon this year. At least seven people were killed and 18 wounded on Friday in two raids by Israel against bases of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah and a Palestinian radio station.

DOC.HEAD: Ireland vs. Hungary in a New York City Bar
DOC.TEXT: On Halloween night 1988, a man with a broken nose strolled into a Greek restaurant and ordered a glass of red wine and a fish dinner. ``I just killed a couple of guys,'' he remarked between bites. ``The police are coming to get me soon.'' Andreas Doczy, 51, was not kidding. In a saloon up the street, Seamus and Padraig Folan, brothers who came to America searching for opportunity, had instead found sudden, irrational, violent death. ``There was an argument over the old country,'' Doczy told the police. Testimony at his murder trial, which is in its second week, helps explain how the Folans died, but not why. The Folans _ Seamus, 38, and Padraig, 27 _ came to New York looking for work. Their native Connemara, a rocky stretch of western Ireland, has exported its young men and women for more than 150 years. The Folans were two of 11 children, 10 of whom came to the United States in the last decade as the Irish economy sagged. They found jobs as construction workers and moved into apartments in Queens and the Bronx. Andreas Doczy was from Hungary. He was one of the few members of his family to survive as the Eastern Front moved rapidly west at the end of World War II, and he fled during the anti-communist uprising in 1956 that was crushed by Soviet tanks. He later joined the U.S. Air Force and served for five years, then started his own business. His lawyer describes him as ``very much a Cold War guy.'' All of which may or may not help explain what happened that Halloween night at McGrath's Bar in Astoria, a working class section of Queens. James Gasiorowski, a former policeman, was tending bar. There were about 10 regulars around, including Doczy and the Folans, who were drinking with a man named Tommy Hughes. The bartender testified last week that the Folans and Hughes were sitting at the end of the bar when Doczy walked over. ``All of a sudden they started arguing with each other. The Folan Brothers told Andy to leave them alone. ... I went over and told them to stop arguing.'' Doczy went to his seat, but soon he was back and the argument renewed. The topics apparently included soccer and the relative merits of Hungary and Ireland. There was a lot of cursing, and Gasiorowski heard Doczy yell something about ``drunken Irish.'' The brothers responded in kind. ``Witnesses say the word `communist' was being thrown around pretty liberally,'' said Richard Piperno, a spokesman for the Queens district attorney. Ireland landed the first blow when Padraig Folan punched the smaller Doczy in the nose, knocking him down; then Seamus kicked him twice in the ribs. The bartender broke up the fight. ``I asked Andy if he was OK,'' Gasiorowski testified. ``He said he was OK and went over to his drink and he said, `I'm going to blow those guys away.''' Doczy walked out, went home and came back about a half-hour later. Hughes had left, but the Folans were still drinking. Doczy went over to them, there was more arguing, and Doczy pulled out a .32-caliber revolver and shot Seamus in the back of the head. Then he turned and shot Padraig. Before he walked out, Doczy remarked: ``I know, I know I'm going to jail.'' Doczy's lawyer last week told jurors that his client did not know he had done wrong: ``You will acquit the defendant by reason of mental disease or defect.'' To the Folans' sister Ann, the insanity defense offered little consolation. ``What happened has changed my attitude about this country,'' she told the Daily News last week. ``It's very hard to get the anger out of you. You keep looking for answers where there are no answers.''

DOC.HEAD: Barge Collision Spills Gas, Diesel into Mississippi River
DOC.TEXT: Two tugboats moving 33 barges collided in the dark on the Mississippi today, spilling more than 160,000 gallons of gasoline and diesel fuel near intakes for public water systems, authorities said. Coast Guard spokesman Lt. Ken Keane said the fuel spilled from two barges, which were still leaking shortly before noon. The Orleans and Jefferson parish water systems said they were checking water quality at the intakes. ``We're not having any problem with drinking water on either side right now,'' said David Mancuso of the Jefferson water system. The tugs _ a 25-barge vessel carrying coal and an eight-barge one moving fuel _ were going in opposite directions when the collision occurred near the Huey P. Long Bridge outside New Orleans, Keane said. It was not immediately clear how the accident occurred, he said. ``We just have two that have holes in them,'' he said. ``There's no doubt there were others damaged.'' The owner of the leaking barges estimated that 84,000 gallons of fuel spilled from each vessel. The Coast Guard instructed barge crews to use their booms to contain the diesel and to leave the gasoline alone, because containing gasoline into a pocket creates a fire hazard, Keane said. He noted gasoline evaporates quickly. Keane said that diesel is poisonous to fish and other wildlife but that any fuel not contained would be diluted quickly in the Mississippi's swift current. The leaking barges were owned by Chotin Transportation of Cincinnati. Chotin Vice President Stephen Frasher said the company was investigating the spill.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Shrinking Some Overnight Delivery Areas
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service is shrinking the areas in which it promises overnight and second-day mail delivery, aiming to provide what it hopes will be more consistent service. Postmaster General Anthony Frank says what customers want most is dependability: ``Just tell me how many days ahead I have to mail my mother's birthday card.'' By concentrating its resources on smaller areas, the agency hopes to better keep its delivery promises, explained Frank. And to keep them honest, the agency is hiring an outside firm to measure its performance and report the results publicly. The effort to make service more consistent comes just two months before the Postal Service is expected to apply for a rate increase to take effect in 1991. The more concentrated service was tested on New York City over the past year with only one complaint, Frank added. Similar plans will be instituted across the nation between June and the end of the year, he said. ``We've already done 29,000 interviews with the public,'' said Frank of the research that led to planned changes in delivery. The biggest complaint? Inconsistent service. Sometimes a letter mailed across town would arrive overnight, sometimes the second day. Sometimes it took a week. People said they want consistent delivery, Frank explained. They know when their check or magazine or other regular mail is sent, and they want to be confident of when it will arrive. ``Just tell me how many days ahead I have to mail my mother's birthday card ... just tell me, I want to be sure it's there,'' Frank quoted as a typical complaint. Second, he said, was that people want their mail delivered at the same time every day. ``I wouldn't have guessed that that would be No. 2,'' he added. ``They don't want to go out there and see it empty.'' ``And the third thing they say is they want local mail delivered overnight,'' he said. In general, the changes mean that areas where the Postal Service promises overnight delivery will shrink somewhat. Two-thirds of all mail is local and will not be affected by the changes, Frank said. In general, he said, between 5 percent and 8 percent of mail might be changed from overnight to second day, or from second day to third day delivery. Currently the postal service manages to deliver about 95 percent of its overnight mail on time, but ``doesn't even come close'' to 95 percent for mail it tries to deliver on the second or third day, Frank said. Following the New York City tests, Frank said local and regional postal officials are developing plans for new delivery areas. They will seek comment and suggestions from postal customers and the changes are expected to take place starting in the summer. Nevertheless, some critics have complained that mail delivery will be slowed by the changes, with consumer advocate Ralph Nader charging that mail standards are deteriorating. From Frank's point of view, the standards were simply out of date and in need of reconsideration. The areas designated to receive overnight and second day delivery were set in 1971, Frank explained. Things have changed since then _ roads are more crowded, space is tighter on airlines and population patterns have shifted. When postal officials began asking customers how large an area they thought should have overnight delivery, it always turned out to be less than what the agency was trying to provide, he added. In some areas the agency has been stretching itself to serve a relatively few customers. For example, every day the Postal Service averages 200 letters between Gainesville, Fla., and Albany, Ga. ``They're 190 miles apart. We give them overnight service,'' said Frank. Trying to maintain service like that strains resources. On the other hand, Frank said some overnight delivery areas should be expanded. For example, Nashua, N.H., is now designated for second day delivery from Boston and Frank thinks it should be overnight. In general, Frank said, he expects to keep overnight delivery for cities, with second day delivery aimed at the area within a state and to adjacent states and third day for the balance of the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Escapee Who Allegedly Cashed Actor's Checks Recaptured
DOC.TEXT: A federal prison escapee has been captured in Florida after living on the lam for more than a year by allegedly cashing stolen checks, including some from actor Burt Reynolds. Richard N. Barefoot, 36, was arrested Wednesday at a motel in Fort Lauderdale. He also had been arrested in August by police in Jacksonville, Fla., but escaped. ``This time he's staying in federal custody until we're done with him,'' said Deputy U.S. Marshal Jennie S. Gower, the Indianapolis case agent. Barefoot, a convicted forger and mail thief, was serving a 10-year sentence at the Federal Prison Camp at Terre Haute when he escaped in September 1988. Investigators believe Barefoot, whose criminal record dates from 1971, collected more than $165,000 in the 16 months after his escape by forging checks in the Carolinas, Georgia and Florida. In seven Florida cities alone, Barefoot allegedly stole $125,000, including an unspecified sum he obtained with checks belonging to Reynolds, who lives in Jupiter, Fla. Jennie Gower, Deputy U.S. Marshall, said Barefoot acquired the checks by driving through affluent residential areas and pulling checks sent by banks from mailboxes. To cash the checks, he obtained several Florida driver's licenses, Gower said.

DOC.HEAD: Fate of Refugees Entwined with U.S.-British Dispute
DOC.TEXT: An international meeting has ended in disarray, and the fate of thousands of Vietnamese refugees hangs on a dispute between the United States and Britain over whether they should be sent home against their will. The 30-nation conference on refugees adjourned Wednesday after U.S. officials insisted no Vietnamese be forced to return home before Jan. 1, 1991. That blocked consensus on a proposed starting date of July 1. After only 10 days in office, the U.N. high commissioner for refugees has been thrust into the argument. Thorvald Stoltenberg, a former Norwegian foreign minister, has the task of negotiating with both on a starting date for mandatory repatriation of Vietnamese who do not qualify for refugee status in Hong Kong, a British crown colony. The U.N. refugee office had proposed the six-month suspension of repatriations as a compromise between U.S. demands and Britain's argument that only immediate deportations would deter another mass influx of boat people to the overcrowded colony. Britain returned 51 Vietnamese to their Communist homeland in December under an agreement reached with Vietnam last year. ``There is no objective justification for a delay in mandatory repatriation, but in the interests of consensus we were prepared to agree on a moratorium,'' said Robin McLaren, head of the British delegation. Although the two-day meeting ended without agreement, it marked the first international consensus that Vietnamese deemed to have fled for economic rather than political reasons should be returned even against their will. ``We do have agreement on mandatory repatriation,'' McLaren told reporters. ``What we don't have is a date.'' The United States relaxed its opposition to forced repatriations and told the meeting it would not block international consensus on forcible return of economic refugees, according to sources present at closed session. For the first time at an international gathering, Vietnam also agreed to take back thousands of the emigrants as part of a U.N.-supported program. It said none should arrive before Oct. 1, however, to allow time for preparations to absorb them into a struggling economy. The U.N. refugee agency, which has opposed forcible repatriations, said it would help monitor those deported to Vietnam if agreement was reached in Geneva. McLaren, the British delegate, was clearly annoyed by the U.S. refusal to compromise despite support for the six-month moratorium by all the other nations except Vietnam. He said the Bush administration should rethink its policy on timing and said he expected Stoltenberg to ``take soundings'' of of the U.S. view by the end of next wek. An apparent contradiction in U.S. policy complicates the matter. Although U.S. delegates softened the stance, Washington's officially opposes forcible return. ``I want to emphasize that the United States position on involuntary repatriation has not changed,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington. ``The United States remains opposed, in principle and in practice, to involuntary repatriation.'' McLaren said lack of an international agreement would not deter Britain from returning boat people under last year's agreement with Vietnam. Geoffrey Barnes, security chief of Hong Kong, told the delegates Hong Kong could not cope with another influx of 35,000 people, the number that arrived in 1989, and spoke of growing pressure to push refugee boats back out to sea. About 109,000 boat people are in camps in Hong Kong, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines, according to U.N. figures. Slightly more than half, or 56,000, are in Hong Kong. The 12,000 who arrived before June 1988 were granted refugee status automatically, but the others are being to determine whether they are politial refugees. The U.N. agency has said about 7,000 people have been screened in Hong Kong and 85 percent of these were classified as economic migrants. About 1,100 people have returned to Vietnam voluntarily since March 1989 and 1,400 more are registered to do so. Each person who returns voluntarily receives the equivalent of $50 from the U.N. agency and qualifies for a year's food aid from the Vietnamese government. In pressing for postponement of mandatory repatriation until next year, the United States argued that the voluntary program needed more time to work.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Seeking More Search Warrants In Mail Bomb Investigation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with O'Ferrell hiring lawyer, no more cooperation, divers search pond. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XEN1
DOC.TEXT: A junk dealer under suspicion in two mail bomb slayings hired a lawyer today and stopped cooperating with authorities. FBI divers, meanwhile, began dredging a pond near his home. Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, who promised cooperation with the FBI while it searched his home and business this week, hired lawyer Paul Harden of Evergreen, who today signaled an end to the open-door policy. ``I'm afraid he's been very cooperative and it concerns me,'' said Harden, who described himself as a long-time friend of the O'Ferrell family. O'Ferrell, 46, has been questioned in the December bombing deaths of a federal appeals judge near Birmingham and a civil rights lawyer in Georgia. Harden spoke with reporters after divers began dredging a pond, about 15 acres in size, across a road from O'Ferrell's home. It was not known what investigators were seeking, although in recent days their search focused on a typewriter. Federal agents spent much of the week going through O'Ferrell's home and business before loading boxes from the business into a truck Wednesday. They pumped out the warehouse septic tank and emptied the septic tank beside his home. They also took hair samples from some of O'Ferrell's relatives. Federal sources speaking on condition of anonymity have confirmed O'Ferrell is a suspect in the slayings of 11th U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance and Robert Robinson, a black laywer from Savannah, Ga. The FBI previously said they believed one or more white supremacists were responsible for mailing bombs to the victims. Federal sources have said polygraph tests administered this week on O'Ferrell indicated he was being untruthful in some instances. But O'Ferrell said: ``I have not been told I am a suspect and I have not been told I failed a lie detector.'' Polygraph results are not always reliable and are inadmissable in criminal trials. Authorities have said they were looking for a typewriter O'Ferrell used to write a letter to the 11th Circuit in 1988. The typewriting in that letter matched that in letters claiming responsibility for the bombings, sources said. O'Ferrell wrote to the court concerning a lawsuit against his former employer, Gulf Life Insurance Co., and said the U.S. court system ``is corrupt.'' But none of his court documents mention racial topics. Last year, a panel on which Vance served ruled against O'Ferrell in that case. O'Ferrell said there were about a half-dozen typewriters at his warehouse, but he denied that authorities had found anything linking him to the case. He said he hoped the FBI would leave him alone.

DOC.HEAD: Comedian Says He's Happy, Angry Over Mayor's Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Former comedian Dick Gregory says he is both happy and angry about the FBI sting that brought the arrest of his friend, Washington Mayor Marion Barry, on drug charges last week. Gregory told the Governor's Forum on Narcotics Control and Drug Abuse here Wednesday that he is happy that ``help is on the way'' for Barry, whom he called an alcoholic. Barry's closest friends ``were tickled to death'' to see the mayor had decided to seek help, said Gregory, a onetime comedian who has been involved in civil rights and anti-drug causes. He said he has been a friend of Barry's for 20 years and that Barry has been an alcoholic at least that long. At the same time, Gregory said he is angry that the federal government has spent so much time and effort trying to get Barry. ``We, in the black community, think it's racist,'' Gregory said. ``The FBI spent $40 million and 12 years to get a user, and not a pusher,'' Gregory said. ``I would feel the same way if it was the head of the Ku Klux Klan (who had been arrested).'' Gregory said he and Barry were together in Miami six weeks ago and he told Barry, ``Man, they're going to get you.'' Barry was arrested on a charge of cocaine possession last week, and announced Sunday he was taking unspecified steps to ``heal my body, mind and soul.'' He has since entered a substance-abuse clinic in Florida. Though he was arrested on illegal drug charge, Barry's spokeswoman, Lurma Rackley, said ``the most serious problem is alcoholism.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Makes Belly Landing; No One Hurt
DOC.TEXT: A commuter plane with 11 people aboard made a spark-throwing belly landing at Raleigh-Durham Airport after its wheels get stuck. No one was hurt. The tws and the fuselage of the Fairchild Metro II, which seats 19. ``It was a little uncomfortable but a first-class job by the flight crew,'' said passenger Jeff Eldridge, 34, of Stratford, Conn. ``It's not something anyone wants to experience again.'' The accident is under investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board. American Eagle is a commuter carrier affiliated with American Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Fewer Firecrackers for Chinese New Year
DOC.TEXT: The bang is gradually going out of Chinese New Year as authorities in Beijing cut the capital's firecracker supply for the third straight year and similar measures are being adopted in other cities. Traditionally, the Chinese greet the Lunar New Year, which this year falls on Saturday, with a long, deafening roar of firecrackers, which are supposed to drive off evil spirits. But this year, roadside stalls doing a brisk business in firecracker sales are conspicuously absent from the capital. The official People's Daily this week reported a 23 percent decrease in Beijing's firecracker supply from last year, although more than 1 billion fireworks are expected to be sold. Shanghai, China's largest city, adopted firecracker regulations last year that include a two-fifths reduction in this year's firecracker sales. Ma Zhengjia, director of the Beijing Public Security Bureau's foreign affairs office, said Thursday that regulations on the sale, transport and shooting off of firecrackers were enacted in 1986 to try to reduce the number of deaths, injuries and fires caused by firecrackers each Lunar New Year, or Spring Festival, as the holiday is called in mainland China. In 1987, 251 people in Beijing were killed or injured by firecrackers, but the following year the figure was down to 26, he said, adding that the number of fires went down from 224 in 1987 to 22 last year. But authorities this year may be more concerned about controlling the holiday celebrations after hundreds of thousands of disenchanted Chinese took to the streets last spring calling for democracy and other changes. Martial law imposed in May was lifted only two weeks ago. As before, bans have been placed on setting off firecrackers at Tiananmen Square, site of last spring's pro-democracy protests, and other public places that draw crowds, including the railway station and airport. But the number of restricted areas _ 610 _ is nearly double what it was two years ago. Ma insisted there was no connection between the regulations, which he said were longstanding, and last year's pro-democracy movement, which was crushed by troops who entered the city, killing hundreds and perhaps thousands of people. ``It has nothing to do with June 3,'' he said, referring to the night the army marched into Beijing. ``As you can see for yourself, our society is very stable right now. The masses are happily preparing for the holiday, the markets are abundently stocked with whatever you want to buy,'' Ma said. Store shelves in Beijing still were well-stocked Thursday, two days before the new year. One little boy, just tall enough to see over the counter, stood with his nose pressed to the glass case trying to decide whether to get pretty fireworks like the ``flash of lightning'' or ``two kicks of the feet'' or the traditional strings of red firecrackers that his father impatiently told him to choose. The cheapest were 3-foot-long sparklers that went for about 3 cents. There were $2 bags of colorful animals and other toys that run in circles while spraying colorful sparks when lighted. The most expensive were strings of 1,000 firecrackers that cost about $2.30 to $3.20. Buyers unhesitatingly paid between $4 and $6, and some said they planned to buy more. ``I'm buying these for my two daughters,'' said a man in his 30s after asking the clerk to show him fireworks ``appropriate for little girls.''

DOC.HEAD: Actress Kim Basinger Buys a Town in Georgia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS next-to-last graf to CORRECT to grandfather sted father.
DOC.TEXT: Kim Basinger welcomes you to visit Braselton, the town she bought with the help of ``Batman.'' ``It's a perfect place for filming,'' the actress said after signing papers Wednesday night in Atlanta to close the transaction that gives her most of Braselton, a northeastern Georgoia town of 500 people. Miss Basinger, whose movies include the blockbuster ``Batman,'' said she hopes to use some of the 1,728 acres for which she paid $20 million to build a ``major film studio'' and a ``major recording studio,'' perhaps the biggest on the East Coast and maybe even the biggest in the world. But she also has promised to keep a flavor of the old-time South. ``I have always dreamed that I would play a major role in preserving a small rural Georgia town similar to the town where my grandparents lived,'' said Miss Basinger, who attended high school in nearby Athens. ``This is God's little 1,800 acres,'' she said with a chuckle. It was that kind of thinking that encouraged the Braselton family _ which has owned most of the town for more than 110 years _ to sell. ``She stated that she would do well for the community and she would do her best to make everybody love her,'' said H.B. Braselton, co-manager of the family business. ``With her background and publicity, I think (the deal) will put Braselton on the map _ make it a tourist attraction,'' added Harrison W. Braselton. Miss Basinger now owns the community's downtown, its water and sewer systems, a bank, a post office, a manufacturing plant and various retail properties. Her plans include a 671-acre industrial park, 510 acres of commercial and retail development and 547 acres for residential use. The industrial park is adjacent to land where Mitsubishi has invested $36 million for new offices and plants. Henry Edward Braselton, the town's mayor, said he has no intention of leaving the city his grandfather founded in 1876. ``It's an historic day and there's some sadness. You don't do something all your life and change without some sadness,'' he said. ``But we think we did the right thing. We're happy it was Kim who decided to purchase it because she's a local person, being from Athens, and she's real sweet.''

DOC.HEAD: Leader Says US Media Perpetuate Mideast Conflict
DOC.TEXT: The president of North Yemen said today the U.S. news media are perpetuating the Arab-Israeli conflict by failing to report adequately on Israeli abuses in the occupied territies. President Ali Abdullah Saleh told reporters that he is convinced ``objective writing about the situation will mobilize public opinion in support of Palestinian self-determination.'' Unless the Palestinian people achieve this goal, ``peace will be in danger,'' he said, blaming the situation on Israeli intransigence. Saleh, speaking to reporters, denied allegations by Yemeni opposition groups that thousands of his countrymen are being detained and tortured for political reasons and that large numbers of others have been executed. Saleh said there has not been a ``single political prisoner'' in North Yemen since 1983. He invited Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, to visit prisons in his country. ``If they find a single one, they can free him immediately,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Files Suit After School Locks Son in Closet for Three Days
DOC.TEXT: A woman is suing a school district for locking her 13-year-old son in a cafeteria closet for three school days for fighting. Frances Allison said her son, Gary DeWayne Morris, has nightmares and refuses to sleep without a light since the incident last March. She is suing the Elmore City School district and a former principal for $100,000. The lawsuit, filed in December, says the boy was kept in the 4-by-5-foot closet from 8:25 a.m. to 2:45 p.m., that meals were served to him and that he had to urinate in a bottle. ``Imagine what they would have done to me if someone had come to my house and noticed Gary in the closet,'' Ms. Allison said. ``They'd put me in jail and take away my kids.'' Delbert Handke, district superintendent, said today that the boy was allowed out to use the bathroom. He said the incident occurred before he became superintendent. The school district said Ms. Allison consented to an in-house suspension. Ms. Allison said the principal told her such a suspension would occur in a classroom away from other students and would be supervised by a teacher.

DOC.HEAD: Cold War Alive in Asia, Japanese Scholar Says
DOC.TEXT: Despite easing tensions in Europe, a Cold War still exists in Asia, where the United States and the Soviet Union have focused on competing military forces, a Japanese scholar told Congress Thursday. ``We see two products of the Cold War firmly intact: a divided Korea and a divided China,'' said Masashi Nishihara, a professor of international relations at the National Defense Academy of Japan. ``There is little dialogue between the two superpowers about how they can resolve their confrontational force structures,'' he said. Nishihara was one of several scholars from overseas testifying before the Senate Armed Services Committee. The panel is holding a series of hearings of U.S. defense needs in light of the changing Soviet threat. Overall, Nishihara said, the Soviet military poses less of a threat to Japan that in the past, even though Moscow continues to deploy modern ships, aircraft and other weapons in the Pacific region. But he said there remain uncertainties in the region that could cause problems for Japanese and U.S. security, including the possible development of nuclear weapons by North Korea and the steady build-up of the Chinese navy. North Korea does not manufacture nuclear weapons yet although it has built a nuclear reactor that produced plutonium, a material needed for a nation to have a nuclear capability, according to Gary Milhollin of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, a group that monitors the development of nuclear weapons worldwide. ``If they get real close (to making weapons), the South Koreans are going to have to react,'' he said. Nishihara also said Japan should be consulted about any U.S. moves to reduce its defenses in the Pacific. While Japan must strengthen its Self-Defense Forces, he said, he doubted whether the United States, the Japanese public or other Asian countries would support a much-expanded defense role for Japanese forces, he said. The Japanese constitution, adopted during the post-war U.S. occupation, curbed military spending.

DOC.HEAD: Constitution Presented to Constituent Assembly
DOC.TEXT: A democratic, Western-style constitution was formally presented Thursday to the Constituent Assembly, which is expected to approve the document and set a date for independence, probably in March. Unlike most constitutions in Africa, the document sets a limit of two, five-year terms for the president, who is to be chosen through national elections. However, to avoid the need for an immediate election, the first president will be chosen by Parliament. The constitution also says Parliament can impeach the president by a two-thirds vote. It prohibits capital punishment. The first president is expected to be Sam Nujoma, leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization. SWAPO waged a 23-year guerrilla war against South African rule that ended in April. South Africa has ruled Namibia for 75 years, but has agreed to grant independence to the semidesert territory under United Nations supervision. Hage Geingob, a SWAPO official who is chairman of the Constituent Assembly, said the committee that wrote the constitution was ``inspired by a spirit of reconciliation, brother and sisterhood, and commitment to the future of this great country.'' All seven political parties that captured seats in November's elections took part in writing the constitution. The full assembly took no immediate action on the document, but is expected to do so when it meets again on Monday. The document has a declaration of fundamental rights, including freedom of movement, speech and a free press. It also envisions a multiparty democracy, regular elections, an independent judiciary and an executive president. Leftist-oriented SWAPO captured 41 of the 72 seats in the Constituent Assembly during elections in November. But at least 48, or two-thirds, of the assembly members must approve the constitution. The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, a multiracial coalition that favors a capitalist economy, has 21 seats. The remaining 10 seats are divided among five other parties. Despite a hard-fought campaign and major ideological differences, the assembly quickly worked out compromises on the constitution after beginnning work in November. The more than 6,000 U.N. military and civilian personnel in Namibia are scheduled to remain until the end of March. The head of the U.N. contingent, Martti Ahtisaari, has said he expects Namibia to attain independence before the U.N. forces leave. Under the proposed constitution, the Constituent Assembly will be converted into the National Assembly, which will be the dominant chamber of Parliament and have legislative powers. A second chamber, the National Council, will consist of members elected on a regional basis. It will be empowered to review legislation and to refer bills back to the assembly, but it cannot kill bills the assembly approves again.

DOC.HEAD: Ava Gardner Dead at 67
LaserPhotos NY25,26
