DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th pvs, ``Her last...'' with 1 graf to CORRECT TV role to `Knots Landing,' sted `Falcon Crest.' Pickup 6th, `Ms. Gardner...'
DOC.TEXT: Ava Gardner, the farmer's daughter who fled Hollywood for Europe after her stormy life began to match the femme fatale roles she played on screen, died today, a friend said. She was 67. The friend, Paul Mills, told Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, the actress died of pneumonia at her home in Kensington, West London. Ms. Gardner had been ill for some time, Press Association said. She was hospitalized in January 1988 for more than a week with a respiratory problem, and she suffered a stroke in October 1986. Ms. Gardner starred in 60 films, beginning with ``We Were Dancing'' in 1942 and including ``The Snows of Kilimanjaro,'' ``The Barefoot Contessa,'' ``Show Boat,'' ``The Sun Also Rises,'' ``Night of the Iguana,'' and ``The Kidnapping of the President.'' In one of her last roles, she appeared on the CBS-TV series ``Knots Landing'' in 1985. Ms. Gardner moved to London after her third divorce, from Frank Sinatra, in 1957. In an interview in 1982, she said she would happily have traded her career for one happy, long-lasting marriage: ``One good man I could love and marry and cook for and make a home for, who would stick around for the rest of my life.'' ``I never found him,'' she said in the interview with London's Daily Express. She was married to Mickey Rooney, jazz musician Artie Shaw, then Sinatra. ``The trouble was that I was a victim of image,'' she said. ``Because I was promoted as a sort of siren and played all those sexy broads, people made the mistake of thinking I was like that off the screen. ``They couldn't have been more wrong. Although no one believes it, I am pathologically shy. I was a country girl and I still have a country girl's rather simple, ordinary values.'' ``No one ever wanted to know the real me at all,'' the actress said in a 60th birthday interview. ``They preferred the myths _ the roaring lady who smashed champagne glasses and seduced bullfighters.'' Ms. Gardner's reputation as a sex goddess was launched in the 1946 film, ``The Killers,'' co-starring Burt Lancaster. She played a wild Spanish dancer opposite Humphrey Bogart in ``The Barefoot Contessa,'' and a love-hungry, hotel proprietress chasing Richard Burton in Tennessee Williams' ``Night of the Iguana.'' Lancaster said from his Los Angeles home: ``She was a wonderful lady, wonderful lady... She was a very simple lady. She used to come down to the beach with us and cook and play with the kids.'' ``I hope she was happy, that's all,'' he said. ``I think she was the last great beauty,'' said Michael Winner, who directed Ms. Gardner in a horror film, ``The Sentinel,'' in 1977. ``She epitomized to an English lad the glitter and beauty of Hollywood,'' Winner said in England. Ava Lavinia Gardner was born December 24, 1922, the youngest of six children of cotton and tobacco farmer Jonas Gardner. He lost his farm when Ms. Gardner was two and worked as a tenant farmer until giving up and moving the family to Newport News, Va. to work in a sawmill. Ms. Gardner's mother, Mary Elizabeth, operated a boarding house. By the time she was a teen-ager, it was clear that Ava Gardner was an exceptionally attractive woman. When she was 18, she visited her older sister, Bea, in New York. Bea's husband, photographer Larry Tarr, shot dozens of pictures of her. He put one up in his studio. It caught the eye of Barney Dunham, then a clerk in MGM's New York legal deparment. Durnham had Tarr send some pictures to Hollywood, and Ms. Gardner wound up with a screen test and a $50-a-week contract as a starlet. Ms. Gardner posed for cheesecake publicity shots and appeared in bit roles in several movies, such as ``We Were Dancing'' and ``Ghosts on the Loose,'' before her career started to break when she played the seductress in ``The Killers.'' In the days of the Hollywood sex goddess, the auburn-haired, green-eyed actress reigned between Rita Hayworth and Marilyn Monroe. Her first marriage in January, 1942 was to Rooney. He was 21 and at one of several career peaks as the star of the Andy Hardy movies. She was 19, an ingenue under contract to MGM. Rooney took a studio press agent along on their honeymoon. They were divorced after 20 months. She met bandleader Shaw at a Hollywood nightclub, and they were married in October, 1945. Shaw took several books to read on their honeymoon. Ms. Gardner later suffered a nervous breakdown, and the marriage ended a year and a week after it began. Between Shaw and Sinatra, her name was linked to billionaire Howard Hughes. She met Sinatra, whose career was in a slump, during a January 1950 Palm Springs party. Sinatra was married at the time to his childhood sweetheard and wife of 12 years. Sinatra and Gardner were married in Philadelphia on Nov. 2, 1951. Ms. Gardner obtained a divorce from Sinatra in July, 1957, just as she finished making ``The Sun Also Rises.'' In 1958, she announced she was quitting MGM, which brought her to Hollywood in 1941. ``MGM was never the right studio for me. They never bought a property for me; they never knew what to do with me,'' she said. ``Most of the time, they loaned me out.'' Mills said Ms. Gardner's body would be taken to Smithfield, N.C. for burial alongside her parents, according to Press Association.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group: Dispense with Disposables
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group mounted a complaint campaign Thursday against manufacturers of disposable and non-recyclable products, charging that wasteful packaging depletes resources and jams the nation's landfills. The New York Public Interest Research Group published a 20-page guide to what it called the worst of environmentally damaging packaging, listing toll-free telephone numbers of the products' makers and urging calls of complaint. ``Consumers need to send these companies a clear message that they don't want and don't need these so-called convenience items and overpackaged products,'' Steven A. Romalewski, author of the guide, said in an interview. Some of the guide's examples are familiar targets of environmentalist criticism, including disposable diapers, disposable razors, plastic utensils, polystyrene foam packages and so-called degradable plastic bags. It also faults specialized convenience products, such as Eastman Kodak Co.'s Fling disposable camera; Quaker Oats Co.'s Aunt Jemima Pancake Express, with mix for six pancakes and a throwaway plastic mixing bowl; and Heinz U.S.A.'s plastic ketchup bottles. The ketchup bottles are nonrecyclable because they are made of laminated plastic layers that cannot be separated easily. Juice boxes used by more than a half-dozen fruit drink producers pose the same problem because they contain layered plastic, aluminium foil and paper. While ``degradable'' plastic bags have been promoted as a partial solution to the landfill crisis, the guide cited complaints from environmental groups that the bags only break down into smaller plastic particles, which remain in the environment. It also said they may not break down when buried, and could weaken products made from recycled plastic. In interviews, spokesmen for some of the companies criticized by NYPIRG protested that they were squeezed by conflicting environmental concerns on one side and consumer preferences on the other. ``We're between a rock and a hard place,'' said Heinz spokeswoman Beth Adams, because consumers prefer plastic bottles and only laminated plastic is airproof enough to keep ketchup from darkening. She said Heinz, in Pittsburgh, continues to sell glass bottles, but they now make up only about 35 percent of its bottled ketchup sales. The company is searching ``fast and furious'' for a recyclable plastic bottle, she said. Ron Bottrell, at Quaker Oats in Chicago, made a similar argument for Pancake Express, saying the company had to balance ``conflicting concerns'' of environmentalists and of most shoppers. While environment groups want biodegradable packaging, ``consumers are telling us with their dollars that convenience is the driving force in their purchasing habits,'' he said. ``The food company is in the middle.'' At Kodak, in Rochester, spokeswoman Holly Walkland read a letter prepared for customers who complain about the Fling camera, maintaining that it does not contain much more material than a drop-in 110 film cartridge. The letter also said photofinishers dispose of the camera ``in a manner prescribed by local ordinances.'' Walkland added that Kodak was ``actively exploring not just for single-use cameras but for all of our products how they can be recycled.'' NYPIRG's Romalewski said such promises were not enough for his group. ``Especially at a time when industries are trying to cash in on the green decade and this new environmentalism, they can't just try to give the appearance that they're doing good for the environment,'' he said. ``They have to take some tough action.'' His group decided against boycotts because it believes they work only when targeted at a single product, Romalewski said. He said NYPIRG instead hoped to make its point by inspiring complaint calls to the nearly two dozen companies whose products it criticized.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The guide is being distributed to consumer and environmental groups and are available for $3 from NYPIRG, 9 Murray St., New York, N.Y. 10007. (212) 349-6460.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Proposes $1.1 Billion Boost in Drug War Budget
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 17th graf pvs, `We don't,' to UPDATE with Bush comment on legalization; INSERTS 3 grafs after 22nd graf pvs, Also, international, to UPDATE with Biden, Bennett comments
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today proposed a $1.1 billion increase in federal spending for the war on drugs and said he was committed to marshaling ``everything that works'' to combat what he called the nation's No. 1 concern. Bush's $10.6 billion plan designates five regions _ New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Houston and the Southwest border of California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas _ as high-intensity drug trafficking areas eligible for millions of dollars in additional federal help this year and next. ``We want to help them map out a more comprehensive, coordinated approach to fight drugs,'' the president said in a luncheon speech to about 75 newspaper publishers. He said his administration has made progress in battling drugs in the four months since he unveiled an action plan, but added: ``Given the headlines we've seen recently, it's clear we're only getting started.'' He also called on Congress to broaden the definition of drug-related crimes for which the death penalty may be applied. The budget proposal would spend 42 percent of the money for domestic law enforcement, 29 percent for border interdiction and international operations and 29 percent for demand reduction, said John Walters, chief of staff to drug policy director William J. Bennett. ``To those who say our program looks top-heavy on the interdiction side, remember that many of the efforts to limit supply are exclusively federal _ and inherently more expensive than demand reduction,'' Bush said. ``We're willing to spend more to limit the drug supply. Simply put, we're willing to do whatever it takes.'' Bush made the comments as he unveiled what he called ``a blueprint for success,'' a series of proposals that build upon the national drug strategy he announced last Sept. 5. ``We're committed to the same aggressive goals and principles we outlined last September: to reduce use, through an integrated mix of supply- and demand-side approaches. And that means doing everything that works,'' Bush said. He said illegal drugs ``remain this nation's No. 1 concern.'' The president reiterated his earlier call for the death penalty for convicted ``drug kingpins'' responsible for drug-related killings, and, he said, ``even in some cases attempted killings.'' ``We want there to be absolutely no doubt about the certainty of punishment,'' Bush said. The proposal calls for allowing the death penalty for drug kingpins even when they or their organizations have not killed anyone; for drug kingpins who attempt to kill in order to obstruct justice; and for federal drug felons whose offenses result in death, such as a drug user's overdose. Bush also praised efforts by the leaders of Mexico and Colombia in fighting drug traffickers in their countries, said said he would ``reinforce our support for the courageous leaders of the region'' at the upcoming Feb. 15 drug summit in Colombia. Bush vowed to do what it takes to see drug operations ``dismantled and destroyed.'' ``We don't make deals with dealers,'' he said. Asked about arguments in favor of drug legalization, Bush said: ``I just think that it would increase, regrettably the habit and I strongly oppose it. ... I'm just going to hold the line against legalization.'' The updated strategy developed by policy director Bennett emphasizes ``the crucial role'' of state and local governments. To that end, it calls for $2.6 billion in 1991 to be sent to the states for law enforcement, treatment and drug prevention efforts, a 108 percent increase over the past two years. Last September, Bush sought $7.9 billion for the war against drugs in 1990, but Congress increased that to $8.8 billion. The current proposal also is subject to congressional approval. Although $8.8 billion has been the universally recognized figure for the 1990 budget, the new strategy uses new figures that take into account other drug expenditures already being made and says the country is now spending $9.5 billion, Walters said. Overall, criminal justice spending will increase 2 percent to $4.3 billion; treatment goes up 12 percent to $1.5 billion; education-community and workplace funding goes up 11 percent to $1.2 billion. Also, international initiatives shoot up 65 percent to $690 million; interdiction efforts increase 17 percent to $2.4 billion; research hikes 20 percent to $383 million; and intelligence efforts zoom up 142 percent to $172 million. Meanwhile, Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., told the National Conference of Mayors that the administration has placed too much emphasis on casual users and not enough on hard-core addicts. ``It's not that the administration doesn't care about hard-core users _ they do,'' the Judiciary Committee chairman said as he touted his rival, $14.6 billion anti-drug strategy. ``But that is not their main emphasis.'' Bennett told reporters earlier that the administration's plan was in ``90 percent agreement'' with Biden's, and he wouldn't oppose it if Congress decides to add more money for 1991 as it did for 1990. ``I could spend any amount of money on this,'' he said. The Pentagon, long reluctant to enter the drug war, will contribute about $1.2 billion in 1991, with about $638 million of that going for detection and monitoring of traffickers trying to enter the country with illicit drugs, according to the new strategy. Its efforts this year total $878 million. Bruce Carnes, Bennett's budget specialist, said the military drug war budget for 1991 represents the biggest dollar increase proposed in the strategy. It is followed by the Department of Health and Human Services' Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration, whose budget would increase from $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion. That includes almost $577 million in block grant money for drug treatment programs, an increase of $100 million in such grants. The third largest dollar increase is for the Agency for International Development, moving from $48 million to $224 million, much of that for the Andean countries where most of the world's cocaine is produced. The fourth largest increase is for the Drug Enforcement Administration, from $549 million to $700 million in 1991. The designation of the high-intensity drug trafficking areas applies to 1990 as well as 1991, according to Walters. The current budget allocates $25 million for those areas, plus up to $21 million more from the federal asset forfeiture fund, said Reggie Walton, associate director of Bennett's office. And the 1991 budget calls for $50 million for those areas. But Carnes said the areas actually will be receiving a total of $1.2 billion worth of federal efforts this year, and would receive a total of $1.4 billion in 1991, when all other federal programs and grants are included. Most of the help will be in the form of money going to federal agencies who will target those areas, not in checks to the local governments. The strategy listed metropolitan areas and surrounding areas that could be included, as well as the cities in those surrounding areas. The New York City area could include Nassau County in New York and Union, Hudson and Essex counties in New Jersey, it said. Carnes said that area would receive $396 million worth of help in 1990 and $436 million in 1991. Los Angeles could include Los Angeles and Orange counties, and would get $151 million in 1990 and $169 million in 1991. Miami, which could include Broward, Dade and Monroe counties, Fla., could get $196 million in 1990 and $223 million in 1991. Houston, which could include Harris and Galveston counties, Texas, could get $168 million in 1990 and $187 million in 1991. The Southwest border includes 35 counties in California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas, would receive $330 million in 1990 and $368 million in 1991. The total number of federal anti-drug workers targeted to each area is: New York, 250; Los Angeles, 300; Miami, 300; Houston, 200; Southwest border, 700, Carnes said.

DOC.HEAD: Welshman Anthony Hopkins to Direct Play on Dylan Thomas
DOC.TEXT: Anthony Hopkins, in town to film a movie and direct a play, said Thursday he hopes to do more directing in coming years. ``I always want to direct when I'm being directed badly. But unfortunately, I've been working with some very, very good directors these last few years,'' Hopkins said at a news conference in Pittsburgh, where he is filming ``The Silence of Lambs.'' The psychological thriller also stars Jodie Foster. Hopkins is also directing ``Dylan Thomas: Return Journey,'' a one-man show featuring Bob Kingdom based upon the Welsh poet's work, anecdotes and letters. The show makes its American debut Feb. 16 in Pittsburgh after having played to British audiences, then goes on to New York. ``I'd always wanted to play Dylan Thomas myself, being Welsh,'' Hopkins said. ``When I heard Bob Kingdom was doing it, I didn't have any resentment. I thought, `Well, I'm a bit too old to do it now.' I thought, `At least somebody's got up and done it.' '' Hopkins, 52, has appeared in many Shakespeare productions and the films ``War and Peace,'' ``The Bunker'' and ``The Elephant Man.''

DOC.HEAD: Detained Lockheed Employees Freed in Chad
DOC.TEXT: MARIETTA, Ga. AP) _ Three Georgia Lockheed employees detained in the African nation of Chad since Jan. 5 left for the Congo on Thursday and a connecting flight to Paris, a Lockheed spokesman said. The five were to have left Sunday but authorities in Chad delayed them. Lockeed spokesman Dick Martin said they left late this morning EST. They had been detained in a contract dispute with the government involving destruction of a maintenance manual for a new C-130 transport plane the government had purchased from the company, based in Marietta, Ga. The five had been detained at police headquarters in the Chadian capital of N'Djamena from Jan. 5-15 and kept under house arrest at a hotel since then. They are Irving Thrash, Marvin Gambill and Ernest Ruse. The wives of two of the men who accompanied them to Chad also were detained and were freed.

President Bush said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has done a ``remarkable job'' in handling the ethnic unrest in Azerbaijan, and that the Soviet president ``is really the best hope'' for continued peaceful change in the world. ``It's not for some president of the United States to say who he thinks should be in that job but as I look around I think Mr. Gorbachev is really the best hope for what our interests are,'' Bush said in a question and answer session with newspaper publishers at the White House. Gorbachev has sent Soviet troops to Azerbaijan to quell the unrest, and they have been battling local resistance for several days. Bush said he wasn't encouraging the use of force ``because we would like to see peaceful change wherever possible.'' But he said that in the Baltics, Gorbachev ``still is talking peaceful change and I think he's done a remarkable job.'' ``We want to see peaceful change continue. We want to see the democratization of Eastern Europe.'' ``I think he has conducted himself in an extraordinarily difficult situation very well,'' Bush said of Gorbachev. ``He remains committed to peaceful change and I don't think anyone is faulting him for the difficulty he has encountered.'' ``I think Mr. Gorbachev is really the best hope for what our interests are.''

DOC.HEAD: Carol Stuart's Family Announces Scholarship Fund
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Other details ...' to fix typo in `eligibility.'
DOC.TEXT: The family of Carol Stuart, the woman apparently killed by her husband in an attack he blamed on a black mugger, announced a scholarship fund today for residents of the inner-city area where the shooting took place. Marvin Geller, a lawyer for the family, said the case had opened ``old scars of racial tension'' in Boston's racially mixed Mission Hill neighborhood, where police launched a major manhunt for the killer after the shooting. ``The DiMaiti family believes that Carol would not have wanted her death to be remembered as the cause of such divisiveness,'' Geller said. ``(Carol) would not have wanted to be remembered as a victim of a sensational murder.'' The DiMaiti family said it had opened a bank account, and it appealed for donations to the fund. The family's lawyers said they donated $10,000. Other details, such as eligibility requirements and what the scholarships will pay for, were not disclosed. The announcement came at a news conference at which Mrs. Stuart's father made his first public comment since her killing. ``Mere words cannot express the terrible emptiness we feel or how much we miss her now,'' Giusto DiMaiti said. ``All she ever wanted to be was a good daughter, wife and mother.'' Charles Stuart had told police that a black gunman attacked the white couple in their car moments after they left a birthing class Oct. 23. His pleas for help over the couple's car phone directed police to his dying wife. Their son was delivered prematurely by Caesarean section and died 17 days later. Stuart apparently jumped to his death off a bridge Jan. 4 after a brother implicated him in the slaying.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Plans are in the works for Paul McCartney to headline two huge rock concerts for the homeless, but they could be snagged by homeowners' concerns about noise and traffic. The concerts would take place this spring at Memorial Stadium on the campus of the University of California at Berkeley, Mayor Loni Hancock and university spokesman Ray Colvig confirmed Wednesday. The promotion company Bill Graham Presents has promised the city at least $100,000 of the proceeds to help Berkeley's homeless, said Peggy Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Hancock. The university would get a similar amount and divide it between homelessness and classical music projects, said Colvig. UC Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman has yet to approve the concerts, tentatively scheduled March 31 and April 1, but Colvig said he expects a decision soon. Sullivan said city officials must clarify whether the concerts would violate an understanding the university reached with neighborhood associations to bar commercial events at the stadium. With field seating, the stadium's capacity is about 90,000. McCartney has been on his first concert tour in 13 years, often playing hits from his years with the Beatles.

Clint Eastwood, paying tribute to Sergio Leone at a film festival, said one of the joys of working with the late Italian director in the 1960s was that he lacked Hollywood's ingrained self-censorship. ``Sergio was not afraid to attack things that were forbidden,'' Eastwood said. ``For instance, you couldn't show a character getting shot. Sergio didn't know that, so he went ahead and filmed it.'' The two met in 1963, when Eastwood accepted an offer to go to Italy and make ``A Fistful of Dollars,'' a western modeled on Akira Kurosawa's samurai movie, ``Yojimbo.'' The only Italian word Eastwood knew was ``arrivederci'' and the only English Leone knew was ``goodbye,'' the actor told movie buffs Wednesday at the Sundance United States Film Festival. As a result, Eastwood said, ``I just did my own thing and Sergio went along with it.'' One of Leone's trademarks was the extreme close-up, sometimes framing only a subject's eyes. ``Actors love those tight shots,'' said Eastwood, 59. ``But I was younger then. Now I tell them to take the camera back.''

Television comedy star Roseanne Barr caused a brief stir when she and her new husband went shopping for University of Texas sweatshirts and T-shirts during their honeymoon, a newspaper reported. Ms. Barr and Tom Arnold, a longtime friend and comedy writer, were wed at Ms. Barr's Los Angeles home Saturday. The couple were accompanied to the University Co-op store Wednesday by an unidentified young woman, the Austin American-Statesman reported. Ms. Barr has a teen-age daughter whom she gave up for adoption years ago and who lives in Texas, the newspaper said. ``They drove up in a big, black-and-brown stretch limo, parked in front of the store and came in,'' said George Mitchell, University Co-op president. ``He (Arnold) was very jovial. He said, `Hi everyone. Here's Roseanne.''' Publicists for Ms. Barr in Los Angeles did not return phone calls Thursday seeking information about her honeymoon itinerary.

Randy Owen, lead singer for the country group Alabama, says that when he shows the cattle he raises, livestock judges don't seem to give his entries equal consideration. ``Many don't take us seriously,'' Owen said. ``They think I'm doing this as a hobby.'' Owen, whose cattle were competing this week in the prestigious Southwestern Exposition and Livestock Show and Rodeo, said he was raised a cowboy. ``I couldn't afford to show cattle when I was growing up, but now that I've got a chance, I make a point of trying to make it to shows we are in,'' he said. The 40-year-old Owen's polled Hereford heifers didn't win any major prize money or award ribbons on Wednesday.
DOC.NOTE: For release at 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Loretta Young starred in dozens of films and won an Oscar for ``The Farmer's Daughter'' in 1947. But success didn't come easily, she recalled in a recent interview. Her father abandoned her at the age of 3, but she was acting as an extra by age 4, and had her first starring role at 13. She didn't attend school past the age of 12, she told Parade magazine for its issue to be distributed Sunday. ``I hated school. One of the reasons was a learning disability, dyslexia, which no one understood at the time,'' said Young, 76. ``I still can't spell, because I see some of the letters backward. ``They had a tutor at the studio for me. Didn't teach me anything, but I learned to be on time and to know my dialogue and to do what the director told me.''

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Visits Theater Where His Banned Plays Ran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to CORRECT spelling of name to Vaclav, sted Vaclaw.
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel made a sentimental visit Thursday to the Warsaw theater where his plays were staged until the 1981 martial-law ban and then revived as Poland turned to democracy. The Teatr Powczechny brought the playwright's work to audiences last year even while Havel still was banned in Czechoslovakia. Havel, who was elected president Dec. 29 after Czechoslovakia's ``velvet revolution,'' included a trip to the theater during an official trip to Poland. Standing amid the crates and cages that form the set for one of his plays, Havel discussed characterizations and dialogue with the actors. As Havel signed underground copies of his plays, one actor said he hoped he would not face arrest if he performed the president's works in Prague. ``Probably no,'' Havel replied. ``The foreign minister is my close friend and he always asks me about everything.'' Havel was greeted by the theater's director, Andrzej Wajda, an internationally acclaimed filmmaker, who said he felt he was welcoming the president home. ``This is his house, we are performing his plays, he is our writer and that is why we consider us to be Havel's home in Warsaw,'' Wajda said. The director recalled the theater gave 11 performances of Havel's plays in 1981 before the martial-law declaration that crushed Solidarity and the cultural outpouring that accompanied the independent movement. The ``Home Theater'' now presenting Havel's works at the Powczechny was created by actors who performed banned works, including his, at private homes during the martial-law period, Wajda said.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Proposes Joint Action on European Integration
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia proposed Thursday that his country, Poland and Hungary work in unison to ``return to Europe'' following decades of Soviet domination. He also called for an international ``peace conference'' that would put ``the definite period mark to World War II and the Cold War and the artificial division'' of Germany and Europe. The goal is clear, Havel said. ``We want to belong to a Europe that is a friendly community of independent states, a stable Europe, a Europe that does not need protection from superpowers because it is capable of defending itself by constructing its own security system,'' he said. The ongoing Helsinki Treaty process and parallel disarmament talks should be accelerated to prepare the way to the peace conference, he said. ``Then both military pacts could be dissolved and the process of all-European integration could be started,'' including the reunification of Germany within the present borders of East and West Germany, he said. The former dissident playwright, elected president last month after Czechoslovakia's peaceful anti-Communist revolution, told the Polish National Assembly that joint action to rejoin Western Europe would avert rivalry among Eastern Europe's emerging democracies. ``We should not compete in who is going to overtake whom and who will be first to win a seat in some European body, but we should do just the opposite: Help each other in the spirit of that Solidarity with which in worse times you protested against our repression and we against yours,'' Havel told the joint session of the Polish Sejm and Senate. ``Western Europe is much more advanced in integration processes and if we were to return to Europe individually it would certainly take much longer and it would be much more complicated that if we act together,'' he said. ``This does not only concern economics. It concerns everything, including disarmament talks,'' he said. Politicians in Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland support the withdrawal of Soviet troops from their territory, but each country has been discussing the issue separately with Moscow. Havel said a power vacuum has existed in central Europe since the collapse of the Habsburg empire at the end of World War . He said the countries of the region _ ``until recently colonized by the Soviets'' _ should unite in a new ``formation.'' Such a grouping would not appear to ``rich Western Europe as an impoverished and helpless-looking amnestied prisoner, but as someone who can also contribute something,'' he said. But Havel said he could not predict the ``institutional shape'' of the proposed cooperation among the three countries. He proposed that Czechoslovakia host representatives of Poland and Hungary at the Bratislava Castle near the Hungarian and Austrian borders to discuss the form of alliance. Observers from other Eastern European countries could also attend and eventually might join in the cooperative effort, he said. A Polish government spokesman, Henryk Wozniakowski, said Poland ``looks positively'' on Havel's proposition and would ``certainly'' be willing to take part in such talks. Havel's speech was the high point of his one-day trip to Poland, his first since his student days in 1956. He planned to take his proposal on European integration to Hungary on Friday. He was warmly received in parliament and was serenaded afterward by members with a round of ``Sto Lat'' _ ``May He Live 100 Years.'' The audience chuckled when Havel recalled the first meeting of Czechoslovak and Polish dissidents in the mountains along the two countries' border in 1978. He recalled how he, Jan Litynski and Adam Michnik, now both Solidarity members of the Polish parliament, and Jacek Kuron, the current labor minister, laughed about being able to duck surveillance for the clandestine meeting. ``If someone had told us then that in 12 years we would be deputies, ministers and presidents, then we would have laughed even more,'' Havel said. In the visit's only discordant note, Havel did not meet with Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, who refused an invitation, citing prior plans to meet shipyard workers in Gdansk and saying he did not want to have ``hand-shaking with no results.'' Walesa instead sent greetings to Havel. Havel was welcomed Thursday at Warsaw's military airport by Communist President Wojciech Jaruzelski, senior government officials, a full military honor guard and the diplomatic corps. He laid a wreath at the grave of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, the pro-Solidarity priest murdered by security police in 1984. It was the first time that an Eastern European state leader had visited the grave. About 1,000 Poles turned out to see Havel, who wrote in the guest book at St. Stanislaw Kostka Church where Popieluszko is buried: ``I have been moved for the first time since I became president.'' He also visited a theater company that has been performing two of his plays for nearly a year, when they still were banned in Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Yankee Restaurants Say Purchase by Japanese Is Tempest in Beanpot
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese now own the Publick House inn and run the food concession at historic Old Sturbridge Village, but the venerable Yankee institutions promise tofu and sushi won't replace turkey and succotash. ``This is an institution, it's a bastion of Yankee cuisine,'' said Buddy Adler, innkeeper at the Publick House Historic Inn, built in 1771 by a revolutionary war hero. ``It is what is. To change it ... nobody would even contemplate that.'' The inn, a cluster of white colonial buildings dotted about the town common, also runs the food service concession at Old Sturbridge Village, a living museum that recreates Massachusetts life in the early 19th century. Crawford Lincoln, director of the non-profit group that runs the village, said Thursday that he, too, doesn't expect any changes now that a Japanese company owns the village's eateries. ``Indian pudding, not sushi, will be the order of the day from the food service,'' he said. The changes took place earlier this week when Kyotaru Co., a Japanese food service company, bought Restaurant Associates of New York City for an undisclosed sum. Restaurant Associates has six divisions with 120 full-service restaurants and generates about $240 million in annual revenue, said company spokesman Dennis Rhodes in New York. In the deal, six top managers retained 15 percent of Restaurant Associates and will continue to operate the business. Hiroshi Tanaka, chairman of Kyotaru, will also be chairman of Restaurant Associates. The acquisition included another venerable landmark, the 84-year-old Italian restaurant Mamma Leone's in New York City, Rhodes said. Although the food will remain the same, Adler said he did not know whether Japanese ownership will have any effect on the ambiance of the Publick House, which includes a 110-room motor lodge and another restaurant and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The change will mean an infusion of capital, and that could fuel expansion, he said. That was welcome news to Sturbridge Town Administrator Kevin Walsh. ``From the standpoint of the town of Sturbridge ... infusion of capital probably means additional expansion and additional tax dollars. If that's accurate that's certainly a positive note,'' Walsh said. Sturbridge, a small town of about 7,700 in central Massachusetts, draws thousands of tourists each year. The population doubles to about 15,000 during summer months. About 350,000 people come to see Old Sturbridge Village to witness life in a recreated New England farm village. The main restaurant is Bullard Tavern, whose menu features such Yankee staples as chicken pot pie and cranberry sauce. ``Old Sturbridge Village is a non-profit living history that sets forth life in rural New England in the early 19th century and as such we will continue to hold fast to all aspects of the New England Experience,'' Lincoln said. He said the change of ownership could mean more visitors from the Far East. ``When visitors do arrive, they will be pleased to find we have our map guide already printed in Japanese,'' said Lincoln.

DOC.HEAD: Warship Whistleblower Case Won't Be Heard By Jury, Maine Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: A former Bath Iron Works employee fired after complaining to the Navy that some steel used in war ships allegedly was not inspected cannot have a jury trial, Maine's highest court ruled Thursday. Leon E. Bard Jr. contends in his wrongful firing lawsuit that he lost his job for whistle blowing, but BIW said he was dismissed for inadequate job performance. ``It will go to trial before a judge,'' BIW attorney Constance P. O'Neil said after the high court ruled that Bard had no grounds for appealing a Superior Court ruling that took his case off a list of lawsuits to be heard by jurors. The justices of the Maine Supreme Judicial Court ruled unanimously that they are able to consider appeals only when cases have proceeded farther than Bard's case had gone. Ms. O'Neil expected a trial date will be set soon in Superior Court in Augusta. Bard, a quality assurance inspector, was fired by BIW in September 1986, after several years in which he had complained about allegedly uninspected steel used in Ticonderoga class cruisers to the Supervisor of Shipbuilding, an on-site Navy office that keeps an eye on BIW's construction of warships in Bath. The Navy investigated Bard's charges, first after he made an initial complaint and a second time when he complained again after being fired, and found no problems with the BIW steel, Ms. O'Neil said. Bard's firing had nothing to do with his whistleblowing, BIW said. ``He was fired for being a less-than-adequate employee,'' Ms. O'Neil said. ``There were others who were making the same kinds of suggestions who are still there. If they (BIW managers) were worried about them, they would have gotten rid of all of them.'' There was no immediate comment from Bard; no phone number is listed for him in the Bath area. His attorney, Elliott L. Epstein of Lewiston, was not immediately available for comment Thursday, according to a secretary. Ms. O'Neil said she was not certain what Bard was seeking in his lawsuit, but she believed he wanted back pay and possibly reinstatement. Bard initially filed a four-count lawsuit against BIW, and the Superior Court dismissed three counts, leaving one that alleged Bard's firing violated the Maine Whistleblowers' Protection Act. The lower court said that case would have to be tried by a judge and not a jury, leading to Bard's appeal to the high court.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Top musicians penned birthday greetings to Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, some of them poetic and some in the ``dear Mo'' vein, in case the famous composer can somehow get the message on his perch up in harmony heaven. ``From measure to measure each note is a treasure,'' rhymed the Cleveland Quartet. ``Thank you, Mozart, for giving an unsettled world so much joy, passion and beauty, which will enrich us forever,'' contributed the Tokyo String Quartet. Mozart was born 234 years ago Saturday. The birthday messages from the likes of Zubin Mehta, Victor Borge, and the New York City Opera were written to mark the day and to publicize a Mozart series planned for 1991-92 at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. They are being displayed on a large poster in front of the center. Violinist Joshua Bell, 22, said, ``Dear Mr. Mozart, You have affected my life immensely. Happy Birthday.'' A somewhat older violinist, Glenn Dicterow, concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic, said, ``A special thanks for your violin concertos and `Symphonie Concertante.''' David Zinman, music director of the Baltimore Symphony, said that Mozart's music ``provides me with hope and courage.'' Mehta, music director of the New York Philharmonic, informed the composer that he's about to become the object of ``this century's most ambitious musical project.'' He referred to a 19-month tribute set to begin a year from Saturday at the performing arts center, during which all of Mozart's compositions will be performed. The onetime child prodigy wrote more than 800 works before he died in 1791 at age 35. The New York City Opera penned a ``wish you were here'' message for its next season ``when Susanna and Figaro renew their vows.'' Pianist Rudolph Firkusny told Mozart that he ``will always remain young, wonderful and alive among us.'' Some of the messages added a note of humor. Soprano Dawn Upshaw said, ``Thanks for saving your best efforts for sopranos!'' ``Even though you only wrote one piece for English horn, happy birthday anyway,'' wrote the Philharmonic's Tom Stacy who, of course, plays English horn. And comedian-pianist Borge's message read in its entirety: ``Dear Mo, As you know, I've always referred to you in my one-man show as a `bust.' However, I consider you one of the world's most successful busts. Please don't get plastered on your birthday. Love, Victor Borge.''

Balladeers of the sagebrush corralled their dogies and rode into town Thursday to duel lyrics with bards from Down Under about life on the open range at the sixth annual Cowboy Poetry Gathering. More than 70 cowboy poets from 16 Western states and six Australians are scheduled to trade lore about riding, roping and the wild but dangerous thrill of taming bucking bulls and broncs. Elko, a 4{-hour drive to Reno and a little more to Salt Lake City, is expected to more than double its 3,500 population through Saturday in the gathering that has gained national attention. ``I think people will be surprised to find they (Australians) basically have a parallel tradition to our cowboy poetry tradition,'' said Hal Cannon, co-founder of the event. ``They have a similar stockmen tradition and their history of settling the outback is similar to our settling the West.'' This year's gathering is dedicated to Curley Fletcher, one of the original cowboy poets who learned their craft sitting around a nighttime campfire. Fletcher, who died in 1954, published poems about the West, including a 1931 rhyme called Strawberry Roan, in which a wild bronc gives the poem's cowboy a hard time in the saddle and finally throws him to the ground. In the last stanza, the cowboy gives the Strawberry Roan his due: ``Then I knows that the hosses I ain't able tuh ride ``Is some of them living, they haven't all died, ``But I bets all muh money they ain't no man alive, ``Kin stay with that bronk when he makes that high dive.''

DOC.HEAD: AM-South Africa,0630
Mandela Says He Remains Committed to Nationalization of Banks, Mines
DOC.TEXT: Jailed black leader Nelson Mandela on Thursday rejected reports that he has converted to capitalism, saying he is firmly committed to nationalization of banks, mines and monopoly industries. Mandela, a leader of the outlawed African National Congress, has been jailed since 1962. He is expected to be freed within a few weeks and to play a role in promoting talks between the government and ANC. The United Democratic Front, a nationwide anti-apartheid coalition aligned with the ANC, released a one-paragraph statement from Mandela that said he wanted to clarify his stance on economic policy. ``The nationalization of the mines, banks and monopoly industries is the policy of the ANC, and a change or modification of our views in this regard is inconceivable,'' the statement said. ``State control of certain sectors of the economy is unavoidable.'' Terror Lekota, chief spokesman for the Front, said the statement was issued because of ``innuendos in press reports that comrade Nelson Mandela no longer subscribes to nationalization and that in this regard he is in conflict with the external leadership'' of the ANC. The statement appeared to be a response to a Jan. 14 article in the nationally circulated Sunday Times. It quoted wealthy black businessman Richard Mapanya as saying after a visit with Mandela: ``He did not believe in nationalization, saying it was clear that such a policy ran counter to the need to keep South Africa growing.'' The ANC's exiled leadership, based in Zambia, says it envisions a mixed economy for South Africa, but has an ideological preference for socialism. South Africa currently has a capitalist economy dominated by the country's 5 million whites. An anti-apartheid Cape Town weekly newspaper, South, on Thursday published the text of lengthy statement it said Mandela wrote prior to his meeting in December with President F.W. de Klerk. Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee said the government had no knowledge of any such statement. Some of Mandela's colleagues said the statement, even if authentic, might be many months old. The ANC ``has no vested interest in violence,'' the statement said. ``But we consider the armed struggle a legitimate form of self-defence against a morally repugnant system of govenrment.'' The statement urged a negotiated settlement, saying ``an overwhelming majority of South Africans, black and white, hope to see the ANC and the government working closely together to law the foundations of a new era in our country.'' The key issue, according to the statement, would be how to reconcile blacks' desire for majority rule with whites' desire to avoid total domination by blacks. Mandela, who is serving a life sentence for planning the start of the ANC's anti-government sabotage campaign, has been meeting regularly with government officials and anti-apartheid leaders. A group of five activists visited him Thursday at his quarters in a former staff home at Victor Verster Prison Farm outside Cape Town. Business Day, the country's leading financial newspaper, said Thursday the government plans to partially lift the state of emergency and remove restrictions on the United Democratic Front. The Front was effectively banned two years ago, but has been operating more or less openly since de Klerk assumed power in August. The Business Day report cited unidentified government sources who spoke to the newspaper following Wednesday's meeting between de Klerk and his Cabinet. De Klerk is expected to outline his plans for reform when he opens Parliament Feb. 2. Business Day said de Klerk probably will announce a partial lifting of the 43-month-old state of emergency, which gives authorities widespread powers to crackdown on anti-apartheid groups.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Planes Hit Bases Belonging to Palestinian Groups
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted bases of three Palestinian guerrilla groups in south Lebanon on Thursday in apparent retaliation for the killing of an Israeli colonel in a guerrilla ambush, police said. One man was killed and three people were wounded, they said. A formation of four jets fired 16 rockets in two sorties on bases of the Fatah-Revolutionary Council led by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal, the Palestine Liberation Front and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine headed by George Habash. Israeli military officials declined comment. The bases in Kfar Jarra, the Majdalyoun Valley and Mrah el-Hbas respectively, are clustered in an area about a mile away from hilltop villages controlled by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army 10 miles east of Sidon. An official of the pro-Syrian, Marxist PLF of Talaat Yacoub said the dead man belonged to his group. An official of Fatah-RC said the radical faction suffered no casualities. ``We vacated our bases Sunday in anticipation of an Israeli attack after the heroic operation at Yaroun,'' the official said. The raid came five days after guerrillas shot and killed Col. Yitzhak Rahimov in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone. He was the highest-ranking Israeli officer to be killed in Lebanon since Israel withdrew the bulk of its forces in 1985. Fatah-RC claimed responsibilty for the attack at the village of Yaron, one mile north of the international border. A communique from Abu Nidal's group later said the attack was only the first step in Israel's retaliation for the death of the Israeli colonel. ``This is not the retaliation,'' the communique said of Thursday's attack. ``This is only the beginning of the retaliation. There will be more attacks soon.'' Abu Nidal, the nom de guerre of Sabri al-Banna, split with Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1973. He has been blamed for numerous terrorist attacks in Europe and the Middle East. The raid was Israel's third on Lebanon this year. At least seven people were killed and 18 wounded in Israel's first and second attacks against bases of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and a Palestinian radio station. Both raids were Jan. 19.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Criticizes Romanian Decision To Ban Protests
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Thursday that Romania's new leaders had gone too far in banning protests in Bucharest, and urged them to reconfirm their commitment to democracy. The criticism contrasted with earlier Bush administration support for the National Salvation Front, the provisonal Romanian leadership that took over in December after hardliner Nicolae Ceausescu was executed. There have been reports that Secretary of State James A. Baker III might visit Romania next month in conjunction with his trip to the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia, but State Department officials say no decision has been made about such a step. Baker arrives in Moscow Feb. 6 for talks over the next two days with Kremlin leaders. ``We are deeply concerned about news reports that the decision of the National Salvation Front has imposed restrictions on demonstrations in Bucharest,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. The Romanian government issued its decree Jan. 3 in response to demonstrations and reissued it after a protest Wednesday by 1,000 people demanding that the front refrain from taking part in elections set for May. The decree outlaws demonstrations in Bucharest and allows them only in some parks, unless the protests are approved by police 48 hours in advance. ``The right of citizens to express their opinions peacefully, including the ability to march and demonstrate, is a fundamental human right,'' Tutwiler said. ``While we recognize that civil authorities may enact reasonable regulations to ensure public safety, these restrictions appear to go well beyond this need.'' Some members of the front have been critical of the United States for not providing more economic help to their country and have asked for the restoration of trade concessions that Ceausescu gave up. The State Department has indicated that any decision by Congress and the administration on the trade concessions would depend on steps by the Romanian government toward free elections. ``The NSF's latest action is all the more disturbing in view of the front's solemn pledge to the Romanian people to build a pluralistic democracy and respect human rights as well as to carry out free, fair and open national elections...,'' Tutwiler said. ``We call upon the NSF to reassure the Romanian people and the international community that it remains committed to moving forward toward democracy,'' she added.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Rich Nations Not to Abandon Poor Ones
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II began a tour of the impoverished Sahel region south of the Sahara by asking rich countries Thursday not to abandon poor nations in favor of Eastern Europe. ``The Holy See and the pope feel allied ... with Africa and other countries of the Third World,'' he told reporters on the flight from Rome to this former Portuguese colony off West Africa. ``We must present to the rich all the needs of the poor. We must insist on solutions. ... How can you not cry out in certain situations?'' On the first stop of an eight-day trip, John Paul also urged peaceful resolution through dialogue of crises in the Soviet Union, including the violence in Azerbaijan. ``These are especially painful events; we seek to participate in the events above all with prayer,'' he said in response to the first Soviet journalist to join one of the pope's foreign tours, a reporter for the labor newspaper Trud. Asked what message he would send President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the pontiff said: ``I would wish him above all ... the gift of good advice.'' John Paul referred to his historic meeting with Gorbachev on Dec. 1, at the Vatican, and said the Soviet leader realized the importance of spirituality in his Communist country. ``Perhaps I can say, without betraying any personal secret, (Gorbachev) was very pleased with the pope's prayers. He said prayer is certainly a sign of spiritual order, spiritual values, and that we have a great need for these values.'' To a question about how much violence could be justified in the U.S. invasion of Panama and the Soviet military intervention in Azerbaijan, he replied that violence is ``always something morally negative ... morally bad.'' He did not refer directly to either of the cases, but said self-defense could be justifiable in some situations. ``We cannot deny the right of the so-called `just war,' to this self-defense either of an individual community or a people when it has suffered violence on the part of others,'' the pope said. His sixth voyage to Africa, the 45th foreign trip of his 11-year-old pontificate, comes at a time when African leaders worry that their persistent need for aid will be pushed aside in the rush to support emerging democratic movements in Eastern Europe. Noting the current focus on that region, which includes his native Poland, the pontiff said developed countries ``cannot abandon their common responsibility for the South, for the problems of the Third World.'' ``For this, I can thank providence that my journey is taking me precisely to Africa. This is an act of providence.'' John Paul emphasized that the duty to help poor nations falls on all countries of the ``North,'' in which he included the Soviet Union and its allies. Cape Verde and the other nations on his itinerary _ Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Burkina Faso and Chad _ are in the Sahel, a region afflicted by drought, hunger, disease and encroaching deserts. ``I am traveling in African countries which are the poorest,'' the pope said. ``This trip is especially dear to me because we are going to meet the poor in the economic and material sense. In a moral sense, poverty means wealth.'' He touched on the same theme in his remarks at Praia airport to President Aristides Pereira. The pontiff's white robes flapped in the strong wind as he declared in Portuguese: ``Originally destined for all men, the goods of this world will never reach this universal destination without the indispensable collaboration of the international community, in the framework of a vast solidarity which includes everyone and responds primarily to the needs of the disadvantaged. ``At the same time, the recipients of aid should not become servile, but maintain the dignity of the interdependence of peoples.'' Cape Verde is an archipelago of 10 islands that gained independence in 1975. Ninety percent of the 360,000 people are Roman Catholic, the highest proportion in Africa. John Paul's next stop is Guinea-Bissau on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Former Exile Says Front Hurting Revolution; Hundreds Defy Ban on Protests
DOC.TEXT: A former diplomat who returned home after 50 years in exile said Thursday he fears the gains of the pro-democracy revolutution are being thwarted by the provisional government. Ion Ratiu, who arrived Wednesday, joined opposition parties in denouncing the decision of the governing National Salvation Front to compete in elections in May. ``This is a negation of democracy in my view,'' he said. For the second straight night, about 300 people gathered outside Front headquarters to demand the governing body's resignation, despite a ban on such protests. The protesters, about 150 feet from the building, shouted ``Down with the Front!'' and ``The National Salvation Front equals the Commmunist Party of Romania!'' Between them and the building stood two lines of police and soldiers in armored vehicles, their guns pointed at the protesters. A similar rally Wednesday ended peacefully. In apparent response to that protest, the governing body Thursday again published in newspapers a decree outlawing demonstrations on Bucharest streets without police permits. Critics say the provisional government cannot remain neutral if it takes part in elections that it administers, and some accuse it of being a front for Communist rule. The U.S. State Department said Thursday Romania's leaders had gone too far in banning protests in Bucharest and urged them to reaffirm their commitment to democratic rule. Three opposition parties called for the Front to resign and for a broader-based interim government to rule until the May 20 elections. The joint communique indicated the parties have formed an alliance against the Front. Ratiu, 72, heads the World Union of Free Romanians, the largest Romanian exile organization. Ratiu was a Romanian diplomat in Britain in 1940 and asked for political asylum when a Nazi government took over his country that year. He moved to Britain and became a millionaire through property and shipping interests. ``I've come to this country ... after having been steeped in Western democracy ... I've come to this country to help establish real democracy,'' he said Thursday. Asked whether he was worried about losing the gains of the revolution that ended one-party Communist rule, Ratiu said: ``I am worried and certainly will do my best to prevent it, because ... people sacrificed their lives for real democracy.'' He said he was most concerned that the Front was not providing equal access to all parties on radio, television and newspapers. He said he plans to start a newspaper. Ratiu hopes to be a candidate for the National Peasant Party in his hometown of Turda in western Transylvania. Asked if he would accept an offer to run for president, he replied, ``I will accept to serve in whatever capacity they ask me.'' Ion Puiu, the party's vice president, on Wednesday called Ratiu ``one of the greatest figures of our party.'' Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown in the revolution Dec. 22 and executed three days later, and the National Salvation Front was to rule until the elections. It first said it would not field candidates, but it reversed itself Tuesday. ``Illusions Lasted Only One Month,'' read a headline Thursday in Romania Libera. ``What kind of elections are we talking about when the National Salvation Front has monopolized in a totalitarian way all the key systems of the state,'' read the opposition parties' communique. It repeated allegations that some Front members were Ceausescu henchmen who want to reinstate Commmunist rule. Former Foreign Minister Corneliu Manescu was quoted Thursday by the independent Paris daily Le Monde as saying former senior Communist officials were trying to re-establish the party. ``I have been asked ... several times by former officials who perhaps have not committed the same mistakes as others to support the creation of a `clean' Communist Party,'' Manescu was quoted as saying. Manescu said he refused. He was foreign minister from 1961 to 1972 and participated in the founding meetings of the Front after Ceausescu's overthrow.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopia Doubles Estimate of Those Needing Famine Aid
With AM-Sudan-Famine Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government nearly doubled its estimate Thursday of how many Ethiopians will need emergency food this year, from 1.8 million to 3.4 million. In its final crop assessment, the Marxist government's Relief and Rehabilitation Commission also raised its estimate of the food required from 377,400 tons to 662,709. Most victims of the Ethiopian drought are in the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, where rebel movements are active. Three months ago, the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization said at least 4 million people would need 700,000 tons of relief aid in Eritrea and Tigre. At the time, the Ethiopian relief commission called the prediction exaggerated, misleading and politically motivated. Its latest report, however, conceded the commission's own assessment was essentially the same. ``Since our estimate does not include the assistance required to the nomadic areas, the difference is negligible,'' the government said. In addition to problems caused by drought, the government said, unseasonal rain had damaged crops in several parts of the country. It described harvests as generally good in central, western and northwestern Ethiopia. Officials told visiting church leaders from Britain, Canada and the World Council of Churches last week the government had agreed on a food distribution program with a consortium of Ethiopian churches. Included in the consortium are the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, Ethiopian Catholic Secretariate and the Mekane Yesus Evangelical Church, a Protestant institution. The churches run a program called the Joint Relief Partnership. Neither the government nor consortium has given details of the plan. The churches also have not said whether they have safe passage for relief goods from the Tigre People's Liberation Front, which controls most of Tigre province. Another possible complication arose last week when the Eritrean People's Liberation Front declared the Red Sea port of Massawa, where supplies would arrive, a war zone. Eritrean rebels have captured a freighter in the Red Sea and have threatened to sink any ship found in the Massawa area. Eritrean rebels have fought a separatist war for three decades in Ethiopia's northernmost province. Rebels in Tigre, just to the south, want to overthrow the central government.

DOC.HEAD: Manslaughter Charge Unlikely in Right-to-Die Case
DOC.TEXT: A second prosecution to seek harsher sentencing is unlikely for an assailant imprisoned before the man he stabbed died after almost four years in coma, a state prosecutor said. Although no formal decision has been reached, it is virtually certain the assailant, Noel Pagan, will not be tried for manslaughter in the May 1985 stabbing, Assistant Attorney General Thomas Goodwin said late Wednesday. Pagan fought unsuccessfully last year to keep Mark Weaver, the person he stabbed, alive on a feeding tube so he would not face additional charges in the case. A judge gave permission for Weaver's feeding tube to be removed last March, and the brain-damaged patient died eight days later at the age of 26. Goodwin said the possibility that the state could obtain a conviction against Pagan on manslaughter would not justify the use of resources needed for another trial. ``At the time Pagan pled and was sentenced on the aggravated assault charge, everyone understood that Mr. Weaver was not going to make it,'' and the judge probably took the inevitable death into consideration in sentencing Pagan, Goodwin said. Pagan pleaded guilty to stabbing Mark Weaver in the neck and was sentenced to 10 years in prison with five suspended. With accrued good-behavior time, he served a little more than three years and is now on probation and living either in Massachusetts or Connecticut, Goodwin said. Sylvia Lane, Weaver's mother, said she had hoped the state would decide not to prosecute Pagan again. She said she bore him no ill will.

DOC.HEAD: Key Witness Confessed Before Getting Warning of Rights
DOC.TEXT: A rifleman who participated in the 1968 massacre of Vietnamese civilians in My Lai blurted out a confession before being told of his rights, the Army's investigator says in a memoir published Thursday. The witness, Paul D. Meadlo, came to his interrogation more than a year after the slaughter ``determined to relieve his conscience and describe the horrors of My Lai,'' retired Col. William Wilson writes in American Heritage magazine. Wilson's investigation for the Army inspector general led to the court-martial of former Lt. William Calley, Meadlo's platoon leader, who was to be convicted of leading a slaughter of at least 175 to 200 unarmed men, women and children in the hamlet. Wilson said that when he embarked on the case, it was viewed as fact-finding rather than a criminal investigation. He said he and Col. Clement Carney, the inspector general's counsel, not wanting witnesses to clam up, decided not to open interviews with the warning that incriminating statements could be used in court. But Wilson wrote he was shocked at how precipitously Meadlo admitted participating in the killing. Meadlo, weeping, immediately described standing guard over about 80 villagers and Calley ordering ``Waste them!'' Wilson wrote. Meadlo said Calley then opened fire on the villagers and Meadlo joined in, spraying four or five clips of ammunition when Calley told him to shoot. ``I stopped him and told him to wait outside the room,'' Wilson wrote. He said he immediately called Carney, who ``instructed me to give Meadlo his warnings and see if he would repeat the confession.'' ``After he was warned that anything he said could be held against him in a court of law, he said, 'I don't care.' He repeated his confession,'' Wilson said. Meadlo went public with his confession on television later that year, but when he testified at Calley's trial it was under a grant of immunity and a threat of being held in contempt. Calley was convicted and given a life sentence that was knocked down eventually to three years of house arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Calls For Peaceful Solution in Azerbaijan, Offers To Help
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran has asked Moscow to withdraw troops from Azerbaijan and expressed willingness to help settle the dispute in the Soviet republic, Tehran television reported Thursday. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said the call was contained in a letter from Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati to his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze. The letter was submitted to the Soviet Foreign Ministry on Wednesday by Iran's ambassador in Moscow, Nasser Heyrani Nowbari, the television said. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Sunday had instructed Velayati to ``take serious steps to solve problems, end bloodshed and halt further violence'' in the Soviet republic that borders northwest Iran. At least 171 people have been killed in ethnic violence that broke out Jan. 13 between the republic's predominantly Moslem Azerbaijanis and Christian Armenians living there. Nationalists in Azerbaijan have turned the ethnic clashes into a call for secession. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared a state of emergency in the Caucasus republic and sent in Red Army units to quell the rebellion. Nowbari told the Soviet deputy foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, that Tehran was ready to offer ``any kind of help to solve the crisis in a just manner,'' the television said. It quoted him as saying that ``by supporting military intervention in Azerbaijan the West is trying to push the Soviet Union into deeper crisis.'' Nowbari announced Iran's willingness to receive a Soviet Foreign Ministry delegation for talks in Tehran about the crisis, the TV reported. ``This was welcomed by the Soviet Union and it was decided that the visit should take place soon,'' the report said. Iranian leaders have condemned the Red Army's crackdown on Azerbaijani nationalists, who are predominantly Shiite Moslems, as are most of Iran's 55 million people. The Soviet media have accused Iran of supplying arms to the nationalists, a charge denied by Iran. Gorbachev last week blamed Moslem fanatics for triggering the violence in Azerbaijan, echoing long-held fears that Iran's Shiite Moslem zealots who seized power in a 1979 revolution would seek to export their fiery brand of Islam across the border. In an open letter to Gorbachev, an Iranian student group denounced ``the massacre of Moslems in Soviet Azerbaijan,'' the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. An Iranian daily Thursday accused Washington of encouraging Gorbachev to send in troops to Azerbaijan in hopes of deepening the crisis, IRNA reported. It quoted the Farsi-language Jomhuri Islamic as saying that the United States has figured ``any military confrontation between the Soviet government and the people of Azerbaijan ... will benefit Washington, because it will disrepute Gorbachev and diminish his stature as the originator of a national and international reform.'' Iran's so-called radicals are diehard supporters of spreading the Islamic revolution to other countries, while Rafsanjani's pragmatic faction favors an opening to the West. Radio Moscow on Tuesday warned Iran that actions ``taken behind Moscow's back'' in Azerbaijan ``will have irrevocable consequences.'' The warning, broadcast on the radio's Farsi-language service, followed a call by more than half of Iran's 270 parliamentarians for Moscow to deal with the Azerbaijani Moslems ``with compassion.'' The radio, clearly telling the Iranians not to interfere in Azerbaijan, declared: ``Any unconsidered nationalistic or religious appeals would be dangerous. ... Brutal and illusory nationalistic flights of fancy have dragged the people to the brink of precipice.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6 p.m. EST _ Time Set By Source
DOC.HEAD: Researchers Find Compound Effective Against AIDS In Test Tube
DOC.TEXT: A synthetic compound has shown in laboratory experiments to prevent reproduction of the AIDS virus in a way different than AZT, the only anti-viral drug now approved for use against AIDS, researchers announced Thursday. The compound, a manmade peptide called U-81749, appears to block the final stage of a process the AIDS virus uses to reproduce itself in human cells. AZT, or zidovudine, attacks an earlier stage in the life cycle of the virus. ``It (U-81749) drastically slows down and reduces the number of mature viral particles you get in an infection,'' said Leonard Post, director of infectious disease research at the Upjohn Co., where the compound was developed. Post said the compound works by inhibiting the action of protease, an enzyme used by the AIDS virus to process proteins during the final stages of its reproduction. The result, he said, is that the virus cannot make mature copies of itself, and this prevents the spread of infection to other cells. He emphasized that the compound has been used only in test tubes on cultured cells and that it will be years before such a compound will be ready for human tests. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. When this virus invades a human cell, it takes over the cell's protein-making machinery to reproduce itself. During this process, the virus directs the creation of a number of different proteins. Protease is an enzyme the virus uses to chop up a large protein molecule, called p55, into several different types of smaller protein molecules needed to make a mature HIV particle. Post said that by blocking the action of protease, the p55 molecule is not processed and the viral particle does not mature. Dr. Bernard Moss, chief of the laboratory of viral diseases at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said the Upjohn research has demonstrated a new vulnerable point in the AIDS virus. ``The major significance of the work is that we are now attacking another target in the HIV virus,'' said Moss. ``There are only a limited number of targets in the virus and protease is one of them. A number of companies will be trying to develop such agents.'' Moss said that Smith-Kline Laboratories in Philadelphia has developed a similar compound. Post said study with U-81749 ``tells us we're on the right track'' in developing a protease inhibitor. He said a whole family of compounds such as U-81749 are now being evaluated and it may take up to two years to determine which is the best to use in human drug trials. Moss said that developing a new type of anti-viral AIDS drug to complement AZT is an important goal in treating the disease. AZT has not been successful with all patients and some patients develop serious side effects from the drug. ``By giving a combination of drugs that work at different stages of the life cycle of the virus it may give a better result,'' he said. The U-81749 research was performed in Upjohn laboratories by a team lead by W.G. Tarpley. A report on the study was published Friday in Science, the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Upholds Bush Veto of Bill Protecting Chinese Students
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today upheld President Bush's veto of a bill protecting Chinese students from deportation, handing him a narrow foreign policy victory in his first showdown this year with the Democratic Congress. The vote was 62-37, short of the two-thirds margin needed to override a presidential veto. Shortly after the vote, Bush appeared in the White House briefing room to hail the action as ``reaffirming our commitment to Chinese students in this country as well as the goal of improving relations with China.'' He said that ``no student is going to be sent back against his or her will'' and that ``we will continue to urge China to respect the human rights of its citizens.'' The issue, which would affect an estimated 40,000 Chinese students studying in the United States, took on added importance as the year's first test of strength between Bush and the Democratic-controlled Congress and as a referendum on the president's China policy. Republican Sen. William Cohen of Maine said in floor debate that he would vote against the president to uphold ``America's symbol to a world that is struggling to throw off the chains of dictators.'' But Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, said the issue was ``really a political challenge to the president's constitutional authority. I believe the challenge is ill-advised, works against our national interest, and is likely to cause a further deterioration of our relationsihp with China.'' In the days before the vote, the White House had mounted a fierce lobbying blitz which included telephone calls from Bush and other top administration officials to wavering senators and personal visits from Vice President Dan Quayle. The vice president presided over the chamber during the vote and his spokesman, Dave Beckwith, said that was his way of ``thanking Republican senators when they were personally inclined to vote the other way.'' Former President Richard M. Nixon, who laid the groundwork for modern U.S.-China relations with a diplomatic opening in the early 1970s, telephoned some senators to say Bush's position was in the long-term interests of the United States. During a lively debate, Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., said some Democrats were guilty of political opportunism and were using the veto-override fight to take ``a gratuitous chop at George Bush in a partisan way.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., called that ``hogwash.'' ``I'd like to believe that there are people here who are speaking for the freedom lobby,'' Kennedy said, his voice rising. ``We're talking about an issue of fundamental importance that has swept the world.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, noted that many Republicans had supported the bill originally, including 26 who urged Bush in a letter not to veto it. ``Now they're being asked to reverse themselves out of personal loyalty,'' he told reporters before the vote. The House voted 390-25 on Wednesday to crush Bush's veto of the legislation designed to shield Chinese students in the United States from deportation and political harassment. Democrats complained Bush's policies are too warm toward the regime that killed pro-democracy protesters in Beijing last June 4. The legislation applied to as many as 32,000 Chinese students now in the United States on ``exchange visitor'' visas. The bill would waive a legal requirement that those students go home for two years after their visas expire before returning to the United States or going elsewhere. In addition, the bill would permit any Chinese students whose visas expire _ as many as 8,000 others _ to remain in the United States as long as danger exists at home, and would allow Chinese students to work while in this country. Bush vetoed the measure on Nov. 30 after it passed unanimously in the House and by a voice vote in the Senate. Chinese student groups had lobbied hard for an override, saying many of them would face political persecution at home because they supported the pro-democracy demonstrations that brought a violent government crackdown. When Bush vetoed the bill, he ordered government agencies to adopt what he contends are essentially the same safeguards. The veto was an effort to preserve executive branch foreign policy prerogatives, he said, and to keep open the door for future student and cultural exchanges. ``I will not break faith with the Chinese students here. ... They were safe then, and they are safe now, and they will be safe in the future,'' Bush told a White House news conference Wednesday. He listed steps the Beijing government has taken which he said justified his policy toward China: the lifting of martial law in the capital; the release of jailed demonstrators; a promise not to sell medium-range missiles to Syria; acceptance of Peace Corps volunteers, Fulbright scholars and a Voice of America correspondent back into the country, and the muting of anti-U.S. propaganda. But critics countered that the missile promise was nothing more than a repeating of assurances given months before the crackdown, the effects of martial law remain in place and arrests, harassment and secret trials of pro-democracy agitators continue. They also contended Bush's administrative actions to protect the students can be revoked at any time and could be subject to a court challenge.

DOC.HEAD: Text of President's Drug Statement
With AM-Bush-Drug Plan
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President's Bush's statement Thursday, announcing his drug plan, at a White House luncheon for newspaper publishers: Well, please be seated and please continue with your coffee. But it's an honor to have you all here, and there may be no group in American more aware of the challenges this country is facing. So my first thought was to give you a general outline of our agenda after our first year. But then I decided to focus on the first item on the domestic agenda: illegal drugs. And they remain this nation's number one concern, and so I chose this forum to announce the second phase of our fight against drugs. This booklet is on our national drug control strategy that I hope we can get distributed to all of you.
