As you know, last September for the first time we launched a comprehensive, coordinated, and I think coherent national strategy to stop the distribution and the use of illegal drugs. We've made some notable progress in the months since the plan was unveiled, attitudes continue to change. Here in Washington, the number of those arrested who test positive for drugs has dropped dramatically over the past three months, especially among juveniles. And abroad, Colombia has extradited 14 of the world's major drug merchants to stand trial here in the United States. Given the headlines we have seen recently though, it's clear that we are only really getting started. And the plan we laid out last fall outlines what we intend to do, and today I want to announce the second phase, as I said, of our strategy which explains how we intend to do it, agency by agency, task by task, dollar by dollar. And today we're releasing a -- what I think of as a blueprint for success. Our outstanding director, Bill Bennett, Drug Control Policy Director, will discuss the program later in depth. And right now I want to just sketch out if I might a few of the highlights, and then open the floor to questions. Our approach remains consistent. We're commited to the same aggressive goals and principles that we outlined last September; to reduce use through an integrated mix of supply and demand side approaches, and that means doing everything that works. Our strategy calls for about a third of its funding to go toward drug education, prevention, treatment and research. We're calling for more prevention programs in schools and workplaces as well as grants for communities to set up education programs. In our treatment strategy, we're also emphasizing what works with careful and constant evaluation of treatment regimes and a new office for treatment improvements at HHS. We're funding new research in areas like law enforcement technology, treatment and drug use forecasting that will help us spot trends, and then target our resources and measure the impact of our strategies. And this spring we're going to be releasing the first of an annual state-by-state status report measuring progress. Rougly another third of the budget is devoted to domestic enforcement, prosecution, incarceration. To help local law enforcement initiatives the '91 fiscal budget calls for nearly $500 million for state and local law enforcement grants, an increase of 228 percent over the last two years. We want to get the right resources to the right people on the right level, street level. Today we'll be announcing five high-intensity drug trafficking areas; cities and areas that are already doing a great deal, but need more support. And we want to help them map out a more comprehensive coordinated approach to fight drugs. We're also increasing the number of DEA and FBI agents and personnel as well as more funding for assistant U.S. attorneys. We support an increase in federal judgeships. We're proposing the death penalty for drug kingpins and those responsible for drug related killings, and even in some cases, attempted killings. We want there to be absolutely no doubt about the certainty of punishment. And the final third of our budget is earmarked for border interdiction and the international operations side. We want the multinational criminal organizations that produce and distribute drugs to be more than disrupted. We intend to see them dismantled and destroyed because we don't make deals with these dealers. We have multilateral programs underway in many parts of the world. Throughout Central and South America particularly we're engaged in expanded and unprecedented levels of cooperation and assistance. We applaud the efforts of President Virgilio Barco of Colombia and also of President Salinas, our neighbor -- President Salinas of Mexico. And I will reinforce our support for the courageous leaders of the region at the upcoming drug summit at Cardagena. Among the steps we're taking to intensify border control, up to an additional 1,000 Customs agents who are already on the job will be given authority to conduct drug investigations to better assist the DEA, the Drug Enforcement Administration. With interdiction in particular, coordination is absolutely crucial and we're putting an end, I hope -- and I believe we are putting an end to turf battles. I met with all our top law enforcement people the other day and they said they had never seen better cooperation between these powerful, in some instances, but between all the agencies. Our budget for all international activities has increased from $419 million to nearly $700 million. We're creating a new national drug intelligence center to ensure all enforcement agencies get the strategic and organizational intelligence that they need. More

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: they need.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury's newly created Financial Crimes Enforcement Network will improve financial intelligence. And the Department of Defense has been increasingly effective in its expanded detection and monitoring roles. Now I imagine the news in this chapter of the war on drugs may be its price tag. Spending understandably gets a lot of attention, and in this case, outlays continue to increase. But I want to emphasize our determination to win this fight without adding to the budget deficit and, yes, I repeat, without raising taxes. In 1990, drug funding totaled almost $9.5 billion -- that was in 1990 -- the largest increase in history. Funding for Fiscal '91 will be expanded by more than $1 billion to over $10.5 billion and outlays will increase 41 percent this year. In fact, with this request the federal drug budget will be 69 percent higher than it was when I took office in 1989. And to those who say that our program looks top heavy on the interdiction side, remember that many of the efforts to limit supply are exclusively federal and inherently are more expensive than demand reduction. We're willing to spend more to limit the drug supply. Simply put, we're willing to do whatever it takes. But the real issue, of course, is not how much. It has got to be how well. And here the distinction between federal and national is crucial. A truly national drug control strategy demands that we tap resources of every description -- public and private; civilian and military; local, state and federal; volunteer, professional and personal. Let me tell you about a man that I know many of you in this room know, but some may not -- Jim Burke, corporate leader, former CEO of Johnson and Johnson, who's been applying the power of the media to unsell drugs, through the Media Partnership for a Drugfree America, the largest volunteer, private sector ad campaign since the war bond drives of World War II. He's energized. And he's doing a superb job. You're all familiar with those hard-hitting ads to discourage drug use. Many of you already contribute space to run them. And that's supporting the Partnership's current goal to raise $1 million a day in advertising time and space every day for the next three years, a remarkable goal indeed. And I know that some of you -- Joe Williams of the Memphis Commerical Appeal, to take a notable example, has made a promotion of volunteerism, an important part of the newspaper's mission. And that's also very, very important. The free press has a right and a responsibility to comment and report on a nation's problems, but your newspapers may also contribute to the progress of the communities they serve by pointing to solutions. And there may be no better outlet for America's volunteer -- volunteer effort, volunteer spirit -- than saving those being lost to drugs. It's too early to tell how our efforts will be judged, but if more concerned Americans become involved Americans, I believe we will succeed.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Say Bush Drug Plan Inadequate
DOC.TEXT: The nation's big-city mayors on Thursday dismissed as inadequate the billion-dollar increase in the war on drugs proposed by President Bush and said it shortchanges their efforts to treat addicts. ``We can't win the war on drugs with $10.6 billion,'' said Philadelphia Mayor W. Wilson Goode, citing the size of the federal anti-drug effort proposed by the White House. ``It is woefully inadequate,'' said New York Mayor David Dinkins, whose city was among those that would get special attention and money as a ``high-intensity'' drug use area under Bush's proposal. ``It'll make some difference, but not much,'' Dinkins said. The mayors were attending the winter meeting of the U.S. Conference of Mayors, a gathering Bush plans to address on Friday. His appearance will be the first by a president since President Carter a decade ago. Goode and Dinkins, both Democrats, were joined by other Democratic mayors and two Republicans, Richard L. Berkley of Kansas City, Mo. and Sue Myrick of Charlotte, N.C. at a news conference providing the organization's official response. While Bush's plan won modest praise as a step in the right direction, none of the mayors suggested the proposal was close to adequate. The president of the conference, Democrat President Kathryn J. Whitmire of Houston, Bush's adopted hometown, said the size of Bush's proposal suggested the drug problem is not at the top of the nation's agenda despite political rhetoric to the contrary. She said mayors agree the federal government should provide direct aid to the nation's cities, rather than through state governments as it does now. A study released by the group this week found only 15 percent of two key grant programs for law enforcement assistance made it to city governments last year. She said mayors also believe federal anti-drug efforts must be sufficient for cities to provide drug treatment for all addicts. Many cities have waiting lists for treatment now. The mayors pointed to the $50 billion savings-and-loan bailout package passed by Congress last year, and said if the nation is serious about fighting drugs it should provide a similar amount to this effort. ``We believe we could solve the problem if we had $50 billion,'' Goode said. San Diego Mayor Maureen O'Connor said Bush's proposal amounted to $44 per person, with only a few pennies additional for treatment, while the S&L bailout costs $208 per person. ``Until we put the same amount in fighting drugs, we have not made it our top priority,'' Whitmire said. Several mayors voiced general support for a $14.6 billion alternative described to them earlier in the day by Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del. Biden's plan would provide immediate treatment for all pregnant women and young children who want it, and would provide treatment on demand by any drug abuser in four years, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Truce Reportedly Reached Along Tense Front; Baltics Offer Mediation
LaserPhotos MOS19,20,21,33; MOSB2,3
DOC.TEXT: Warring nationalists agreed Thursday to a cease-fire along one of the tense battlefronts of the bloody conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan, Tass said. The announcement came as Baltic activists, worried that the dispute might affect their own peaceful push for independence, offered to help mediate the blood feud between Armenia and Azerbaijan. Iran, which has ethnic and religious ties to Azerbaijan, also offered to help settle the crisis. There were fewer reports of fighting Thursday. Tass said life was returning to normal in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital that was the scene of much of the violence. During talks in the Armenian town of Yeraskhe, representatives of the Armenian All-National Movement and the People's Front of Nakhichevan agreed to lay down their weapons, the Soviet news agency said. ``According to the agreement ... along the entire border between Armenia and the Nakhichevan Autonomous region all exchanges of fire between opposing informal groups must stop,'' Tass said. Nakhichevan is culturally and politically a part of Azerbaijan, although it is physically separated from the republic by Armenia, which lies on its northern border. It is bounded by Iran on the south and a small section in the west borders Turkey. Tass did not say whether the truce was holding. It also was uncertain whether the two organizations could enforce it. Martin Martirosyan, a spokesman for the the Armenian All-National Movement, said no agreement had been reached yet on an exchange of hostages. He said three Armenians were being held by Azerbaijanis. Tass also said a truce was reached on the border of Armenia's Idzhevan district and Azerbaijan's Kazakh district. Christian Armenians and Moslem Azerbaijanis have been feuding for the past two years primarily over control of Nagorno-Karabakh, a section of Azerbaijan populated mainly by ethnic Armenians. The feud has exploded into a virtual civil war and has fueled a nationalist movement to make Azerbaijan independent of the Soviet Union. On Jan. 13-14, Azerbaijanis attacked ethnic Armenians living in the Baku, killing dozens. Fighting between armed groups has killed dozens more. On Jan. 19, Soviet soldiers moved into Baku to smash barricades set up by nationalists and end the bloodshed. In less than two weeks of violence, at least 171 people have been killed. The 130-mile border between Armenia and Nakhichevan has been among the most tense in the struggle. On Sunday, a funeral was held in Yerevan, Armenia, for an Armenian nationalist leader, Mofses Gorgisyan, who was killed in fighting there last week. Witnesses said they have seen nationalists fighting there with automatic weapons and artillery taken from Soviet soldiers. Tass added that a meeting of the leaders of the informal organizations would take place Saturday to agree on further separating the militias. The fighting is perhaps the biggest internal crisis that has faced President Mikhail S. Gorbachev during his nearly five years in power. Gorbachev's fostering of greater freedom has helped spur the nationalist movements in several Soviet republics and in the East bloc. President Bush praised Gorbachev Thursday as the ``best hope'' in the Soviet Union for the United States, and he declined to fault him for using force to restore order in Azerbaijan. ``I want very much for him to succeed. I think he has conducted himself in an extraordinarily difficult situation very well. He remains committed to peaceful change. And I don't think anyone is faulting him for the difficulties that he has encountered in Azerbaijan,'' Bush said, giving his strong endorsement to the Soviet leader for the second straight day. In London, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons she had ``great sympathy'' for Gorbachev as he tries to keep his nation from unraveling. In an interview with the Wall Street Journal, she was quoted as saying the reunification of Germany _ which one East German official on Thursday called inevitable _ could topple Gorbachev. The pro-independence movements from the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia stepped into the dispute between Armenia and Azerbaijan. They called for nationalist groups in the warring republics to take part in a peace conference Monday in Riga, the Latvian capital. Spokeswoman Anda Anspoka of the Latvian People's Front in Riga said the Armenian All-National Movement confirmed it would attend. But the Azerbaijani People's Front was not expected to decide until Friday whether to participate, Usus Samed Ogli, a front director, said by telephone from Baku. Ogli said front leaders had gone underground because they fear they will be arrested by the KGB, but that the group would meet Friday to discuss the peace conference. Political movements in the Baltic republics have been pressing peacefully for greater autonomy, and have a strong interest in avoiding the precedent of the military moving in to restore order. An airlift of families of ethnic Russian servicemen was suspended Thursday because the danger had subsided, said Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov. More than 30,000 people had been evacuated since the airlift began, he added. Tass said tensions in Baku were easing. The news agency said stores were re-opening, a newspaper began publishing again and transportation was resuming. Earlier, it was reported to be paralyzed by a strike to protest the Soviet occupation. Azerbaijanis have pledged not to end their strikes until Soviet troops withdraw. The republic's Central Committee convened late Wednesday, after a nighttime curfew began, and ousted Abdul-Rakham Vezirov from the party, less than a week after he was removed as party chief. He was accused of making ``serious mistakes'' that led to the crisis. Gerasimov said military forces arrested 20 people after boarding two merchant ships that led a blockade of the Baku harbor that was broken Wednesday. Tass cited Baku Radio as saying troops had detained Mamed Ali-Zade, chairman of the Defense Committee of the Azerbaijan People's Front.

DOC.HEAD: Army Officer Pleads Innocent
DOC.TEXT: An Army officer pleaded innocent Thursday to an assault charge for allegedly flipping his wife over an eighth-floor railing at a hotel. The plea was entered for Maj. David Schneider, 34, at a hearing in Platte County Circuit Court. Judge John Yeaman set a June 11 trial. Schneider remained free on $25,000 bond. Schneider stood in uniform with his hands behind his back as his lawyer, Dick Fickle, waived a formal reading of the charge and entered the plea. Schneider did not speak. The government contends Schneider tried to kill or seriously injure his 34-year-old wife, Deborah, by flipping her over an eighth-floor railing at the Embassy Suites Hotel near Kansas City International Airport on Nov. 4. Schneider had told authorities earlier that he had picked up his wife in a romantic gesture and lost his grip. Mrs. Schneider suffered multiple fractures to her legs and pelvis in the 80-foot fall. She has undergone physical therapy and uses a walker. Prosecutors said Mrs. Schneider, who has said she does not remember the circumstances of her injuries, no longer lives with her husband. A 15-year-old girl testified at a hearing last week that she saw Schneider place one hand on his wife's chest and his other hand on her back before her fall. The girl said she was standing about 100 feet away on another section of the eighth floor. The assault charge carries sentences ranging from 10- to 30-year prison terms to life in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Khark 5 May Be Leaking Again, Environment Ministry Says
DOC.TEXT: The crippled Iranian tanker Khark 5 may again be leaking crude oil off the Cape Verde Islands in ``a serious manner,'' said a statement released Thursday by the Environment Ministry. Attempts to transfer 53 million gallons of oil remaining on the Khark 5 to another tanker are threatened by rough seas near its position off West Africa, the statement said. The ministry listed no source of information and there was no independent confirmation late Thursday from other countries of a leak. The Dutch salvage company Smit Tak, which is heading operations to save the ship and shift its cargo of crude to the Iranian tanker Shir Khooh, has consistently said all leaking has stopped. The Khark 5 lost 19 million gallons of Iranian light crude after a Dec. 19 explosion ripped a hole in the vessel's hull. Before drifting seaward, the resulting oil slick threatened Morocco's fisheries and beaches but authorities said warm offshore waters helped break up virtually all of the slick. Smit Tak hopes to transfer the remaining oil in international waters about 300 miles from the Cape Verde Islands. After the blast, Spain, Portugal, Morocco and Cape Verde barred the Khark 5 from entering their 200-mile territorial waters for fear of pollution. Rough winter weather has prevented the salvors from beginning the three-day pumping operation. The explosion, which occurred in stormy weather 400 miles north of Las Palmas in the Canary Islands, began a fire that forced the Khark 5's crew to abandon ship. Nobody was injured in the incident, the cause of which has not been determined.

DOC.HEAD: Costs to Employers Jumped 5 Percent in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Americans' wages, salaries and other benefits rose 5 percent last year, the government said Thursday in a report that economists took as a sign that high labor costs may worsen the nation's inflation problems. The Labor Department said its Employment Cost Index, considered one of the best gauges of inflationary wage pressures, showed an increase equal to the 5 percent rise in 1988 in employment costs. Rising health care costs, in part, pushed the index forward both years, the agency said. The increases in compensation showed that labor costs are failing to moderate despite a slower economy, some analysts said. That's because the slowdown has not pushed the unemployment rate much above its 15-year low of 5 percent last March. The jobless rate was 5.3 percent last month. ``The slowdown has been too mild to rein in compensation costs,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``While this is good in the short-term for the worker, it raises the question that inflation is going to increase.'' Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co., called the report disappointing because ``it's very hard for me to believe that overall inflation will come down much.'' Benefit costs jumped 6.1 percent in 1989, compared to a 6.8 percent gain in 1988. But the 1988 increase was attributed in part to a 5 percent increase in the employer's Social Security tax rate. Escalating health insurance costs last year kept the cost of benefits high even without a big change in the Social Security tax, the Labor Department said. Before 1988, benefit costs had grown consistently for the past three years at about 3.5 percent. ``It's going to be a steady fight to bring that down,'' economist Cynthia Latta of DRI-McGraw Hill said of the 6.1 percent hike in benefit costs. ``They're trying to pass this on to workers, and that's going to take a while.'' While overall employment costs rose, wage and salary increases lagged behind inflation for the third straight year. They grew by 4.2 percent in 1989, under the year's 4.6 percent inflation rate. In 1988, wages and salaries were up 4.1 percent while inflation was 4.4 percent. According to the Labor Department, employment costs for state and local government workers rose 6.2 percent, up from 5.6 percent in 1988. It cost private industry employers 4.8 percent more last year to pay wages, salaries and benefits than it did in 1988, the department said, compared with a 4.9 percent gain in 1988 over 1987. Federal government costs are not included in the report. Sales workers, whose pay is heavily influenced by commissions, experienced a 7 percent wage jump in 1989, compared with a 6.6 percent gain in 1988 and just a 1 percent gain in 1987. Workers in the rapidly expanding service sector of the economy, where the tight labor market is felt, experienced a 4.5 percent wage gain, while those working in goods-producing industries saw their pay increase on average by 3.9 percent. For the sixth straight year, non-union workers in private industry received greater wage and salary increases than did their unionized counterparts, with the increases averaging 4.1 percent and 3.1 percent, respectively. State and local government workers received on average a 5.3 percent pay gain in 1989, up from the 4.8 percent increase of 1988, with the increase in that sector highest among hospital workers, who averaged 6.1 percent pay raises.

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire in Air, Charge Azerbaijan Government Office
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Helmeted police firing into the air charged the Azerbaijan government office in Moscow late Thursday and briefly detained three people, witnesses said. Police broke a side window of a sedan driven by one Azerbaijani man, Mekhti Sadirov, as it pulled up to the downtown office and dented it by hitting the car with the butts of their automatic weapons, the witnesses said. Three men who recently had arrived in Moscow from Azerbaijan, where unrest has been wracking the region, were taken to a police station for verification of their documents, said one witness, Sabinir Shabanov. Sadirov, whose car was damaged, was not among those detained. The three were released within minutes without charge, Shabanov said. No one was hurt, and polce provided no immediate explanation. Police Lt. Col. Dmitri Lyubimov was said to be meeting after midnight behind closed doors and was not available to discuss the incident. The office serves as headquarters for the government of the Azerbaijan republic in the Soviet capital, but has been the scene of news conferences by the Azerbaijan People's Front political movement and a center for Azerbaijani protests in Moscow. Azerbaijan is involved in a violent dispute with neighboring Armenia over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region. Soviet soldiers crashed through barricades of buses and trucks set up in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, on Saturday to take control of the city from armed nationalists.

DOC.HEAD: Where the Money Would Go
With AM-Bush-Drug Plan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's plan to spend about $10.6 billion on the war against drugs in 1991 sticks to a heavy-on-law-enforcement theme, with almost four-fifths of the money devoted to enforcement at home and abroad. At the same time, the proposed drug war budget _ up almost 12 percent from this year's spending of $9.5 billion _ would hike treatment funds by 12 percent to $1.5 billion, and education, community and workplace use-prevention funds by 11 percent to $1.2 billion. The breakdown comes to 42 percent for domestic law enforcement, 29 percent for border drug interdiction and international operations and 29 percent for demand reduction, said John Walters, chief of staff to drug policy director William J. Bennett. ``To those who say our program looks top-heavy on the interdiction side, remember that many of the efforts to limit supply are exclusively federal _ and inherently more expensive than demand reduction,'' Bush said in a speech to newspaper publishers as he unveiled the updated version of the strategy announced in September. ``We're willing to spend more to limit the drug supply. Simply put, we're willing to do whatever it takes.'' If Congress goes along with Bush, local and state officials will get their hands on $2.6 billion, or about one-fourth of the total, through grants for law enforcement, treatment and prevention efforts, a 108 percent increase over the last two years. The five regions designated as high-intensity drug-trafficking areas _ New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Houston and the Southwest border of California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas _ will benefit from total federal efforts of about $1.2 billion this year and, if Congress approves, $1.4 billion in 1991. The agency that would get the largest chunk of the $10.6 billion is the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration, part of the Department of Health and Human Services, which would be given $1.4 billion. Of that, $577 million would be for block grants for drug-treatment programs, an increase of $100 million. The agency that would receive the second largest amount is the Pentagon with $1.2 million, of which $638 million would go for detection and monitoring of drug traffickers crossing the U.S. borders and $227 million would be for operational costs such as flying and sailing time, Walters said. The State Department's Agency for International Development would get $224 million, up from $48 million. Much of the money would go to aid the Andean countries, where most of the world's cocaine is produced. The Drug Enforcement Administration would get $700 million, up from $549 million, to raise the number of DEA personnel from 5,224 to 5,601. Elsewhere in law enforcement, the budget envisions money for about 410 additional federal prosecutors, an additional 100 FBI workers and 75 new federal judges. Overall, criminal justice spending would increase 2 percent to $4.3 billion; international initiatives would shoot up 65 percent to $690 million; interdiction efforts would increase 17 percent to $2.4 billion; research would rise 20 percent to $383 million; and intelligence efforts would zoom up 142 percent to $172 million. In other areas, the drug strategy: _Calls for almost doubling funds for eradication of domestic marijuana production, to $35 million in 1991. This was done in part, Walters said, to show foreign governments urged by the United States to stamp out their drug production that the U.S. government is serious about wiping out domestically produced supplies as well. _Envisions spending $400 million in prevention and treatment for pregnant women who use drugs and for their children, part of an effort to combat the problem of ``cocaine babies'' and those born addicted to other drugs. _Continues the Andean strategy, launched last September, by spending $2.2 billion over five years in drug law enforcement and economic development funds for Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. The proposed budget would increase from $217 million in 1990 to $423 million in 1991, including $50 million in additional aid for Colombia, Walters said. The five areas of the country designated as high-intensity drug-trafficking areas appear on the surface to be slated to receive only $25 million this year and $50 million next year. But they actually will receive help worth a total of about $1.2 billion this year and, presuming Congress agrees, $1.4 billion next year. Most of the aid would be in the form of additional federal agents assigned to those areas to enhance law enforcement and interdiction efforts. But some of that money will come in the form of block grants similar to those being given out nationwide. According to Bruce Carnes, Bennett's budget specialist, the New York City area, which could include Nassau County in New York and Union, Hudson and Essex counties in New Jersey, would receive $396 million worth of help in 1990 and $436 million in 1991. Los Angeles, which could include Los Angeles and Orange counties, could get $151 million in 1990 and $169 million in 1991. Miami, which could include Broward, Dade and Monroe counties, could get $196 million in 1990 and $223 million in 1991. Houston, which could include Harris and Galveston counties, could get $168 million in 1990 and $187 million in 1991. The Southwest border, which could include 35 counties in California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas, could receive $330 million in 1990 and $368 million in 1991. The total number of federal anti-drug workers targeted to each area is envisioned as: New York, 250; Los Angeles, 300; Miami, 300; Houston, 200, and the Southwest border, 700, Carnes said.

DOC.HEAD: Local Officials Hope To See Increase In Anti-Drug Agents
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcement officials in President Bush's newly designated high-intensity drug-trafficking areas said they were pleased with the prospect of more dollars and more attention focused on their regions. ``We certainly need more people down there,'' said Jim Piatt, regional commissioner for the U.S. Customs Service based in Houston. ``We need more people looking at cars coming across the border. We need more officers looking at cargo. We need more canine teams. ... We need more technology.'' The president Thursday proposed a $1.1 billion increase in drug-fighting funds on a wide variety of fronts, including new spending in five high-priority areas: New York, Miami, Houston, Los Angeles and the Mexican border area from Texas to California. Piatt said the mere designation of Houston and the border as drug target areas was very important. ``What that's going to do is beyond whatever additional money Houston gets with this drug strategy, what it's going to do is add focus. All the various federal agencies are going to realize they're going to have to put more resources into these areas to work on this drug problem. So I think there are going to be a lot of spinoff benefits.'' He called Houston ``a conduit for smuggling across the border. ... There's a lot of drug drug money that's floating around. To the extent that we can work on joint money laundering projects, a lot of that money can go right back to the city.'' On the technology side, he suggested that ``There's got to be a way we can X-ray vehicles and trucks. That would certainly make us far more effective than we are now.'' In Miami, Customs Commissioner Carol Hallet said she was ``delighted'' with the new initiative. ``We are in this war to win it and Customs, the Coast Guard and the DEA will help us see an end to this scourge that is a global problem.'' ``We will study the high intensity areas to see what needs to be done.'' The new federal funds includes increases for education and treatment, but the focus in the Miami region will continue to be on halting drug shipments, Ms. Hallet said. Customs, she said, will ``continue to be the lead agency when it comes to interdiction on the land. We will be adding not only agents but additional inspectors and K-9 teams.'' Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez said he has always been pleased with federal help in anti-drug efforts in the region, but wished the new money would give local officials had more say in how it was spent. ``We'd like to have some discretion on the use of the money,'' he said. Two Southern California congressmen said the declaration of Los Angeles County as a high-intensity drug trafficking area was a long overdue step. Rep. Mel Levine said the Bush administration ``seems to understand the seriousness and magnitude of the drug problem facing Los Angeles County'' but must allocate even more resources to the area. ``The resources announced today are woefully inadequate and need to be dramatically increased,'' Levine said in a statement. Rep. Howard Berman, who like Levine is a Democrat, said the administration should have taken the step a year ago and in the meantime much ground was lost. ``I hope the administration realizes that, excellent as this is, it's jut a start,'' Berman said. In New York, Mary Cooper, a spokeswoman for the New York region of the Drug Enforcement Administration, said officials in her office were meeting Thursday to discuss the anticipated extra funds. And New York City police Sgt. Ralph St. Just said if any of the funds make it to the local level, that's when NYPD will decide. ``We've got to have it in our possession before we decide what we're going do with it,'' said St. Just.

DOC.HEAD: Shiites Trade Gunfire in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem factions fought shelling duels in south Lebanon on Thursday and President Elias Hrawi's government endorsed a plan that would ban militias in Moslem west Beirut. Christian radio and television stations ended a week-long newscast strike after a compromise was worked out with Gen. Michel Aoun, leader of a renegade Christian army, on the titles of rival government leaders. Police said at least five fighters of the pro-Iran Hezbollah, or Party of God, were wounded when a tank cannon fired by the mainstream Shiite Amal militia blasted their position in Iqlim al-Tuffah. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with standing regulations, said Amal and Hezbollah were reinforcing their positions and massing fighters in an apparent preparation for resuming ground offensives. The latest casualties raised the overall toll to 98 killed and 286 wounded since Dec. 23, when the latest round of Amal-Hezbollah clashes for control of the 1.2 million Shiites broke out in the province. The Shiites are the largest community in Lebanon, which has a population of 4 million people belonging to 17 sects. Renewal of the Amal-Hezbollah confrontation after a 16-day relative lull underlined the failure of Iranian and Algerian mediations to halt the intermittent, 2-year-old conflict that has killed 930 people and wounded 2,753. Police said renewal of the Amal-Hezbollah hostilities led to an exodus from disputed villages of the mountain regions, east of the southern provincial capital of Sidon. ``The few civilians who had returned to their homes during the lull left late Wednesday,'' the police spokesman said. Meanwhile, Hrawi's government announced that it approves a new security plan banning militias from operating in Beirut's western sector. Soldiers of Gen. Emile Lahoud's 22,000-strong army loyal to Hrawi are to carry out the new security plan ``soon,'' the statement said. It did not set a date. The statement said the Lebanese soldiers are to deploy in west Beirut in ``coodination with the Syrian forces.'' It did not disclose further details. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the new security plan covers the western edge of south Beirut, but not the slums that are a traditional Hezbollah stronghold. ``The Lebanese army will not move into Bir el-Abed and the other Hezbollah districts in south Beirut,'' the source said without further elaboration. Some of the 18 Western hostages are believed held by Hezbollah-affiliated underground factions in the slums of south Beirut where the Syrians do not maintain any presence. The security plan, reached earlier this week during three days of talks between Hrawi and Syrian President Hafez Assad in Damascus, appears to be similar to one applied by the Syrians when they moved into west Beirut to end three years of militia anarchy Feb. 22, 1987. Leftist and Moslem militias were then banned by the Syrians from operating in west Beirut and Hezbollah maintained its control over the city's southern slums. However, leftist and Moslem gunmen re-emerged in west Beirut last summer during a six-month artillery confrontation between the Syrians and Aoun's 20,000 troops. The Syrians made no moves to prevent the militias from returning to the capital. Aoun has vowed to drive the Syrians from Beirut and has refused to recognize or take part in the Christian-Moslem government headed by Hrawi and formed last year with Syrian support. Christian radio stations resumed newscasts Thursday after media in the Christian enclave reached a compromise with Aoun. According to the compromise, reported by Voice of Lebanon and Voice of Free Lebanon radio stations, Hrawi will be referred to only as ``Mr. Elias Hrawi.'' The compromise also allows the media to refer to Aoun only as ``Gen. Michel Aoun'' and not as interim prime minister. Hrawi, immediately upon his election as president Nov. 24, dismissed Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister. Aoun on Jan. 16 banned the media from referring to Hrawi as president, recalling that he had declared Parliament dissolved to prevent the election of a pro-Syrian head of state.

This is the text of President Bush's Thursday news conference on the Senate vote to uphold his veto on legislation affecting Chinese students in the United States: PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I have two subjects I'd like to address myself to. First, I want to acknowledge the vote in the Senate upholding my veto this afternoon and reaffirming our commitment to Chinese students in this country as well as the goal of improving relations with China. No Chinese student in this country is going to be sent _ sent back against his or her will. And we will continue to urge the People's Republic of China to recognize the human rights of its citizens to participate in the affairs of the world community. And I do want to express my personal thanks to the leadership of the Republican Party in the Senate _ Sen. Dole, Sen. Simpson _ who led this effort with courage and determination. And a special thanks to all of those members who voted for the values of justice and human freedom that I believe were at stake in this question. Secondly, this morning, I called President Endara of Panama to assure him of our continuing support of his efforts to establish democracy in Panama. Now part of this effort involves the establishment of a healthy economy, and I am deeply impressed with his commitment to reform Panama's economy. And based on this commitment and the report I received from Larry Eagleburger and John Robson with us here, I informed President Endara that we'd arrived at an economic assistance package to help assist Panama in its economic recovery. Our plan, valued at about a billion dollars, includes 500 million in humanitarian assistance for housing, emergency public works, business assistance, loans, guarantees and export opportunities, and then a $500 million _ in addition _ assistance package for balance of payment support, public investment and economic restructuring. The vice president will review the details of this plan with President Endara on his visit to Panama. And we're going to work closely with the Congress on this package to ensure its prompt implementation. The economic challenges that Panama faces are great, but we will work with the people to build a prosperous democratic nation. I've just met again with Secretaries Robson and Eagleburger and they believe, given the history in Panama, the business side, that this economic assistance can indeed result in the short-run, in a very _ in a vastly improved economic situation. Helen? Q: Mr. President, isn't it about time that you told the American people what were the results of two secret missions to China, whether you got any kind of promise from Beijing for losening up and becoming a more tolerant society? And will this victory lead now _ lead you to try to lift the sanctions against China? A: Well, I think I addressed myself to that yesterday, but let me repeat, I was very pleased at their lifting of martial law, I was very pleased at the release of 573 people from jail in a kind of an amnesty. I've said that these weren't all the steps that need to be taken. I'm very pleased that they've stopped harassing the United States mission there, our embassy in Beijing. I'm very pleased that they've lightened up on the areas where I think we can really move things forward, and that is the Peace Corps and the Fulbright exchanges. So, this was all part of the debate on the Hill. And I must say that I think that _ the fact that they had made those moves carried some weight with some of the senators. Q: Well, is that the promise that you were given? And they say now that martial law is still _ A: No promises. I'm looking for action; not words. Q: How about the sanctions? A: That's a third question. And _ what sanctions? Which part of the sanctions? Q: The military technical assistance _ A: Well, we're looking at the whole performance scale, and I expect they are, too. So _ but I'm very, very pleased with the results on the Hill today. Yeah, Terry?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Nigeria Reduces Detention Without Charge Period to Six Weeks
DOC.TEXT: President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida signed a decree Thursday reducing the military government's power to detain people without charge from six months to six weeks. The decree, imposed in 1984, permitted senior government officials to order the detention without charge of people deemed to be security threats. The detention orders allowed detention of up to a half-year, and could be renewed. The new decree limits detentions to six weeks, at which time they can be renewed but must be reviewed by a panel made up of government officials, religious leaders, a retired judge, a representative of the Nigerian Bar Association and others. The decree also authorizes only the general chief of staff of the military to order detentions. Previously the minister of international affairs and inspector general of police also had the power to authorize detentions. In announcing the amendments, Justice Minister Bola Ajibola said the government was bowing to demands for a relaxation of the decree from human rights groups and the bar association.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... Yeah, Terry?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, there are 535 members of Congress; 62 supported you on this veto. Do you view that as any kind of a _ (aside to other reporter) _ no, overall _ (returning) _ do you view that as a mandate for your policies _ A: Yeah. Because you've got to give disproportionate weight to how the Executive Branch feels. We're an equal branch. So you add to that the support on the Hill; we come out more than equal. Q: And does it give you any support for new initiatives toward China? A: It gives me _ the thing I like about it, given the mournful predictions of some a couple of weeks ago, is that it gives me the confidence that I'm going to go forward the way I think is correct here. And I've had a lot of chance to talk to people that voted with us and some that didn't. And I understand their sensitivities, and I vow to do a better job of informing them as these things develop as to what it is we're intending. But I'm very, very pleased with the results _ for reasons that I'm sure everybody out here can understand. Yeah, Brit. And then Charles. Q: Mr. President, back to the Chinese students for a moment. Does your commitment that no Chinese student would be sent back against his or her will _ does that run absolutely or is that something that will run until such time as you feel that China has changed its ways in some way that meets your approval? A: ``Against his will _ his or her will'' is the controlling statement, yeah. Yeah, Charles? Q: Mr. President, on the aid to Panama, some assessments say 1 billion is only a fraction of what it will need to restore the effects down there. What is your assessment? And what are people saying? Is this what you're hearing? A: Well, I'm basing my judgment on what President Endara said and on the recommendations of the economic mission that went there. And President Endara seemed very pleased at this. I said to him, ``If there's additional categories where we can _ in which we can be helpful, please let me know.'' But I think he was very pleased. And I think both Larry and John feel that it is a very good step; whether it's the last step or not, I don't know. We've got to see how that private sector responds, and how _ you know, how the economic recovery goes forward. But I wouldn't say this is the end of the road in terms of what we can do to help them. Q: Is there a full assessment of what the total cost will be? A: Well, I think they feel that this is ``Let's go here, see what happens, and then take another look.'' Some may come up with higher figures, but this is what we think is a good and full program to give them the help they need right now. Yes? Q: Mr. President, have you been personally briefed on the exact number of people left homeless as a result of the US invasion of Panama, and when, specifically sir, can they expect to get new homes to replace those _ A: I think these programs will give instant _ or as close as instant relief as we can hope for here. In fact, there's a provision _ I'd like to ask Larry and John to take a couple of questions after I bail out on this that will address themselves in more specificity, because I don't have the exact number there, but I would like to help as best I can with the reconstruction. Yes, John?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks More Money, Higher Penalties in War on Drugs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, vowing ``to do whatever it takes,'' proposed a $1.1 billion increase Thursday for the war against drugs, targeting more money for a Pentagon attack on cocaine traffickers and urging the death penalty for drug kingpins. Overall, Bush's package would total $10.6 billion and boost the cost of the nation's drug-fighting strategy in fiscal 1991 by 11.6 percent over current spending of $9.5 billion. A rival plan from the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., would cost $14.6 billion, give the president's drug policy coordinator Cabinet status and outlaw semiautomatic weapons. Bush said he expects the Senate will try to approve a higher budget than he is asking, but said, ``We do sense a desire on the part of the Congress to cooperate. ... ``In terms of the objectives of this strategy, we're in pretty close accord with both Democrats and Republicans on the Hill, so I think we can get early action,'' Bush said. Early congressional reaction split predictably along party lines. Calling drugs ``this nation's No. 1 concern,'' Bush announced his proposal in a White House speech to newspaper editors. The plan is the second phase of the drug war strategy unveiled in September and targets five areas for intensified federal drug-fighting efforts. While claiming progress in the drug war, Bush said, ``Given the headlines we've seen recently, it's clear we're only getting started.'' In response to a question, Bush said he felt ``great sadness, great tragedy'' over the arrest of District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry on misdemeanor cocaine charges. ``My thought went to the kids, kids in the schools. It's a matter of sadness, and Barbara (Bush's wife) shares my view on this.'' The president also vowed ``to hold the line'' against proposals to legalize drugs. ``We're willing to spend more to limit the drug supply,'' Bush said, calling his package ``a blueprint for success.'' ``Simply put, we're willing to do whatever it takes,'' he said. His plan designates five regions _ New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Houston and the Southwest border of California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas _ as high-intensity drug-trafficking areas. Federal anti-drug efforts in those areas will benefit from millions of dollars in additional federal help this year and next. The current budget allocates $25 million for the worst-afflicted areas, plus up to $21 million more from the federal asset forfeiture fund, said Reggie Walton, associate director of Bennett's office. The 1991 budget calls for $50 million for those areas. Bush said one-third of his drug-control budget would go toward education, prevention and treatment programs; another third to domestic enforcement and the final third for border interdiction and international operations. Bennett's office, however, said that 29 percent of the money would go for education and other demand-reduction efforts, 42 percent for domestic enforcement and 29 percent for border interdiction and international efforts. The largest spending increase would go to the Pentagon to expand its drug-fighting role. It would receive $1.2 billion, up from about $878 million in the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30. About $638 million of the Pentagon funds would be earmarked for detection and monitoring of traffickers trying to enter the country with illicit drugs. Moreover, the plan envisions ``ship- and aircraft-detection activities in the Caribbean Sea in concert with foreign governments.'' ``Our approach remains consistent ... to reduce use through an integrated mix of supply- and demand-side approaches. And that means doing everything that works,'' Bush said. The second-largest increase would be for the Department of Health and Human Services' Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration, which would have its budget increased from $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion. That includes almost $577 million in block grant money for drug-treatment programs, an increase of $100 million. Bush said he was proposing an increase in FBI and drug enforcement agents, as well as 75 new federal judges. ``We are proposing the death penalty for drug kingpins and those responsible for drug-related killings, and even, in some cases, attempted killings,'' Bush said. ``We want there to be absolutely no doubt about the certainty of punishment,'' he said. Currently, the maximum penalty for ``leaders of continuing criminal enterprises'' is life imprisonment. ``We want the multinational criminal organizations that produce and distribute drugs to be more than disrupted _ we intend to see them dismantled and destroyed because we don't make deals with dealers,'' Bush said. He also praised efforts by the leaders of Mexico and Colombia in fighting drug traffickers and said said he would ``reinforce our support for the courageous leaders of the region'' at the Feb. 15 drug summit in Colombia. Congressional reaction to the president split largely along party lines, with Democrats saying more money is needed to get to the root of the drug problem and Republicans lauding Bush for seeking $1.1 billion more for the drug war. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y. and chairman of the House Narcotics Committee, said the Bush plan failed to address lack of education and unemployment, which Rangel said must be faced as part of the drug battle. Biden said Bush should target casual users less and hard-core addicts more. But Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., said Bush's plan ``signals the kind of get-tougher approach that the public is crying for. ... ``When the mayor of the capital city of the free world is arrested for crack use, the American public knows that the drug situation in this country has gotten out of hand.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... Yes, John?
DOC.TEXT: Q: I know you're talking about foreign policy, but may I ask you a drug question since you were talking about that today, though? A: Yes, sir? Q: Given the fact that in your inaugural address you talked about the promise to stop the scourge of drugs and given the fact that today you told the newspaper publishers that drugs was at the top of your agenda, is this going to be the primary test for your administration in its first four years, at least, in its primary domestic phase, assuming the economy doesn't fall apart? Is this the big one? A: I think it's the big one, and I think it's a test not for the administration, but for every community in the country, every state, every local _ local government, for the people. And somebody asked me if you had to set goals, changes in the education system or _ but where could you most readily hope to see results, I would say in the anti-narcotics fight. I think it's really that kind of priority. Yes, Dave? Q: Mr. President, can you _ A: You're next, Michael. Q: Going back to China, you gave us an accounting of why Gen. Scowcroft went in December, but I wonder if I could ask you to go back to July. Could you give us an accounting of that trip? What happened? What did you learn? Why did you send him then? A: To see _ to make clear to the Chinese leadership that the relationship is important, but that it could not go forward until certain changes were _ had taken place, and that, in sum, is what it was about. Q: Was it your initiative or theirs, sir? A: Mine. My initiative. Yeah? Q: Back to the override vote. Does this suggest to you, your victory today, that, if you can win here, you can win on anything with Congress? A: No, because I think we had very good case here. If I took a case up there that wasn't any good, well, I'd probably get beat. But this one, I think people, you know, were willing to listen, some that had been positioned opposed to it, opposed to my position. And I think when they heard the full argument, I think they decided, ``Well, we should support the President on this one.'' Q: Could you expand a little bit on that, Mr. President? Given that you've pointed out repeatedly that you have done administratively what Congress sought to do legislatively _ A: Yeah. Q: _ why was it so important to win this vote? A: Well, I said yesterday, I mean for several reasons. One reason, I think there was a political ingredient in it and nobody likes to get (unintelligible) on that. And also I think, from a foreign policy standpoint, I think it's better to do it this way. I think there is a trust factor that hopefully will result in changes that are satisfactory to the American people and to me _ a trust factor in the administration. And I hope that I can use that, having won this now, to further the kinds of things that I think will help move China forward. See, just as _ back _ I think that the unilateral decision by President Nixon to send Kissinger on a secret mission to establish contact in days when they were far darker in China's U.S. relations was a good decision. And I think the decisions I've made are good decisions. I can understand the controversy and I can understand why there wasn't _ excuse me _ a unanimous endorsement, but I view this _ I'm not _ I view it as a very good step. I will pledge right here to work with the Congress. I love the way the debate ended with both Sens. Mitchell and Dole saluting each other for the way in which the matter was discussed, and I think that's a good signal for the political fights that may lie ahead. And _ Michael? Q: If I could follow up on David's question _ A: Yeah. Q: _ you said that Mr. Scowcroft's trip in July, the Chinese were told certain things had to happen for the relationship to go forward. Could you elaborate on those things _ A: No, I can't do it. Q: _ tell us what happened? A: No, because I think that we've seen China take certain steps and in diplomacy, I don't think you make progress by throwing down a list of things telling somebody else how to behave. I do think you adhere to your own principles and I think sometimes you have to undertake the kind of diplomacy that I engaged in here to reiterate principles and to explain the severity of problems to people. But if you do it publicly all the time and you do it so you're painting somebody into a corner, I don't think you get results and that's why I did what you've done. Q: Is the status of Mr. Fang one of those things that needs to be resolved? A: I hope they _ it certainly is a matter that's on _ that I would like to see resolved. Yes? Yeah, Jim?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Ava Gardner, an Unhappy Film Siren, Dead at 67
LaserPhotos NY25,26,27,28,35,38
DOC.TEXT: Ava Gardner, who lived a Hollywood siren's life of fast cars, failed marriages and heated affairs but failed to find happiness in love or in her 60-film movie career, died Thursday at her west London home. She was 67. Paul Mills, a long-time friend who announced the death, said she had been ill with pneumonia. The dark-haired, green-eyed actress, born a farmer's daughter, fled Hollywood for Europe in the 1950s. She complained, ``The image I seem to have, that I'm a loudmouthed, temperamental, oversexed, sultry siren, sometimes terrifies me.'' Miss Gardner was married briefly to actor Mickey Rooney and to big band leader Artie Shaw, and for six years to singer Frank Sinatra. ``I loved them all,'' she said of her husbands, ``but I never understood any of them, and I don't think they understood me.'' ``She was a wonderful lady, wonderful lady,'' said Burt Lancaster, who starred with her in ``The Killers,'' the film that launched her sex goddess image in 1946. ``She was a very simple lady. She used to come down to the beach with us and cook and play with the kids,'' Lancaster said from his home in Los Angeles. ``She was probably the most beautiful woman I ever met ... sheer enchantment,'' said Donald Sinden, who appeared with her in 1953 in ``Mogambo.'' The film, which also starred Clark Gable and Grace Kelly, brought Miss Gardner her only Academy Award nomination. The star of such films as ``On the Beach,'' ``Night of the Iguana,'' ``Show Boat,'' ``The Barefoot Contessa'' and ``The Snows of Kilimanjaro'' regarded herself as a simple country girl who would have traded all the glitter for one happy, long-lasting marriage. ``That's what I grew up hoping to find: One good man I could love and marry and cook for and make a home for, who would stick around for the rest of my life,'' she said in an interview with London's Daily Express in 1982. ``I never found him.'' She also had well-publicized romances with billionaire Howard Hughes, actors George C. Scott and Robert Mitchum, Spanish bullfighter Luis Miguel Dominguin, Cuban playboy Porfirio Rubirosa and Italian comedian Walter Chiari. After leaving Hollywood in 1958 she was sometimes seen dancing a passionate flamenco in Madrid, and survived two road accidents in the high-power cars she raced down narrow Spanish roads. Ava Lavinia Gardner was born Dec. 24, 1922 in Grabtown, N.C., the youngest of six children of cotton and tobacco farmer Jonas Gardner. Her father lost the farm when she was 2 and later he worked in a sawmill in Newport News, Va., where her mother Mary Elizabeth ran a boarding house. When she was 18, she visited her older sister, Bea, in New York. Bea's husband, photographer Larry Tarr, shot dozens of pictures of her and displayed one in his studio. Barney Dunham, then a clerk in MGM's New York legal department, urged Tarr to send some pictures to Hollywood. The result was a screen test and a $50-a-week contract. Her first film role came in ``We Were Dancing'' in 1942, the year she married Rooney. He was 21 and she was 19. The union lasted 20 months. ``My heart is broken with the loss of my first love,'' Rooney said in a statement released in Los Angeles. She met Shaw at a Hollywood nightclub. They married in October 1945. Shaw took books to read on their honeymoon. Miss Gardner later suffered a nervous breakdown, and the marriage ended a year and a week after it began. In 1950 she met Sinatra, who was married and mired in a career slump. They were married in November 1951 and divorced in July 1957. Each was an only child, she said of her husbands. ``And each one was basically a musician. Highly talented and, uh, highly strung.'' Then, rolling her eyes, she added: ``That's putting it mildly, baby.'' She moved permanently to London in 1968. ``I'm one Hollywood broad who hasn't taken the sleeping tablets, tried to slash my wrists or kick a cop,'' she told one interviewer. ``London gave me back my sanity.'' She complained to an interviewer on her 60th birthday, ``The trouble was that I was a victim of image. Because I was promoted as a sort of siren and played all those sexy broads, people made the mistake of thinking I was like that off the screen. ``They couldn't have been more wrong. ... I am pathologically shy. I was a country girl and I still have a country girl's rather simple, ordinary values. ``No one ever wanted to know the real me at all. They preferred the myths _ the roaring lady who smashed champagne glasses and seduced bullfighters.'' That was her role, hard-living Lady Brett in the 1957 film version of Ernest Hemingway's novel, ``The Sun Also Rises.'' Joseph Mankiewicz, who directed her as the wild Spanish dancer in ``The Barefoot Contessa,'' said in Los Angeles Thursday, ``I don't think Ava ever put body and soul into her performance. She put body and soul into living a life.'' Miss Gardner said in announcing in 1958 she was quitting MGM, the studio that brought her to Hollywood in 1941: ``MGM was never the right studio for me. They ... never knew what to do with me. Most of the time, they loaned me out.'' In one of her last roles, she appeared on the CBS-TV series ``Knots Landing'' in 1985. Mills said Miss Gardner's body would be taken to Smithfield, N.C. for burial alongside her parents. He said Miss Gardner had not felt completely healthy since suffering a stroke in 1986, and for three months had been unable to take her Corgi dog for walks in Hyde Park. ``She was joking last night,'' Mills said. ``My wife is one of her oldest friends. They were on the phone talking last night, and she was a little bit sad because she wanted to be better.'' A sister, Myra Pearce of Winston-Salem, N.C., said Miss Gardner's housekeeper called her early Thursday to say the actress had died in her sleep.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Sending Congress Sweeping Base Hit List
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is sending Congress a sweeping list of proposed military base closures and reductions in moves President Bush pledged on Thursday will not ``cut the muscle of our defense.'' While Bush and Cheney have both declined to outline the exact number or scope of the changes, Pentagon and congressional sources said the suggestions target dozens of installations. ``I have a three-inch folder on my desk'' outlining the changes, said one Pentagon official. Last week, Cheney promised that the hit list would be ``extensive,'' above and beyond the 86 domestic bases that Congress agreed last year would be closed. A blue-ribbon panel made that recommendation, a device widely expected to be resurrected in order for Congress to swallow any of the proposed changes. Cheney is slated to formally unveil the list on Monday, but officials have already begun notifying congressional delegations of the proposed shut-downs and changes, congressional sources said. The Pentagon and congressional sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, warned that last-minute changes could be made, given the volatile political nature of the suggested cuts. The sources said the list of suggested closures and reductions has targeted, among others: _The Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, a shipbuilding and repair center which has 9,000 military and 20,000 civilian workers. _In California, San Francisco's Treasure Island Naval Station, the Alameda Naval Air Station, the Oakland Naval Supply Center and the Oakland Naval Hospital, as well as the Long Beach Naval Shipyard. _The Army's Fort Monroe, a training center in Hampton, Va. _The Army's 2nd Armored Division at Fort Hood, Texas, which would be disbanded under the plan. About 10,000 soldiers, one-fourth of Fort Hood's troop population, are connected with the armored division at the base, the largest military installation in the free world. Part of the division is stationed in Europe and Pentagon officials stressed that any reduction in forces there would be along the lines of superpower arms control reduction pacts. _Fort Ord, Calif., would be closed, and the 7th Infantry Division stationed there would be transfered to Fort Lewis, Wash. _The 9th Infantry Division at Fort Lewis is slated to be sharply cut back. _Besides the reductions in Europe, several military installations in the Pacific are also on tap for closure, the sources said. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, said he could neither confirm nor deny speculation that besides Fort Hood, Bergstrom Air Force Base and the Red River Army Depot might be affected. Gramm said he did not believe any ``hard and fast decisions'' had been made and that the speculation of targeted bases could be nothing more than ``trial balloons'' being floated by the Pentagon. As the reports surfaced, accusations and denials of partisanship surfaced. One Pentagon source argued that officials weren't being political about the changes because ``some of the best friends of the military,'' such Rep. Marvin Leath, D-Texas, a member of the Armed Services Committee, had bases in their districts that had been targeted. However, Leath _ whose district contains Fort Hood _ has announced that he will retire at the end of this year. ``If we were really partisan, we'd be going into (Rep.) Patricia Schroeder's (D-Colo.) backyard,'' he said. ``Really, this is all designed to make military sense.'' But some of the congressional sources contended that liberal Democrats' districts were being targeted under the plan. Another Pentagon source noted that such proposals are always bound to produce complaints and that Cheney fully expects it. ``This is just the tip of the iceberg,'' the source said of the reported closures. ``There's a whole lot more coming.'' ``We've warned all along that reductions in the military budget are going to be painful,'' added one military official. Bush, asked about the affect such closures might have during a session with newspaper publishers, said the Defense Department was ``wrestling with this whole concept of what facilities will remain as fully funded in the future as they have in the past.'' The president admitted that the issue was a hot potato politically _ and one he himself has been guilty of battling against. ``We're all familiar with what happens _ everybody says cut and then when somboedy has to make the call, they say, `Please, cut in this other guy's district, don't cut in mine. Mine's absolutely essential.''' ``And I was guilty of the same thing when I was a member of Congress and so I understand it,'' Bush said. ``I think we can come up with a formulation of where we have to cut, doing it in a way that we don't cut into the muscle of our defense.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Arrest of DC Mayor `Great Tragedy'
With AM-Bush-Drug Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 3 grafs more Bennett comment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday said that the arrest of District of Colombia Mayor Marion Barry on a cocaine charge was a ``great tragedy'' that made him think of the impact on schoolchildren. The mayor was arrested by federal agents at a local hotel last week and charged with one misdemeanor count of possession of crack cocaine. Asked his reaction, Bush told newspaper publishers Thursday, ``Great sadness. Great tragedy ... My thought went to the kids, the kids in the schools. It's a matter of sadness. Barbara shares my view on that.'' He declined to comment further, saying, it ``would be most inappropriate for a president to prejudge a matter that is in the court.'' Asked whether the mayor should resign, he said, ``I don't want to get into the case because I think it would be inappropriate. Let's let the system work. I think the city is capable of making that determination.'' Later Bush's drug policy director, William Bennett, said the Barry case might be ``one of these watershed kind of events'' that changes people's attitudes on drugs. Bennett refused to comment directly about Barry but said his government had been a barrier to a concentrated federal effort to help the city deal with its drug problem. ``We threw a rope to a city drowning and we found a lot of knots got tied, but there wasn't enough pulling to get up,'' Bennett said. ``Every American has to ... weep a little bit for this city and for the fact that it's the murder capital of the country,'' Bennett added.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Soldiers Leave Few Alive in Hunt for Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Liberian soldiers accused of massacring civilians are leaving few survivors in their relentless search for rebels near the Ivory Coast border, diplomats and medical workers said Thursday. ``They tell really horrendous stories of soldiers spraying entire villages with .50-caliber machine guns,'' a Western diplomat said. Bullets from such heavy weapons tear huge holes in bodies. The diplomat and Ivorian sources estimated at least 500 civilians had been killed in Liberia's eastern Nimba region since soldiers were sent to stop rebel attacks that began Dec. 24. ``Refugees say there are not many wounded people because the soldiers slaughtered so many,'' the diplomat said. He visited refugees Tuesday with Ivorian officials, aid workers and other diplomats from nations donating food, medicine and money. Officials fear an outbreak of disease because of a stream of refugees estimated Thursday to number more than 60,000. About 12,000 to 15,000 other Liberians have sought refuge in Guinea, the diplomat said. At the Ivorian border village of Danane, refugees tell of dashing to safety in the forest when they hear the daily machine-gun fire across the frontier. ``They are traumatized by the combat and watching some of their relatives being killed,'' said Claude Regnier, a French adviser to the Ivory Coast government who heads a committee coordinating aid to the refugees. ``When the gunfire starts, they rush to the forest and come out ... only when it stops,'' he said in an interview. A Western diplomat said the killing began in Liberia after rebels from the Gio tribe increased attacks in an attempt to oust President Samuel Doe, who seized power in 1980 from the descendants of freed American slaves who founded the West African nation in 1847. The Gio long have felt oppressed by Doe's Krahn tribe. ``It started with Gio rebels attacking military outposts in their own ethnic heartland in Nimba county,'' the diplomat said, also speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The army came in and just went nuts because everyone looks like a rebel to them. There has been some very heavy-handed slaughter.'' The rebels retaliated about 10 days ago by moving south into traditional Krahn territory and slaughtering civilians there, he said. That caused a second wave of victims to flee east into Ivory Coast and north into Guinea, he said. Killings of innocent people continue despite a warning from Doe on Monday that soldiers who harmed civilians would be executed, the diplomat said. Doe told reporters Thursday the army was having difficulty containing the situation in Nimba because the rebels used hit-and-run tactics, and that it was hard for his soldiers to identify rebels wearing civilian clothes. He added, however, that security forces had been cautioned to distinguish more carefully between civilians and rebels. Initially, Justice Minister Jenkins Scott said soldiers killed only armed civilians who attacked them. Regnier said 40 percent of the refugees were women and children and 30 percent boys or youths. Doctors said refugees hospitalized in Ivory Coast included a 5-year-old girl shot in the leg. Dr. Maurice Kouame, director of Man Hospital, a regional health center 75 miles from Danane, said his staff was caring for only eight seriously wounded Liberians. He said people with light wounds were treated at a clinic in Danane. Among the eight was a man whose arm had been hacked off, Kouame said in a telephone interview. According to Regnier, refugees have crowded into a 30-mile stretch along the Ivorian side of the border and have been taken in by villagers of the same language and culture. He said many were related. ``They are sleeping 40 to 50 in a hut,'' Regnier said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... Yeah, Jim?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, on capital gains, you pointed out on several occasions that because of parliamentary rules you've been thwarted, you've asked that Congress give the majority the right to exercise their will by passing capital gains. A: Yeah. Q: Now in this case, you technically won on this veto because of parliamentary rules, but the vast majority voted against you on this. Don't you believe that that is, in fact, a repudiation of your Chinese policy? A: No, I don't see a parallel. This is Executive Branch. You're equal with the Legislative Branch. The whole ball game is entitled to have the veto process. Part of the election is about the veto process. It's not a question of whether _ but when you have a majority of senators up there doing one thing, that's fine, provided the president agrees with it. But that's what I'm saying. I mean _ Q: But I'm talking specifically about what Congress did over the last couple of days. A: Surprised you, didn't it? Q: The majority of congressmen in both the House and the Senate voted against you on this issue. Do you that that's a repudiation by Congress of your Chinese policy? A: No, they're entitled to do the thing and the Executive is entitled to do its thing and it worked. And we're going to stay right on track and I think the process worked very well. I don't view it as a repudiation at all. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, I understand that Transportation Secretary Skinner was among those making calls on the vote. A: I hope so. Q: Well, that's just a little pork barrel persuasion as well. But was there something more than just the pure merits of this? A: Highways in China? What are you talking about? (Laughs.) Q: Well, I mean, was it just the pure merits of the case that won the day, or was it, you know, ``win one for the'' _ A: I think there was some politics in it. I think there was politics in it. Q: On both sides? A: Yeah, both sides. I'd say _ yeah, because some of them said, ``Look, let's stand with the President,'' some that may have had a slight difference of emphasis on our side. And clearly there was plenty on the other side when you don't see one single vote come across the aisle, not one. Q: Did you _ A: Not one. Q: _ make specific promises to anyone on _ A: No. Q: _ help on any other issue? A: No, uh-huh. Yes? Q: Mr. President, you've spoken of a trust factor _ A: (Responding to an off-mike comment.) (Inaudible) _ a great big, fat one coming over the pike. Excuse me. Q: On the trust factor, I wonder if I can apply that to the American people, sir. What can you say to convince the people that the missions to China weren't secret simply to avoid the overwhelming public opposition to them? A: I say I think what I'm doing is correct, and I say I think I was elected to do in foreign policy what I think was correct. And you have the checks and balances of the Congress. They had a shot to say that it wasn't correct in this instance. And so I say that I feel encouraged that the process worked out this way, and I point back to the original relationship with China. And I don't believe you'd have ever had it if there hadn't been some secret diplomacy. Yeah?
