DOC.HEAD: High Wind, Heavy Snow, And Thunderstorms
DOC.TEXT: Storms brought snow, thunder and high wind to the Great Lakes on Thursday, rain fell along much of the East, and a new storm spread rain and snow over the Northwest. In Alabama, a tornado touched down about 21 miles west-southwest of Troy during the early morning, ripping through a mobile home park and injuring at least 24 people. Wind blowing at 40 mph whipped up to 9 inches of snow across southeastern Wisconsin, snarling traffic, closing schools and airports at Milwaukee and elsewhere and forcing a small plane to crash-land. The pilot of the plane that crash-landed walked away without injury. Wisconsin Electric Co. reported more than 60 electrical wires were downed by the wet, heavy snow, cutting power for about 10,000 customers in Milwaukee, Kenosha and Racine counties. The storm whipped up near blizzard conditions in Illinois north of Chicago, the National Weather Service said. Up to 9 inches of snow fell overnight while wind gusted to 60 mph. The cover of new snow ranged from 6 to 10 inches from Moline to Chicago by noon. Northwestern Lower Michigan was covered with up to 8 inches of new snow at noon. At midday, snow was falling across northern Lower Michigan, Upper Michigan, Wisconsin, the northern two-thirds of Illinois, central Indiana, and east-central Minnesota. Earlier, snow also fell across parts of Iowa, with 3 inches at Burlington. Precipitation from that storm turned to showers and thunderstorms from south-central Lower Michigan across western Ohio into northeastern Kentucky. Thunderstorms caused scattered wind damage in Michigan, the weather service said, with gusts to more than 50 mph at Ann Arbor. In the Northwest, winter storm warnings were posted over the Washington Cascades and Olympics and the Oregon Cascades. Winter storm watches were posted into Friday across west-central and southwestern Idaho and a snow advisory was issued for northwestern Wyoming. Snow was scattered over western Wyoming and the Idaho Panhandle. Rain fell across much of Washington state and northwestern Oregon. Wind gusted during the morning to 55 mph at Bellingham, Wash., and to 58 mph at Livingston, Mont. In the East, rain was falling at noon from southern Maine across northern Delaware, from New York state across western Virginia, eastern West Virginia, western North Carolina, western South Carolina and the northern half of Georgia. A flood watch was in effect into Friday morning over western Vermont and eastern New York state. In Florida, Jacksonville reached a record high of 83 and Palm Beach hit a record high of 84. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 10 degrees below zero at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 15 at Warroad, Minn., to 85 in Florida at Barton, Lakeland and Fort Myers.

DOC.HEAD: Spiritual Leader of Maine Shakers Dead at 92
DOC.TEXT: Sister R. Mildred Barker, the spiritual leader of Maine's tiny Shaker community, died Thursday after an extended illness. She was 92. Her death leaves just eight Shakers in the last active Maine community of the Protestant faith, said Leonard Brooks, director of the Shaker museum in Gloucester, where the group has its 1,900-acre farm. A religous sect that flourished in the 19th century, Shakerism practices celibacy and a communal life revolving around worship and farming. Sister Mildred was put in charge in 1931 of the Shaker's jelly and jam industry, as well as a candy-making business. She made sales trips as far away as Boston and sold eggs in Portland, Maine, the Shakers said in a statement. In 1950, she was chosen trustee of the community, overseeing business and financial matters. The community raises sheep and grows apples and herbs. Sister Mildred was born in Providence, R.I., on Feb. 3, 1897, and at age 7 after her father died her mother placed her among the Shakers, Brooks said. Brooks said former President Ronald Reagan recognized Sister Mildred in 1983 for her expertise in singing old Shaker songs, many of which were recorded on four albums. ``Sister Mildred's single greatest delight was singing the beautiful old Shaker hymns that had been taught to her in her youth,'' the statement said. ``She personally knew thousands of songs and sought to preserve them.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... diplomacy. Yeah?
DOC.TEXT: Q: If I could ask the question again, sir, what _ A: You might. You'll get the same answer if you ask the same question. Q: Were the missions not kept secret to avoid the overwhelming public opposition to them? A: No. The missions were kept secret because I believe this is the best way in dealing with China to effect change, positive change. Yes? You warned yesterday about China's action if your veto was not sustained. What I don't understand is why China would _ since you've promised to do the same things administratively that the Pelosi bill would have done, why _ A: Yeah. Q: _ China would regard that as interference, but you doing it they wouldn't. A: I think they would see it as a further public slap at a time when they feel some steps have been taken that are positive. And I think that is probably what _ but let there be no mistake about it, they _ I'm sure they're not very happy with my executive order. I mean, they're entitled to their view and we're entitled to ours. And I have a mandate to protect these students, and China, as you know, has a very different view on it. But I think that's the only thing I can think of. Yeah? Q: May I ask on a different topic _ on the Middle East? You've had three press conferences in two days now, and there's been no questions at all about the Middle East. Is this a signal that your administration and that the American public as a whole is disgusted with the slow pace of events towards the peace process? A: No, because I don't write the questions for the press conference. I mean, I can't help it if they had no questions. But, I don't think there should _ anything in the status quo should be interpreted as a lack of interest in trying to be helpful on the talks going, if that's what you mean. In fact, there is discussion going on. We had discussions with our most recent visitor, President Salih. I've just concluded a meeting with Senator Specter who is just back from Syria and from Iraq. And there's a lot going on. I wish I could tell you I felt that there was demonstrable progress. But, no, please don't assume because I've addressed myself in the statements to the China question and the question of Panama or the question of our domestic agenda that we have lost interest in trying to be a catalyst in the Middle East. Q: Do you think one side is being more recalcitrant than the other? A: I don't think it would be helpful to quantify recalcitrance. I think what we ought to do is what Jim Baker is trying to do right now and that is to facilitate the talks to get them started. Yeah. Q: Mr. President, with this victory in the Senate, do you anticipate sending Gen. Scowcroft or perhaps some other envoy back to China to talk again perhaps in the open this time? A: I'm not sure Scowcroft and Eagleburger want anymore grief like this _ (laughs). There's no plans to do _ (laughs). You know, there's no _ (laughing) _ let me be very clear, this again _ and I'm not dodging the question _ one, there are no plans for anything of that nature. Secondly, this was my idea, for good or for bad. And these are seasoned diplomats and seasoned people in national security, and we talk about these matters. And when the President makes a decision, why they _ they do what I suggest here. And so, I don't want to be doing anything other than expressing total confidence in them and in their mission. And I know it's been controversial, but I'm not _ I'm not somebody that's always looking for a way to do something in secret. When I see though, back to the question I was asked, that in my judgment a quiet conversation might lead to progress, I hope I will continue to feel I have the flexibility to pursue such a conversation. Yeah _

DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, when you send your memorandum of disapproval of the China students bill, you characterized it as a pocket veto and said that the constitutional provision precluded it becoming law, and yet, we haven't heard you object to the fact that the Congress took the vote to override. Have you changed your mind on that? A: I need a lawyer on that one. I don't _ I really am not _ (sighs) _ I don't change _ Q: I certainly would like to follow it up somehow _ A: Well, yeah, let's get _ let's _ I think we should get _ Q: You need a lawyer here. A: I really do. (Laughter.) That gets technical and I can't _ Q: Some people said that, by sending the message back, you undid your pocket veto and actually gave them a veto to override. Yeah, in the middle? Q: You indicated in the beginning of your statement that you feel you do have a mandate now on this China policy. A lot of people have criticized it as a secret policy. DOC.HEAD: At Least 24 Dead, 32 Missing in Tunisian Floods
With AM-Europe-Storms
DOC.TEXT: Authorities raised the death toll from flooding this week to at least 24, with another 32 people missing and thousands homeless, the official news agency TAP reported Thursday. The torrential rains that struck the North African country on Monday slackened Thursday as the United Nations and foreign countries responded to a government appeal for food, tents, water pumps and other emergency aid. Floodwaters receded in central and southern Tunisia, normally arid regions that were hit hardest by the storm, and overland links were reestablished with the communities of Sidi Bouzid, Gafsa, Gabes, Tozeur and Kasserine, TAP reported. About 14,000 homes were destroyed in the flooding, TAP said, and thousands of homeless people sought shelter in schools, mosques and public buildings. The Health Ministry issued a statement saying there appeared no risk of an epidemic. The news agency earlier reported a riot Wednesday by Islamic fundamentalists in the central city of Sidi Bouzid, where 13 people died, TAP said. About 800 sympathizers of the outlawed fundamentalist movement An Nahda hurled rocks at government buildings and burned a parked car as they paraded around the body of a person they said had died in the floods, TAP reported. Police arrested 26 people in the demonstration. TAP said the protesters expressed their hostility toward the Tunisian educational system ''without any relationship to the situation brought on by the flooding.''

DOC.HEAD: FDA Criticism Criticized
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration's warning against an American Heart Association food-labeling plan was criticized Thursday by a consumer group and at least one food company wanting to display the plan's seal of approval on its products. The association said it will begin ``Heartguide'' on Monday, despite the FDA's warning that participating companies could face enforcement action if their products are found to be mislabeled, and will stick to its plan to extend the labels to more foods. The Heartguide program puts an association ``Heart Healthy'' seal on approved products. Two of the nine companies with Heartguide-approved products said they will remain in the program, though their packaging with the Heartguide seal won't go on sale until mid-Febrary or March. The other companies either had not yet decided how to react to the warning or did not return telephone calls. Bruce Silverglade, legal director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, an advocacy group that frequently seeks tougher food and drug regulations, said that while he shares some of the FDA's concerns about Heartguide, the agency's action is ``premature and unfortunate.'' ``The federal government has defaulted on its obligation to control misleading health claims by food manufacturers, and the heart association's plan does represent an attempt to provide some reliable health information to consumers,'' he said. He said the FDA has been trying for several years to adopt a regulation restricting health claims that food manufacturers can put on their labels. The agency has also been criticized for moving too slowly to revise requirements for food labeling in general. The FDA held hearings last fall on food labeling and plans to draft a proposal by summer, a spokesman said. In a letter to the association Wednesday, the FDA expressed concern that the Heartguide program will increase consumer confusion and could lead to endorsement of some margarine and oil products that ``do not represent the kinds of foods that ought to be promoted to achieve healthy hearts.'' Silverglade said he shares that concern and added that the association ``may be giving out the seal a little to generously and that their standards were not strict enough.'' For the first phase of the program, more than 100 brands of margarine, oil, crackers and vegetables have been tested and approved. They include Mazola corn oil, Promise margarine, Pam cooking sprays, Melba Toast and Hanover frozen vegetables. Companies pay a fee _ up to $640,000 depending on sales _ to participate in the program. In the second phase, which initially was put on hold after the FDA letter but put back on track Thursday, the seal will be offered to other products, including cereals, cheese, cookies, pasta, salad dressings and other foods. The FDA has no authority to stop the program, but it could take companies to court if it finds their labels misrepresent their products. One of the companies in the program said it intends to advertise its seal of approval, despite the FDA warning. ``I don't think I'm afraid of it because I think there will be a resolution to the problem,'' said Bob Maier, chairman of California & Washington Co., a San Francisco-based company that markets frozen vegetables. ``I think both groups are trying to do best for the consumer.'' He noted that other third-party endorsements, including the Good Housekeeping seal of approval and the American Dental Association, are being used now to guide consumers in other markets.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Budget Will Aim to Improve Government Statistics
DOC.TEXT: The budget President Bush will propose Monday will include about $50 million to improve government statistics affecting most Americans, ranging from cost-of-living wage increases to prices of stocks in which pension funds invest heavily, the president's chief economic adviser said Thursday. Contending that the U.S. statistical system is among the finest in the world, Chairman Michael J. Boskin of the Council of Economic Advisers admitted it still has serious problems, especially in the rapidly changing areas where accuracy is most needed. ``The economic statistics are important because of their large impact on the economy,'' Boskin said at a news briefing on Bush's initiative to improve economic statistics. ``Private orders and contracts, cost-of-living adjustments, the federal budget and monetary policy are all based on the economic information produced by the federal statistical system,'' he added. Boskin said various government agencies are expected to report in about three months on how they plan to implement 25 recommendations already made by the presidential Economic Policy Council's working group to improve the system. Boskin, who heads the group, said the most serious problem facing the government's statistics-gathering operation is estimating quality change in many important sectors. ``When we as a nation produced mostly things like steel and wheat, output was easy to count _ tons of steel and bushels of wheat,'' he said. ``Today a larger share of output is in sectors where better performance means quality and improved convenience,'' he continued. ``Consider the impact of 24-hour automatic teller machines, and the changes in desktop and laptop computers.'' As an example of the need to examine measurement problems, Boskin cited price indexes that should adjust for quality change. ``When the Commerce Department recently introduced a new computer price index that only partially adjusted for quality change, it raised real GNP (gross antional product) growth from 3.8 to 4.1 percent (a difference reaching $70 billion by 1988) and lowered the rate in inflation (as measured by the GNP price deflator) from 3.6 to 3.3 percent between 1982 and 1988,'' he said. Boskin also said the government's statistical system has not kept up with changes in the economy, including airline deregulation, which he said produced lower fares and widespread discounting, causing passenger miles to increase by over 60 percent in the 1980s. ``Yet the price index is still heavily based on full-fare tickets, which now account for only 10 percent of tickets'' he noted.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Oil Pipeline Dynamited, Spill Covers Two Miles
DOC.TEXT: A dynamite attack on the country's main petroleum pipeline Thursday caused an oil spill covering nearly two square miles and leaked thousands of barrels of crude into a mountain stream, the state petroleum company Ecopetrol reported. An Ecopetrol communique did not say who was responsible for the attack outside Teorama, but authorities believe it was almost certainly perpetrated by leftist guerrillas belonging to the National Liberation Army, known as the ELN. The ELN has claimed responsibility for 115 attacks against Colombian petroleum facilities since 1986 in an effort to force the government to nationalize the industry. The group called a halt to the attacks in the second half of 1989 but renewed them this year to protest a hike in the domestic price of gasoline. The Ecopetrol communique said the blast near Teorama would have serious ecological consequences because thousands of barrels of spilled crude flowed into a pristine stream that feeds the Catatumbo River. Teorama is 260 miles north of the capital Bogota. Thursday's attack was the third this year against the pipeline running from the Cano Limon oil field on the border with Venezuela to the Caribbean port of Covenas, near Cartegena. Ecopetrol said it was stopping the flow of crude through the pipeline until a team could repair it.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... done. Yes?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, as you analyze the outcome today and the vote itself, how much of it was a vote on the Chinese student issue, and how much of it do you perceive to be a vote on your overall approach to China? A: I _ or on the political side, I don't know. I don't know how you measure it, but I do think this: As I had an opportunity to discuss it with individuals and as our team did, I think there was much more understanding of the merits than had been granted originally. And I think we'd all agree, everybody here, that a couple of weeks ago, there was just _ it just was kind of written off as _ and getting pounded on the merits as well as on the politics. So the consultations and the discussions to try to get support for this, I think, have increased understanding even by those that didn't vote for me. At least I think they understand that there were some merits to what I was trying to do. They may have disagreed with it. Some may have agreed with what is the thrust of some of these questions, on the secrecy question. Some may have felt that legislation is better than the, you know, executive branch authority doing it. But I think I was given the benefit of the doubt by some in terms of knowledge of the importance of the relationship with China. I think I hopefully dissuaded some in terms of some of the propaganda on the other side that I didn't care about human rights. So, it was an interesting development here, taking a project that many had considered extraordinarily difficult and then seeing it resolve itself in this way. But there is no _ you know, there is no intention on my part to crow about it. I mean it was a very close vote, and it worked out better than many had felt it would and now we've got to go forward. Tomorrow it's something else. I am not going to live there on this thing forever. Q: If I may follow? Was there not a broader issue in regard to China policy here than just the situation with the students? A: What? I don't want to _ I am not sure I _ Q: Was this not a congressional mandate or a Senate mandate on the way you handled the overall China policy, more than just the student issue? A: Well, some of it was. Some of it was political, some of it was _ we'd already accomplished by executive order what the Pelosi Bill was going to do, so some of it was a feeling that maybe it'd be better to lock it in on legislation. Some of it was they wanted to make a statement. There's a lot of _ you have to just ask those who voted as they did. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, a lot of the emotion over your China policy had to do with the famous Scowcroft toast on videotape. It angered a lot of people to see him toasting people responsible for the Tiananmen Square massacre. Would you say that at least that part of it was a mistake, that it _ A: No, because when you go to China, that is _ I don't know of anybody that's been there that doesn't engage in that activity. And if you read the full context of what was said, I think it was a very unfair shot. But I agree with you, some people used that as something that was outrageous, but they ought to go over to China and just understand how it works and _ Q: If it had not been televised, do you think the public reaction _ if people had only known that he went over there and that he had had talks, do you think the public reaction would have been different than it was when they saw him toasting on television? A: No, I think the people that are outraged by it and expressed themselves were concerned about my whole approach to it. I think, but I can't say that that _ I think that it may have affected one or two, I don't really know the answer to that one. Michael, did I answer or did you get the question? DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Gorbachev America's `Best Hope' in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout to reflect second news conference
DOC.TEXT: President Bush praised Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday as the ``best hope'' for the United States in the Soviet Union and declined to fault him for using force to restore order in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. The president also hailed a Senate victory on his China policy, calling it a ``good signal for the political fights'' ahead. Bush gave a new strong endorsement to the embattled Soviet president, telling a luncheon audience of 75 newspaper executives: ``I think we have a lot at stake in continuing to deal with this man.'' ``I want very much for him to succeed,'' Bush said. ``And I don't think anyone is faulting him for the difficulties that he has encountered in Azerbaijan.'' The president used the luncheon to unveil his latest anti-drug strategy, but he also fielded questions on a range of other subjects. Then, after the Senate vote upholding his veto of a bill to prohibit the deportation of Chinese students, Bush bounded to the White House briefing room to applaud the vote. ``Surprised you, didn't it?'' he said of the Senate outcome. He called the vote ``a good signal for the political fights that may lie ahead.'' Asked whether the victory with which he had started the year would transfer to other issues, Bush said: ``I'm not in a mode of talking about momentum or something of that nature. I do think, because of the way it worked out, it's going to be helpful in reaching accommodation in the Senate and in the House on certain of our objectives.'' ``I don't come in here with any sense of gloating,'' he said. ``Excuse me if the adrenalin flew,'' he said as he conducted the day's second half-hour news conference, at which he also announced a $1 billion aid package for Panama. Bush was asked at the session with newspaper executives about Gorbachev's use of military force in an effort to put down the separatist rebellion in Azerbaijan. ``You see blockades of your ports, and the man has to respond,'' Bush said. ``I'm not encouraging that course, because we would like to see peaceful change wherever possible.'' Overall, he said, Gorbachev has done ``a remarkable job.'' Asked about contentions of some analysts that Gorbachev's political position was precarious, Bush said he ``wouldn't speculate on the totality of survival.'' ``It's not for some president of the United States to start saying who he thinks ought to be in that job,'' Bush continued. ``But, as I look around, I think Mr. Gorbachev is really the best hope for what our interests are.'' ``We want to see peaceful change continue, we want to see democratization of Eastern Europe, we want to see openness, bring about market-force economies inside the Soviet Union. And all of these things are in our interest.'' On other subjects, Bush said at either the session with newspaper executives or the later news conference in the briefing room: _ He did not wish to point a finger at any party for the apparent impasse in Middle East peace talks and promised that the United States would ``continue to be a catalyst'' in trying to bring Israel, the Palestinians and Egypt to the bargaining table. _ There have been ``some very ugly incidents'' among recent bombings and racial violence but, ``I'd like to think there is not a rising tide.'' _ He will tell Americans in his State of the Union address next Wednesday that he has a ``feeling that the country is going to be in pretty good shape.'' _ ``A strong and vigorous economy'' is the best answer for helping communities affected by military base closings to recover. He plans to send a list of proposed base closings to Congress on Monday when he submits his fiscal 1991 budget. Bush said that in the past, private business had often moved in and provided jobs in areas that lost government installations. _ His position ``has not changed on gun control. ... I think the thing is to enforce the laws on the books.'' _ ``While the matter is in the courts'' he would not comment on whether he would consider pardons for former Reagan White House aides Oliver North or John Poindexter. North is appealing his convictions and Poindexter is awaiting trial. _ He hopes to be able to do more in the coming months to combat the problem of homelessness, saying that ``when you go upstairs and look out that window you see some pretty heart-rending sights.'' He was referring to homeless people who sleep on heating grates within sight of the White House.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... No, I _
DOC.TEXT: Q: Back to Panama, sir. The election last May is the one that never really resulted in a full count, because of General Noriega. Yet that's the same election on which the Endara government is basing its legitimacy. Is it time, sir, for another election in Panama? A: Well, I think that, fortunately, the Endara has been endorsed by the electoral commission. They kind of were a little diverted from their normal course of business by Mr. Noriega a while back, but I think that's a matter for the Panamanians to decide. I think it would be a little bit outrageous for us to come charging in and tell them when they ought to have an election. Way in the back? Q: But what is your opinion? A: You're not way in the back. You're in the middle. Huh? Q: What is your opinion on this? A: Well, I'm not going to have an opinion. I want this to be the Panamanian system. The emphasis from now on ought to be Panama's democracy, Panama determination. Let Panama figure out and then we'll try to help, or if they ask for criticism or suggestions, fine. But I don't want to be appearing that we are trying to _ to run the new democracy in Panama from up here. That would the worst thing we could do. Way in the middle and in the back. Q: On another topic, several key Democratic senators say they no longer _ they don't believe that President Cristiani has control of the military any longer. What is your response to that? They are also drafting legislation which would kill future military aid. Do you think you will be as successful in defeating that passage as you were today? A: I hope so because Cristiani is trying hard and I think that there is some evidence that he doesn't control all his military. The very fact he is trying to bring some to justice who at least have been accused of wrongdoing demonstrates that. But the man was elected, certifiably free elections. He is trying very hard. He has taken some extraordinarily courageous and tough steps and he has my full support. Jessica and then Ellen _ these three in this triangle here and then I'm going. Jessica, you lead off. Q: My question is about Mexico and Venezuela and other countries in South America that have been offended by the invasion in Panama. A: Yes. Q: I wonder if _ could you have spoken with their leaders and used some of your personal diplomacy to convince them that you didn't intend any offense and won't be invading any other countries any time soon. (Laughter.)

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Drug Plan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The revised national drug control strategy unveiled Thursday by President Bush carries a price tag of $10.6 billion for 1991, up $1.1 billion from the current $9.5 billion in spending. Here, at a glance, are the main features of the proposal, most of which needs congressional approval. _Of the total spending, 42 percent would be for domestic law enforcement, 29 percent for drug interdiction at the borders and international operations and 29 percent for demand reduction, including prevention and treatment. _Treatment funds would increase by 12 percent to $1.5 billion; anti-drug education and community and workplace programs to prevent drug abuse would get $1.2 billion, an 11 percent increase. Research would increase by 20 percent to $383 million, _Criminal justice funds would increase by 2 percent to $4.3 billion; interdiction efforts would increase by 17 percent to $2.4 billion; international initiatives would rise by 65 percent to $690 million, and intelligence budgets would go up by 142 percent to $172 million. _The strategy calls for expanding the circumstances under which drug kingpins could face the death penalty, including cases in which they or their organizations have not killed anyone, when they try to kill in order to obstruct justice, or when their offenses result in death, such as a drug user's overdose. _About $2.6 billion of the total budget would be distributed to state and local governments in the form of block grants for law enforcement, drug treatment and anti-drug education programs. _Five areas are designated as high-intensity drug-trafficking areas _ New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Houston and the Southwest border of California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas. Although the budget specifically mentions spending $25 million extra for those areas this year and $50 million next year, officials said total federal anti-drug spending in the five regions would be $1.2 billion this year and $1.4 billion next year. _The Andean strategy of buttressing the drug-fighting efforts of the main cocaine-producing countries of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia with $2.2 billion in drug law enforcement and economic development aid over five years continues, increasing from $217 million in 1990 to $423 million in 1991, including $50 million in additional aid for Colombia. _Pregnant women who use drugs and their drug-addicted babies would be targeted with $400 million in prevention and treatment funds. _New attention is focused on eradicating domestic marijuana fields, with a virtual doubling of federal funds, to $35 million. _The Pentagon takes a much more significant role in the drug war with a budget of $1.2 billion, up from $878 million this year, with $638 million to be used for detection and monitoring of drug traffickers crossing the U.S. borders.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Announces Billion-Dollar Aid Package for Panama
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with details of package, reaction from Panama; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday announced he will offer an aid package of more than $1 billion to help Panama recover from the U.S. military invasion and achieve ``as close to instant relief as we can expect.'' ``The economic challenges that Panama faces are great, but we will work with the people to build a prosperous, democratic nation,'' Bush told a news conference. His package, much of which needs congressional approval, includes: _$42 million in humanitarian assistance for housing, emergency public works, small business rehabilitation for looting victims and technical assistance to the government. _$400 million in Export Import Bank guarantees to finance sales of American products to Panama. _$15 million in Agency for International Development lending to private sector borrowers. _$50 million in Overseas Private Investment Corporation programs to support U.S. private investment in Panama. _$30 million in Agriculture Department programs. _$28 million to restore Panama's suspended sugar quota for 1989 and 1990. Another $500 million would go to balance of payment support, public investment, economic restructuring and development needed in the wake of the invasion and two years of economic starvation due to U.S. economic sanctions against the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. That sum will include $150 million toward helping Panama pay its foreign debt of more than $500 million, officials said. That $500 million needs congressional approval as a supplemental appropriation, while the other monies will come from reprogramming of existing funds, they said. Bush said foreign aid would have to be cut from other countries, but did not specify which ones. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger told reporters Bush had not made that decision yet. The package will go toward repairing damages estimated at up to $2 billion stemming from the Dec. 20 invasion. ``These programs will give as close to instant relief as we can expect here,'' Bush told reporters in a hastily called news conference where he also claimed victory in the Senate vote upholding his veto of Chinese-students legislation. Bush said he called the U.S.-installed president of Panama, Guillermo Endara, on Thursday morning ``to assure him of our continued support of his efforts to establish democracy in Panama.'' ``Part of this effort involves the establishment of a healthy economy,'' he said. Vice President Dan Quayle, who visits Panama this weekend, will review details of the plan with Endara, Bush said. ``We're going to work closely with the Congress on this package to ensure its prompt implementation,'' Bush said. He predicted a short-run ``vastly improved economic situation.'' Bush also said he told Endara that if he has further needs for aid, ``please let me know'' but that Endara seemed pleased with the $1 billion package. Bush added, ``I wouldn't say this is the end of the road in terms of what we can do to help them.'' But Endara said in Panama that the proposed $1 billion package was about half what his government had requested. Endara said in a statement that the aid would help create jobs and revitalize the international banking system, which was once the backbone of Panama's economy. But he also said the government would require a ``substantial reduction of its payroll.'' Bush also did not offer any compensation for the families of 202 civilians killed in the fighting, which the Panamanians have insisted upon. In the Senate, leading members of the Foreign Relations Committee, including Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and Republican Richard Lugar of Indiana, indicated they generally backed aid to Panama. ``I applaud that effort,'' said Pell. Several liberal Democrats, however, were more cautious and expressed concern that Noriega associates would benefit. ``My concern is that we are changing the name, changing the uniform, but they are still the same people,'' said Sen. Christopher dodd, D-Conn. The administration will encourage other nations to also help Panama clear its debt and seek ``an early and generous rescheduling of Panama's debt to foreign governments'' under the auspices of the so-called Paris club of major lender nations. The United States already has released $400 illion in Panamanian assets frozen in the United States in earlier efforts to topple the Noriega regime. The program, if approved, would make Panama one of the largest per capita aid recipients in the world. Panama, which has 2.2 million residents, is behind on its foreign loan repayments, owing $534 million. Bush also said that it should be up to the Panamanian people to decide whether to have a new election instead of accepting Endara, a candidate in last year's election who was installed when Noriega fled in the face of the U.S. invasion. ``I don't want to be appearing that we are trying to run the new democracy in Panama from up here. That would be the worst thing we could do,'' Bush said. Asked whether other Latin governments, upset about the Panama operation, should be worried about future invasions, he quipped: ``I haven't given them my invasion list.'' But he said that he believes the Latin nations, upset over the invasion, now understand the U.S. position. Especially given the U.S. history in the region, Bush said, ``Anytime you undertake an engagement like I authorized, you've got to assess what the downside is because there is a history.''

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Columbia Mounted on Jet, Leaves California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, bgn `The plane...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with plane landing in San Antonio, comments from NASA. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Columbia, the...'
DOC.TEXT: A modified jumbo jet carried space shuttle Columbia and a rescued satellite out of California on Thursday for a two-day piggyback flight to Florida's Kennedy Space Center, NASA said. The Boeing 747 shuttle carrier aircraft, with Columbia mounted on top, took off about 7:30 a.m. PST. ``It was a pretty sight,'' said Don Haley, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``The sun was just up and it was glistening in the air.'' The plane landed for a refueling stop at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base near Tucson, Ariz., about 1{ hours later and at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio, Texas, about 3:10 p.m. for an overnight stop. If weather permits, the plane will refuel again Friday at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida before returning to the space center at Cape Canaveral. One extra refueling stop was added to each day of the trip from California to Florida because of extra weight added by the satellite the shuttle is transporting, NASA spokeswoman Pat Phillips said in San Antonio. During the San Antonio stop, cool air will be blown on the shuttle to keep the cargo within specified temperature ranges, she said. Columbia, the oldest shuttle, landed at this Mojave Desert military base at 1:35 a.m. PST Saturday after a record 10-day, 21-hour mission. The shuttle's five-member crew deployed a Navy communications satellite then retrieved the 11-ton, 30-foot-long Long Duration Exposure Facility, a science satellite that soon would have burned up in Earth's atmosphere if it had not been plucked from its decaying orbit. The LDEF will be removed from Columbia's cargo bay after arrival at Kennedy Space Center. NASA will begin work immediately to prepare Columbia for its next launch, scheduled May 3. The next shuttle mission is scheduled to start Feb. 22, when Atlantis is to be launched on a classified Defense Department mission. Atlantis was moved to its Cape Canaveral launch pad Thursday. Sources close to the project report the secret payload to be deployed by Atlantis' all-military crew of five is a spy satellite capable of snapping super-sharp reconnaissance photos and eavesdropping on military communications. Discovery will be launched no earlier than April 19 to place the powerful Hubble Space Telescope in orbit. During its next mission in May, Columbia is scheduled to deploy Astro-1, which is an orbiting ultraviolet telescope, and the Broad Band X-ray Telescope.

DOC.TEXT: A: Well, I haven't given them my invasion list _ (laughter) _ but I have _ I have _ no, but seriously, it's a very important question diplomatically. It's a good question and I _ I _ first place, as of today, because of what's happened since the fighting began, things are better. Some of it may be just that time heals. Secondly, I think that they have been informed, some by me _ mail, phone calls when these actions took place, and by many other _ our State Department and our representatives as to what our intention was, what the cause was, what we're doing. And any time you undertake an engagement like I authorized, you've got to assess what the downside is because of the history. But, Jessica, I am _ I am pleased with where we are now and I have not engaged in the last week or so in a lot of diplomatic activity with my friends, but I've sent enough communications that I think they know what my heartbeat is on this and I think they _ I hope now when they saw what happened with the Panamanian people that they made profound impression on them. And they've seen Endara go forward, and they've seen the stamp of approval given to that _ his democracy. And they see that now, as of today, that we're determined to help, not just with rhetoric but with the means of recovery. So things are better and, I think, in _ given the action that I authorized _ in pretty good shape. I'm not suggesting I have no diplomacy ahead. Yeah? Q: Yes, Mr. President, a surprise victory to start the year. Will this transfer to other issues? And is this what someone once called the ``big mo'' _ momentum starting off 1990? (Laughter.) A: Hey, listen, I learned a lesson, not to talk about that, and I learned it the hard way; took it right on the chin. And I'm coming in here in a spirit of cooperation. And excuse me if the adrenalin flew in one or two of the questions because, you know, things didn't look too bright just a little while back. But, no, there's no point in _ this is too serious a business, especially as it relates to this China policy. And _ so I'm not in a mode of talking about momentum or something of that nature. I do think because of the way it worked out it's going to be helpful in reaching accommodation in the Senate and in the House on certain of our objectives. And by that I mean, I'm _ offer out that hand of cooperation. But it is a two-way street. I simply cannot accept legislation that is _ that is opposed to principles I believe in. So, I don't know where it will fall out, but there isn't _ I promise you, I don't come in here with some sense of gloating or anything of that nature at all. It was too tough a vote for a lot of my friends on both sides of the aisle. Yeah, Ellen, last one. Q: Mr. President, in announcing $1 billion for Panama, that's an awful lot of money. So who _ what countries are going to get less money as a result of our generosity to Panama? A: Well, there will be offsets and we will, at the appropriate time, which is fairly soon, tell the Congress where we think those offsets should come from. But let me reiterate my _ my philosophical approval for the Bob Dole position, which is to give the President more flexibility on this concept of earmark. I've _ I've _ I've _ I've boycotted the back benches, so we're going to end with this one right here. Q: Mr. President, do you agree with the NAACP, and other organizations, that there is a rising tide of racism in this country? A: I had a long talk with some of the executives of the NAACP the other day and they expressed to me their concerns, and I share their concerns. But whether it _ I like to think that there isn't a rising tide, I think that there are some very ugly incidents, and if I can use this platform, the White House, to speak out against that bigotry and against that ugliness, perhaps it will help. I don't _ but I will tell you that several of those leaders felt that there was a growing pattern of racism and, as you _ you know, your question said ``a rising tide.'' I don't know that I agree with it, but I do agree there are some very ugly incidents lately, and we all ought to do what we can to make clear that is not the American way. Thank you. I really do have to go. Thank you all. You guys have been stiffed, but I'll get you next time, I promise.
DOC.HEAD: END TEXT
AFT Forms Project to Help Eastern Europe Teachers
DOC.TEXT: The American Federation of Teachers said Thursday it will help educators in Eastern European countries and others emerging from dictatorship teach the principles and practices of democracy and the operation of teachers' unions. The project, named ``Education for Democracy-International,'' will begin immediately in Poland where a delegation will hold a seminar Sunday for Teachers Solidarity to give advice on collective bargaining and negotiating. Albert Shanker, president of the union, said that the Polish efforts will be a pilot program that can be repeated in other countries. Requests already have arrived from union leaders and educators in Hungary, Chile, South Africa and Czechoslovakia, he said. ``People in Romania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and elsewhere are not only trying to recover from years of political and economic repression but they also are trying to build democratic states.'' Shanker said. ``We owe it to them to do whatever we can to help.'' Diane Ravitch, a professor at Teachers College of Columbia University in New York City, said the two one-week sessions will try to give more than 50 leading teachers and union leaders the opportunity to decide for themselves what democratic structures will best serve their members. ``We don't come pushing ourselves or anything that we do,'' explained Ms. Ravitch. ``We will deal with questions like `How to run a trade union meeting. How to bring a question to a vote.' It's not a matter of delivering answers but to share the problems too.'' To help American teachers instruct students about the liberation of Eastern Europe from dictatorship and about democratic principles in general, the AFT's U.S. Education for Democracy Project will provide materials to American teachers. The first information kit will deal with Czechoslovakia and will be available in February. The two projects also will sponsor ``classroom-to-classroom'' programs linking U.S. schools with counterparts in Hungary and Poland, Shanker said.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Scientist: Corn Probably Escaped Contamination
DOC.TEXT: An Agriculture Department scientist said Thursday the 1989 corn crop probably escaped high levels of contamination by aflatoxin, a natural cancer-causing chemical that plagued growers in 1988. Microbiologist Donald T. Wicklow of the department's Agricultural Research Service said the weather conditions necessary for unusually high aflatoxin levels generally were not present on a national scale last year. He said none has been reported since last fall's harvest. Wicklow works for the agency's northern regional research center in Peoria, Ill. His comments were released here by the agency. Aflatoxin is a poisonous chemical produced by two soil fungi, Aspergillus flavus and A. parasiticus. Wicklow said A. flavus has been found most commonly in peanuts and corn, especially in hot, dry weather as in 1988. Corn will not necessarily be contaminated simply because it was grown in a field that previously produced aflatoxin-tainted corn, Wicklow said. Neither will it pick up aflatoxin from being stored in bins that previously held tainted corn.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Congress-China,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the key provisions of President Bush's order, issued Nov. 30, protecting Chinese students from deportation: _An irrevocable waiver of foreign residency requirements, which can be invoked anytime until Jan. 1, 1994. _Assurances that Chinese nationals who were legally in the United States as of June 5, 1989, be considered to have maintained lawful status for the purposes of adjustment or change of nonimmigrant status. _Authorization for Chinese nationals who were in the United States last June 5 to be legally employed. _An easing of steps against Chinese nationals whose nonimmigrant status has expired. They will receive notice of expiration of nonimmigrant status rather than institution of deporation proceedings. _Enhanced consideration under immigration laws for individuals from any country who express fear of persecution upon retorn to their homeland related to that country's policy of forced abortion or sterilization.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Accused in Illegal Nuclear Exports to Pakistan, India, SAfrica
DOC.TEXT: Five West Germans have been accused of exporting components to Pakistan that could be used to make nuclear weapons and of shipping reactor material to South Africa and India, officials said Thursday. The case is the worst export scandal to hit West Germany since accusations last year that West German companies helped build an alleged chemical weapons plant outside Tripoli, Libya. The five suspects are accused of violating West Germany's laws for the control of war weapons and its export regulations, said a statement by the prosecutor's office in Hanau, near Frankfurt. According to the statement, the suspects are Rudolf Ortmayer, former head of the Neue Technologie GmbH company of Gelnhausen; a former business partner, physicist Peter Finke; chemist Heinrich Weichselgartner; and two unidentified businessmen. From 1981-88, Ortmayer and Finke allegedly sent Pakistan equipment and components for producing nuclear fuel rods without obtaining the necessary permit, the statement said. The prosecutors also said the two unidentified men and Weichselgartner are suspected of illegally shipping tritium gas to Pakistan in 1985-86, as well as shipments of equipment for collecting and purifying the gas. Tritium can be used in the manufacture of nuclear weapons. Ortmayer was additionally accused of exporting to India material for two atomic reactors, and a test device for measuring fuel rods to South Africa, in both cases without the necessary permits, said the statement. Both Ortmayer and Finke were additionally charged with failing to pay about 5 million marks ($2.9 million) in taxes, the statement said. The statement said arrest warrants for the suspects were ``carried out'' but it did not say if all five were in custody. The investigation was launched in November 1987, and the case has been the subject of special parliamentary hearings. The suspects could face up to 18 years in prison if convicted. The case follows last year's scandal triggered by U.S. accusations that West German firms helped build an alleged poison gas plant in Libya. The West German government at first rejected the reports, but later German prosecutors launched an investigation that is continuing. West Germany, embarrassed by the Libya scandal, toughened up its export laws last year and vowed to crack down on violators.

DOC.HEAD: Measure Proposed To Increase Unemployment Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version is on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Raising unemployment taxes now would prevent painful increases during a possible recession, sponsors said Thursday as they introduced legislation to raise an extra $2.6 billion a year from those taxes by 1993. The plan by three House Democrats comes at a time when many members of Congress are discussing a cut in the Social Security payroll tax, which would provide millions of workers with a tax cut. One of the sponsors, Rep. Tom Downey of New York, chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee on human resources, said the two issues should not be linked because Social Security funds are ``flushed at the current time'' and unemployment accounts are not. He said workers have historically supported unemployment programs because they stand to benefit from them. The AFL-CIO supports the plan, said a spokeswoman. Downey, noting President Bush's no-new-taxes campaign pledge, defended the measure as merely an expansion of an old tax that has not kept pace with increases in the amount of benefits paid to unemployed Americans. The White House has not reviewed the legislation or taken a stand, said spokesman Stephen Hart. The measure would make other changes in unemployment compensation law such as allowing ex-military personnel to receive benefits for 26 weeks, just like civilians out of work, instead of the 13 weeks now permitted. Downey said there is now an $11 billion shortfall in federal unemployment compensation accounts, including the fund used for making loans to states so they can make payments. Without some change, nearly half the states would run out of funds to pay benefits if another recession hits, he predicted. ``We can pay additional unemployment taxes now during good economic times, or we can pay more unemployment taxes later when we have another recession,'' Downey said. Under current law, the federal government taxes employers 0.8 percent on the first $7,000 paid to each employee. Businesses also pay state unemployment taxes on top of that. Though businesses write checks to the government, many economists believe workers shoulder the actual burden through smaller wage increases. Downey's measure would increase the federal wage ceiling to $10,000 by $1,000 a year for the next three years. The current 0.8 percent tax rate includes a 0.2 percent surtax that is set to expire at the end of 1990. Downey's measure would allow the surtax to expire. States must set their taxable wage base at least as high as the federal ceiling. An increase in the federal ceiling to $10,000 would cause $3,000 increases in 17 states and smaller increases in another 18 states. The other sponsors are Reps. Sander Levin of Michigan and Don Pease of Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Cartel Frees Another Hostage, Says He Is the Last
DOC.TEXT: The Medellin cocaine cartel freed the fifth captive Thursday since announcing defeat by the government last week, and said the man was its last kidnapping victim. Juan Camilo Pelaez, a wealthy merchant, was found chained to a window grating of a house in residential section of Medellin, two radio networks reported. He was abducted Jan. 10 in Medellin, hub of Colombia's cocaine trade. ``Mr. Pelaez is the last of our hostages,'' said a statement from the cartel, which declared a week ago that the government anti-drug campaign had won and it would end a terror blitz of bombings, kidnap and murder. Caracol radio said the traffickers gave Pelaez the document and told him to carry it to the press. Authorities said 15 people abducted in the last two months remained in the hands of the traffickers. The cartel denied it held other hostages in Antioquia state, which includes Medellin, but said it knew who did. ``Next week, we will publicly denounce the gang that has the rest of the kidnapping victims in its power in our state,'' the statement said. It accused police of abducting and massacring 12 people, including 10 hired assassins, last week in Gomez Plata, a town 55 miles north of Medellin. Last Sunday, authorities announced the discovery of 12 bullet-riddled bodies at a tourist ranch near Gomez Plata. Antioquia state police identified the victims as two managers of the ranch and 10 Medellin youths who may have belonged to a gang of hired killers. The police said they were investigating the motive. The Medellin cartel leaders said in the statement they would provide evidence and testimony to prove members of the Bogota police force were responsible if the government gave guarantees in return. They did not specify the guarantees. Thursday's message carried the slogan of the Extraditables, a name the Medellin traffickers adopted when they became subject to extradition to the United States. The slogan is: ``We prefer a tomb in Colombia to a jail cell in the United States.'' Since President Virgilio Barco's government declared war on the traffickers in mid-August following the slaying of a popular presidential candidate, bombings and other attacks attributed to them have taken 209 lives. The cartel said in its capitulation last week it would free all hostages, and also would abandon the cocaine trade in return for ``constitutional and legal guarantees,'' which officials interpreted to mean an end to extradition. Barco said he would wait until the traffickers fulfilled their promises before responding to their requests. His government has extradited 13 Colombians wanted on drug charges in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: President Taps Dunne, Former N.Y. Legislator, as Civil Rights Chief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 4 grafs reaction after 4th graf pvs, Dunne, who. Adds 2 grafs Thornburgh comment.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced Thursday that he will nominate former New York state legislator John R. Dunne to the top civil rights job in the Justice Department, a post that has been vacant for more than a year. Bush's first choice for the job, William Lucas, failed to win Senate confirmation last year. The job has been vacant since December 1988, when William Bradford Reynolds stepped down as assistant attorney general for civil rights. Reynolds provoked controversy by opposing affirmative-action programs that involved racial preferences. Dunne, who will turn 60 on Sunday, has a sparse background on civil rights. A former chairman of the New York State Senate Judiciary Committee, he is a graduate of Georgetown University and Yale Law School. Colleen O'Connor, a spokeswoman for the American Civil Liberties Union, said the New York chapter had for years studied Dunne's record on civil rights and found it lacking. ``I think it's fair to say these questions are going to come up'' when Dunne is examined by the Senate Judiciary Committee, she said. ``Because he has not built a solid record that I think will please the civil rights community.'' Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said he did not know enough about Dunne to have formed an opinion. ``We wait to see what this man's record is and we will be looking at it,'' Hooks said. After initial reports in November that Dunne was in line for the civil rights post, he resigned from the all-male Garden City Golf Club, which he had belonged to for 32 years. His hometown is Garden City, N.Y. During most of his 24 years as a state legislator, a part-time post, Dunne lived in Albany at the Fort Orange Club, which until 1988 barred women. The White House announced the Dunne nomination shortly after Bush finished a news conference at which he was asked whether he agrees with NAACP leaders that there is ``a rising tide of racism'' in the country. Bush said he does not view it as ``a rising tide,'' but said, ``There are some very ugly incidents.'' Bush said he shares the concerns of the civil rights leaders about the recent wave of racial bombings and threats in the South. The Lucas nomination was scuttled by intensive lobbying by civil rights groups troubled by Lucas's lack of legal experience and his views that Supreme Court rulings had not eroded civil rights protections under the law. The Senate Judiciary Committee rejected his nomination Aug. 1. Lucas, a onetime Michigan sheriff and Wayne County executive, is now a public liaison official at the Justice Department, a post that did not require confirmation. Dunne, in an interview with The Associated Press on Wednesday, said he had reviewed videotapes of the Judiciary Committee's grilling of Lucas to prepare for his own hearings. ``I looked at that video again over the weekend and it was a very tough spot they put him in,'' said Dunne. ``It's an altogether different ballgame in Washington. Gosh, they play for keeps,'' said Dunne. He acknowledged, ``I haven't had as much experience as I'm sure many civil rights activists perhaps would like to see.'' But Dunne said he has been sufficiently involved in civil rights to have ``an understanding and a sensitivity and caring'' about the issue. Dunne has the backing of Democratic Rep. Charles Rangel, an old friend and the most powerful black member of New York's congressional delegation. Dunne is white. ``If the president has to pick a Republican, he couldn't pick a more decent person than John Dunne,'' Rangel said in a recent interview. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, in a Jan. 2 letter to Bush, called Dunne ``an honorable and conscientious public servant, an able lawyer dedicated to the rule of law, a committed family man and a very decent person.'' Cuomo is also a Democrat. Dunne resigned his legislative seat last September after losing a contest for majority leader in the Republican-controlled state Senate. He is a partner in a Uniondale, N.Y., law firm. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, a longtime friend of Dunne's, noted that Dunne was called to Attica State Prison in 1971 by rioting prisoners to help negotiate the end of a stalemate with state authorities. Dunne ``has devoted most of his professional life as a public servant dedicated to matters relating to the administration of justice, including the rights of institutionalized persons and increased access by the public to legal services,'' Thornburgh said.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Opens Fund-raising Drive for White House Upkeep
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush, saying she wants to keep the White House as ``the first house in the land,'' launched a drive Thursday to raise a $25 million endowment fund for the upkeep and improvement of its famed public rooms. Ms. Bush, announcing the membership of the new White House Endowment Fund, called it ``truly a celebration ... for this splendid house.'' ``Throughout our history the White House has always held a special place in the hearts of Americans, even those 19th century miscreants who cut little pieces of the curtains as souvenirs,'' Mrs. Bush said. The aim is to create an endowment to ensure ``the best care and upkeep of all of its splendid public rooms,'' Mrs. Bush said. The fund-raising effort will be spearheaded by Dorothy M. Craig of Midland, Texas, a friend from the Bushes' days in the oil business. The White House Endowment Fund will be a subsidiary of the White House Historical Association that Jacqueline Kennedy helped create back in the 1960s to produce a guide book and educational materials about the mansion where every president except George Washington has lived. The Historical Association includes such prominent Washington figures as lawyer Clark Clifford and J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery of Art. They were among three dozen people who joined Mrs. Bush in the State Dining Room to announce the fund-raising drive. ``As Clark Clifford told me, Jackie Kennedy said the White House should be the first house in the land, and that's what we're hoping to keep it,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters. The move comes 12 years after an attempt during the Carter administration to raise a $20 million preservation fund failed. Over the years, money has been raised privately from benefactors to buy furniture, paintings and other appointments for the White House, but it has never had an endowment. Just this week the White House announced installation of a new rug, drapes and other furnishings in the Oval Office at a cost of $62,000. Mrs. Craig, whose husband Earle M. Craig Jr. is a retired oilman, said she is hoping to raise the $25 million ``within 2{ to 3 years.'' Mrs. Craig has been part of past preservation efforts at the White House, and also helped raised about $200,000 for refurbishing of the vice presidential mansion when the Bushes lived there. She also played a role in raising funds for the new Oval Office rug. ``Some of my friends at home think I'm going to redecorate the White House. That is not the case,'' she told reporters. ``I'm simply a fund-raiser.'' ``We are starting from scratch,'' she said. Nancy Reagan helped win formal museum status for the White House's public rooms, including the State Dining Room, the East Room, the Green Room and the Blue Room, which tens of thousands of visitors troop through each year.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Made Sexual Advances to Woman Before Arrest, Sources Contend
DOC.TEXT: The night he was arrested on a cocaine possession charge, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. made repeated sexual advances to the woman reported to have helped the FBI lure him to the room, law enforcement sources said Thursday. Barry, who the FBI says was videotaped buying and smoking crack cocaine, kissed and touched Rasheeda Moore during his visit to her hotel room, the law enforcement sources said. She rebuffed him, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. According to an FBI affidavit filed in connection with the misdemeanor drug possession charge, agents used a surveillance camera located in an adjacent room during Barry's 45-minute visit to Ms. Moore's room at the hotel Thursday night. During the visit, the mayor spoke in a decisive voice while conducting city business on the telephone, said one source. The account of sexual advances was first published Thursday in The Washington Post. Barry on Monday checked into a rehabilitation center in West Palm Beach, Fla., after turning over his duties to city administrator Carol Thompson. In developments Thursday: _ Prosecutors delayed the appearance of two of Barry's bodyguards before a grand jury. A scheduling conflict with federal prosecutors investigating Barry's ties to a convicted drug dealer forced the postponement, a source familiar with the probe said. Four members of the mayor's security detail, who are assigned to the mayor on a round-the-clock basis, have been subpoenaed to testify about whether they have knowledge of any Barry drug use, said law enforcement and city government sources. _ Business, labor and community leaders were meeting Thursday night to discuss plans to encourage Jesse Jackson to become a candidate in the November mayoralty election. Meanwhile, however, Jackson complained in comments in The New York Times that the mayor's position had ``zero political leverage.'' _ Former comedian Dick Gregory, who spent several days immediately following Barry's arrest at the mayor's residence, said in Las Vegas that Barry's closest friends were ``tickled to death'' to see that he was seeking help. However, Gregory said at a Las Vegas meeting that he was angry that the federal government has spent so much time and effort in arresting the mayor. _ Bush administration drug policy coordinator William J. Bennett said Barry's arrest ``might be one of these watershed kind of events that changes peoples' attitudes and makes people really realize they have to do something.'' Law enforcement and other sources say Ms. Moore, 38, had a longstanding romantic relationship with the mayor but began cooperating with the FBI's investigation several weeks ago following her arrest on a drunken driving charge near her home in Burbank, Calif. She had been told by the FBI not to have sexual relations with Barry during Thursday night's sting operation, law enforcement sources said. She also was instructed not to smoke any crack or to make any suggestion about using illegal drugs, to avoid any subsequent defense claim of entrapment, the sources said. Barry himself raised the subject of drugs, and purchased a small quantity of crack cocaine from an FBI undercover agent posing as a friend of Ms. Moore, according to a court affidavit and sources. Ms. Moore began cooperating with the FBI after her arrest in North Hollywood, Calif. Jan. 1. The FBI, which had lodged a ``material witness warrant,'' was put in touch with her, authorities in California said. She agreed to cooperate in the sting operation after being confronted with grand jury testimony she gave last spring during which she denied using cocaine with the mayor, sources said. They said she told investigators that she and Barry used drugs on repeated occasions over a number of years, including a March 1988 weekend trip to the Virgin Islands. Her story corroborates testimony by convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, who said he used cocaine with Barry during the Virgin Islands trip and at a downtown hotel in the nation's capital. Law enforcement sources say prosecutors are trying to build a perjury case against the mayor, who denied in sworn grand jury testimony that he ever used illegal drugs. The grand jury has called additional witnesses, including members of the mayor's security detail. A native of Washington, Ms. Moore graduated from modeling school here and has posed in the past for such national magazines as Essence. She was employed by the city government as a social worker in 1987 and 1988, according to a statement this week by the mayor's office.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
East Germany's Communist-Led Government Faces Breakup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with minority party quitting government, East German premier to meet Gorbachev in Moscow Tuesday. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A minority party in East Germany's Communist-led government resigned its three Cabinet posts late Thursday and called on other coalition partners to do likewise. The withdrawal by the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), effective Feb. 9, heightened the crisis of confidence faced by the Communist government of Premier Hans Modrow. The official ADN news agency also said Modrow has been invited to visit Moscow on Tuesday for talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It said the trip would be a ``working visit,'' but gave no details. The government was forced earlier Thursday to agree to major concessions to encourage free enterprise because of growing pressure for market reforms and reunification with West Germany. CDU leader Lothar de Maiziere said the three CDU ministers would serve in the 27-member Cabinet until Feb. 9, effectively setting a deadline for Modrow to build a new Cabinet that includes pro-democracy opposition groups. ADN quoted de Maiziere as saying his party took the step to ``make way for negotiations with new parties and groups'' toward formation of a new government, and ``assumes other parties in the government will take the same steps.'' Communists now hold 16 ministerial posts, Liberal Democrats four, Christian Democrats three, and the National Democrats and farmers' party two each. De Maiziere is a deputy premier. The two other CDU Cabinet members are Construction Minister Gerhard Baumgaertel and Post Minister Klaus Wolf. The CDU threatened on Jan. 17 to pull out of the government to protest the Communists' tight grip on power. The non-Communist Cabinet members are all from officially recognized parties once aligned with the Communists. All have tried to distance themselves from a party now disgraced and stripped of authority. Modrow has agreed to include opposition forces in his Cabinet until free elections are held on May 6, but the pro-democracy groups like New Forum, Democratic Awakening and the Social Democrats disagree among themselves how large a role they should take on. The parties would also be taking on partial responsibility for the disastrous state of the East German economy and the uncertain political situation. Earlier Thursday, a leading politician, Dresden Mayor Wolfgang Berghofer, told his city council that German unification is inevitable because East Germany never developed a separate national identity. Germany was split into Communist East and capitalist West after Adolf Hitler's Nazi regime was defeated in World War II. ``It is unavoidable that what belongs together will grow together,'' said Berghofer, who quit the Communist Party on Sunday. ``The only question is in what time frame and in what manner it will occur.'' Modrow will visit Bonn on Feb. 13-14 to meet with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to discuss the dire economic and political problems in East Germany, Kohl chief of staff Rudolf Seiters announced. On Thursday, Economics Minister Christa Luft told a news conference the government has scrapped plans to limit foreign ownership of joint ventures to 49 percent, a concession to Western business executives who spurned the earlier conditions. East Germany also will lift all restrictions on competition among private industry and crafts people, effectively opening the national economy to free enterprise, government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer announced. The steps embracing capitalism illustrate the heightened fears among East German leaders that the nation is headed toward economic collapse. Statistics this week showed a sharp drop in production, and Ms. Luft confirmed that about 2,000 East Germans are fleeing the nation each day. Hundreds of thousands of East Germans fled last year. Growing street protests toppled the hard-line regime of Erich Honecker. New Communist leaders opened the Berlin Wall and promised free elections to placate the masses. But the exodus West apparently has not been halted. Seiters said more than 42,500 East Germans had moved to West Germany since Jan. 1. The exodus has robbed East Germany of vital labor strength and undermines economic recovery efforts. Communist officials tried unsuccessfully beginning last fall to adopt an economy combining socialism and capitalism, but pressure for more radical change forced the Communists to yield to Western business demands. Majority foreign ownership of East German businesses will be allowed for any small and medium-size firms, and for any projects ``in the public's economic interest,'' Ms. Luft said. Ms. Luft suggested that the condition of ``public economic interest'' would be loosely defined to ensure interest among Western investors. She also confirmed that East Germany has accepted West German promises of $3.5 billion in aid _ an offer initially rejected on the grounds that Bonn's demands for a freer East German market were unacceptable. The conditions involved changing the East German economy, such as competition among enterprises and favorable tax laws and other incentives for foreign investors.

DOC.HEAD: Minesweepers Returning to US
DOC.TEXT: Three U.S. minesweepers operating in the Persian Gulf will return to the United States because of a reduced mine threat in the waterway, the Pentagon announced on Thursday. The ships _ the USS Esteem, USS Enhance and the USS Conquest _ are expected to return to their home ports on the West Coast, the Pentagon said in a statement. The redeployment ``in no way reflects a decrease in the U.S. commitment to the area,'' the statement said. ``The U.S. is firmly committed to promoting the stability of the Persian Gulf region. The free flow of oil through the Strait of Hormuz and the principle of freedom of navigation are vitally important to our country,'' the statement said. In mid-1987, there was a massive U.S. naval buildup in the Persian Gulf in the wake of the Iran-Iraq war, during which some 540 commercial ships were damaged or sank. The U.S. sharply increased its forces in the gulf to protect U.S. shipping, as well as to escort Kuwaiti-owned tankers registered under the Stars and Stripes. Although Pentagon officials declined to say exactly how many U.S. ships were operating in the gulf, they said some 20 U.S. ships were operating in the vicinity of the Indian Ocean.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Warns About Dangers of L-tryptophan Supplement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling ``systeine'' and ``systine'' to ``cysteine'' and ``cystine'' in penultimate graf, which is last bullet graf
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday cautioned consumers against buying potentially dangerous L-tryptophan dietary supplements distributed nationally by a California company. The company _ NutriCology Inc. of San Leandro, Calif., which also markets under the name of Allergy Research Group _ has not complied with an urgent FDA recall request, the agency said. A woman answering the company's telephone refused to relay repeated calls to an official of the company or a supervisor in charge. The agency said 334 other manufacturers, repackers and distributors have complied with the Nov. 17 request for recall of products that would result in a total dietary intake of 100 milligrams or more of L-tryptophan a day. The FDA requested the recall because L-tryptophan, an amino acid, has been linked to eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, which is marked by severe muscle and joint pain, swelling of the arms and legs, skin rash and sometimes fever. The Centers for Disease Control has reports of 1,143 cases of the syndome, including nine deaths _ one of which has been confirmed to have been ``clearly associated'' with L-tryptophan. Cases have been reported in all 50 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Public health experts have not been able to identify a specific lot, brand, manufacturer or supplier of the supplement as the cause of the outbreak. They also have been unable to identify a specific chemical or microbial contaminant that could be responsible, the FDA said. The L-tryptophan products made by the company are: _L-tryptophan capsules, 500 milligrams, 100 capsules to a bottle, under the Allergy Research Group label. _Tryptophan P.R.N., 350 milligrams, 30 capsules to a bottle under the NutriCology and Allergy Research labels. _Free Aminos, 750 milligram capsules, and Free Aminos without cystine and cysteine, both in 100-capsule bottles, and Free Aminos powder in 50 and 100 gram bottles, all under both labels. The FDA said the company responded to the November recall request by saying they ``may recall'' their products, but that company officials have refused to furnish the agency with any proof they have begun a recall.

DOC.HEAD: Endara Welcomes U.S. Aid; Says Cuts in Gov't Payroll Needed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Washington breakdown of aid, Endara quote, results that indicated Endara's presidential victory. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Guillermo Endara, installed as president by the United States during last month's invasion, called the proposed $1 billion U.S. aid package for Panama ``generous support'' but said it was about half what his government had requested. Endara said in a statement that the aid would help create jobs and revitalize the international banking system, which was once the backbone of Panama's economy. But he also said the government would require a ``substantial reduction of its payroll.'' Endara had asked for nearly $2 billion in a letter to Bush two weeks ago, saying his country required that much in assistance and rebuilding following the Dec. 20 invasion by 26,500 U.S. troops that ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power. ``Although the amounts announced do not reach the total we wished, the total sum constitutes a generous support and the quickness with which it was announced is very timely,'' Endara's statement said. U.S. officials in Washington said the asssitance would include developmental aid, loan guarantees and programs to encourage investment in a country that until recent years, as Noriega took complete control of Panama, was a thriving center for foreign banks. Bush said the package, which requires congressional approval, includes $500 million in humanitarian assistance for housing, public works and business assistance, and the balance for outstanding debts and economic restructuring. A spokesman for Endara said further details of how the aid would be channeled to Panama would be made public next week during a goodwill visit by Vice President Dan Quayle. Panamanians have insisted the United States must also provide compensation to families of the estimated 202 civilians killed in the fighting and for losses from three days of looting of businesses. Estimates of the looting losses range as high as $700 million. Local insurance companies have refused to cover the looting, saying it was the result of acts of war. The aid package includes assistance to enable Panama to obtain $400 million in loans from international lending agencies.
