DOC.HEAD: Late-Talking Toddlers May Need Therapy
DOC.TEXT: Many toddlers who are slow to speak fail to outgrow the problem by the time they reach age 3, suggesting treatment should be considered to expand their vocabulary, a scientist says. ``Traditional wisdom has counseled a wait-and-see attitude for 2 year olds with delayed language development,'' said Rhea Paul, an associate professor of speech and hearing sciences at Portland State University. But while some such toddlers improve spontaneously, many who show early signs of trouble expressing themselves may experience ``long-term difficulty in language and school achievement,'' she said. Paul's study involved 42 toddlers with language considered normal, and 36 considered ``language delayed,'' producing fewer than 10 intelligible words at 18 to 23 months, or fewer than 50 words or no two-word combinations by 24 to 34 months. Of the 2-year-olds who were ``language delayed,'' 41 percent couldn't express themselves as well as they should have by age 3, Paul found. And more than half of the 3-year-olds showed delays in their ability to understand. Paul said slow development of language ability may be linked to immature or underdeveloped abilities to socialize with other children. If so, treatment by a specialist should emphasize the use of language in daily conversation and social situations, she said.
DOC.HEAD: Bacteria Can Detoxify Cancer-Causing Vinyl Chloride
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have isolated natural soil bacteria that can detoxify cancer-causing vinyl chloride and related pollutants. ``Our work should lead to practical biological methods for cleansing the environment of these toxic chemicals in the near future,'' said Charles Castro, a chemist at the University of California, Riverside. Vinyl chloride, which the Environmental Protection Agency says causes cancer, is used for making polyvinyl chloride pipes and insulation. PVC, which isn't considered carcinogenic, also is used in floor tiles and upholstery. Vinyl chloride and other related chemicals called organic halides _ including fungus-killing EDB and DBCP _ reach the environment as pesticides or manufacturing byproducts. EDB and DBCP have been found to pollute groundwater in some areas. The bacteria isolated by Castro produce enzymes that break chemical bonds responsible for the toxicity of vinyl chloride and other organic halides. The breakdown products further decompose to create non-toxic substances such as carbon dioxide, simple alcohols and organic acids, the university said. Castro said his research is aimed at making it commercially possible to use the bacteria to detoxify the pollutants. He said research first must show exactly how and how quickly the process works.
DOC.HEAD: Inflamed Sinuses Can Cause Toothaches
DOC.TEXT: Infected, inflamed sinuses can masquerade as a dental problem by causing a toothache in the upper molars, says an association of ear, nose and throat doctors. ``Patients should be suspicious that they have sinusitis and not dental problems if their pain is combined with nasal discharge or stuffiness and if the tenderness is localized in the upper jaw area, said Dr. David W. Kennedy, of the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery. Moira DeWilde, the group's spokeswoman, said the academy decided to publicize the problem after a staff member rushed to her dentist in acute pain, only to find the problem was with her sinuses, not her teeth. The maxillary sinus cavity above the upper jaw has membranes that can be inflamed and swollen by infection, causing pain and tenderness in the upper jaw and teeth. The condition, acute sinusitis, usually happens after a cold, flu or allergy attack causes swelling of membranes in the nose. The swelling blocks tiny openings from the sinuses to the nose, allowing mucus to build up in the sinuses and causing a feeling of pressure. Dental X-rays may not reveal sinusitis, which can be treated with antibiotics to fight the bacterial infection and with decongestants to reduce swelling and help the sinus drain. Recurrent or persistent sinus infections sometimes require surgery.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Jan. 29

DOC.TEXT: Car and truck sales in mid-January rose 3.7 percent compared with last year, mainly because of strong, incentive-inspired light truck buying, automakers said. The eight major U.S. automakers said Wednesday they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 29,677 from Jan. 11-20, compared with 28,619 last year. Car sales were even and truck sales shot up 9.4 percent. For the first two selling periods of 1990, car and truck sales were up 13.6 percent, with car sales up 12.6 percent and truck sales up 15.1 percent.

The nation's economy is expected to grow slowly in 1990, the Federal Reserve said in a report that forecast improvements in some regions later in the year. ``Economic activity is expanding slowly in most of the nation, with conditions somewhat stronger in the West than in the East,'' the central bank said Wednesday in a summary of its ``Beige Book.'' The report did not mention any inflationary problems _ the reason the Fed originally slowed the economy by driving up interest rates to dampen demand and cool off price pressures.

Exxon Corp. said its fourth-quarter profits plunged more than 40 percent because of continued huge costs of cleaning up its Alaska oil spill, which by year's end totaled nearly $2 billion. Exxon said Wednesday it took a $500 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover its estimated out-of-pocket expenses for the spill. That provision is on top of charges totaling $880 million in the first and second quarters and more than $400 million in insurance proceeds Exxon said it expected to have available to help pay for spill-related cleanup costs.

UAL Corp.'s three employee unions proposed the acquisition of 75 percent of the airline company's stock by all employees, leaving the remaining 25 percent in public hands. In a letter to the company's board of directors Wednesday, United Airline's pilots, flight attendants and Machinists said they were prepared to negotiate as a group for the acquisition of stock through one or more employee stock ownership plans, or ESOPs. UAL's board is scheduled to meet Thursday. The development is likely to forestall the board's consideration of a recapitalization being pressed on the company by a major shareholder.

A top regulator warned that President Bush's $50 billion savings and loan bailout likely will fall short, but assured members of Congress that the crunch probably wouldn't come until after this year's election. ``Someone will be back to ask for more money one of these days. I think that's a high probability,'' L. William Seidman told the House Banking Committee Wednesday. Seidman is chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and of the Resolution Trust Corp., a new agency created to clean up the S&L industry.

The Interior Department has reached agreement with environmental groups on a new plan to strictly enforce the nation's strip mining laws. The agreement Wednesday is intended to make it easier to revoke coal mining permits issued to companies or individuals with records of past violations and to block the issuing of new permits in such cases.

IBM and Siemens AG, the German electronics giant, said they would jointly develop a new generation of computer memory chips. Under the agreement announced Wednesday, the two companies will work on developing a 64-million-bit dynamic random access memory chip, or DRAM. The largest-capacity chip now on the market holds 4 million bits of information. That chip was first introduced commercially by International Business Machines Corp. last year.

NBC-TV and Thomson SA, the French electronics company, will announce a joint venture with North American Philips Corp. to develop an improved television system that is expected to lead eventually to high-definition TV. An industry source, speaking on condition of anonymity, on Wednesday confirmed a report on the joint venture in this week's issue of Broadcasting magazine. North American Philips is part of the Dutch electronics giant Philips NV.

BankAmerica Corp. Chairman A.W. ``Tom'' Clausen reportedly is stepping down from the nation's fourth-largest banking concern, following a turnaround that moved the company from financial turmoil to record profits. The San Francisco Examiner said the 66-year-old Clausen's retirement and his successor would be announced before the bank's annual meeting on May 24. BankAmerica spokesman Peter Magnani declined comment Wednesday about the report, which was attributed to unidentified bank sources.

Stock prices declined broadly in heavy trading Wednesday despite bargain hunting and program buying. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off more than 60 points in early trading, closed 10.82 points lower at 2,604.50, extending its slide over the last three weeks to more than 205 points. The dollar finished lower against most major currencies. Bond prices were unchanged to slightly lower. Orange juice futures prices plummeted; livestock and meat futures fell; gold advanced while silver retreated; oil futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Takes $500 Million Charge; Fourth Qtr. Earnings Tumble
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. said the cost of cleaning up the Alaska oil spill has reached about $2 billion and cautioned that the final tab could climb higher still. The company on Wednesday reported taking a $500 million after-tax charge for the fourth quarter to cover expenses for cleaning some 1,000 miles of Alaska shoreline soiled when the Exxon Valdez ran aground last March. The charge contributed to a 40 percent drop in earnings in the period. Previously, Exxon took charges of $880 million in the first and second quarters for the cleanup. The company also has said it expects to have ``in excess'' of $400 million in insurance proceeds to help pay for the spill. William Randol, analyst with the investment firm First Boston Corp., said he was surprised by the size of the latest provision. ``That's a lot of money,'' Randol said. Bernard Picchi, analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc., said the provision might include money for environmental costs other than the Alaska spill, as well as potential legal costs. ``There might be more there than meets the eye,'' Picchi said. ``If it does include any provision for lawsuits I can guarantee they won't say it.'' Exxon officials refused to specify in detail how the $500 million in the latest charge had been spent, but they said the funds covered only cleanup costs and were not being set aside for potential legal liabilities. ``It would be interesting to see a breakdown showing exactly where the money went,'' said Dennis Kelso, Alaska's commissioner of environmental conservation. ``They've certainly been spending a substantial amount of money on spill response, but I don't have any way of evaluating whether that's an accurate assessment,'' he said, referring to the $2 billion figure. Company spokesman Bill Smith hinted that more charges could follow in 1990. ``We've spent about $2 billion on the cleanup,'' Smith said. ``This is our best judgment on what it will cost. We don't know if it will be more.'' Exxon halted cleanup for the winter and has said it would survey the area after the spring thaw to determine whether additional treatment is necessary. In the three months ended Dec. 31, Exxon said its net earnings were $785 million, or 61 cents a share, down 43 percent from $1.4 billion, or $1.06 a share, in the comparable 1988 period. Revenue rose 15 percent to $26.6 billion from $23 billion. The world's largest oil company said fourth-quarter earnings would have been $1.3 billion, or $1.01 a share, if not for the cleanup charge. In keeping with the industry trend, Exxon said higher crude prices in the fourth quarter helped boost its exploration and production earnings, while refining, marketing and chemicals earnings declined. For the year, Exxon's earnings fell 28 percent to $3.8 billion, or $2.98 a share, from $5.3 billion, or $3.95 a share, in 1988. Revenue rose about 9 percent to $96.1 billion from $88.6 billion. The Alaska spill occurred last March 24, when an Exxon tanker ran aground in Prince William Sound and spilled some 11 millions gallons of oil. The nation's worst oil spill occurred last March 24 when an Exxon tanker ran aground in Prince William Sound and spilled some 11 million gallons of crude oil. Environmentalists and government officials criticized the company harshly, saying it responded too slowly to contain the spill. ``The financial effect of the Exxon Valdez accident was clearly the major reason for lower net income in 1989,'' Exxon Chairman Lawrence G. Rawl said in a news release. Exxon said the latest spill-related provisions still do not cover the cost of potentially damaging lawsuits that number more than 150 so far and could take years to settle. The provisions also do not cover costs associated with Exxon's latest pollution incident _ a Jan. 2 pipeline rupture that left 567,000 gallons of heating oil floating in the Arthur Kill waterway between New York City and New Jersey. Exxon has offered to cover the costs of environmental studies and cleanup of that spill, which has generated lawsuits of its own, including one by the state of New Jersey. Exxon said its full-year results also reflected an accounting change that boosted earnings by $535 million in the first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Home Satellite Industry Continues Slow Rebound
DOC.TEXT: Satellite television industry officials say sales of home dishes are making a slow comeback four years after signal scrambling sent the market into a tailspin. But with half of the nation's estimated 2.8 million dish owners still receiving their signals through illegal decoders, officials are planning a crackdown on piracy to try to boost their industry's image. ``Piracy not only keeps some legitimate businessmen out of our business, it keeps consumers from buying because of the stigma they perceive,'' said Chuck Hewitt, president of Satellite Broadcasting and Communications Association, the industry's trade group. ``One of the reasons we believe 1990 will be a good year is we believe we can bring piracy under control.'' Delegates attending the trade group's winter convention here this week were generally upbeat over projections that some 350,000 home satellite television dishes would be sold in 1990. That's about even with 1988 and 1989 but well above 1986. Sales in that year plummeted to 200,000 units from 750,000 in 1985 after major broadcasters began to scramble their signals. ``We're making a gradual comeback but we don't see big growth until 1991 or 1992,'' Hewitt said. Officials are pinning their growth hopes on a variety of subscription packages now being marketed nationally that are generally cheaper than cable television. Consumers with satellite receivers equipped with legitimate descramblers _ which nearly all new systems now have _ can call toll-free numbers and order just about any scrambled stations they want, including pay stations such as HBO, Showtime and the Disney Channel. That's in addition to some 75 other unscrambled channels that are available free to dish owners. ``We are slowly overcoming the confusion among consumers about scrambling,'' Hewitt said. ``By ordering these packages, consumers are paying the programmers but can still get two pay services and 14 to 16 channels for under $20 a month.'' Hewitt said his organization is starting to crack down on illegal descramblers with investigations and legal action against dealers who sell illegal decoders and people who use them. With as many as half of all current dish owners using illegal devices, some potential customers shun buying a dish because they think they will be doing something under the table, he said. ``Our message is we've got a great value here already and there's no reason not to pay for legitimate programming services,'' he said. ``We've got some people who could buy eight or nine years of legitimate services for the money they pay for a descrambler trying to get it illegally.'' Although the industry touts its programming prices as lower than cable, the average satellite system remains costly. Dealers at the show were hawking receiver@dish combinations beginning at about $2,000, with some fancier systems running several thousand dollars more. ``Even the basic units give you remote control and compact disc quality sound, though,'' Hewitt said. ``And the picture quality is better than you can get anywhere.'' Unlike previous industry shows, this year's convention space was 40 percent rented by programming packagers, including HBO, which is marketing its own station along with Cinemax and 20 other stations for $21.75 a month. ``We don't release subscription figures, but we're very pleased with our sales,'' said Bob Caird, an HBO vice president. ``A considerable number of home satellite owners prefer receiving their favorite channels in one neat package.'' Hewitt said about 630,000 satellite dish owners nationwide now buy programming from various sources, with total spending of about $150 million a year.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler's Incentives Look Strong, for Now
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp.'s incentives kept working in mid-January and helped boost sales of North American-made vehicles 3.7 percent over the same period last year, the automakers say. The cash rebates and low-interest loans announced Dec. 15 appeared be working best on the No. 3 automaker's popular minivans _ the Plymouth Voyager, Dodge Caravan and Chrysler Town and Country. ``I think the big boost to Chrysler overall is that discount on the Caravan and the Voyager,'' said auto analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. in New York. A Chrysler-Plymouth dealer in Houston said Wednesday he and his sales staff were hustling. ``If there was any more traffic I would die of a heart attack,'' said Alan Helfman, general manager of River Oaks Chrysler-Plymouth of Houston. ``There's an incredible number of people coming through for these Voyagers with not enough Voyagers to handle it,'' Helfman said. ``It's just average action on the rest of the cars.'' The effect of Chrysler's rebates was evident in the sales numbers. Chrysler's mid-January truck sales, which include minivans, soared 35.6 percent over the same period last year while car sales dropped 8.8 percent. General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. also offer rebates, but to a lesser extent. Overall, the eight major U.S. automakers said they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 29,677 vehicles during the Jan. 11-20 period, compared with 28,619 during the same time last year. Car sales were even and truck sales shot up 9.4 percent. ``We think these (figures) were in line with expectations as opposed with early January which we thought was abnormally high,'' said analyst Steven Girsky of PaineWebber Inc. of New York. For the first two selling periods of 1990, car and truck sales were up 13.6 percent, with car sales up 12.6 percent and truck sales up 15.1 percent. During mid-January, the Big Three lost ground in the North American-made car market to cars made in ``transplants,'' or factories owned in part or outright by Japanese companies. The Big Three's share fell to 87.6 percent in the period from 93.1 percent last year. Chrysler's combined car and truck sales were up 14.1 percent during the mid-January period, and up 20.5 percent for the first two selling periods combined. Ford reported its vehicle sales were down 6.1 percent in mid-January, with car sales dropping 10.4 percent and truck sales up 0.2 percent. For the first 20 days of the year, Ford's vehicle sales were up 2.5 percent. GM said its mid-January car and truck sales were up 1.1 percent, with a 5.9 percent increase in truck sales being diluted by a 1.5 percent decline in car sales. So far this year, GM's vehicle sales are up 16 percent.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chief: Ban Bond Sales Like Lincoln's
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top stock and bonds policeman wants federal law changed to prevent savings and loans from selling their own securities. ``If a customer walks in with a Social Security check, we don't think they should be able to walk out with a junk bond,'' Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said. The comment, made Wednesday in a speech to a meeting of the Securities Regulation Institute, referred to Irvine-based Lincoln Savings & Loan Association, whose failure is expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion. Lincoln is fighting a class-action lawsuit on behalf of 23,000 investors who bought now-worthless unsecured bonds of Lincoln's parent, American Continental Corp., at Lincoln branches. The sale of the high-risk, high-yield junk bonds was permitted under federal and state laws. But the investors, many of them elderly Californians who lost their life savings, contend they were led to believe the bonds were federally insured, like savings accounts. Breeden said allowing the sale of such bonds inside savings and loan branches was an invitation for fraud. Meeting with reporters separately, Breeden said long-term investors would be making a mistake to flee the stock market despite its recent losses and volatility. He acknowledged that small investors might be scared by stories of computer trading and ``corrections'' that now drive prices down sharply in hours instead of days or weeks, but said they would do well to hold on for the long haul. ``For the individual investors who bought securities on Jan. 1 last year and held them until Dec. 31, they had an aggregate gain of 31 percent last year,'' Breeden said. ``I would think it would be a shame for people who are saving for the long term, to buy a house or pay for a college education, to give up a 31 percent return for a bank CD at 7 percent.'' He made clear he was not guaranteeing the performance of any given stock. Breeden also urged Congress and the Bush administration to knock down a variety of domestic hindrances to the free flow of money, saying that an economically deregulated Europe in 1992 would otherwise overcome America's competitive edge as an attractive site for investment. ``The Europeans are systematically removing the barriers among their 12 nations,'' standardizing disclosure regulations, takeover rules, banking laws, he said. He urged Congress to allow banks to set up affiliated securities companies, something that is banned now under the Glass-Steagall Act. Breeden also called on Congress to remove barriers to stock market trading of ``hybrid'' securities that have elements of futures. A federal court recently banned trading of a stock-index future on the Philadelphia and American stock exchange because of restrictions limiting such products to commodities exchanges. Similar securities are available to investors on the London and Toronto stock exchanges. At a separate session, former SEC Chairman David S. Ruder, who presided over the SEC during two years that included the October 1987 stock market crash and the Wall Street inside trading scandals, called for a major SEC study of wide-ranging securities industry reforms, like one undertaken in 1962. ``There should be a study not only of volatility, but of little-known problems in the industry ... and we need to assess whether the crazy-quilt regulation we have in the U.S. over the banking and securities industries is the right one,'' Ruder said. Breeden agreed that having separate regulators for stocks and bonds, commodities and banking had led to problems in an increasingly interconnected financial world. But he said there is too little time to undertake a major study like the one in 1962, which took two years. ``I'd like to see Congress and the administration get on with the task of reforming the securities market,'' he said. Ruder said he felt Congress would be forced to re-evaluate scrapping the Glass-Steagall Act to allow banks to underwrite securities. ``Our financial institutions are going to be at a severe competitive disadvantage in the world if they cannot engage in banking and securities transactions at the same time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound, Dollar Declines.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose moderately today while the dollar edged down against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 145.30 yen, down from Wednesday's close of 145.80 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 190.13 points, or 0.52 percent, ending the day at 36,969.11. It had lost 599.04 points Wednesday. Dealers attributed the Nikkei's rebound to smaller-than-expected losses on Wall Street overnight. ``Market players were somehow reassured by the New York market's overnight performance, and they began to buy back issues,'' said Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities, Co. The Dow Jones industrial average closed 10.81 points lower Wednesday at 2,604.50 after plunging more than 60 points in early trading. Following Monday's 77.45-point decline in the Dow, Japanese market players have expected continuing weakness on Wall Street and remained reluctant to buy issues. In currency dealings, the dollar opened lower in Tokyo following a similar weakness in overseas markets overnight.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Says It Will Not Return To Valdez In Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Exxon will not set up a large base in Valdez next spring, whether or not it decides to continue its cleanup work on Prince William Sound shorelines blackened in the nation's worst oil spill. Exxon will keep its spill headquarters in Anchorage, Otto Harrison, head of the company's cleanup effort, said Wednesday. The Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation is expected to do the same, and the Coast Guard already has moved to Alaska's largest city. Exxon Corp.'s fourth-quarter profits plunged more than 40 percent because of the nearly $2 billion it spent cleaning the spill, the company announced in New York. In the three months ended Dec. 31, Exxon's net earnings were $785 million, or 61 cents a share, down 43 percent from $1.4 billion, or $1.06 a share, in the same period in 1988, the company said. Revenue rose 15 percent to $26.6 billion from $23 billion. Valdez City Manager Doug Griffin said Exxon's decision would give his hard-hit port community a needed breather this summer. ``We kind of lost the year in some respects because of the oil spill,'' he said. Exxon moved its operation from Valdez to Anchorage late last year as the cleanup wound down. Harrison said the company considered several factors in deciding to keep its headquarters in Anchorage. ``When you take in all the locations we're looking at _ Valdez, Seward, Cordova _ your flying conditions are better out of Anchorage than out of Valdez,'' Harrison said. If the company decides to resume its cleanup in the spring, it likely would send small teams to far-flung locations. ``Valdez is not central to supplying that kind of operation,'' Harrison said. Environmental Conservation Commissioner Dennis Kelso said Exxon talked with his agency last week about the switch to Anchorage. ``I don't see it as a problem for us,'' he said. ``As long as the job gets done, that's our main concern.'' The Exxon Valdez rammed Bligh Reef on March 24, spilling about 11 million gallons of thick crude oil that coated the sound and the Gulf of Alaska. After a stuttering start, Exxon pressed thousands of workers into the cleanup. The huge cleanup turned Valdez into a boomtown, with garbage, sewer and housing problems. The crime rate soared, and Exxon received several calls from people concerned about tourism and fish processing, said company spokeswoman Christina Stevens. Harrison said Exxon would not be taking up much hotel or office space this summer. ``We should not be providing any disruption to the citizens for their normal business,'' he said. No decision has been made about the cleanup effort, Harrison said. After an intensive survey in the spring, the Coast Guard will determine what needs to be done, he said. Plans will be formulated in March and a decision on whether to proceed with a cleanup will be made in April. The cleanup, if it occurs, would not begin until May, Stevens said.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Wants Feds to Keep Bovine Hormone From Public
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Debate over a synthetic hormone that makes cows give more milk is heating up with a renewed demand by a group of farm and consumer advocates to keep milk from test herds from going into the consumer market. The group argues that if the Food and Drug Administration refuses to suspend sales until the agency makes a final decision on the drug, the agency should at least require labels on milk and other dairy products that originate from test cows treated with bovine growth hormone, or BGH. A similar request for halting distribution of milk from test herds was made last August, but the FDA did not respond, Brian Ahlberg of the National Farm Coalition told a news conference. The genetically engineered hormone is bovine somatotropin and is usually called BST by the Agriculture Department and the chemical companies that make it. The hormone also occurs naturally in a cow's body. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said last week in discussing the hormone that ``unenforceable labeling laws have been proposed that would attempt to enforce mandatory labeling by farmers and processors.'' Yeutter told the Milk Industry Foundation and International Ice Cream Association meeting in Palm Beach, Fla., that safety for consumers, animals and environment is the ``only one criterion'' on which the use of the hormone should hinge. ``Thus, BST measures up on all these counts,'' he said. ``And if it continues to do so it should ultimately receive approval ... for commercial use, just as should any product that the FDA deems to be safe.'' Jeremy Rifkin of the Foundation for Economic Trends, a longtime critic of the synthetic growth hormone, said his organization is preparing a petition asking the FDA for ``a full, thorough, internal investigation'' into allegations the agency worked with drug companies and has been hiding test results from the public. Rifkin said the hormone ``has no redeeming social value'' and is bad for farmers, cows, taxpayers and ultimately, perhaps, consumer health. However, during questions, coalition spokesman Ahlberg said the group was not claiming adverse health effects from milk produced by hormone-treated cows. Rifkin also accused FDA of promoting the growth hormone before the agency has given it final clearance. ``This is outrageous,'' Rifkin said. ``This is activity that should have been condemned a long time ago.'' Rifkin said if FDA approves commercial use of the drug, his group will seek court action to ban it. ``We are determined that this product will never reach the marketplace in the United States and Europe,'' he said. ``We will litigate, will inform consumers with the mass media, will do whatever is necessary.'' The FDA did not return calls for comment on Rifkin's allegation that the agency has been actively promoting the drug prior to its final approval. Speakers said they had no information from the FDA about the extent of testing or how much milk is entering the U.S. consumer pipeline, although Rifkin and others have said they thought the percentage is quite small. They said producers include herds maintained by land-grant universities and private farmers. The common practice is to sell milk from test herds to local dealers, who then mix it with other milk for distribution. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, has asked the General Accounting Office to investigate allegations by Dr. Richard Burroughs, a fired FDA veterinarian, that tests of the chemical were inadequate. Burroughs has accused the FDA of toning down criticism of research on the hormone at the request of the chemical companies. The FDA has said the hormone-treated milk is safe to drink. The hormone is manufactured by Monsanto, Eli Lilly, Upjohn and American Cyanamid, who have said the FDA review has been the most thorough of any study of animal drugs. And the FDA says it has not made any exceptions in its drug-testing standards.

A quarterly report by the Agriculture Department shows cattle feedlot inventories in the nation's 13 leading beef states totaled 9.94 million head as of Jan. 1, up 3 percent from a year ago but 2 percent fewer than two years ago. Increases from a year ago were reported Wednesday in California, Colorado, Iowa, Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma and Texas. South Dakota was unchanged, and decreases were reported for Arizona, Idaho, Illinois, Minnesota and Washington. Marketings of feed cattle for slaughter during October, November and December totaled 5.36 million head, down 2 percent from the same period of 1988 and 5 percent below 1987, the report said. Further, the placement of new cattle and calves on feed during the fourth quarter of the year totaled 7.32 million head, up 10 percent from 1988 and 7 percent from 1987. Cattle feeders indicated they expect to market 5.69 million head during January, February and March, up fractionally from last year's first quarter but 3 percent below 1987, the report said. State feedlot cattle inventories are listed here for the 13 states, which account for about 85 percent of the nation's beef. The first number is the number of cattle, in thousands, as of Jan. 1, and the second number is the percentage of a year earlier.

Arizona 253 92 California 490 101 Colorado 900 102 Idaho 200 84 Illinois 310 91 Iowa 980 107 Kansas 1,595 109 Minnesota 300 97 Nebraska 2,060 106 Oklahoma 325 107 South Dakota 260 100 Texas 2,100 101 Washington 170 89

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Moynihan Spar Over Social Security Tax Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is refusing to rule out a Republican plan that would ultimately make the Social Security system private, as the battle sharpens over a Democrat's bill slashing the retirement system's payroll tax. Bush told reporters Wednesday that a plan by Rep. John E. Porter, R-Ill., and the No. 2 House Republican leader, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, to place workers' retirement payments into private accounts ``has some interesting ingredients to it'' and is worthy ``of consideration, of some study.'' But he added, ``I'm not prepared to endorse that.'' The president cautioned that his 1991 budget proposal _ which he unveils Monday _ will contain a different plan for addressing the huge Social Security surpluses. But he said, ``People are concerned about Social Security, so when you have innovative thinking of that nature, I don't want to just gun it down. I'm not going to support it.'' Porter and Gingrich want to gradually divert Social Security taxes, which are paid by workers and their employers, into a sort of mandatory Individual Retirement Account. As workers' IRAs grow, their claims on Social Security would decline. When today's workers are retired _ about 50 years from now, Porter estimated _ Social Security would be fully privatized. Seldom since Republican nominee Barry Goldwater's losing 1964 presidential campaign has a national GOP figure spoken publicly of even the remote possibility of replacing Social Security with private retirement plans. The Porter-Gingrich plan looms as the major GOP alternative to a plan advanced last month by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. Moynihan, considered one of Congress' experts on Social Security, has proposed scaling back the system's payroll tax, once immediately and again next January. He has argued the surplus the Social Security system is banking _ $66 billion this year and growing _ is cloaking the true size of the federal deficit, rather than being banked to pay future retirement benefits to Baby Boomers. Bush called Moynihan's plan ``a disguise for increased taxes around the corner'' and a ``sleight of hand operation.'' He referred to a separate bill proposed by Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., that would replace the monies lost by a Social Security tax cut with a new federal sales tax. Moynihan counterattacked on the Senate floor later in the day. ``There is no sleight of hand whatsoever,'' Moynihan replied, ``and I do not see that there was any need to make such a characterization.'' He also questioned Bush's characterization of the Porter-Gingrich bill of ``innovative thinking,'' asking ``Was it innovative thinking after 50 years of steady payments to start dismantling Social Security? I don't think so.'' Also on Wednesday: _Bush said Congress should wait to see his own proposal to gradually take Social Security surpluses out of the federal deficit calculation. That long-range plan, starting in 1993, would require that a growing portion of the surplus be used to retire publicly held debt. _House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he has serious reservations about Moynihan's proposed tax cut, which would require Congress to find an additional $55 billion for deficit reduction this year. He said he fears that instead of raising taxes or cutting spending to make up the loss, Congress and the president would opt for increased borrowing. _Reps. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., and Richard Durbin, D-Ill., proposed to roll back only this year's increase in the Social Security tax rate _ which rose from 7.51 percent to 7.65 percent of the first $51,300 of wages. Congress then could use the rest of this year to devise a plan for ensuring that Social Security taxes are used solely for Social Security.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Built Record 13 Million Vehicles in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Robust domestic sales pushed Japan's motor vehicle production to a record high of 13,025,741 in 1989, up 2.6 percent from the previous year, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said Thursday. JAMA officials attributed the surge to brisk domestic sales totaling 7,256,669 vehicles, up 8 percent from a year earlier. Domestic sales set a record for the eighth consecutive year. Exports, however, fell an estimated 3.6 percent to 5.89 million. It was the fourth consecutive year of declining exports. The association is scheduled to release exact 1989 export figures at the end of January. Overseas shipments have been diminishing in part because many Japanese manufacturers now are producing automobiles abroad. Passenger car output climbed 10.4 percent to a record 9,052,406 in 1989, while production of trucks dropped 11.5 percent to 3,931,261. Bus production dropped by 26.7 percent to 42,074. Strong personal spending, the removal of a commodity tax on cars and the introduction of new models helped boost domestic sales, JAMA officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal Would Hold Weapons Contractors Liable for Fines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department is proposing holding its nuclear weapons contractors liable for environmental fines and other costs resulting from their own negligence. The proposal, announced Wednesday by Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, marks the department's most substantial effort to improve work at the weapons plants, which are plagued by mismanagement, safety lapses and environmental problems. ``This proposal reflects my goal of safeguarding the public and protecting the environment,'' Watkins said in a statement. The 17 major weapons production plants and research laboratories are owned by the department but operated under long-term contracts by private companies. Since the start of nuclear arms production in the 1940s, the plant operators have enjoyed virtually complete protection from financial liability for their mistakes. Federal auditors last year reported that the Energy Department had paid hundreds of thousands of dollars in environmental fines incurred by weapons contractors, plus related legal costs that totaled about twice as much as the fines. Under the new system, contractors would have to pay fines they could reasonably have avoided, plus legal costs. They also would be charged for expenses resulting from damage to government property, although not in all cases. The department is expected to announce soon a related proposal for increasing the amount of bonus money that the contractors can earn for excellent performance. That would partly offset the increased financial liability. The Watkins proposal is subject to change based on comments received during a 30-day public comment period. Reaction on Capitol Hill was mixed. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., who sponsored legislation last year to increase the weapons contractors' liability for environmental violations, said in an interview Wednesday that he was not satisfied that Watkins' proposal was tough enough. ``It is just full of potential loopholes and, I think, dangerous hedging,'' Wyden said. He noted, as an example, a provision that would set a ceiling on the amount of damages for which the contractors would be liable. Rep. David Skaggs, D-Colo., whose district includes the Rocky Flats weapons plant, issued a statement calling the proposal ``a real victory for common sense.'' He said it offered new hope for improving the contractors' performance. ``Now their own money will be at stake, and that's a strong incentive for contractors to do the job right,'' he said. Steven Wakefield, the department's general counsel, said the weapons contractors had been briefed on the outlines of the proposal. He said some didn't like certain provisions of the plan but that none had threatened to quit.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Engineers Prepare to Vote on Contract Offer
DOC.TEXT: Union leaders are predicting easy approval of a three-year contract offer giving Boeing Co. engineers 9 percent more in annual bonuses than an offer they rejected last month. Daniel M. Mahoney, general counsel of the Seattle Professional Engineering Employees Association, said the leadership was recommending acceptance after taking no position on the earlier offer. ``We're all happy, the negotiators,'' Mahoney said. ``We view this as quite an achievement.'' Mahoney said ballots would be mailed to the 9,276 members of the union's professional unit on Monday, with a count set for Feb. 7. ``We are pleased that an tentative agreement has been reached,'' said Paul Binder of Boeing. The settlement, which would replace a three-year contract that expired Dec. 1, was negotiated in a 3{-hour meeting Wednesday involving the two sides and federal mediator Ben Youtsey. It was the second bargaining session since a three-year offer without any general pay raises or bonuses after the first year was rejected on a 69 percent vote Dec. 18. A recess to review positions on each side followed a meeting Jan. 10. The revised offer includes a 3 percent pay increase in the first year and productivity bonuses of 10 percent of gross pay in the first year, 5 percent in the second and 4 percent in the third. In addition, money equal to 2 percent of all salaries in the unit is reserved for additional, selective pay increases every six months, with the entire pool to be spent. In rejecting the initial offer, many engineers noted that Boeing production workers won three years of bonuses and general wage gains in a 48-day strike last fall. The company offer was increased by some $56 million after ``our general management met with the engineering management'' and considered ``the feedback that we received from engineers,'' Binder said. Union leaders cited a survey of 100 companies by the engineering trade magazine Design News that showed Boeing engineers generally earned $32,000 to $35,000 after five years, one of the lowest pay levels among the major companies covered in the report. Binder questioned whether the survey considered regional variations in living costs and other factors. The union, which claims to be the largest representing engineers and technicians outside the AFL-CIO, has no strike fund and has never called a walkout. Strike authorization was rejected in the same balloting in which the initial offer was rejected. The professional unit represents 15,245 engineers, scientists and other highly educated employees, nearly all in the Seattle area, with an average salary of $39,683. The 8,317 members of the union's other unit, which represents 12,796 technicians with an average salary of $28,079, voted Dec. 18 to accept a three-year contract with pay hikes of 3, 2 and 2 percent; bonuses of 10, 5 and 4 percent, and a selective pay pool of 2 percent a year. Following a 48-day strike, Boeing members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers voted Nov. 18 to accept a contract with pay raises of 4, 3 and 3 percent; bonuses of 10, 5 and 4 percent, and a boost in the cost of living formula from 86 percent of inflation to nearly 100 percent. The Machinists represent 57,800 production workers, including 43,300 in the Puget Sound area, and the strike virtually halted work at Boeing plants in Seattle; Wichita, Kan., and Portland, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Empire of America Seized By Regulators
DOC.TEXT: An aggressive expansion program that for years drained Empire of America Federal Savings Bank's profits ultimately backfired when the state's third largest savings and loan was placed under federal control. Customers were left uneasy by the government's move Wednesday to take over financially strapped Empire and transfer control to the Resolution Trust Corp., a federal agency created in August to dispose of all failed savings institutions. ``I'm very disappointed,'' said Empire customer Jenny Plotar outside a bank branch here. ``We've dealt with them for 40 years and I felt so safe and secure. Now I don't.'' But Curt Reid, an RTC official at the bank's headquarters, stressed that it will be business as usual for depositors. ``They can continue to deposit and write checks and, most importantly, their money will continue to be federally insured.'' Analysts were hopeful that the move would result in an infusion of capital. ``There are many positivies,'' said Rosemarie Ligotti, a vice president at Prescott, Ball and Turben. ``A stronger company will come in and merge'' with Empire. Empire, New York's third-largest savings and loan, has been losing millions since it swallowed up 13 failing S&Ls with the support of federal regulators. Late last year, the thrift announced it was insolvent and asked for federal help. ``They've experienced losses for quite some time,'' said Robert Albanese, senior deputy director for the New York district of the Office of Thrift Supervision. ``At this point, we don't see any ability for the institution to be recapitalized without government assistance.'' The Resolution Trust Corp. has installed a managing agent and removed the board of directors, but the bank's officers will remain, Albanese said. Empire of America has 125 branches in New York, California, Florida, Michigan and Texas. In June 1989, it was the 12th largest bank in the United States and the third largest in New York, with $11.3 billion in assets, according to Sheshunoff Information Services Inc., a Texas firm that rates banks. However, Albanese said that the bank's assets had dropped to $8.8 billion at yearend. Still, he said, the thrift was among the five largest seized by federal regulators to date. RTC has taken control of about 280 thrifts and has disposed of more than 30 nationwide. The problem was Empire had tried to expand in a hurry. As it bought these sickly S&Ls between 1981 and 1986, Empire found that the thrifts' liabilities _ which mostly consist of deposits and can be withdrawn any time _ exceeded the value of their assets by $926 million. To make its accounts balance, Empire added $926 million of ``goodwill'' to its assets. In accounting, goodwill is a non-cash asset, but it must be written off over a number of years as a charge against the company's income. Empire found that goodwill was draining $95 million to $110 million from its profit each year.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to ADD two more Truck & Bus plants to GM, picks up penultimate graf: Ford said ...
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 33,600 General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. workers will be laid off for at least a week in the latest series of layoffs blamed on slow sales or too-high inventory. Aside from the layoffs announced Wednesday, effective in the next five weeks at nine car and truck assembly plants, the Big Three automakers have announced indefinite layoffs at 11 assembly plants affecting more than 13,500 employees. Other layoffs in supplier and component plants are likely because of the assembly plant shutdowns. It is difficult to track those plants because of their numbers and the possibility that they will continue production and build inventory despite the shutdown of an assembly plant they supply. GM said Wednesday that car assembly plants in Atlanta and Doraville, Ga.; Fairfax, Kan.; Lansing, Mich., and Linden, N.J., along with a van plant in Lordstown, Ohio, and a Truck & Bus Group plants in Baltimore; Shreveport, La., and Pontiac, Mich., would be down for at least a week apiece in late January through mid-February. The production cuts will affect about 27,600 workers. Ford said the new layoffs would involve 5,600 workers at plants in Edison, N.J.; Kansas City, Mo.; and Louisville, Ky., and come in addition to 5,600 layoffs previously announced for the company's car and truck plants in Lorain, Ohio. Chrysler Corp. spokesman Doug Nicoll said Wednesday the No. 3 automaker had no new temporary plant closings to announce. Through mid-February, Chrysler will temporarily idle six plants for at least a week each, resulting in 21,600 temporary layoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Collective Bargaining Contracts Provided Wage Increases of 3.3 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Contracts settled through collective bargaining last year provided workers average annual wage increases of 3.3 percent over the life of the pacts, the government said today. The Labor Department said 1989 was the first time since 1981 that negotiated settlements provided larger wage adjustments than the contracts they replaced. The last time parties to 1989 settlements negotiated, usually in 1986 or 1987, average wage rate adjustments were 2.4 percent over the contract term. Wage restorations in steel and other industries, as well as wage gains for nurses, accounted for the difference, the agency said. Last year's 3.3 percent wage gains also were up from the 2.4 percent average wage gains contained in collective bargaining agreements settled in 1988. The collective bargaining report, like the Labor Department's broader Employment Cost Index report, showed workers in the fast-growing service sector winning larger wage gains than manufacturing workers. Service workers received an average of 3.5 percent hikes over the life of the contracts while manufacturing workers received 3.2 percent raises. The Labor Department said the 459 collective bargaining agreements it analyzed covered about 1.85 million workers. The government tracks agreements covering bargaining units with at least 1,000 workers. The government said 114 such contracts covering 743,000 workers had been expired or reopened in the last quarter but had not been settled or ratified by Dec. 31. About half of those workers are employed in railroads.

The stock market staged a moderate rally today, bidding to reverse its sharp decline of the past three weeks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 7.66 to 2,612.16 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 2 in nationwidyPzrading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 721 up, 285 down and 419 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 23.49 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said several worries that had been weighing down the market showed signs of easing today. Prices rose in the Japanese stock market, after a series of recent selloffs that had unsettled other markets around the world. Interest rates in the U.S. government securities market, meanwhile, backed off a bit from their abrupt rise of late. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds dropped to the 8.38 percent-8.40 percent range, against 8.44 percent-8.45 percent at one stage on Wednesday. Brokers said those developments were enough to encourage ``bargain hunting'' in many stocks that had been under selling pressure since early this month. Gainers among the blue chips included American Telephone & Telegraph, up ] at 41|; Philip Morris, up [ at 38[; American Express, up [ at 30}, and Sears Roebuck, up ] at 37~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .60 to 183.24. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .88 at 355.55. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average finished with a 10.82 loss at 2,604.50. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 3 to 1 on the NYSE, with 384 rising, 1,207 falling and 399 unchanged. Big Board volume came to 207.83 million shares, up from 179.30 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Record Earnings in '89 for Forestry Products Giant
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp., currently involved in a bitterly opposed attempt to acquire a rival paper products company, today reported sharply higher earnings for the final quarter and all of 1989. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, Georgia-Pacific said net income jumped 21.7 percent to $157 million, or $1.84 a share, from $129 million, or $1.36 a share in the year-ago period. Net sales, however, slipped 8 percent to $2.4 billion, from $2.6 billion in the final quarter of 1988. Declines occurred both in Georgia-Pacific's building products and pulp and paper segments. For the year, net income totaled a record $661 million, up 41.5 percent from $467 million in 1988. Earnings per share amounted to $7.42, compared with $4.76 a share in 1988. For the year, net sales rose 7 percent to $10.2 billion, from $9.5 billion in 1988. ``Despite a substantial decrease in housing starts for the third consecutive year, our building products segment showed strong performance and increased operating profits,'' said Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn. Demand for structural panels decreased toward the end of the year, Hahn said. Georgia-Pacific launched a bid to buy out Norwalk, Conn.-based Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. on Oct. 31. The offer, opposed by Great Northern, now stands at $3.8 billion, or $63 a share.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Existing Homes 4.6 Less Than in Previous Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf, The National, to CORRECT and say sales on an annual rate; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes edged down in December, bringing the 1989 total to 3.43 million units, or 4.6 percent less than the previous year's sales, a real estate trade group reported today. The National Association of Realtors said December sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.55 million units, down 1.1 percent from 3.59 million units in November. The Realtors attributed part of the last month's decline to severe weather conditions in the Northeast and South and to a large drop in the West from an extremely high November level. For the year, sales were down from the 1988 total of 3.59 million units which the Realtors said was the strongest year of the decade. The national median price for existing single-family homes in December was $92,500, 4.3 percent above the December 1988 median of $88,700. The median price for the year was $93,100, also up 4.3 percent from 1988. The median price means that half of the homes cost more and half less. Realtors President Norman D. Flynn called last year's sales ``healthy'' and said that while they declined in 1989, the decline was from the highest resale volume since 1979. ``Last month's resale pace indicates a stable market,'' Flynn said. ``With plenty of homes available at good prices, and relatively low mortgage rates, it is really a `buyer's paradise' right now,'' he said. Sales in the Northeast totaled 570,000 units on an annual basis, down 3.4 percent from November. For the year, the resale pace was 585,000 units, 13.1 percent below that of 1988. The Northeast median price was $143,100 in December, up 0.1 percent from December 1988. The 1989 median price was $145,200, 1.5 percent higher than 1988. ``The essentially unchanged median home prices in the Northeast reflect a continuing slump in many of the large metropolitan areas,'' said John A. Tuccillo, NAR chief economist. The resale pace in the West was 600,000 units, down 6.3 percent from November. The 1989 total was 605,000 units, 5.l8 percent below the 1988 total. The median price in December was $135,300, 5.1 percent higher than December 1988, while for the year it was $139,900, up 12 percent from 1988. Sales in the South slipped 3.5 percent in December to 1.38 million units. For 1989, resales totaled 1.31 million units, 2.9 percent below those of 1988. The median price in the South was $83,200 in December, 6.4 percent above that of December 1988. For the year, the median price was $84,500, 2.8 percent above 1988. The Midwest posted the only sales increase in December, rising 3.1 percent to 990,000 units. For the year, the total was 926,000 units, 0.3 percent below the 1988 total. The median price was $72,100 last month, 6.5 percent above December 1988. The 1989 median price was $71,200, 4.1 percent above 1988.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 12 grafs NEW with hearing today, picking up 5th pvs, Seidman resisted; moving general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: An official of the agency overseeing the savings and loan bailout today defended it against complaints from Democrats that it is dragging its feet in establishing a program to provide housing to poor people. ``The (Resolution Trust Corp.) is moving forward to quickly develop a program,'' said Stephen S. Allen, director of the agency's low income housing. However, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said earlier testimony from Allen's superiors ``did not demonstrate a commitment to making lower income occupancy of these properties a reality.'' In bailout legislation enacted in August, Congress instructed the RTC to give poor people and low-income housing groups a 90-day right of first refusal on low-priced housing the government is inheriting from failed S&Ls. The law gives the agency the option of cutting the price on the property, but the RTC is not doing that for now. Allen acknowledged that only 700 properties are being offered initially in the low-income housing program, out of a total of more than 26,000 residential properties. However, he said about 10,000 properties eventually will be moved into the low-income program, with most of them, 5,174, in Texas; 968 in Oklahoma; and 881 in Louisiana. Republicans on the panel said the housing program could increase the cost of the bailout to taxpayers. The properties should be sold as soon as possible to reduce carrying costs, they said. ``We can't tell the RTC that time is of the essence ... and then hamstring them. ... We have to keep focused on cleaning up the mess in the S&L industry,'' said Rep. Toby Roth, R-Wis. Meanwhile, in testimony Wednesday, a top regulator edged closer to admitting what private analysts have been saying for months _ that President Bush's $50 billion savings and loan bailout doesn't provide enough money. L. William Seidman, nicknamed the bailout czar for his dual role as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the RTC, stopped just short of acknowledging taxpayers need to make a second installment on the cleanup. ``Someone will be back to ask for more money one of these days. I think that's a high probability,'' Seidman said. Panel members reacted with dismay, but Seidman assured them the crunch would likely come after congressional elections this November. Seidman resisted several efforts to pin him down to a new loss estimate, but figures in his testimony suggest losses in the range of $74 billion to $82 billion. As of Jan. 16, the RTC had seized 333 institutions with assets totaling $136 billion. The loss on those is about $42 billion, he said. The remaining $8 billion would be enough to cover the losses at additional S&Ls with assets of $40 billion. However, the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision is predicting the failure of another 225 to 295 institutions, with assets of $160 billion to $200 billion. And, Seidman said his agency found ``no reason to question'' that estimate. If the S&Ls yet to fail have losses in the 20 percent range _ the level in the most recent thrift takeovers _ total thrift losses would be at least 50 percent higher than the $50 billion provided in legislation enacted in August. ``The thought of more dollars having to be spent on the S&L mess sends shudders down the spine of every congressman,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. Seidman replied, ``Probably the shivers will be there. Maybe we can get them past the election.'' His assessment was the most pessimistic yet from a government official. A day earlier, Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson conceded it was possible that $50 billion is inadequate, but said it was too soon to know for certain. On another subject, Seidman defended his agency from charges it is moving too slowly. It has disposed of only 40 S&Ls since August. He said the cumbersome bureaucracy created by the bailout bill ``guarantees a slower process.'' Employees of Seidman's FDIC, an independent regulatory agency, are doing the bailout work. However, the policy and pursestrings of the bailout are controlled by an administration oversight board headed by the treasury secretary. ``Where does the buck stop in this process? ... It's almost impossible to tell,'' Seidman said. Daniel Kearney, president of the oversight board, disputed that. ``We're certainly not slowing down the resolution process. ... Seidman has a free hand on that except for funding and we've given him the funding,'' he said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: New York Partnership Files Reorganization Plan for AI
DOC.TEXT: The investment firm Japonica Partners has made a second takeover offer for Allegheny International Inc. as the small appliance maker struggles to emerge from bankruptcy protection. New York-based Japonica wrapped its proposal into a formal reorganization plan filed late Wednesday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court, just before today's hearing on Allegheny International's proposal for emerging from Chapter 11 protection. Japonica issued only sketchy details of its latest plan, which it said would involve a $650 million, all-cash deal that is about $34 million lower than one it proposed in November. The offer includes a $120 million cash infusion and $375 million in bank financing. Allegheny International, based in Pittsburgh and known for its Sunbeam and Oster small appliances, sought protection from creditors in February 1988. Robert Sable, lead attorney for AI's bondholders and other unsecured creditors, hadn't seen the plan but said he suspected it is loaded with conditions. ``As far as my committee is concerned, there's only one plan on the table, the company's,'' Sable said. A Japonica spokesman conceded the group's financing hinges on a condition that caused one of AI's previous reorganization plans to collapse. Japonica also said it would pay holders of AI's publicly held securities premiums of 25 to 75 percent more than current market prices, amounts it said top the payouts called for in AI's plan. AI has proposed repaying virtually all of its creditors other than trade suppliers in new stock. AI spokesman Edward M. Romanoff said the company had no comment on the offer.

The stock market edged upward today, bidding to reverse its sharp decline of the past three weeks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 205.65 points from Jan. 2 through Wednesday's close, rose 1.81 to 2,606.31 by 11 a.m. today on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 736 up, 471 down and 483 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 52.17 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said several worries that had been weighing down the market showed signs of easing today. Prices rose in the Japanese stock market, after a series of recent selloffs that had unsettled other markets around the world. Interest rates in the U.S. government securities market, meanwhile, backed off a bit from their abrupt rise of late. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds dropped to the 8.38 percent-8.40 percent range, against 8.44 percent-8.45 percent at one stage on Wednesday. Brokers said those developments were enough to encourage ``bargain hunting'' in many stocks that had been under selling pressure since early this month. DuPont led the active list, down 1| at 37}. On Wednesday the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of 71 cents a share, barely topping the 70 cents a share it posted for the comparable period a year earlier. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .40 to 183.04. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .64 at 355.31.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending the previous session's losses amid concerns about the slow pace of export sales. Analysts said one reason for the slack foreign demand was a lull in buying by the Soviet Union, where ports are jammed with nearly 3 million metric tons of imported grain because of a shortage of unloanding and distribution equipment. Forecasts for wetter-than-normal weather across the United States next week also prompted selling of grain futures. The wheat and soybean markets posted the greatest early losses. Corn futures were off fractionally. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 1} cents lower with March at $3.89} a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.40 a bushel; oats were } cent to 1 cent lower with March at $1.38\ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 1} cents lower with March at $5.64} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The live cattle market defied predictions for a lower opening based on Wednesday's quarterly Agriculture Department cattle-on-feed report, which showed fewer-than-expected marketings of cattle off of feedlots during the last three months of 1989. Live cattle futures were .05 cent to .72 cent higher with February at 79.42 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .43 cent higher with January at 84.47 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 49.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .38 cent to 1.28 cents higher with February at 55.15 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly lower on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide Profits Off Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp. on Thursday reported a 71 percent plunge in fourth-quarter net income partly because of shutdown and personnel costs resulting from the restructuring of its industrial gas subsidiary. The company said net income totaled $47 million, or 33 cents per share, in the final quater, which included a $56 million after-tax charge associated with the restructuring. That compared with profits of $161 million, or $1.17 per share, for the same period in 1988. Fourth-quarter results in 1988 included a $58 million charge for the $470 million settlement to the India government for the 1984 Bhopal gas leak. Net sales for the fourth quarter of 1989 totaled $2.08 billion, down 3 percent from $2.14 billion in the last quarter of 1988. Union Carbide said $45 million of the charge taken last year covered facility shutdown costs as well as severance and relocation benefits paid to employees. The company said it undertook the restructuring to reduce overhead and operating costs and make its industrial gas component more competitive. The company said $11 million of the charge was associated with costs incurred in realigning its core business and subsidiaries and in restructuring a carbon products facility in Canada. For the full year, Union Carbide's net income dropped 13 percent, from $662 million or $4.66 per share, in 1988 to $573 million or $4.07 per share. Sales for the year rose 5 percent, from $8.32 billion in 1988 to $8.74 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: NBC, Thomson Announce High-Definition TV Venture With Philips
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with announcement; CLARIFIES reason that HDTV proposal would require reallocation of broadcast signals; CORRECTS that NBC-Thomson-Philips system would be compatible with existing TV sets, sted incompatible, in penultimate graf pvs. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. division of Dutch electronics giant Philips NV said today it will join a joint venture of NBC-TV and the American arm of France's largest electronics company to research advanced television systems. Thomson Consumer Electronics Inc., the U.S. operation of Thomson SA of France, and Philips Consumer Electronics Co. announced the joint venture at a news conference at NBC headquarters. The venture eventually is intended to lead to a high-definition television system, which would provide picture quality vastly improved from today's best sets. ``We want U.S. consumers to have access to advanced TV services as quickly as possible,'' said J. Peter Bingham, vice president of technology for Philips Consumer Electronics. Philips, which makes the Magnavox, Sylvania and Philco brands, has said it is working on an improved television system called High-Definition System for North America. NBC, which is owned by General Electric Co., has been cooperating with Thomson at the David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, N.J., to develop advanced television systems. NBC and Thomson, which owns the former GE and RCA television lines, are working on a system called Advanced Compatible TV, which would provide an improved picture on TV sets being developed by Thomson while allowing continued use of conventional sets. Advanced Compatible TV would require only minor, low-cost adjustments to equipment at local TV stations, Thomson and NBC said. Last April, NBC and Thomson tested the system during a news show on NBC's New York station, WNBC. The improved picture was viewed by reporters and others on a special TV set at the non-profit Sarnoff center. NBC said it was the first commercial broadcast of an improved TV signal. But development of the true HDTV system would require a reallocation of broadcasting signals by the Federal Communications Commission because it would use two channels to broadcast both the HDTV signal and a signal compatible with convention TV sets, said James Tietjen, president of the Sarnoff Center. Several Japanese companies are working on HDTV systems of their own. In addition, Zenith Electronics Corp., the last major U.S. TV manufacturer, has joined with American Telephone & Telegraph Co. to develop an HDTV system. Like the NBC-Thomson system, Zenith's system would provide full HDTV pictures while remaining compatible with conventional TV sets, although these existing sets would not receive an improved picture, said Zenith spokesman John Taylor. Thomson in 1987 traded its medical equipment business and cash for the GE and RCA television lines plus the rest of General Electric's consumer electronics businesses.

DOC.HEAD: HP Offers Extra Money As Early Retirement Incentive
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. will offer about 2,400 longtime workers early retirement incentives. ``We're offering this ... as part of HP's continuing efforts to balance the work force and to slow the growth of expenses,'' President and Chief Executive John A. Young said in a statement Wednesday. Hewlett-Packard estimated that 800 to 1,000 of its 60,000 employees in the United States will take advantage of the voluntary program, which will be available to workers at least 55 years old and with 15 or more years with the company. About 780 employees chose early retirement after the computer and scientific instrument maker offered a similar program in 1986. Employees can start signing up for the program starting Feb. 1, and participants will retire on or before March 30. HP, which expects no significant growth in its worldwide workforce of 95,000 in 1990, said it also is retraining and reassigning some of its workers. ``The redeployment of employees is necessary because of manufacturing efficiencies, plant consolidations and widely differing growth rates among HP's broad product lines,'' Young said.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Announces Grants for Watersheds in 36 States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: More than $17 million is being provided by the Agriculture Department this year to help improve water quality in specified watershed areas in 36 states and Puerto Rico, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced today. Yeutter told a Senate Agriculture Committee hearing the areas were selected from recommendations submitted by USDA and several other federal agencies, including the Environmental Protection Agency, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and U.S. Geological Survey. A number of other projects also are on tap, he said, including eight additional projects ``to demonstrate farmers' willingness to adopt newly developed conservation measures'' to more effectively manage the use of fertilizers and pesticides, which can be sources of water pollution. ``Other assistance will be targeted to regional programs that address multi-state water quality problems, such as the Great Lakes, Puget Sound, the Gulf of Mexico, the Chesapeake Bay and the Tennessee River,'' Yeutter said. The $17 million in assistance will be provided cooperatively by several USDA agencies, he said. About $7 million will be in the form of cost-sharing of improvements such as animal waste-control facilities, sod waterways, water management systems and integrated crop management. The Extension Service will provide $4.55 million in education assistance; the Soil Conservation Service, $5.36 million in technical assistance; and the Economic Research Service, $150,000 for evaluation of projects. The hydrological units, or watershed areas, were chosen primarily from those identified in assessment reports prepared by states in response to requirements of the Water Quality Act of 1987. The areas are: Alabama _ Sand Mountain-Lake Guntersville. Arizona _ Casa Grande-Coolidge. Arkansas _ Moore's Creek. California _ Westside San Joaquin Valley. Connecticut _ Housatonic River. Delaware _ Inland Bays. Florida _ Middle Suwannee River. Illinois _ Illinois River Sands. Iowa _ Union Grove and Black Hawk. Indiana _ Upper Tippecanoe. Louisiana _ Bayou Queue De Tortue. Maine _ Long-Cross Lakes. Massachusetts _ Buzzards Bay. Michigan _ Sycamore Creek. Minnesota _ St. Peter-Prairie Du Chien. Mississippi _ Tangipahoa River. Montana _ Godfrey Creek. Nebraska _ Elm Creek. New Hampshire _ Great Bay. New Mexico _ Dona Ana-Sierra. New York _ East Sidney Lake. North Carolina _ Goshen Swamp. North Dakota _ Bowman-Haley. Ohio _ Indian Lake. Oklahoma _ Battle Branch. Oregon _ Ontario. Puerto Rico _ Lake Loiza. Rhode Island _ Pawcatuck. South Carolina _ Camping Creek. South Dakota _ Richmond Lake. Tennessee _ North Fork Creek and Fall Creek. Texas _ Upper North Bosque. Utah _ Little Bear River. Vermont _ Lower Missisquoi. West Virginia _ Greenbriar River. Wisconsin _ Plover-Whiting Wellhead Area. Wyoming _ Ocean Lake.

The stock market was mixed today, attracting only spotty support after its sharp decline of the past three weeks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 205.65 points from Jan. 2 through Wednesday's close, slipped another 5.63 to 2,598.87 by noontime on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 741 up, 563 down and 476 unchanged. Analysts said several worries that had been weighing down the market showed signs of easing today. Prices rose in the Japanese stock market, after a series of recent selloffs that had unsettled other markets around the world. Interest rates in the U.S. government securities market, meanwhile, backed off a bit from their abrupt rise of late. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds dropped to the 8.38 percent-8.40 percent range, against 8.44 percent-8.45 percent at one stage on Wednesday. But brokers said that apparently wasn't enough to allay fears that the risks were increasing of a persistent slump in economic growth and corporate profits. DuPont ranked among the volume leaders, down 2 at 37]. On Wednesday the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of 71 cents a share, barely topping the 70 cents a share it posted for the comparable period a year earlier. Procter & Gamble, which also posted virtually flat quarterly profits, slipped | to 65|. Gainers among the blue chips included American Telephone & Telegraph, up | at 41~; Philip Morris, up \ at 38\, and American Express, up [ at 30}.
