DOC.HEAD: Portfolio Manager Reveals it Sold Investors' Interest in Texas Air
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Heebner thruout, no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Texas Air Corp.'s stock lost nearly 16 percent of its value the same day a large portfolio manager revealed it had sold its investors' interest in the nation's largest airline company. Loomis Sayles & Co., an investment firm based in Boston, on Wednesday sold off its stake in Texas Air, the parent of Eastern Airlines and Continental Airlines. Last summer, Loomis Sayles controlled 12.3 percent of the company. ``I sold every share I owned,'' said Ken Heebner, Loomis Sayles' portfolio manager. ``If I had other airlines, I would have sold them.'' He said airline stocks no longer seem attractive. Some 6.67 million shares _ nearly 17 percent of the 40 million Texas Air shares outstanding _ changed hands Wednesday, making it the most actively traded issue on the American Stock Exchange. Texas Air stock dropped 1] to close at 7]. Last August, when Loomis Sayles revealed its Texas Air holdings, the stock was trading at $18 a share. Texas Air spokesman Art Kent declined to comment on Wednesday's action. Officials of Eastern were scheduled to meet with the airline's major creditors today in New York to present a revised reorganization plan for the carrier, according to sources close to the situation. Miami-based Eastern has been rebuilding under bankruptcy court supervision since last spring, when it was hit by a strike by its three unions. Heebner would not say how much Texas Air stock Loomis Sayles sold Wednesday or how much it paid for its stake, which once exceeded 4.9 million shares. When Loomis Sayles began buying up the company's stock last summer, Heebner said he thought at the time that Texas Air would begin making money in 1990. But Heebner has revised his estimates and now expects the company will continue to lose money for another year and a half to two years. Texas Air has not yet reported its fourth-quarter results. But Heebner did not blame Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo for his decision to sell the stock. Instead, Heebner called Lorenzo a ``courageous man.'' Loomis Sayles is owned by New England Mutual Life Insurance Co. With offices in 10 U.S. cities, the company has about $20 billion in assets under management.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Unions Propose Buying 75 Percent Of Stock
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES with earnings, trims, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s board of directors has a new option to consider: a proposal by its three unionized employee groups for workers to buy 75 percent of the airline company's stock and leave the rest in public hands. Meanwhile, UAL today reported a 67 percent plunge in fourth-quarter profit and 71 percent drop in annual net income. United Airlines' pilots, flight attendants and Machinists outlined their employee stock ownership proposal in a letter Wednesday to parent company UAL's board, which is meeting today. The letter offered few details of the plan. Nevertheless, the development marks a distinct change in attitude on the part of the Machinists union, whose opposition to employee ownership and increased corporate debt helped scuttle a pilot-management bid for the company last year. And it offers a chance for resolution of the 6-month-old cliffhanger that has preoccupied United, the nation's second-largest commercial carrier, while rival American Airlines steadily has strengthened its industry-leading position. ``We are unified as never before in our view that majority ownership of the company is the only acceptable means to resolve the issues that plague United,'' concluded the group's letter. The proposal also drew a positive response from a major UAL shareholder that had been pushing for a recapitalizatin to boost the stock price. The group's letter was signed by John F. Peterpaul, vice president of the Machinists union; Frederick C. Dubinsky, chairman of the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association and Diana Robertson, president of the United chapter of the Association of Flight Attendants. The union leaders said they were prepared to negotiate as a group for the acquisition of stock by all UAL employees, including non-union workers, through one or more employee stock ownership plans or ESOPs. They offered wage concessions and long-term contracts in return. An ESOP typically buys stock with borrowed money and pays it back over a number of years with dividends on the shares. The letter contained no details on how the employees proposed to structure or finance the purchase of 17 million of UAL's 22.6 million shares, or what price the workers would pay. The plan would cost about $2.7 billion at Wednesday's closing stock price of $161.50. Nor did the letter describe how the stock would be divided among the four employee groups. Union leaders did not return telephone calls seeking such details. ``All we have here is a statement that the unions are agreeing between themselves that they want to own United,'' said airlines analyst Samuel Buttrick of Kidder Peabody & Co. ``The apparent concordance among the unions ... is a positive,'' Buttrick said, ``but the notable lack of specifics on structure and financing indicates that only minimal progress has been made on an ultimate resolution.'' Separately, UAL said net income totaled $6.8 million, or 31 cents a share for the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with $20.9 million, or 97 cents a share, for the same period of 1988. Revenue totaled $2.4 billion, up from $2.2 billion in 1988. For all of 1989, UAL reported net income of $324.2 million, or $14.96 per share on revenue of $9.8 billion, compared with profits of $1.1 billion, or $37.87 per share on revenue of $9 billion in 1988. UAL said 1988 earnings included a $393 million pre-tax gain from the partial sale of its Covia automated reservations system and a $523.9 million gain from the January 1988 sale of Westin Hotel Co. In the fourth quarter, expenses of $60 million related to last year's failed buyout bid were partially offset by a $40.7 million gain from stock appreciation rights also keyed to the buyout attempt. These items combined depressed fourth quarter earnings by $11.6 million. A 34 percent increase in jet fuel expenses also depressed earnings, UAL said. UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf called the results ``disappointing'' even without buyout related effects. At today's board meeting, UAL directors had been scheduled to consider a recapitalization urged on the Chicago-based company by the Coniston Partners investment group, holder of an 11.8 percent stake. But in an interview Wednesday evening, Coniston principal Keith Gollust praised the ESOP proposal as ``a giant step forward'' and said he and his partners were backing away from their insistence on a recapitalization to boost the value of UAL shares. He said a recapitalization, which likely would involve new borrowing by UAL to make a payout to shareholders, ``ought to remain as a backup alternative.'' UAL spokesman Joe Hopkins declined comment on the ESOP proposal. In return for a majority stake in the company, the employees said they were prepared to make ``significant investments,'' including accepting lower wages, and sign five-year contracts.

DOC.HEAD: SCI Television Says Bondholder Group Reps Back Revised Debt Exchange Plan
DOC.TEXT: SCI Television Inc. said Thursday representatives of two major bondholder groups that own most of its $507 million in outstanding publicly traded bonds have agreed to support a revised exchange offer for the securities. The privately held company, which owns six television stations, has been negotiating with its public bondholders over the exchange offer since it was proposed last October after the company ran into problems repaying its debts. The company is controlled by media entrepreneur George N. Gillett Jr. A group led by the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. is a major equity holder. Under terms of the revised exchange offer, public bondholders would end up with a 39 percent equity stake in the company. Gillett's 54 percent stake would be reduced to 41 percent and the Kohlberg Kravis-led group's stake would be cut to 15 percent from 46 percent. Banks, which have $650 million in outstanding loans to SCI, would get a 5 percent equity stake under the exchange offer. SCI said in a statement that the bondholder reprsentatives agreed on certain technical modifications to the exchange offer at a meeting Wednesday. As a result, SCI said the representatives would unanimously recommend to their groups that they tender all bonds under SCI's exchange offer. The offer was to have expired at 12:01 a.m. Wednesday, but SCI said it was extending the expiration until 12:01 a.m. Thursday. The offer requires that at least 95 percent of each of three public debt issues be tendered. Three holders of a small amount of SCI bonds have asked a federal bankruptcy court to force SCI to liquidate, and SCI has asked that the request be denied. SCI said a hearing that had been scheduled for Thursday in federal bankruptcy court in Delaware has been postponed until next Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Existing Home Sales Last Year Fell to Lowest Level Since 1985
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Existing home sales, dragged down by high interest rates, slumped 4.6 percent last year, to the lowest level since 1985, but were rebounding as the year ended, a real estate trade group reported Thursday. Sales of existing homes totaled 3.43 million units, compared with 3.59 million in 1988, the strongest year of the decade, according to the National Association of Realtors. They reached 3.21 million in 1985 after rising from the 1982 recession-year total of 1.99 million. Sales ended the year totalling a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.55 million units in December, down 1.1 percent from the previous month partly because of severe weather over much of the country, the association said. Nevertheless, the organization's chief economist, John A. Tuccillo, said that, ``last year, existing home sales totaled nearly 3.5 million units, which would be the fourth consecutive year in which home sales reached or exceeded that level.'' ``With the gradual decline in interest rates expected in 1990, we should continue to see a healthy market this year,'' he added. Home sales had plummeted by midyear as the housing industry was hammered by high mortgage interest rates forged by tight credit as the Federal Reserve sought to slow the economy and contain inflation. Sales, which had reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.55 million units last January, plummeted to 3.21 million in May. But the central bank began at midyear to gradually allow rates to drop and the pace of housing sales began to pick up. Despite the overall 1989 sales decline, association president Norman D. Flynn described last year's pace as ``healthy,'' and said, ``Last month's resale pace indicates a stable market.'' The 1989 median price of an existing home was $93,100, up 4.3 percent from 1988. The median in December was $92,500. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. Despite the severe weather, the Midwest posted the only sales increase in December, rising 3.1 percent to 990,000 units at an annual rate. For the year, the total was 926,000 units, 0.3 percent below the 1988 total. Tuccillo called the December improvement a signal that the market in the Midwest is turning around and ``is expected to continue growing in the 1990s.'' Sales in the Northeast totaled 570,000 units on an annual basis, down 3.4 percent from November. For the year, the resale pace was 585,000 units, 13.1 percent below that of 1988. The resale pace in the West was 600,000 units, down 6.3 percent from an eight-month high in November. The 1989 total was 605,000 units, 5.18 percent below the 1988 total. Sales in the South slipped 3.5 percent in December to 1.38 million units. For 1989, resales totaled 1.31 million units, 2.9 percent below those of 1988.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Says Lawmakers Misjudged Agency in Chicago Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration says a House report recommending a criminal probe into the firings of Chicago air-traffic controllers was ``seriously flawed'' and repeated allegations already resolved by the courts. The FAA's comments, contained in a document filed with a federal workers' board, are the agency's first formal response since members of Congress accused officials of lying and doctoring time sheets to justify the 1981 firings. ``Many of the report's findings are premised upon conjecture, theory or speculation,'' the FAA said, referring to a report released by a House Public Works and Transportation subcommittee in September. ``The report does not contain new ... evidence regarding the reliability of the timekeeping records and its conclusions are seriously flawed,'' the agency said in the document, which was obtained Wednesday. Lawmakers spent three years investigating how FAA officials at the Chicago Air Route Traffic Control Center in Aurora, Ill., prepared to defend the firings before the Merit Systems Protection Board. In their report, lawmakers concluded that attendance records were in such poor condition that officials decided to create documents to bolster the case against controllers who joined a nationwide strike. The report also said FAA officials may have committed perjury during appearances before the merit board, which considers appeals from fired federal workers. Armed with the subcommittee's report, attorneys for the controllers are now asking the board to overturn the firings. But the FAA cites several reasons why the board should not reopen the case: _The allegations are not new. The agency said the board in 1985 and a federal appeals court in 1987 upheld the dismissals after considering similar complaints about time sheets. _The board cannot reopen a case that has been decided in court. _The subcommittee made errors and its report should not be considered. ``The report not only ignored significant evidence and sworn testimony, but revealed a significant misunderstanding as to the ... procedures which were used in the removal process,'' the FAA said. FAA officials acknowledged that some records had been amended, but maintained the changes were made to ensure accuracy, not to cheat controllers. There was no ``scheme to alter and manufacture evidence which did not exist at the time of the strike and which was not prepared in the ordinary course of business,'' the FAA said. Scot Imus, staff director of the Public Works and Transportation investigations subcommittee, was not immediately available for comment Thursday, an aide said. During their investigation, members of the subcommittee said they were not judging the merits of the 1981 strike, which led to the firings of approximately 450 controllers in Chicago and thousands more across the country. Rather, they said they were concerned with the actions of FAA officials who were defending the firings before the MSPB. The subcommittee sent its report to the Justice Department, suggesting possible criminal misconduct. Prosecutors, however, have asked the Transportation Department inspector general to review the findings.

DOC.HEAD: Cable Group Says `Free TV' Ads Are Misleading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Cable TV executives are seeing red over a promotional campaign that tells viewers ``free TV'' may one day be a thing of the past. The executives asking the Better Business Bureau to look into the series of 30-second ads, running this month on televisions stations nationwide, that show future generations of youngsters expressing amazement that TV programs once could be had without paying a subscription fee, a cable TV official said Wednesday. In one ad, a little girl stands next to a blank TV screen at her grandmother's house, turning the knobs in a vain attempt to get the set to work. ``Grandma, how come we can't watch TV at your house?'' the girl finally says as the message ``sometime in the future'' slips onto the screen. ``Honey, I just can't afford the programs,'' her grandmother answers. ``Dad said when he was a little boy, TV was free. Is that true?'' ``It sure was. Back in the 1990s we watched free TV all the time.'' In another of the ads, which are being produced and distributed to TV stations by the National Association of Broadcasters, a little girl and her grandfather discuss a ``rabbit ears'' TV antenna shown in a vintage 1990 picture in an old photo album. ``Rabbit ears?'' she asks. ``Yeah, TV was free then. Me and your dad watched movies, local news, the Super Bowl right off the air,'' the grandfather says. An announcer ends the segment with: ``Free TV should never be just a memory. Call this station for more information.'' Cable TV executives say viewers are being duped. Broadcast television is not free, they argue, claiming that consumers eventually get soaked for the $27 billion that U.S. businesses spend on TV advertising each year. ``That's a little bit like telling people that all the rides at Disneyland are `free,''' Community Antenna Television Association President Stephen Effros said in a complaining letter this week to the Better Business Bureau. ``The rides may be free, but you have to pay to get into the park.'' Effros, in his letter to Ronald Smithies, vice president of the bureau's national advertising division in New York, said the ads are false and misleading and are ``attempting to lull American consumers into the belief that they don't pay a dime for all of those `free' programs on their television sets.'' He said the cost of TV advertising simply is passed on to consumers to the tune of about $298 per TV household _ ``whether we watch `free TV' or not.'' NAB spokesman Walt Wurfel on Wednesday said Effros was ``ignoring a number of studies over the years that make it clear that advertising is a service to consumers that adds competition and helps them make the wisest buy and tends to hold costs down.'' Smithies said his office, if it determines that the cable group is raising a legitimate truth and accuracy question, will contact NAB officials and ask them to substantiate their ``free TV'' campaign claims. Negotiations then would take place, he said, in hopes that either the cable group will accept the ads as truthful or the broadcasters will change the ads. The BBB, which published the conclusions of its investigations, has no legal enforcement power, Smithies said.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Rise in Dull Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close, comment, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose modestly in dull trading on London's Stock Exchange Thursday. Shares raced higher at the outset on scattered bargain-hunting and mild optimism over performances on international stock markets. But a sluggish start on Wall Street spoiled the enthusiasm, dealers said. At the close of the London session, the Dow Jones industrial average had advanced just 3.16 points to 2,607.66. Trading slowed during the afternoon as many brokerage firms closed early because of a windstorm that swept through the city. At London's close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 11.3 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,289.9 points. The Financial Times 30-share index rose 6.9 points to close at 1,835.5. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 8.11 points to 1,251.49 at the close. Volume came to a moderate 462.2 million shares, compared with 531.1 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Lauder, U.S. Ambassador Form Central European Investment Company
DOC.TEXT: Cosmetics heir Ronald S. Lauder and U.S. Ambassador Mark Palmer on Thursday announced the founding of a Central European investment company formed to take advantage of the lifting of the Iron Curtain. The Central European Development Corp., made up of U.S. and Canadian investors, bought a 50 percent interest in the Hungarian General Banking and Trust Company Ltd. for $10 million, a company release said. Lauder, the son of Estee Lauder and a Republican outsider in last year's New York mayoral race, is the chairman of the new venture. Palmer, the ambassador to Hungary, will serve as president and chief executive officer. Palmer plans to resign from the State Department and end his diplomatic career following Hungarian general elections in late March, the release said. Lauder, a former U.S. ambassador to Vienna, said the company would initially concentrate on business opportunities in Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Company headquarters, now at Lauder's New York City office, will be moved to Budapest in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Writers and Directors Reach Creative Rights Accord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Two Hollywood labor unions reached a creative rights accord that gives script writers input into the movie-making process and television directors a bigger role in TV series. ``We believe this cooperative venture will enhance the creative input of both writers and directors,'' Writers Guild of America executive director Brian Walton said Wednesday. ``It portends a new beginning,'' said Glenn Gumpel, Directors Guild of America executive director. ``I think if directors and writers work together, you're going to see from a creative standpoint the emergence of another interesting base in the community.'' Directors and writers have long been at odds over the issue of creative control of movies and TV shows. In the movie-making process, the director has long been creative king, while in television the producer, usually a WGA member, reigns. The plan calls for the guilds to avoid confrontation on the creative rights issue during bargaining and to create a joint committee that would develop guidelines governing the roles in creativity areas. The plan asks the guilds not to interfere in each others' creative authority in collective bargaining proposals but for each side to review them prior to submission. DGA president Arthur Hiller said collaboration will lead the guilds toward ``fulfilling our creative destinies.'' ``This will make creative bargaining easier. We've had conflicting claims to various creative rights,'' said J. Nicholas Counter, president of the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents major studios.

DOC.HEAD: Phillips Reports Fourth-Qtr Loss
DOC.TEXT: Phillips Petroleum Co. reported a net loss of $255 million in the fourth quarter, due largely to a $280 million after-tax charge for its offshore California investments, the company said Thursday. The write-down amounted to a loss of $1.04 a share in the final quarter of 1989, the company said. For the same period a year earlier Phillips had net income of $135 million, or 55 cents a share. Revenue totaled $3.03 billion, up about 6 percent from $2.86 billion a year ago. For the year, Phillips' net income plunged 66 percent to $219 million, or 90 cents a share, from $650 million, or $2.72 a share, in 1988. Revenue totaled $12.49 billion, up 9 percent from $11.49 billion. Phillips Chairman C. J. Silas attributed the fourth-quarter loss and the decline in yearly earnings mainly to the $280 million writedown for ``protracted delays in gaining regulatory approval to begin production of the Point Arguello field'' off the southern California coast. Texaco Inc. and Chevron Corp. also have recently taken write-downs on the Point Arguello field. Silas said lower refining and marketing earnings stemming from higher crude oil costs and an Oct. 23 explosion that destroyed its Houston Chemical Complex also had a negative impact on the company's results. The explosion, which killed 23 workers and injured more than 100 others, destroyed the company's U.S. polyethylene capacity. Silas said chemicals earnings also declined in the fourth quarter and Phillips paid a $50 million deductible for its business interruption insurance. In keeping with the industry trend, the company's exploration and production businesses posted higher earnings for the fourth quarter due to higher crude prices.

Stock prices fell again today, extending the sharp decline of the past three weeks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 205.65 points from Jan. 2 through Wednesday's close, dropped another 21.62 to 2,582.88 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 582 up, 804 down and 494 unchanged. Analysts said several worries that had been weighing down the market showed signs of easing today. Prices rose in the Japanese stock market, after a series of recent selloffs that had unsettled other markets around the world. Interest rates in the U.S. government securities market, meanwhile, backed off a bit from their abrupt rise of late. DOC.HEAD: Second-Quarter Earnings Up 8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Procter & Gamble Co. said Thursday its second-quarter earnings rose by 8 percent to $350 million from $325 million in the same 1988 period. The laundry, cleaning and food products manufacturer said earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31 were 98 cents per share, up from 96 cents the previous year. Worldwide sales totaled $6.02 billion, up 14 percent from $5.27 billion in net sales a year earlier. The quarterly earnings included a $91 million gain from the previously announced sale of the Crush soft drink business, and a $174 million charge to form a reserve to finish consolidating some worldwide manufacturing operations. For the six months ended Dec. 31, P&G reported earnings of $914 million, or $2.57 per share, a 26 percent increase from $725 million and $2.14 per share a year earlier. Worldwide net sales for the six months were $11.7 billion, up 11 percent from last year's $10.5 billion. The cost of the consolidations reserve was offset almost entirely by revenue from sale of the Crush business and from settlement of litigation P&G filed to protect its Duncan Hines cookie business. P&G said it accounted for its Nov. 30 merger with Noxell Corp. as a pooling of interests and included Noxell's results beginning last July 1. Noxell, based in Hunt Valley, Md., makes and sells skin care products, including lotions and cosmetics. Procter & Gamble makes and sells personal care products, laundry and cleaning goods, and food and beverage products.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat, Soybean Futures Down Sharply On Slack Demand
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices of wheat and soybeans fell sharply Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late selloff linked to improving crop weather and slack demand for feed grains both domestically and abroad. Corn and oat futures also closed lower. A flurry of grain and soybean buying late last year and earlier this month has filled delivery pipelines, resulting in a demand lull. Ports in the Soviet Union are reportedly jammed with nearly 3 million metric tons of imported grain waiting to be unloaded In the wheat market in particular, ``the chance for doing any significant business is limited and we're in a liquidating market,'' said Jerry Zusel, manager of trading floor operations for the brokerage Balfour Maclaine Corp. Meanwhile, a change this month to warmer weather patterns in the United States and Europe has eased feed-grain consumption, while recent precipitation in the nation's midsection has raised soil moisture levels in winter wheat areas and replenished water supplies in the Corn Belt. At the same time, rains in the South American soybean belt have gotten the crop there off to a good start, analysts said. At the close of trading, wheat futures were 2\ cents to 6{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.85 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2{ cents lower with March at $2.39\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1} cents lower with March at $1.37\ a bushel; soybeans were 5{ cents to 7 cents lower with March at $5.59} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Investors Seen Dumping U.S. Securities for Japanese Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Rising interest rates have made Japan's government bonds ``the most attractive paper on earth'' at the moment, but forecasts of a mass exodus of funds from U.S. investments may be overblown, some experts say. World markets were unnerved this week when a U.S. offering of bonds to finance the savings and loan bailout did not attract the usual active interest among the Japanese. That incited fears in the United States because the Japanese have been eager buyers of U.S. government securities over the last several years, helping to finance the federal budget deficit and hold down interest rates. One broker, Joan Anway of W.I. Carr's Tokyo office, proclaimed Japanese bonds the world's most attractive, but others say the factors adding to their allure could be temporary. U.S. analysts pinned the rise in Japanese interest rates to inflation fears in Japan, where the rate more than doubled last year to 2.5 percent and where workers are seeking wage increases of 6 perent. For Japanese investors, the ability to obtain a high return without risk ``is bound to be remarkably attractive,'' said Seiichi Kaneko, manager of research in the international asset management division of Asahi Mutual Life. The yield on benchmark 10-year Japanese government bonds was quoted at 6.57 percent Thursday compared to about 8.40 percent for a similar U.S. Treasury issue. The Japanese bond is up from about 5.5 percent at the start of the year. Although the gap between the rates offered on U.S. and Japanese securities is definitely narrowing, Kaneko predicted there would not be ``any massive exodus of money from the U.S. over the course of the year.'' He said stock portfolio managers may liquidate some U.S. holdings to take profits and offset recent losses in the Tokyo stock market. But after the new Japanese fiscal year begins April 1, Kaneko expects managers to reinvest in the United States. An indication of the extent to which Japanese investors are fleeing the United States will come from the U.S. Treasury Department's next refunding auction in early February. Kozo Nogami, manager of international securities investment for the largest Japanese insurer, Nippon Life, said his firm still has a ``strong interest'' in U.S. Treasury bonds. Nogami said Nippon Life stayed out of Tuesday's bond auction to finance the savings and loan bailout only because ``the term was 40 years, too long for us.'' ``We haven't sold any U.S. bonds lately ... and we'll continue to buy,'' he said. But Nogami added that with Japanese interest rates rising, ``Japanese bonds are fairly attractive,'' especially since they carry no currency exchange risk for Japanese investors. The central bank has raised its official discount rate _ the interest it charges commercial banks _ three times since last May, bringing it to 4.25 percent from 2.5 percent, in moves aimed at bolstering the yen and heading off inflation. In turn, the yield of government bonds, calculated on the basis of price plus interest rate in secondary trading, has shot up. But world market turmoil and the political climate at home have kept Japanese funds from being repatriated in large sums, said Richard C. Koo, senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute, an arm of the Nomura Securities Co. Money leaving U.S. stocks and bonds appears to have been parked abroad, leaving the yen vulnerable in the short run, he said. ``The markets are in such a mess that very few people are tempted to move funds home,'' Koo said. He said that after Japan holds elections next month and if the stock market settles down, the foreign exchange market will respond, strengthening the yen. Still, broker Anway believes funds already are flowing out of the United States into Japan. ``If people weren't buying yen to get out of the U.S., the dollar would be at 165 (yen) right now. That's where it should be if everyone is really nervous about Eastern Europe,'' she said. The dollar closed in Tokyo Thursday at 145.30 yen, indicating no strong demand for dollars, which investors need to make U.S. investments. American analysts said that if Japanese investors do move money from the United States back home, they may not be tempted to re-enter the U.S. market immediately. ``If they're going to leave because of the interest rate differential it could be difficult for them to come back without our rates moving higher,'' said Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Showing a More Aggressive Stand on Antitrust
DOC.TEXT: When Gillette Co., a household name in the shaving business, said it would acquire part of the Wilkinson Sword blade and razor line last month, it looked like a good deal. Too good, if you ask the Bush administration. Gillette already had an estimated 64 percent of the U.S. blade and razor market, and the company's plan to take over Wilkinson's 1.8 percent share set off alarms in the Justice Department's antitrust division _ alarms that were largely muffled during the Reagan years. Analysts expect more bells to sound. A year into George Bush's presidency, they say there are signs the government is taking a more aggressive stance on enforcing antitrust rules than the laissez-faire approach of the Reagan administration. ``I am clear in my mind that the Bush administration will be less lenient, less lax in merger enforcement,'' said Robert Pitofsky, a Georgetown University law professor who described the Reagan administration as ``more lenient about merger policy than anyone has been since the late 1930s.'' Lawrence J. White, a New York University professor who was chief economist in the Justice Department's antitrust division during Ronald Reagan's first term, agreed: ``I just have a sense both from the rhetoric and the actions (of Bush administration officials) that a tougher line is being taken.'' The rhetoric White referred to was in the form of statements by James Rill, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division and Janet Steiger, who chairs the Federal Trade Commission. Rill, in one of first declarations of Bush administration antitrust policy, said last November, ``The fact is that antitrust is critical to the well-being of the American economy, and plays a vital role in the governing process.'' Meanwhile, Ms. Steiger, who appeared with Rill at a Harvard University lawyers conference, said the FTC would be more vigilant in examining proposed mergers than it was during the Reagan administration. Rill's division is now challenging Gillette's plan to buy Wilkinson's blade and razor business outside of Europe on the grounds the deal would reduce competition in this country. It has asked both companies to submit information and documents about the planned acquisition by Jan. 29. But not all observers believe there's been a big change in government policy under Bush. ``Put the noise aside, there's nothing substantive,'' said Sam Pelzman, an economics professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business. However, he added, ``You hear that it's toughening up. It's probably a signal.'' Pitofsky, who was an FTC commissioner during the Carter administration, predicted that under Bush there would be ``far more investigations of mergers than was the case a few years ago ... (and) challenges to the kinds of cases that sailed through'' the Reagan administration. The shift in policy comes as no surprise _ in fact, it was anticipated in 1988, the year that takeover activity reached its peak. Analysts said then that many corporate acquirers wanted to get their deals done before the more permissive Reagan administration left office. The changed takeover environment, with mergers and acquisitions slowed considerably by a virtual halt in junk-bond financing, may also make it easy for the administration to appear more activist. But it's not just heavily leveraged buyouts that the Bush administration is looking at. White, the NYU professor, pointed to the Justice Department's opposition last spring to Eastern Airlines' plan to sell gates at Philadelphia International Airport and some of its routes to USAir, which already had a large presence in the Philadelphia market. He also noted the department had scotched plans by Delta Air Lines and American Airlines to merge their computer reservation systems. ``It would have been a tougher call'' for the Reagan administration to make, White said. The professors predicted that as time goes on, the new attitude will become even more apparent. ``It takes some time for a change of policy to work itself through the pipeline,'' said Pitofsky. But he added, ``Most lawyers who work in this field believe that the rules are going to be tightened.''

Stock prices fell to a six-month low today, yielding to a late burst of selling as the market's early-1990 slide continued. Analysts said some of the worries that had been weighing down the market appeared to have eased a bit. Prices rose in the Japanese stock market, after a series of recent selloffs that had unsettled other markets around the world. But brokers said that apparently wasn't enough to allay fears that the risks were increasing of a persistent slump in economic growth and corporate profits. Interest rates reversed an early decline and extended their recent rise today in the market for U.S. Treasury securities. In addition, more blue-chip companies came in with fourth-quarter earnings reports that disappointed investors.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: disappointed investors.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 43.46 to 2,561.04, closing for the first time below the 2,569.26 level it hit in a severe but short-lived selloff last Oct. 13. The average, which has fallen nearly 249.11 points over the past 17 trading days, reached its lowest close since it stood at 2,544.76 last July 18. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 9 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchang, with 520 up, 933 down and 490 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 172.27 million shares, against 207.83 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index fell 2.03 to 180.61.

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Profit Down; Blumenthal Retiring
DOC.TEXT: Unisys Corp. said Thursday that W. Michael Blumenthal, its chairman and chief executive officer, will retire in April to join the investment banking firm Lazard Freres & Co. as a limited partner. Blumenthal, 64, will remain chairman of the Unisys board, the company said. Meeting in Detroit, the company's board of directors chose President James A. Unruh, 48, to assume the additional duties of chief executive officer after Blumenthal's retirement. ``After almost two decades of managing major industrial companies and 10 years at Burroughs and Unisys, the times has come for my long-planned retirement,'' Blumenthal said in a statement. Blumenthal, who engineered Burroughs Corp.'s 1986 takeover of Sperry Corp. to form Unisys, was treasury secretary in the Carter administration. He indicated last year he planned to retire shortly. At New York-based Lazard Freres, Blumenthal will serve as co-chairman of a new international investment group, his statement said. Unisys also announced its fourth-quarter profit fell 84 percent as a weak U.S. market offset strong international business growth and previously announced layoffs took a toll. For the three months ended Dec. 31, the company reported net income of $34 million, or 5 cents per fully diluted common share, compared with $218 million, or $1.05 a share, in the same quarter of 1988. Revenue for the fourth quarter totaled $2.97 billion, up 2 percent from $2.91 billion a year earlier. Decreases in defense business and U.S. commercial computer orders offset double-digit growth in international orders, Unisys said from its headquarters here. The U.S. business was hurt temporarily by a $230 million restructuring, charged against third-quarter earnings, that included the layoff of about 8,000 employees and consolidation of factories, the company said. But the restructuring helped the company return to profitability and a positive cash flow from operations after a $648.2 million loss in the third quarter, Unisys said. For all of 1989, Unisys reported a loss of $639.3 million, or $4.71 a share. In 1988, the company reported a profit of $680.6 million, or $3.27 per share. Revenue for the year rose 2 percent to $10.10 billion from $9.94 billion. Unisys said inventories were cut $216 million during the quarter to $1.8 billion, bringing the year's reduction to $723 million. The company had set a goal of reducing inventories by $500 million after they rose $628 million in 1988 to $2.5 billion. ``We are encouraged by the very early results from our fundamental cost structure initiatives,'' Blumenthal said in a statement. ``Our program is on schedule. Benefits are expected to accelerate gradually with the full impact to be realized in the latter part of this year.'' Unisys will seek to reduce debt by $600 million to $800 million in 1990, in part through the sale of non-strategic and idle assets, Blumenthal said. ``Overall, 1989 was a difficult and disappointing year,'' he said. ``We believe we have made progress against problems unique to Unisys, such as the high inventory position entering 1989. And we moved decisively to adapt to the rapidly emerging new economic model for the industry in the 1990s. These actions will facilitate additional progress in the implementation of our strategic plans.''

DOC.HEAD: Auto Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 196,405 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 135,527, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 256,151 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 120,820 cars this week, compared with 83,560 a week ago and 161,350 in the same week in 1988. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 75,585, compared with last week's 51,967 and last year's 94,801. Canadian automakers were to build 19,740 cars this week, up from 13,090 a week ago and down from last year's 20,792. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 16,624, compared with 16,624 a week ago and 13,464 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Race To Develop High-Definition TV Heats Up With New Consortium
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The race to develop high-definition television heated up Thursday with the announcement that the U.S. divisions of two European electronics giants have joined NBC-TV to research advanced TV systems. Philips Consumer Electronics Co. said it will join an existing research venture of Thomson Consumer Electronics Inc. and NBC. Philips is part of NV Philips of the Netherlands, while Thomson is the U.S. division of Thomson SA of France. The venture faces stiff competition from research efforts under way in Japan and Europe into high-definition television, which promises picture quality as crisp as photographs and crystal-clear sound. In addition, Zenith Electronics Corp., the last major TV manufacturer in the United States, has joined American Telephone & Telegraph Co. to develop a HDTV system. The new three-way alliance of Philips, Thomson and NBC drew praise from several industry observers. ``I think it's a fairly wise, competitive decision,'' said Pat Hill Hubbard, a vice president of the American Electronics Association. ``Research is very costly in this field.'' Laura J. Lederman, an analyst with the Chicago investment firm Duff & Phelps Inc., said the combination of manufacturers and broadcasters was critical. ``If you have companies that build a set but you don't have broadcasters you're missing some of the pieces,'' she said. Together, Philips and Thomson control almost 40 percent of the U.S. television-set market. Philips makes the Magnavox, Sylvania, Philco and Philips brands, while Thomson owns the former General Electric and RCA lines. NBC, which is owned by General Electric Co., has been cooperating with Thomson for several years at the David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, N.J., to develop advanced television systems. NBC and Thomson are working on a system called Advanced Compatible TV, which would provide an improved picture on new wide-screen TV sets while allowing continued use of conventional sets. Advanced Compatible TV would require only minor, low-cost adjustments to equipment at local TV stations, Thomson and NBC said. Philips on Thursday endorsed the Advanced Compatible TV system. ``We want U.S. consumers to have access to advanced TV services as quickly as possible,'' J. Peter Bingham, vice president of technology for Philips Consumer Electronics, said at a news conference at NBC's headquarters. Philips has been working on its own improved-TV systems in this country, and said it would merge its efforts with those of NBC and Thomson. The consortium, which invited other companies to join its effort, said it hoped to have the advanced TV system operating and the sets on sale by 1993. The companies said they expected the sets would sell for $500 to $1,000. At the same time, the consortium said it will pursue a true high-definition TV system, which would provide even sharper pictures. The HDTV system being considered would require a reallocation of broadcasting signals by the Federal Communications Commission since it would use the blank channels that now separate the channels in use in any one area. The system would transmit an HDTV signal on one channel and a conventional signal on a second channel to meet an FCC requirement than any HDTV system not make conventional sets obsolete. Ms. Hubbard, of the American Electronics Association, said the trade group was pleased that the consortium joins three companies ``who are trying to keep the technology base in this country.'' Asked whether Zenith would consider joining the consortium, spokesman John Taylor said, ``We're very pleased with the progress that we have been making in the development of our own system.'' Each of the groups developing high-definition TV systems in the United States hopes its version is picked as the nation's standard by the FCC, which is scheduled to start testing proposed systems soon. In addition to their U.S. venture, Thomson and Philips are involved in a European government-industry consortium to develop HDTV there. Japan has been researching HDTV for more than two decades and is considered by many experts to have the lead. Some experts say the nation that wins the HDTV race will have an enormous advantage in the broader electronics market.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $1.64 Billion in Latest Week, Fourth Consecutive Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 490 money market mutual funds climbed $1.64 billion in the latest week to a record high for the fourth consecutive week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise to $383.07 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a revised $5.61 billion increase in the funds' assets to a revised $381.44 billion the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The institute had reported last week that assets had risen $5.29 billion to what was then a record $381.11 billion. Over the past four weeks, money fund assets have climbed more than $17 billion as investors have evidently sought a refuge from declining prices in the stock market. The pace of the increases has slowed, however. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 243 general purpose funds rose $1.16 billion to $128.08 billion and assets of 98 broker-dealer funds increased $771.8 million to $162.58 billion. But it said assets of 149 institutional funds slipped $294.2 million to $92.41 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.70 percent from 7.74 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield also fell to 7.83 percent from 7.88 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 41 days, up from 38 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts held steady at 6.32 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, also was unchanged from the previous week at 5.07 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.87 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 7.93 percent on 1-year CDs, up from 7.92 percent; 7.91 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 7.89 percent; and 7.93 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 7.91 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Slack Demand And Wetter Weather Pummel Wheat, Soybean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices sank to four-month lows Thursday and soybean futures reached their lowest levels since mid-October in a sell-off linked to wetter weather and slack demand for feed grains both domestically and abroad. Corn and oat futures also retreated in active trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. On other commodity markets, oil futures rose; sugar futures were up sharply; pork bellies soared while livestock futures were mixed; and precious metals were mixed. Wheat futures settled 2 cents to 6 cents lower with the contract for delivery in March down 6 cents at $3.85{ a bushel, the lowest settlement of a near-month wheat contract since Sept. 20. Soybeans ended 7{ cents to 8\ cents lower with March down 7} at $5.58\ a bushel, the lowest daily settlement for near-month soybeans since Oct. 17. Corn futures settled 1\ cents to 2\ cents lower with March at $2.39\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 2 cents lower with March at $1.37 a bushel. A flurry of grain and soybean buying late last year and early this month has filled delivery pipelines, resulting in a demand lull, analysts said. Ports in the Soviet Union, for example, are reportedly jammed with nearly 3 million metric tons of imported grain waiting to be unloaded. In the wheat market in particular, ``the chance for doing any significant business is limited and we're in a liquidating market,'' said Jerry Zusel, manager of exchange floor operations with the brokerage firm Balfour Maclaine Corp. Meanwhile, a change this month to warmer weather patterns in the United States and Europe has eased feed-grain consumption, while recent precipitation in the nation's midsection has raised soil moisture levels in winter wheat areas and replenished water supplies in the Corn Belt. At the same time, rains in the South American soybean belt have gotten the crop there off to a good start, analysts said. Petroleum futures finished mostly higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, supported by a strong cash market for crude oil and worries that a ferocious storm in Britain could disrupt North Sea oil production as it moves offshore. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures climbed 38 cents to 65 cents with February settling at $22.24 a barrel; heating oil futures were .05 cent lower to .33 cent higher with February at 59.77 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.22 cents to 1.5 cents higher with February at 60.60 cents a gallon. Sugar futures surged on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid rumors of Soviet sugar purchases on the world market. Further buying was sparked by the Brazilian government's estimate of Brazilian sugar production for the 1989-90 crop year at 6.9 million tons, down from 8 million a year earlier. Sugar futures settled .31 cent to .43 cent higher with March at 15.16 cents a pound. Pork belly futures finished sharply higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, strongly supported by Wednesday's monthly Agriculture Department cold storage report showing lower supplies of frozen bellies than the market had expected. Cattle futures were mixed with strong cash markets offsetting a bearish quarterly USDA cattle-on-feed report, which was also released on Wednesday. Live cattle settled .15 cent lower to .80 cent higher with February at 79.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .25 cent higher with January at 84.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .28 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 49.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .37 cent to 1.25 cents higher with February at 56.10 cents a pound. Gold futures slipped on New York's Commodity Exchange after two days of sharp gains. Silver futures also retreated. Gold settled $1.40 to $1.70 lower with February at $416.30 a troy ounce; silver was .3 cent to 1.2 cents lower with March at $5.253 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Company Led by Ex-Macmillan Boss Agrees to Buy Transport Press
DOC.TEXT: An investment group led by the former head of Macmillan Inc. said Thursday it had agreed to acquire the assets of International Thomson Transport Press Inc., which publishes material for the shipping, rail and trucking industries. K-III Holdings LP, which is headed by former Macmillan chairman Edward P. Evans, declined to disclose terms of the proposed transaction. Thomson Transport Press is a New York-based subsidiary of the publishing giant Thomson Corp., which is based in Toronto. Charles G. McCurdy, executive vice president of K-III Holdings and the former chief financial officer at Macmillan, said the purchase is ``part of our continuing program to build the K-III group of companies through acquisitions and product development.'' He said the deal is expected to be completed in February. K-III Holdings was formed last February in association with the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. to acquire and manage publishing businesses. Last summer, K-III made its first acquisitions, paying $310 million for Interterc Publishing Corp., a publisher of trade magazines and technical books, and Macmillan Books Clubs, a direct marketing operation. Evans had headed a Macmillan management group backed by Kohlberg that lost a bitter takeover struggle for Macmillan in 1987. Macmillan was acquired by Britain's Robert Maxwell for $2.5 billion, and Evans left the company shortly after the takeover.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply were mixed in the week ended Jan. 15, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,218.3 billion from $3,216.1 billion the previous week. But an even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,038.7 billion from $4,042.2 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $791.1 billion from $794.0 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.6 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 2.1 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,203.5 billion, a 7.4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,031.6 billion, up 3.2 percent, while M1 rose 6.4 percent to an average of $792.6 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $329 million in the week ended Jan. 17. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $347 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $198 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $299.4 billion in the two-week period ended Jan. 10, up from $295.7 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures End Higher
DOC.TEXT: Stormy weather in the North Sea helped boost energy futures Thursday amid concerns about possible supply disruptions. ``The main story was the rough weather in the North Sea and the impact it could have on the Cadillac crudes _ Brent and WTI _ and on gasoline,'' said Peter Beutel, energy analyst with Elders Futures Inc. Brent and West Texas Intermediate are the main crude oils of Britain and the United States, respectively. They are light crudes and preferred by refiners for making gasoline. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, jumped 65 cents to $22.24 a 42-gallon barrel after losing a penny on Wednesday. April WTI advanced 49 cents to $21.41 a barrel and May added 44 cents to $20.97. Among refined products, regular unleaded gasoline for February delivery ended 1.22 cents higher at 60.60 cents a gallon. The March contract rose 1.33 cents to 61.61 cents a gallon and April moved up 1.29 cents to 62.47 cents. Heating oil for February, which gained 0.29 cent in the previous session, added another 0.20 cent to close at 59.77 cents a gallon. March rose 0.33 cent to 57.69 cents and April ended up 0.09 cent at 55.27 cents. Later contracts were mixed. Analysts said bad weather in the North Sea raised concern about possible disruptions of Brent oil shipments. ``People are worried about possible loading problems in the North Sea,'' said Nick Fujita, energy broker for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Fujita said the energy markets also are concerned about the impact of possible oil supply cutbacks by Russia to Eastern European countries. The Spviet Union is the biggest supplier of oil to Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Reports Big Gain in Fourth Quarter, Year; Nynex Earnings Down
DOC.TEXT: AT&T reported sharply higher earnings Thursday for the 1989 fourth quarter and the year, calling it the best annual performance for the telephone giant since the breakup of its monopoly six years ago. Meanwhile, Nynex Corp., one of the ``Baby Bells'' spun off from American Telephone & Telegraph Co., reported a loss for the fourth quarter and lower earnings for the year. AT&T said its improved results partly reflected a $6.7 billion charge it took in 1988 to modernize and streamline the nation's biggest long-distance phone network that drastically lowered earnings that year. AT&T said it earned $705 million, or 65 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, vs. a loss of $3.34 billion, or the equivalent of $3.11 a share, a year earlier. Quarterly revenue totaled $9.3 billion vs. $9.21 billion. For all of 1989, the company earned $2.70 billion, or $2.50 a share, on revenue of $36.1 billion. In 1988, the company reported a loss of $1.67 billion, or $1.55 a share, on revenue of $35.2 billion. Excluding the 1988 charge, AT&T's 1988 results would have been $593 million, or 55 cents a share, for the fourth quarter and $2.27 billion, or $2.11 a share, for the year. When compared with those results, the company's 1989 fourth quarter and yearly earnings both rose 19 percent. ``It was a year of excellent earnings _ our strongest since divestiture six years ago,'' Chairman Robert E. Allen said in a statement. ``It was a year in which AT&T became a trimmer, more responsive and more aggressive competitor.'' Allen said key events that shaped AT&T's performance last year included a reorganization into more focused business units, more freedom from federal regulatory constraints and a trimming of the work force. More than 21,000 jobs were eliminated, leaving the company with 283,500 employees by yearend. One industry analyst said AT&T turned in improved results despite the increased competition it faces both in long-distance services and the telephone and computer equipment it sells. ``The numbers were pretty good. To me it indicates a continuing of their progression toward better earnings,'' said Pat Jurczak of Merrill Lynch & Co. Jurczak said he believed AT&T would increase its dividend in March. Nynex, which provides local phone service in New England and New York state, said it lost $43.7 million, or 22 cent per share, in the fourth quarter, compared with a profit of $342 million, or $1.74 a share, in the 1988 quarter. Revenue totaled $3.4 billion, compared with $3.2 billion in the 1988 quarter. Nynex blamed the loss in part on one-time charges totaling $325 million after taxes it took in the quarter. The charges related in part to a four-month strike against the company. Nynex Chairman William Ferguson also blamed the loss on a soft regional economy, a downturn in the financial services industry and increased competition. For the year, Nynex earned $808 million, or $4.10 a share, down from $1.32 billion, or $6.63 a share, in 1988. Revenue totaled $13.2 billion compared with $12.7 billion in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Award Damages in Discrimination Case Against Brokerage
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Thursday ordered Bear, Stearns & Co. to pay more than $215,000 to a former vice president who sued the brokerage house for age and sex discrimination. The 50-year-old woman, Edith Wulach, claimed she was denied consideration for a partnership and then was forced to resign in September 1985 when she was stripped of her duties and given menial assignments like stuffing envelopes. A jury of five men and one woman in U.S. District Court ruled in Wulach's favor and awarded her $215,283.94 in back pay and damages. Wulach was vice president of Clearance Accounting Services at Bear Stearns from 1979 until her resignation. Paul T. Williams, an attorney for the company, said he was surprised and disappointed with the verdict. ``The company did not do anything improper or discriminatory in this case.'' Among the witnesses who testified for the brokerage house was Bear Stearns chief executive officer, Alan Greenberg. ``It wasn't a case for money. It's a matter of principle,'' Wulach said. She is now a private consultant who does accounting work for mutual fund and money market companies.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 11 Percent Increase
DOC.TEXT: Allied-Signal Inc. said Thursday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 11 percent, largely because of cost-cutting and strong performance from its aerospace division. The company also said weak U.S. car sales hurt its automative parts division, and the performance of its third major area of business, engineered materials, changed little. Earnings rose to $115 million, or 78 cents a share, from $104 million, or 70 cents a share a year earlier. Sales for the three months ending Dec. 31 were $3.06 billion vs. $3.01 billion. For the year, Allied-Signal earned $528 million, or $3.55 a share, on sales of $11.94 billion. In 1988, it earned $463 million, or $3.10 a share, on $11.91 billion in sales. An unusually low tax bill helped the bottom line in 1988. Allied-Signal's tax liability was eased by credits from over-paying taxes on the sale of businesses, and a favorable tax rate in Brazil for operations there, said spokesman Michael Ascolese. The company paid $176 million in taxes in 1988 and $241 million last year.

DOC.HEAD: Ingersoll Sells Five Dailies to Thomson Group
DOC.TEXT: Ingersoll Publications Co. on Thursday announced the sale of five daily newspapers in Indiana, Ohio and Wisconsin to Toronto-based Thomson Newspaper Corp. for $270 million. Ingersoll said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the Anderson Herald-Bulletin of Anderson, Ind.; The Tribune-Star of Terre Haute, Ind.; the News Journal of Mansfield, Ohio; The Tribune Chronicle of Warren, Ohio; and The Sheboygan Press of Sheboygan, Wis. As part of the deal, Ingersoll said it is buying the Thomson-owned Geauga Times Leader in Chardon, Ohio, a suburb of Cleveland. ``This transaction completes the sale of the last of our newspapers in areas which are not in or adjacent to major metropolitan centers,'' Ingersoll President Robert M. Jelenic said in a statement. ``As we have previously announced, our strategy for the 1990s is to concentrate exclusively on urban properties in the United States, Ireland and the United Kingdom and on the development of new urban markets in the United States and Europe,'' he said. Ingersoll last September began publishing a new daily tabloid, The St. Louis Sun. Ingersoll, based in Princeton, N.J., owns more than 25 daily newspapers and more than 150 weekly newspapers in the United States. Thomson Newspaper, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Thomson Corp., owns more than 100 newspapers in the United States and more than 50 in Canada. Also Thursday, Thomson sold the assets of a subsidiary that published material for the shipping, rail and trucking industries to an investment group led by the former head of Macmillan Inc. K-III Holdings LP, which is headed by former Macmillan Chairman Edward P. Evans, agreed to acquire New York-based International Thomson Transport Press Inc. No price was disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Closes Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Ryan said ...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY report by adding that Greenspan actually warned against any impediments on foreign investment; picks up 6th graf pvs, `There also ...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed mostly lower Thursday as a variety of rumors heightened trader fears about foreign investment in the United States. Gold prices were mixed. The U.S. currency suffered its largest drop against the Japanese yen after reports that Japanese institutional investors were selling large amounts of dollars, said Robert Ryan, senior trader at Bank of New York Co. Reports that the Federal Reserve was selling dollars against the yen also took a toll, Ryan said. The dollar slumped to 143.925 yen in New York from late Wednesday's 145.715 yen. In earlier Tokyo trading, the dollar fell 0.50 yen to 145.30 yen, and in London, it was quoted late in the day at 144.40 yen. Ryan said the dollar was also hurt by a report that Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan was calling for a withholding tax on foreigners investing in the United States. Such a move would drive down foreign investment in this country, and in turn, foreign demand for dollars. In fact, Greenspan cautioned Congress in testimony Thursday against placing any new impediments on foreign investment, saying it would force interest rates higher and ``probably curb economic activity.'' There also were rumors in the market that the Group of Seven _ the United States, Britain, Japan, France, West German, Italy and Canada _ would meet informally over the weekend, Ryan said. ``The dollar's been all over the place,'' Ryan said. In Europe, the dollar was mixed in directionless trading. Volume grew thinner throughout the afternoon because of a severe storm, which disrupted transportation and forced many London banks to close early. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6570 from $1.6555 late Wednesday. In later New York dealings, the pound rose to $1.6600 from $1.65255. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6850 West German marks, down from 1.6912; 1.4850 Swiss francs, down from 1.4965; 5.7255 French francs, down from 5.7465; 1,253.75 Italian lire, down from 1,258.75; and 1.18755 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18535. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Wednesday included: 1.6870 West German marks, up from 1.6855; 1.4870 Swiss francs, down from 1.4975; 5.7305 French francs, unchanged; 1.8975 Dutch guilders, unchanged; 1,254.75 Italian lire, down from 1,255.75, and 1.1903 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1852. Gold prices were mixed in New York. On the Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of gold fell $1.20 to $416, but Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $417 a troy ounce, up 40 cents from Wednesday. Gold fell in London earlier to a late bid price of $416.25 a troy ounce from $421.50 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $413.50 from $420. bid late Wednesday. The Hong Kong gold market was closed Thursday for the Lunar New Year holidays. Trading will resume on Jan. 30 Silver prices fell. A troy ounce of silver fell 0.3 cents to $5.212 on the Commodity Exchange. In London, silver fell to a late bid price of $5.22 a troy ounce from Wednesday's $5.34.

DOC.HEAD: Sues Electronics Giants Second Time
DOC.TEXT: After limited success pursuing a claim of worldwide conspiracy by giant Japanese electronics firms, a small Scottsdale company has dusted off the allegation in a new federal lawsuit. Go-Video Inc., which says it is counting on sales of its patented, dual-deck videocassette recorder for survival, filed the complaint Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Phoenix against six of the companies and their U.S. subsidiaries. It alleges that Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. and its Panasonic division; Victor Co. of Japan Ltd. and its JVC Corp. subsidiary; Sanyo Electric Co. Ltd.; Sony Corp.; NEC Corp.; Sharp Corp.; and Sanyo Electric Co. Ltd. tried to monopolize markets and prevent introduction of Go-Video's VCR-2. The defendants did not immediately respond. The new complaint expands on a conspiracy claim Go-Video first leveled in 1987. The company plans to introduce the dual-deck VCR on March 28 with a $995 suggested retail price. In its first suit, Go-Video alleged that the six Japanese companies and others conspired to block marketing of the VCR-2 because they had been unable to develop a machine that has the same capabilities _ playing two movies at one time or recording from one tape to another. The new suit repeats the allegations and alleges the formation of a cartel to control the consumer-electronics market, including conventional VCRs, digital audio-tape recording equipment and high-definition television. ``Since we filed our first lawsuit, we have uncovered facts we believe suggest the existence of a conspiracy that is much more extensive than what we knew about or suspected when we started the first case,'' said Joseph M. Alioto, an antitrust attorney for Go-Video. Alioto spent several weeks last year investigating and taking depositions from executives of Japanese electronics manufacturers and others about their role in the alleged conspiracy against Go-Video. Some of the defendants have reached out-of-court settlements with Go-Video, paying the company a total of $1.9 million. The company has spent about $700,000 on litigation.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Rally Outside Plant to Close in a Week
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of autoworkers chanting ``Lay off Lee'' rallied in the rain Thursday outside a Chrysler Corp. plant scheduled to close next week. The United Auto Workers protest, with its pointed references to Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca, comes amid a deepening slide in the auto industry that has resulted in thousands of layoffs around the country in advance of talks on a new UAW contract later this year. The closing of Chrysler's Jefferson Avenue plant on Feb. 2 is part of a series of plant closings or indefinite production cuts scheduled at General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler plants nationwide. The 1,700 people who will lose their jobs at the Jefferson Avernue plant are among 13,500 workers at 11 GM and Chrysler plants who will get indefinite layoff notices between January and March. Another 33,600 workers will be idled for at least a week at 20 GM, Ford or Chrysler assembly plants. The layoffs are being blamed on slow sales, high inventory and shrinking orders from auto dealers. The two-hour demonstration was organized by an ad hoc group made up mostly of UAW dissidents belonging to the so-called New Directions movement. One of New Directions' leaders, Don Douglas, president of UAW Local 594 in Pontiac, Mich., called the closing of the Jefferson Avenue plant ``another broken promise.'' GM plans to idle its Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta in mid-March. GM and Chrysler also are trimming production rates at other plants in response to slumping sales. Ford so far has avoided large-scale, indefinite shutdowns by temporary plant closings and eliminating overtime. In 1988, when Ford was posting record profits, the company was building up to 15 percent of its new cars on overtime. ``It's going to be tough,'' Pete Kelly, president of UAW Local 160 at GM's Technical Center in Warren, Mich., said of the coming negotiations, which are expected to focus on the issue of job security. ``I think there is as much dissension among salaried employees as among hourly,'' Kelly said at the rally. Each of the UAW's contracts with the Big Three has language restricting plant closings, mostly to those whose products aren't selling. Chrysler said the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon subcompact cars aren't selling well enough to support the Jefferson Avenue plant, and used that to justify the closing. The UAW is challenging that claim and has suggested to Chrysler that the Omni and Horizon continue to be built and sold only in areas where the model has proven to be a success. Many of Thursday' marchers came from GM or Ford locals, and waited for the end of the only shift at the plant to swell their ranks. But the parade didn't grow appreciably after the workers inside the factory came outside. One worker, Al Jones of Detroit, said he wasn't sure what he would do after the closure of the plant where he's worked for 22 years. He and other members of UAW Local 7, like other laid-off autoworkers, are eligible for benefits from a variety of funds which could pay them as much as 95 percent of their normal wage.

DOC.HEAD: Say Check Cashing Costs Rising
DOC.TEXT: New studies show fees at check-cashing outlets nationwide continue to climb and a majority of Americans support forcing banks to offer basic services to low-income families, consumer advocates and civil rights groups said Thursday. The organizations and a congressional backer said they will push for passage of legislation in the Senate to require banks and savings and loans to provide low cost banking services to the working poor and recipients of government aid. ``Many low-income and elderly persons can't even find a financial institution to cash their government checks,'' said Sen. Howard H. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, at a news conference to release the consumer studies. However, ``Many institutions ... don't normally maintain the cash level that could handle that sort of a mandate,'' said Jim Grohl, spokesman for the League of Savings Instititutions. ``Banks are businesses,'' said Donald G. Ogilvie, executive vice president of the American Bankers Association, in a written statement. ``They price their services in a competitive marketplace.'' Ogilvie said more than half the nation's banks offer a basic banking account and a majority of them already will cash a government check for a non-customer. ``It's a checkmate,'' for the working poor, said Peggy Miller, a researcher for the Consumer Federation of America. A CFA survey conducted between Oct. 3 and Dec. 1, 1989 showed a general increase in the rates for cashing payroll checks and in the number of outlets entering the payroll check-cashing market. A four-state study released Thursday by the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, showed only 14 percent of the financial institutions surveyed in New York, New Jersey, Oregon and California offer low-cost accounts. Only 31 percent of the banks surveyed would cash government checks for non-depositors. The Public Interest Research Group collected data from 499 financial institutions in the 1989 study. Metzenbaum argued that fees for basic services and minimum deposits and balances required by many institutions for check-cashing privileges are too high for low-income, elderly and minority people. Metzenbaum's legislation suggests $2 be the minimum required balance for basic accounts at banks and savings and loans. ``This country's older and poorer residents are being denied something that many people take for granted _ the ability to have a basic bank account,'' said Francisco Carranco, a member of the board for the American Association of Retired Persons, a lobbying group for the elderly. AARP backs Metzenbaum's legislation. The National Urban League, the NAACP and the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now joined the consumers groups in backing the senator's proposals. A Gallup poll released Thursday by AARP said that a majority of Americans _ 73 percent of those surveyed _ believe financial institutions should offer some basic banking services to low-income people. Sixty-nine percent would support a law that required financial institutions to offer ``no-frills'' checking account to low-income consumers at a price set by the government, the AARP survey said. The survey also found 17 percent thought the institutions should restrict their services to those most profitable for their business. Gallup conducted telephone interviews with 2,008 adults from Oct. 9-18, 1989. The margin of error for the Gallup study was plus or minus 3 percent.
