DOC.HEAD: Board Issues Statement Opposing Campbell Soup Sale; Analysts Wary
DOC.TEXT: The board of directors of Campbell Soup Co. said Thursday it would maintain the food makers' independence despite efforts by some members of Campbell's founding family to sell the company. In a statement, the board said it had given ``careful consideration'' to a move announced last month by an investor group that it would push to sell the entire company. The dissident group, which includes relatives of Campbell's late chairman John T. Dorrance Jr., said it was putting its 17 percent stake in the business up for sale and planned to seek ``a price per share significantly in excess of current market value.'' But the company's board reaffirmed its intention to resist pressure to put Campbell on the auction block. ``We have concluded that now is not the time to pursue a sale or merger of the company,'' the board said. ``We are convinced that maintaining the company's independence is the superior means of maximizing the wealth of the company's shareholders over the long term.'' The board, holding its regular monthly meeting at the company's corporate headquarters in Camden, endorsed a plan ``designed to leverage the extensive brand power of Campbell Soup Co. and to deliver the financial results needed to build long-term shareholder wealth.'' Campbell provided no specific details. David Hackney, a company spokesman, declined to elaborate. Signs of disagreement within the Dorrance family, which has controlled Campbell for nearly a century, has fueled speculation that some major stockholders want to sell the company. Earlier this month, Campbell named David W. Johnson its new chief executive, in part to squelch such rumors, and analysts predicted the selection would bring stability to the company. ``Today's statement was an aim to quell takeover rumors and try to get the investment community to believe that Mr. Johnson is going to be running this company for a long time and that he's going to be able to show dramatic improvement over the next couple of years,'' said Marvin B. Roffman, of Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. Last week, two branches of the Dorrance family, told the board they would not oppose a tax-free merger transaction. Dorrance's three children, who own about 31 percent of the company's 129.6 million outstanding shares, have said they intend to hold their shares and keep the company independent.

DOC.HEAD: Top Partners Reportedly Concerned by Greed, Changing Values
DOC.TEXT: Top partners at Goldman, Sachs & Co., the largest private partnership left on Wall Street, have expressed concerns about the greed of some employees, changing values within the firm and a failure to promote women and minorities, a newspaper reported. The views were expressed in a study surveying 11 current and former top partners of the firm, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times. The study included excerpts of executives' comments but did not name the individuals making them, the newspaper reported. The study quoted one partner as saying, ``In the old days, when you became a partner, you would feel free to give your wallet to another partner to hold for safekeeping. I do not think it is that way today.'' The partners also expressed frustration over the firm's inability to keep some of its brightest stars, the Times reported. They attributed the defections to factors like the 1987 stock market crash and the growth of small boutique investment firms that raid larger houses for talent, the newspaper said. One partner was quoted as saying, ``We've seen a lot of change within the firm _ growth, international business, bringing in people from the outside, etc. It's brought a lot of things with it. Things like more backbiting, comments made about other people and other activities, and they affect what it's like to work here.'' Some partners also expressed concerns about the firm's record of hiring women and minorities, the newspaper said. ``We have to do a better job of selection and need to get more people into the process,'' one partner was quoted as saying. ``We've hire too many blacks and females from places like Harvard and Stanford. They don't turn out to be as successful as those from other schools (like Villanova) who have struggled more and are more street smart.'' One partner expressed doubt that the firm would add a second woman to its roster of 128 partners any time soon, the Times said. The study, believed to have taken several months and been completed in December 1988, was conducted by the Delta Consulting Group, a small consulting firm, with assistance from two Harvard Business School professors, John J. Gabarro and Jay W. Lorsch, the Times said.
